zh: “他们怎么能那样砰砰地敲门呢！”娜农大声叫嚷道，“他们想破门而入吗？”
en: “How can they bang in that way!” exclaimed Nanon, “do they want to break in the door?”

zh: “到底是谁呀？”葛朗台喊道。
en: “Who the devil is it?” cried Grandet.

zh: 第三章
en: Chapter III

zh: 娜农拿起其中一支蜡烛去开门，身后跟着她的主人。
en: Nanon took one of the candles and went to open the door, followed by her master.

zh: “葛朗台！葛朗台！”他的妻子突然感到一阵恐慌，大叫着往门口跑去。
en: “Grandet! Grandet!” cried his wife, moved by a sudden impulse of fear, and running to the door of the room.

zh: 打牌的人全都面面相觑。
en: All the players looked at each other.

zh: “咱们都去吧，怎么样？”德格拉桑先生说，“这敲门声让我感觉来者不善。”
en: “Suppose we all go?” said Monsieur des Grassins, “that knock strikes me as evil-intentioned.”

zh: 德格拉桑先生瞥见一个年轻男子的身影，身影后跟着驿站的搬运工，扛着两个大旅行箱，拖着一个旅行包，这时，葛朗台先生突然转身对他妻子说道——
en: Hardly was Monsieur des Grassins allowed to see the figure of a young man, accompanied by a porter from the coach-office carrying two large trunks and dragging a carpet-bag after him, than Monsieur Grandet turned roughly on his wife and said,—

zh: “葛朗台太太，回去玩你们的摸彩去，我来招呼这位先生。”
en: “Madame Grandet, go back to your lotto; leave me to speak with monsieur.”

zh: 然后他很快拉上了门，兴奋的玩家们回到了各自的座位上，但没有接着玩儿下去。
en: Then he pulled the door quickly, and the excited players returned to their seats, but did not continue the game.

zh: “是索米尔的人吗，德格拉桑先生？”他妻子问道。
en: “Is it any one belonging to Saumur, Monsieur des Grassins?” asked his wife.

zh: “不是，是个外地的。”
en: “No, it is a traveller.”

zh: “他一定是从巴黎来的。”
en: “He must have come from Paris.”

zh: “对极了，”公证人说着，取出了他的表，那块表有两英寸厚，样子像一艘荷兰军舰，“九点了，交通局的驿车倒是从不晚点。”
en: “Just so,” said the notary, pulling out his watch, which was two inches thick and looked like a Dutch man-of-war, “it’s nine o’clock; the diligence of the Grand Bureau is never late.”

zh: “那位先生是个年轻人吧？”克吕绍神父问道。
en: “Is the gentleman young?” inquired the Abbe Cruchot.

zh: “是的，”德格拉桑先生回答，“他带来的行李，差不多有三吨重。”
en: “Yes,” answered Monsieur des Grassins, “and he has brought luggage which must weigh nearly three tons.”

zh: “娜农没回来。”欧仁妮说道。
en: “Nanon does not come back,” said Eugenie.

zh: “肯定是你们家的一个亲戚。”庭长说。
en: “It must be one of your relations,” remarked the president.

zh: “咱们继续玩吧，”葛朗台太太轻声说道，“听葛朗台先生的口气，我想他是生气了，发现咱们谈论他的事，他也许会不高兴的。”
en: “Let us go on with our game,” said Madame Grandet gently.“I know from Monsieur Grandet’s tone of voice that he is annoyed; perhaps he would not like to find us talking of his affairs.”

zh: “小姐，”阿道夫对她的邻座说，“毫无疑问，那是你的堂弟葛朗台——一个很英俊的年轻人，我在德纽沁根先生家的舞会上见过他。”阿道夫没有继续说下去，因为他母亲踩了他一脚，然后大声问他要两个苏来给她下注，她低声说道：
en: “Mademoiselle,” said Adolphe to his neighbor, “it is no doubt your cousin Grandet,—a very good-looking young man; I met him at the ball of Monsieur de Nucingen.”Adolphe did not go on, for his mother trod on his toes; and then, asking him aloud for two sous to put on her stake, she whispered:

zh: “你能住嘴吗，你个大傻瓜！”
en: “Will you hold your tongue, you great goose!”

zh: 这时葛朗台回来了，大个子娜农没跟着回来，她和搬运工的脚步声在楼梯上回响着，他们正在上楼。葛朗台身后跟着那个远道来客，他刚才曾激发了在座者的好奇心和活跃的想象力，所以等他进了屋子，突然来到这群人的中间，就好比是一只蜗牛进了蜂窝，或是一只孔雀进了某个农家养家禽的棚子。
en: At this moment Grandet returned, without la Grande Nanon, whose steps, together with those of the porter, echoed up the staircase; and he was followed by the traveller who had excited such curiosity and so filled the lively imaginations of those present that his arrival at this dwelling, and his sudden fall into the midst of this assembly, can only be likened to that of a snail into a beehive, or the introduction of a peacock into some village poultry-yard.

zh: “坐到壁炉旁边吧。”葛朗台说。
en: “Sit down near the fire,” said Grandet.

zh: 落座之前，这个年轻的陌生人非常得体地向大家行了礼。男士们站起来礼貌地欠身还礼，而女士们则按照礼节屈膝行礼。
en: Before seating himself, the young stranger saluted the assembled company very gracefully.The men rose to answer by a courteous inclination, and the women made a ceremonious bow.

zh: “你一定觉着冷吧，先生，”葛朗台太太说，“你大概是从——”
en: “You are cold, no doubt, monsieur,” said Madame Grandet, “you have, perhaps, travelled from—”

zh: “婆婆妈妈！”老葡萄园主停下正看着的一封信，抬起头说道，“让这位先生歇一歇！”
en: “Just like all women!” said the old wine-grower, looking up from a letter he was reading.“Do let monsieur rest himself!”

zh: “可是，父亲，也许这位先生需要点什么。”欧仁妮说。
en: “But, father, perhaps monsieur would like to take something,” said Eugenie.

zh: “他自己有嘴。”老头厉声说道。
en: “He has got a tongue,” said the old man sternly.

zh: 这个陌生人是唯一对此场景感到吃惊的人，其余所有人早就习惯了男主人的这种霸道劲儿。但是在两番问答之后，新到者还是站了起来，转身背对壁炉，抬起一只脚来烤靴底，并对欧仁妮说——
en: The stranger was the only person surprised by this scene; all the others were well-used to the despotic ways of the master.However, after the two questions and the two replies had been exchanged, the newcomer rose, turned his back towards the fire, lifted one foot so as to warm the sole of its boot, and said to Eugenie,—

zh: “谢谢你，堂姐，不过我在图尔吃过晚饭了。而且，”他看了看葛朗台，又说道，“我什么都不需要， 一点儿也不累。”
en: “Thank you, my cousin, but I dined at Tours.And,” he added, looking at Grandet, “I need nothing; I am not even tired.”

zh: “先生是从首都来的？”德格拉桑太太问道。
en: “Monsieur has come from the capital?” asked Madame des Grassins.

zh: 夏尔先生——这是巴黎葛朗台先生的儿子的名字——听到有人跟自己说话，拿起一只链子挂在脖子上的小单片眼镜，戴在右眼上仔细看着桌子上的东西，又看看围坐在桌子边的人。所有想看的都看过之后，他非常放肆地盯着德格拉桑太太，对她说——
en: Monsieur Charles,—such was the name of the son of Monsieur Grandet of Paris,—hearing himself addressed, took a little eye-glass, suspended by a chain from his neck, applied it to his right eye to examine what was on the table, and also the persons sitting round it.He ogled Madame des Grassins with much impertinence, and said to her, after he had observed all he wished,—

zh: “是的，夫人。你们在摸彩，伯母，”他接着说，“请别因为我打断你们，请继续玩儿吧：太好玩儿了，别停下。”
en: “Yes, madame. You are playing at lotto, aunt,” he added.“Do not let me interrupt you, I beg; go on with your game: it is too amusing to leave.”

zh: “我敢肯定这就是那位堂弟。”德格拉桑太太一边想着，一边不住地瞟着他。
en: “I was certain it was the cousin,” thought Madame des Grassins, casting repeated glances at him.

zh: “四十七！”老神父大声叫道，“记上它，德格拉桑太太。那不是您的号吗？”
en: “Forty-seven!” cried the old abbe.“Mark it down, Madame des Grassins.Isn’t that your number?”

zh: 德格拉桑先生往他妻子的牌上放了一个筹码，他妻子坐着，根本没把心思放在摸彩上，她先是看看那位从巴黎来的堂弟，然后又看看欧仁妮，有了一种悲凉的不祥预感。年轻的女继承人不时地偷偷打量着她的堂弟，银行家的妻子很容易就看出了她内心里那越来越强烈的惊讶和好奇。
en: Monsieur des Grassins put a counter on his wife’s card, who sat watching first the cousin from Paris and then Eugenie, without thinking of her lotto, a prey to mournful presentiments.From time to time the young heiress glanced furtively at her cousin, and the banker’s wife easily detected a @crescendo@ of surprise and curiosity in her mind.

zh: 夏尔·葛朗台先生是一个二十二岁的英俊青年，此刻与这些地道的外省人形成了一种奇特的对照，他们非常厌恶他的贵族气派，都在细细打量他，打算讽刺挖苦他一番。这需要解释一下。在二十二岁的时候，年轻人还稚气未脱，他们的行为举止经常会显得很幼稚。很可能，他们一百个人当中，就有九十九个人的行为举止会和夏尔·葛朗台先生现在的表现一模一样。
en: Monsieur Charles Grandet, a handsome young man of twenty-two, presented at this moment a singular contrast to the worthy provincials, who, considerably disgusted by his aristocratic manners, were all studying him with sarcastic intent.This needs an explanation.At twenty-two, young people are still so near childhood that they often conduct themselves childishly.In all probability, out of every hundred of them fully ninety-nine would have behaved precisely as Monsieur Charles Grandet was now behaving.

zh: 几天前，他父亲吩咐他去索米尔的伯父家住上几个月。葛朗台先生可能想到了欧仁妮。夏尔平生第一次被差遣到外省来，便设想着要摆出时尚人士那高人一等的派头来，让整个郡的人都因他的阔绰而自惭形秽，同时还希望他此行能开风气之先，将巴黎生活的高雅精致引入到这偏僻之隅。简而言之，一句话，他打算在索米尔比在巴黎花更多的时间涂抹他的指甲，在衣着上要格外漂亮雅致，而有些时髦的年轻人往往会故意不修边幅，好显得更潇洒些。夏尔因此随身带了一整套猎装，巴黎最漂亮的猎枪和最好的猎刀，猎刀配有最漂亮的刀鞘。他带来了一整套的马甲。马甲有各种各样的——灰的，黑的，白的，金甲壳虫色的：有些闪着金色，有些装饰着金属片，有些织着云纹；有些是双排扣的，交叠着像块长方形披巾，有些是直领的；有些是翻领的，有些则从上到下都扣着镀金纽扣。他带来了那个时代最流行的各种硬领和领带。他还带来了两套比松外套和他所有最好的内衣。他还带来了一套漂亮的纯金梳洗用具——这是他母亲送他的礼物。他带来了公子哥儿的所有玩意儿，连一个精致的小文具盒都没忘，那是一位最可爱的女士送的——至少他觉得可爱——一位他称为安妮特的时髦女子，此刻正疲惫不堪地和丈夫一起在苏格兰旅行，因受某种猜忌中伤而不得不暂时牺牲一下幸福。文具盒里有很多漂亮的信纸，他可以每两周给她写一封信。
en: Some days earlier than this his father had told him to go and spend several months with his uncle at Saumur.Perhaps Monsieur Grandet was thinking of Eugenie.Charles, sent for the first time in his life into the provinces, took a fancy to make his appearance with the superiority of a man of fashion, to reduce the whole arrondissement to despair by his luxury, and to make his visit an epoch, importing into those country regions all the refinements of Parisian life.In short, to explain it in one word, he mean to pass more time at Saumur in brushing his nails than he ever thought of doing in Paris, and to assume the extra nicety and elegance of dress which a young man of fashion often lays aside for a certain negligence which in itself is not devoid of grace.Charles therefore brought with him a complete hunting-costume, the finest gun, the best hunting-knife in the prettiest sheath to be found in all Paris.He brought his whole collection of waistcoats.They were of all kinds,—gray, black, white, scarabaeus-colored: some were shot with gold, some spangled, some @chined@; some were double-breasted and crossed like a shawl, others were straight in the collar; some had turned-over collars, some buttoned up to the top with gilt buttons.He brought every variety of collar and cravat in fashion at that epoch.He brought two of Buisson’s coats and all his finest linen. He brought his pretty gold toilet-set,—a present from his mother.He brought all his dandy knick-knacks, not forgetting a ravishing little desk presented to him by the most amiable of women,—amiable for him, at least,—a fine lady whom he called Annette and who at this moment was travelling, matrimonially and wearily, in Scotland, a victim to certain suspicions which required a passing sacrifice of happiness; in the desk was much pretty note-paper on which to write to her once a fortnight.

zh: 总之，他尽可能带全了巴黎浮华生活的全套行头——从决斗开场时用的小马鞭，到结束决斗时用的雕花精美的手枪，游手好闲的年轻人打发日子的整套家当，他是应有尽有。他父亲曾嘱咐他单独出行，不要铺张，他就独自包了一辆轿式驿车，很高兴不用糟蹋那辆漂亮的旅行马车了，那是他专门定做的，打算明年六月坐着到巴登温泉和那位贵妇人——他的安妮特相会的。夏尔猜想在他伯父家会见到很多人，还能到伯父家的森林里打猎——总之，过上典型的庄园生活。他不知道伯父住在索米尔，只是在打听去弗罗瓦丰的路时顺便问到了他。当得知伯父就在城里时，他以为伯父应该住在一座豪宅里。
en: In short, it was as complete a cargo of Parisian frivolities as it was possible for him to get together,—a collection of all the implements of husbandry with which the youth of leisure tills his life, from the little whip which helps to begin a duel, to the handsomely chased pistols which end it.His father having told him to travel alone and modestly, he had taken the coupe of the diligence all to himself, rather pleased at not having to damage a delightful travelling-carriage ordered for a journey on which he was to meet his Annette, the great lady who, etc.,—whom he intended to rejoin at Baden in the following June.Charles expected to meet scores of people at his uncle’s house, to hunt in his uncle’s forests,—to live, in short, the usual chateau life; he did not know that his uncle was in Saumur, and had only inquired about him incidentally when asking the way to Froidfond.Hearing that he was in town, he supposed that he should find him in a suitable mansion.

zh: 索米尔也好，弗罗瓦丰也好，为了在见伯父的第一面时显得体面些，他穿上了他最高雅的旅行套装，简单却精致，用当时概括一个人或一件东西完美无缺的词来讲，就是“妙极了”。在图尔，一个理发师把他那一头漂亮的栗色头发重新烫了一下。他在那里换了内衣，戴上了一条黑缎子领带，配上圆衬衣领，把他那笑吟吟的漂亮脸蛋衬托得更可爱了。一件旅行长大衣的扣子只扣了一半并卡着腰，露出了前开口的开司米毛背心，里面还有一件白布背心。他的表上面拴着一条短的金表链，很随意地放在一个口袋里，并系在了扣眼上。他的灰色裤子两边系扣，接缝口饰有黑色丝绸绣花图案。他优雅地挥着一根手杖，手杖上的雕花金手柄并没有令他那副灰色手套有分毫减色。最后，他的帽子也是品位高雅的。只有巴黎人，而且是上层圈子的巴黎人，才可以这样打扮而不会显得滑稽可笑，其他人是无法将自命不凡和所有这些纨绔子弟的做派协调起来的，不过，这副做派倒是因为那股帅气而被人接受了——一个年轻人有漂亮的手枪，百发百中的枪法，还有安妮特。
en: In order that he might make a becoming first appearance before his uncle either at Saumur or at Froidfond, he had put on his most elegant travelling attire, simple yet exquisite,—“adorable,” to use the word which in those days summed up the special perfections of a man or a thing.At Tours a hairdresser had re-curled his beautiful chestnut locks; there he changed his linen and put on a black satin cravat, which, combined with a round shirt-collar, framed his fair and smiling countenance agreeably.A travelling great-coat, only half buttoned up, nipped in his waist and disclosed a cashmere waistcoat crossed in front, beneath which was another waistcoat of white material.His watch, negligently slipped into a pocket, was fastened by a short gold chain to a buttonhole.His gray trousers, buttoned up at the sides, were set off at the seams with patterns of black silk embroidery.He gracefully twirled a cane, whose chased gold knob did not mar the freshness of his gray gloves.And to complete all, his cap was in excellent taste.None but a Parisian, and a Parisian of the upper spheres, could thus array himself without appearing ridiculous; none other could give the harmony of self-conceit to all these fopperies, which were carried off, however, with a dashing air,—the air of a young man who has fine pistols, a sure aim, and Annette.

zh: 现在，如果你想了解这群外省人和这个年轻的巴黎人对彼此的惊讶，如果你想看清来客的高雅风度在屋子那灰暗的阴影和屋里所有人的脸上投下的光彩，就使劲在你的脑海里想象一下三位克吕绍的样子吧。三个人都吸鼻烟，鼻涕流出来，许久都不去理会，泛黄的衬衣褶边和皱巴巴的领子那发黄的折缝上散落着褐色污渍，他们也长时间没有清洗过。他们软塌塌的领带一系上脖子就拧得像绳子一样。他们的衬衣特别多，足可以六个月才洗一次衣服，在这期间，那些衬衣就都放在柜底，日子久了，上面沾满了污迹和霉斑。不修边幅和衰老在他们身上很好地融合起来，他们的脸像他们破旧的衣服一样褪了色，像他们的裤子一样打了皱，是衰老的、干瘪的，又是皱巴巴的。至于其他人，都普遍不讲究穿着，像所有外省人的着装一样，衣服不配套，也不光鲜，外省人下意识里觉得穿衣打扮不是为了给别人看，他们非常关心的是一副手套的价格，这与克吕绍家的不修边幅倒是一致的。　厌恶时髦是德格拉桑派和克吕绍派唯一意见一致的地方。
en: Now if you wish to understand the mutual amazement of the provincial party and the young Parisian; if you would clearly see the brilliance which the traveller’s elegance cast among the gray shadows of the room and upon the faces of this family group,—endeavor to picture to your minds the Cruchots.All three took snuff, and had long ceased to repress the habit of snivelling or to remove the brown blotches which strewed the frills of their dingy shirts and the yellowing creases of their crumpled collars.Their flabby cravats were twisted into ropes as soon as they wound them about their throats.The enormous quantity of linen which allowed these people to have their clothing washed only once in six months, and to keep it during that time in the depths of their closets, also enabled time to lay its grimy and decaying stains upon it.There was perfect unison of ill-grace and senility about them; their faces, as faded as their threadbare coats, as creased as their trousers, were worn-out, shrivelled-up, and puckered.As for the others, the general negligence of their dress, which was incomplete and wanting in freshness,—like the toilet of all country places, where insensibly people cease to dress for others and come to think seriously of the price of a pair of gloves,—was in keeping with the negligence of the Cruchots.A horror of fashion was the only point on which the Grassinists and the Cruchotines agreed.

zh: 这个巴黎人拿起他的眼镜，仔细审视这所住宅里古怪的陈设——天花板的托梁，木构件的颜色以及上面的斑迹，那是苍蝇留下的，数量多得简直可以给《箴言报》和《百科全书》加标点了。这时，玩摸彩的人们抬起头看着他，那好奇的神情就像在看一只长颈鹿。对德格拉桑先生和他的儿子来说，一个年轻人打扮入时的样子并不新奇，但是，他们也和在座的其他人一样感到惊讶，也许是受到了大众情绪无以名状的感染，也许是和其他人的看法一样，他们也同样露出嘲弄的目光来，似乎在对同乡说——
en: When the Parisian took up his eye-glass to examine the strange accessories of this dwelling,—the joists of the ceiling, the color of the woodwork, and the specks which the flies had left there in sufficient number to punctuate the “Moniteur” and the “Encyclopaedia of Sciences,”—the lotto-players lifted their noses and looked at him with as much curiosity as they might have felt about a giraffe.Monsieur des Grassins and his son, to whom the appearance of a man of fashion was not wholly unknown, were nevertheless as much astonished as their neighbors, whether it was that they fell under the indefinable influence of the general feeling, or that they really shared it as with satirical glances they seemed to say to their compatriots,—

zh: “这就是你们在巴黎能见到的！”
en: “That is what you see in Paris!”

zh: 他们可以悠闲地打量着夏尔，而不必担心会惹这家的主人不高兴。葛朗台正全神贯注地看着握在他手里的那封长信。为了看信，他拿走了牌桌上唯一的蜡烛，全然没有理会他的客人们，也不顾他们的兴致。欧仁妮来从没见识过这样完美的衣着和人物，她简直都觉得在堂弟的身上看到了从天而降的天使。那颗漂亮的脑袋上顶着优美的卷发，她愉快地闻着从上面飘出来的香气。那双手套很精致，用小山羊皮做成的，软软的，她真想摸一摸。她羡慕夏尔的小手、他的肤色和他脸庞的娇嫩精美。总之，这位优雅的人物对她这个没见过世面的女孩所产生的影响大致如此。这女孩总是一刻不停地忙于修补袜子或是她父亲的衣服，她的生活就在这些肮脏的椽木下慢慢过着，除了见到寂静的街上偶尔经过的路人外，别人谁都看不见。见到她的堂弟时，她的心里泛起了一阵萌动，就像一个年轻人看到了韦斯特福尔为英语《文集》所画、由芬登兄弟所雕刻的娇美的女士画像，会为之动情一样，那画像用笔如此精妙，以至于我们担心往纸上吹口气，那些天仙就会被吹走。
en: They were able to examine Charles at their leisure without fearing to displease the master of the house.Grandet was absorbed in the long letter which he held in his hand; and to read it he had taken the only candle upon the card-table, paying no heed to his guests or their pleasure.Eugenie, to whom such a type of perfection, whether of dress or of person, was absolutely unknown, thought she beheld in her cousin a being descended from seraphic spheres.She inhaled with delight the fragrance wafted from the graceful curls of that brilliant head.She would have liked to touch the soft kid of the delicate gloves.She envied Charles his small hands, his complexion, the freshness and refinement of his features.In short,—if it is possible to sum up the effect this elegant being produced upon an ignorant young girl perpetually employed in darning stockings or in mending her father’s clothes, and whose life flowed on beneath these unclean rafters, seeing none but occasional passers along the silent street,—this vision of her cousin roused in her soul an emotion of delicate desire like that inspired in a young man by the fanciful pictures of women drawn by Westall for the English “Keepsakes,” and that engraved by the Findens with so clever a tool that we fear, as we breathe upon the paper, that the celestial apparitions may be wafted away.

zh: 夏尔从他的口袋里掏出一块手绢，是那位此时正在苏格兰游历的贵妇人绣的。当欧仁妮看到这件闲暇时怀着热恋完成的精品时，她瞅着堂弟，看他是否真会拿来用。这个年轻人的举止、手势、拿起长柄眼镜的样子、装模作样的傲慢、对那个刚才博得富家小姐欢心的针线盒的不屑一顾，他显然认为那是毫无价值的，甚至是可笑的——所有这一切，令克吕绍和德格拉桑两家人深感震惊，却让欧仁妮喜欢得要命，她睡觉前还老想着这位出类拔萃的堂弟。
en: Charles drew from his pocket a handkerchief embroidered by the great lady now travelling in Scotland.As Eugenie saw this pretty piece of work, done in the vacant hours which were lost to love, she looked at her cousin to see if it were possible that he meant to make use of it.The manners of the young man, his gestures, the way in which he took up his eye-glass, his affected superciliousness, his contemptuous glance at the coffer which had just given so much pleasure to the rich heiress, and which he evidently regarded as without value, or even as ridiculous,—all these things, which shocked the Cruchots and the des Grassins, pleased Eugenie so deeply that before she slept she dreamed long dreams of her phoenix cousin.

zh: 彩号抽得很慢，不久游戏突然结束了。大个子娜农走进来，大声说道：
en: The lotto-numbers were drawn very slowly, and presently the game came suddenly to an end.La Grand Nanon entered and said aloud:

zh: “夫人，我要先生床上的床单。”
en: “Madame, I want the sheets for monsieur’s bed.”

zh: 葛朗台太太跟着她出去了。德格拉桑太太低声说道：
en: Madame Grandet followed her out.Madame des Grassins said in a low voice:

zh: “咱们把钱收起来，别玩儿了。”
en: “Let us keep our sous and stop playing.”

zh: 众人从他们放钱用的缺了口的小碟里拿起自己的两个苏，然后一起都坐到了壁炉边。
en: Each took his or her two sous from the chipped saucer in which they had been put; then the party moved in a body toward the fire.

zh: “你们不玩儿了？”葛朗台没有抬头，继续看着信说道。
en: “Have you finished your game?” said Grandet, without looking up from his letter.

zh: “是啊，是啊！”德格拉桑太太一边答道，一边挨着夏尔坐下。
en: “Yes, yes!” replied Madame des Grassins, taking a seat near Charles.

zh: 像很多初次春心萌动的少女一样，欧仁妮突然闪了个念头，她离开屋子，去帮她母亲和娜农了。如果那时有个能干的告解神甫盘问她，毫无疑问，她会坦率地承认她既没想着母亲，也没想着娜农，而是一门心思在她堂弟身上，急切地想为堂弟的卧室张罗张罗，看看需要添置些什么东西，有没有什么疏漏，要尽可能样样周全，让房间既舒适又漂亮。而实际上，她及时赶到了，向她母亲和娜农证明一切都还没做到位。
en: Eugenie, prompted by a thought often born in the heart of a young girl when sentiment enters it for the first time, left the room to go and help her mother and Nanon.Had an able confessor then questioned her she would, no doubt, have avowed to him that she thought neither of her mother nor of Nanon, but was pricked by a poignant desire to look after her cousin’s room and concern herself with her cousin; to supply what might be needed, to remedy any forgetfulness, to see that all was done to make it, as far as possible, suitable and elegant; and, in fact, she arrived in time to prove to her mother and Nanon that everything still remained to be done.

zh: 她提醒娜农拿只暖床炉来暖暖被褥。她亲自往旧桌子上铺了块桌布，嘱咐娜农每天早上要更换；她说服母亲，必须生旺炉火，并敦促娜农瞒着她父亲，把一大堆木柴放到走廊里。她跑过去，从大厅的一个角柜拿了一只古漆盘子，那是已故的德拉贝尔特利耶先生的遗物，同时还拿了一只六棱水晶高脚杯、一把失去光泽的镀金勺子和一个刻着丘比特的旧水瓶，她得意洋洋地把这些东西全都放在堂弟卧室的壁炉台角上。在这一刻钟里，她脑子里涌现的想法比她出生以来所有想法还要多。
en: She put into Nanon’s head the notion of passing a warming-pan between the sheets.She herself covered the old table with a cloth and requested Nanon to change it every morning; she convinced her mother that it was necessary to light a good fire, and persuaded Nanon to bring up a great pile of wood into the corridor without saying anything to her father.She ran to get, from one of the corner-shelves of the hall, a tray of old lacquer which was part of the inheritance of the late Monsieur de la Bertelliere, catching up at the same time a six-sided crystal goblet, a little tarnished gilt spoon, an antique flask engraved with cupids, all of which she put triumphantly on the corner of her cousin’s chimney-piece.More ideas surged through her head in one quarter of an hour than she had ever had since she came into the world.

zh: “妈妈，”她说，“我堂弟绝对受不了油蜡烛的气味，咱们买支白蜡烛怎么样？”说着她像只小鸟一样轻快地冲了出去，拿来她刚得到的五法郎，那是她每月的零花钱。“喂，娜农，”她叫着，“快点！”
en: “Mamma,” she said, “my cousin will never bear the smell of a tallow candle; suppose we buy a wax one?”And she darted, swift as a bird, to get the five-franc piece which she had just received for her monthly expenses.“Here, Nanon,” she cried, “quick!”

zh: “你父亲会怎么说呀？”当看到女儿拿起一只旧塞夫尔糖罐时——那是葛朗台从弗罗瓦丰庄园带回来的，葛朗台太太厉声反对道，“还有，你去哪里弄到糖呢？你疯了吗？”
en: “What will your father say?”This terrible remonstrance was uttered by Madame Grandet as she beheld her daughter armed with an old Sevres sugar-basin which Grandet had brought home from the chateau of Froidfond.“And where will you get the sugar?Are you crazy?”

zh: “妈妈，娜农买蜡烛时，可以买些糖。”
en: “Mamma, Nanon can buy some sugar as well as the candle.”

zh: “可你父亲呢？”
en: “But your father?”

zh: “可他侄子不能连杯糖水也喝不上吧？而且，他不会注意这个的。”
en: “Surely his nephew ought not to go without a glass of @eau sucree@?Besides, he will not notice it.”

zh: “什么也逃不过你父亲的眼睛。”葛朗台太太说着，摇了摇头。
en: “Your father sees everything,” said Madame Grandet, shaking her head.

zh: 娜农犹豫着，她很了解她的主人。
en: Nanon hesitated; she knew her master.

zh: “拜托，娜农，去吧——因为今天是我的生日。”
en: “Come, Nanon, go,—because it is my birthday.”

zh: 当听到她年轻的女主人头一次开起了玩笑，娜农大笑起来，然后照她的吩咐做去了。
en: Nanon gave a loud laugh as she heard the first little jest her young mistress had ever made, and then obeyed her.

zh: 正当欧仁妮和她母亲千方百计布置葛朗台先生为侄子安排的卧室时，德格拉桑太太正向夏尔大献殷勤，从表面来看，她正在挑逗夏尔。
en: While Eugenie and her mother were trying to embellish the bedroom assigned by Monsieur Grandet for his nephew, Charles himself was the object of Madame des Grassins’ attentions; to all appearances she was setting her cap at him.

zh: “您非常勇敢，先生，”她对年轻的时髦公子说道，“在这个季节不在首都好好享受，却跑到了索米尔。不过，要是您没有被我们吓跑的话，您会发现，即使在这里也是有些乐趣的。”
en: “You are very courageous, monsieur,” she said to the young dandy, “to leave the pleasures of the capital at this season and take up your abode in Saumur.But if we do not frighten you away, you will find there are some amusements even here.”

zh: 她向他抛了个外省式的媚眼。在外省，女人们的眼中有太多的拘谨和矜持，反而使她们的眼神中流露出一种假装正经的色欲，那正是某些将一切娱乐视为盗窃或罪过的教士所特有的神态。夏尔在这个宅子里觉得非常不自在，这所宅子同想象中伯父应有的巨大庄园和奢华生活相去甚远，所以在看着德格拉桑太太时，他察觉出她的脸上有模模糊糊巴黎人的影子。他优雅地答复了对他的邀约，然后非常自然地开始了交谈。交谈中，德格拉桑太太渐渐压低了嗓门，以便与她正说的悄悄话合上拍。她和夏尔一样，都有说说悄悄话的需要，所以，调了一会儿情，又开了几个一本正经的玩笑之后，想着不会被别人听到——其他人正在谈论时下索米尔人都关心的酒市行情，这位聪明的外省人说道——
en: She threw him the ogling glance of the provinces, where women put so much prudence and reserve into their eyes that they impart to them the prudish concupiscence peculiar to certain ecclesiastics to whom all pleasure is either a theft or an error.Charles was so completely out of his element in this abode, and so far from the vast chateau and the sumptuous life with which his fancy had endowed his uncle, that as he looked at Madame des Grassins he perceived a dim likeness to Parisian faces.He gracefully responded to the species of invitation addressed to him, and began very naturally a conversation, in which Madame des Grassins gradually lowered her voice so as to bring it into harmony with the nature of the confidences she was making.With her, as with Charles, there was the need of conference; so after a few moments spent in coquettish phrases and a little serious jesting, the clever provincial said, thinking herself unheard by the others, who were discussing the sale of wines which at that season filled the heads of every one in Saumur,—

zh: “先生，如果您肯赏脸光临寒舍，我丈夫和我都会感到非常荣幸。我们的沙龙是索米尔的商界巨头和贵族聚会的唯一场所。我们都是这两个阶层的成员，他们来我们家会面，仅仅是因为他们觉得有意思。我丈夫——我敢自豪地说——在两个圈子都颇受敬重。在您小住期间，我们会尽量给您解解闷。假如您总是和葛朗台先生呆在一起，天哪！您会变成什么样啊？您的伯父是个贪婪的吝啬鬼，一心只想着他的葡萄藤；您的伯母是个虔诚的教徒，没什么主见；您的堂姐是个小傻瓜，没受过教育，非常粗俗，没有嫁妆，一辈子就是缝缝补补。”
en: “Monsieur, if you will do us the honor to come and see us, you will give as much pleasure to my husband as to myself.Our salon is the only one in Saumur where you will find the higher business circles mingling with the nobility.We belong to both societies, who meet at our house simply because they find it amusing.My husband—I say it with pride—is as much valued by the one class as by the other.We will try to relieve the monotony of your visit here.If you stay all the time with Monsieur Grandet, good heavens! What will become of you?Your uncle is a sordid miser who thinks of nothing but his vines; your aunt is a pious soul who can’t put two ideas together; and your cousin is a little fool, without education, perfectly common, no fortune, who will spend her life in darning towels.”

zh: “这个女人确实不错。”夏尔·葛朗台一边想着，一边适时地应付着德格拉桑太太的卖弄风情。
en: “She is really very nice, this woman,” thought Charles Grandet as he duly responded to Madame des Grassins’ coquetries.

zh: “太太，我看你要独霸这位先生了。”壮实的银行家笑着说道。
en: “It seems to me, wife, that you are taking possession of monsieur,” said the stout banker, laughing.

zh: 听到这句话，公证人和庭长也说了几句不咸不淡的俏皮话，可是神父却狡猾地看着他们，他捏了一撮儿鼻烟，一边向大家让着他的鼻烟壶，一边把众人的想法概括了一下，说道：
en: On this remark the notary and the president said a few words that were more or less significant; but the abbe, looking at them slyly, brought their thoughts to a focus by taking a pinch of snuff and saying as he handed round his snuff-box:

zh: “要为这位先生尽到地主之谊，索米尔有谁能比得上夫人呢？”
en: “Who can do the honors of Saumur for monsieur so well as madame?”

zh: “啊！您的话什么意思，神父先生？”德格拉桑先生问道。
en: “Ah! What do you mean by that, monsieur l’abbe?” demanded Monsieur des Grassins.

zh: “我这话对您、对夫人、对索米尔城，还有对这位先生都是一番好意。”狡猾的老家伙一边说，一边转向了夏尔。
en: “I mean it in the best possible sense for you, for madame, for the town of Saumur, and for monsieur,” said the wily old man, turning to Charles.

zh: 克吕绍神父已猜到了夏尔和德格拉桑太太之间的谈话内容，表面却装着没有注意的样子。
en: The Abbe Cruchot had guessed the conversation between Charles and Madame des Grassins without seeming to pay attention to it.

zh: “先生，”阿道夫带着一副故作轻松随意的神情，对夏尔说道，“我不知道您是否记得我，但是在德纽沁根男爵举办的舞会上，我曾有幸见过您一面，而且——”
en: “Monsieur,” said Adolphe to Charles with an air which he tried to make free and easy, “I don’t know whether you remember me, but I had the honor of dancing as your @vis-a-vis@ at a ball given by the Baron de Nucingen, and—”

zh: “没错，我记得很清楚，先生。”夏尔回答道，很高兴地发现自己成了大家关注的对象。
en: “Perfectly; I remember perfectly, monsieur,” answered Charles, pleased to find himself the object of general attention.

zh: “这位先生是您的儿子吗？”他对德格拉桑太太说道。
en: “Monsieur is your son?” he said to Madame des Grassins.

zh: 神父不怀好意看着她。
en: The abbe looked at her maliciously.

zh: “是的，先生。”她回答道。
en: “Yes, monsieur,” she answered.

zh: “那您很年轻就去巴黎了？”夏尔向阿道夫问道。
en: “Then you were very young when you were in Paris?” said Charles, addressing Adolphe.

zh: “您肯定知道，先生，”神父说，“他们一断奶，我们就把他们送到巴比伦那样的花花世界了。”
en: “You must know, monsieur,” said the abbe, “that we send them to Babylon as soon as they are weaned.”

zh: 德格拉桑太太审视着神父，一眼就看穿了他。
en: Madame des Grassins examined the abbe with a glance of extreme penetration.

zh: “只有在外省，”他接着说，“您才能见到像夫人一样三十出头、仍然充满青春活力的女人，看看，儿子都快拿上学位了。我简直觉得自己又回到了过去的时光，那时年轻人都站在舞厅的椅子上看您跳舞，夫人。”神父扭身对他的女对手说道，“对我来说，您的辉煌仿佛就是在昨天——”
en: “It is only in the provinces,” he continued, “that you will find women of thirty and more years as fresh as madame, here, with a son about to take his degree.I almost fancy myself back in the days when the young men stood on chairs in the ball-room to see you dance, madame,” said the abbe, turning to his female adversary.“To me, your triumphs are but of yesterday—”

zh: “这个老浑蛋！”德格拉桑太太心想，“难道他已经猜出了我的心思？”
en: “The old rogue!” thought Madame Grassins, “can he have guessed my intentions?”

zh: “看来我会在索米尔大出风头的。”夏尔一边想着，一边解开了他大衣的纽扣，将一只手放进马甲里，目视远方，模仿着尚特雷塑造的拜伦勋爵的姿势。
en: “It seems that I shall have a good deal of success in Saumur,” thought Charles as he unbuttoned his great-coat, put a hand into his waistcoat, and cast a glance into the far distance, to imitate the attitude which Chantrey has given to Lord Byron.

zh: 葛朗台老头不理会大家，或者更确切地说，他全神贯注看信的情形，没有逃过公证人和庭长的警觉，这个吝啬鬼那几乎不动声色的脸被烛光照得清清楚楚，他们试图通过这张脸猜测信里的内容。他明显在尽力保持平时的镇定，当他读到下面这封要命的信时，事实上，我们是可以想象出这样一个人竭力维持的表情，信上写道——
en: The inattention of Pere Grandet, or, to speak more truly, the preoccupation of mind into which the reading of the letter had plunged him, did not escape the vigilance of the notary and the president, who tried to guess the contents of the letter by the almost imperceptible motions of the miser’s face, which was then under the full light of the candle.He maintained the habitual calm of his features with evident difficulty; we may, in fact, picture to ourselves the countenance such a man endeavored to preserve as he read the fatal letter which here follows:—

zh: 我的哥哥——我们有近二十三年没有见面了。最后一次见面是在我的婚礼上，之后我们俩就高高兴兴地分开了。当然，那时我是无法预见到，你有朝一日会成为家里的顶梁柱，你那时就估计到了家业会兴旺。
en: My Brother,—It is almost twenty-three years since we have seen each other.My marriage was the occasion of our last interview, after which we parted, and both of us were happy.Assuredly I could not then foresee that you would one day be the prop of the family whose prosperity you then predicted.

zh: 当你手握这封信时，我应该已不在人世了。处在我现在的位置，我是无法在破产的耻辱中苟且偷生的。我在深渊边上等到最后一刻，希望能救自己。末日来了，我注定无法逃脱。我的经纪人和我的公证人罗甘双双破产，卷走了我最后的资财，使我一无所有。我欠了将近四百万的债，只有不到百分之二十五的资产可用来偿还，痛苦至极。你们的葡萄收成不错、质量又好，以至于我仓库里的酒价格大跌。三天之后，巴黎人会大声叫喊：
en: When you hold this letter within your hands I shall be no longer living.In the position I now hold I cannot survive the disgrace of bankruptcy.I have waited on the edge of the gulf until the last moment, hoping to save myself.The end has come, I must sink into it.The double bankruptcies of my broker and of Roguin, my notary, have carried off my last resources and left me nothing.I have the bitterness of owing nearly four millions, with assets not more than twenty-five per cent in value to pay them.The wines in my warehouses suffer from the fall in prices caused by the abundance and quality of your vintage.In three days Paris will cry out:

zh: “葛朗台先生是个无赖！”
en: “Monsieur Grandet was a knave!”

zh: 而我这个诚实的人，就要躺在声名狼藉的裹尸布中。我毁了我儿子的好名声，我玷污了它，还夺走了他母亲的财产，我全都赔了。他对此还一无所知，——我心爱的不幸的孩子！我们分手时依依不舍。他高高兴兴，全然不知我生命最后的感情都倾注在了那次诀别中。将来有一天他不会诅咒我吧？我的哥哥，我的哥哥！我们孩子的诅咒是可怕的，对我们的咒骂，他们可以求得宽恕，可他们的诅咒却是无法挽回的。葛朗台，你是我的长兄，你应该保护我，帮帮我，别让夏尔在我的坟前说出狠毒的话来！我的哥哥，写这封信时我痛苦万分，即使是用我的血、我的泪写信，我的痛苦也不会有如此之深的，——不会这么痛苦，因为如果是那样，我会哭泣，我会流血，我会死去，我不会再受折磨，可是现在我很痛苦，干瞪着双眼看着死亡临头。
en: And I, an honest man, shall be lying in my winding-sheet of infamy.I deprive my son of a good name, which I have stained, and the fortune of his mother, which I have lost.He knows nothing of all this,—my unfortunate child whom I idolize!We parted tenderly.He was ignorant, happily, that the last beatings of my heart were spent in that farewell.Will he not some day curse me?My brother, my brother! The curses of our children are horrible; they can appeal against ours, but theirs are irrevocable.Grandet, you are my elder brother, you owe me your protection; act for me so that Charles may cast no bitter words upon my grave!My brother, if I were writing with my blood, with my tears, no greater anguish could I put into this letter,—nor as great, for then I should weep, I should bleed, I should die, I should suffer no more, but now I suffer and look at death with dry eyes.

zh: 从今以后，你就是我儿子的父亲，在他母亲那边，他没有亲人，这你很清楚。为什么当初我就没有考虑社会偏见呢？为什么我要向爱情让步呢？为什么我要娶一个贵族老爷的私生女呢？夏尔没有家了。哦，我不幸的儿子！我的儿子！听着，葛朗台！我求你，不是为了我自己——再说，你的家产可能也不够担负三百万的抵押——而是为了我的儿子！哥哥，想到你时，我是双手合十的，看看这双手吧！葛朗台，我在临死时把我的儿子托付给你，想到你会当他的父亲，面对死亡时，我也不那么痛苦了。我的夏尔，他很爱我，我对他也很疼爱，我从来没有让他伤心过，他也不会诅咒我的。啊，你看！他很温和，像他的母亲，他不会让你伤心的。可怜的孩子！享受惯了荣华富贵，对你我小时候缺衣少穿受的苦，他一无所知。是我让他倾家荡产了！孤苦伶仃！是的，我所有的朋友都会躲着他，是我让他遭受这样的羞辱！我要是有力气能一把把他推到天堂他母亲的身边就好了！疯了！我还是回头说说我的灾难——也是他的灾难。我把他送到你那里，你可以用某种恰当的方式把我的死讯和他未来的命运告诉他。做他的父亲吧，可要做个好父亲啊。不要马上让他脱离他的悠闲生活，那会要了他的命。我要跪下来，求他放弃作为他母亲的继承人对我的财产的所有权利。但是这样的祈求是多余的，他是讲体面的，而且他会觉得不应该和我的债权人站在一起。在适当的时候让他明白这一点，向他说明我给他造成的艰难的生活状况，如果他对我还有一丝温情，以为的名义告诉他，一切还不是完全无法挽回的。是的，工作和劳动曾救了我们两个，它们也会让他挣回来我败掉的家业。如果他听他父亲的话，我要从墓穴里说给他听，他应该远走印度。我的哥哥，夏尔是个正直勇敢的年轻人，给他必要的资金，让他做投机生意，他是宁死也不会赖掉你借给他的资金的。葛朗台！如果你不这样做的话，你会后悔不已的。啊，我的孩子不会从你那里既得不到情义又得不到帮助吧，那我就会祈求上帝来报复你的冷酷无情！
en: From henceforth you are my son’s father; he has no relations, as you well know, on his mother’s side.Why did I not consider social prejudices?Why did I yield to love?Why did I marry the natural daughter of a great lord?Charles has no family.Oh, my unhappy son! My son!Listen, Grandet!I implore nothing for myself,—besides, your property may not be large enough to carry a mortgage of three millions,—but for my son!Brother, my suppliant hands are clasped as I think of you; behold them!Grandet, I confide my son to you in dying, and I look at the means of death with less pain as I think that you will be to him a father.He loved me well, my Charles; I was good to him, I never thwarted him; he will not curse me.Ah, you see! He is gentle, he is like his mother, he will cause you no grief.Poor boy! Accustomed to all the enjoyments of luxury, he knows nothing of the privations to which you and I were condemned by the poverty of our youth.And I leave him ruined! Alone!Yes, all my friends will avoid him, and it is I who have brought this humiliation upon him!Would that I had the force to send him with one thrust into the heavens to his mother’s side!Madness!I come back to my disaster—to his.I send him to you that you may tell him in some fitting way of my death, of his future fate.Be a father to him, but a good father.Do not tear him all at once from his idle life, it would kill him.I beg him on my knees to renounce all rights that, as his mother’s heir, he may have on my estate.But the prayer is superfluous; he is honorable, and he will feel that he must not appear among my creditors.Bring him to see this at the right time; reveal to him the hard conditions of the life I have made for him: and if he still has tender thoughts of me, tell him in my name that all is not lost for him.Yes, work, labor, which saved us both, may give him back the fortune of which I have deprived him; and if he listens to his father’s voice as it reaches him from the grave, he will go the Indies.My brother, Charles is an upright and courageous young man; give him the wherewithal to make his venture; he will die sooner than not repay you the funds which you may lend him.Grandet! If you will not do this, you will lay up for yourself remorse.Ah, should my child find neither tenderness nor succor in you, I would call down the vengeance of God upon your cruelty!

zh: 如果当初我能够从残局中抢救出点什么，我就有权给他留下至少他母亲的部分遗产，可是我最后的月开销耗光了一切。对孩子的命运没有把握，我是不愿撒手人寰的，我真想握着你的手来感受一下神圣的誓言，那可能会让我的心感到温暖：可是时间不等我。当夏尔赶赴你那里时，我正着手准备我的财产转让书。我将竭力以条理清晰而诚实的账目来证明，我的灾难既不是因为过失也不是因为欺诈。正是为了我儿子的缘故，我才拼命这样做的。
en: If I had been able to save something from the wreck, I might have had the right to leave him at least a portion of his mother’s property; but my last monthly payments have absorbed everything.I did not wish to die uncertain of my child’s fate; I hoped to feel a sacred promise in a clasp of your hand which might have warmed my heart: but time fails me.While Charles is journeying to you I shall be preparing my assignment.I shall endeavor to show by the order and good faith of my accounts that my disaster comes neither from a faulty life nor from dishonesty.It is for my son’s sake that I strive to do this.

zh: 再见，我的哥哥！我托付给你这个高洁的监护权，你会接受的，对此我毫不怀疑，愿上帝赐福于你。在那个我们所有人都得去的世界，有一个人将从此永远为你祈祷。当你读到这些话时，我已经在那里了。
en: Farewell, my brother!May the blessing of God be yours for the generous guardianship I lay upon you, and which, I doubt not, you will accept.A voice will henceforth and forever pray for you in that world where we must all go, and where I am now as you read these lines.

zh: 维克托-安热-纪尧姆·葛朗台
en: Victor-Ange-Guillaume Grandet.

zh: “这么说你们在聊天？”葛朗台老头一边说道，一边小心地把信按原来的折痕折好，放进了他的马甲口袋里。他带着一副谦卑怯懦的神情看着自己的侄子，实际上他是在掩饰自己的情绪和种种盘算。“你暖和过来了吗？”他对夏尔说。
en: “So you are talking?” said Pere Grandet as he carefully folded the letter in its original creases and put it into his waistcoat-pocket.He looked at his nephew with a humble, timid air, beneath which he hid his feelings and his calculations.“Have you warmed yourself?” he said to him.

zh: “完全暖和过来了，我亲爱的伯父。”
en: “Thoroughly, my dear uncle.”

zh: “哦，那些女人们在哪里？”他伯父说道，已经忘了侄子要睡在家里。这时欧仁妮和葛朗台太太回到了大厅。
en: “Well, where are the women?” said his uncle, already forgetting that his nephew was to sleep at the house.At this moment Eugenie and Madame Grandet returned.

zh: “屋子准备好了吗？”葛朗台恢复了镇定，说道。
en: “Is the room all ready?” said Grandet, recovering his composure.

zh: “是的，父亲。”
en: “Yes, father.”

zh: “那好，侄儿，如果你累了，娜农会带你去你的房间。那可不是公子哥的房间，但是你要原谅一个穷种葡萄的，一个子都没有剩下过。税款吞光了一切。”
en: “Well then, my nephew, if you are tired, Nanon shall show you your room.It isn’t a dandy’s room; but you will excuse a poor wine-grower who never has a penny to spare.Taxes swallow up everything.”

zh: “我们不想打搅了，葛朗台，”银行家说，“您可能和令侄有话想谈，所以我们要跟你们道晚安了。”
en: “We do not wish to intrude, Grandet,” said the banker, “you may want to talk to your nephew, and therefore we will bid you good-night.”

zh: 一听这话，大家都起了身，每个人都按照各自的身份行了告别礼。老公证人走到门口拿了自己的灯笼，又回来把灯笼点着，并提出要陪德格拉桑一家回去。德格拉桑太太没料到中途会出事，晚会竟提前结束了，结果她的佣人还没来。
en: At these words the assembly rose, and each made a parting bow in keeping with his or her own character.The old notary went to the door to fetch his lantern and came back to light it, offering to accompany the des Grassins on their way.Madame des Grassins had not foreseen the incident which brought the evening prematurely to an end, her servant therefore had not arrived.

zh: “能赏脸让我搀您吗，夫人？”神父说。
en: “Will you do me the honor to take my arm, madame?” said the abbe.

zh: “谢谢，神父先生。可是我儿子会搀我的。”她冷冷地答道。
en: “Thank you, monsieur l’abbe, but I have my son,” she answered dryly.

zh: “女士们和我在一起不会受连累的。”神父说。
en: “Ladies cannot compromise themselves with me,” said the abbe.

zh: “让克吕绍先生搀着吧。”她丈夫说。
en: “Take Monsieur Cruchot’s arm,” said her husband.

zh: 神父挽着这位美丽的女士快步走开了，很快就把众人甩得远远的。
en: The abbe walked off with the pretty lady so quickly that they were soon some distance in advance of the caravan.

zh: “那是个英俊的年轻人，夫人，”他一边说，一边抓紧了她的胳膊，“酒做好了，葡萄就没用了。咱们都没戏了。我们可能要跟葛朗台小姐说再见了。欧仁妮将会属于那个花花公子。除非这个堂弟爱上了某个巴黎女人，否则令郎阿道夫会有个情敌的，在——”
en: “That is a good-looking young man, madame,” he said, pressing her arm.“Goodby to the grapes, the vintage is done.It is all over with us.We may as well say adieu to Mademoiselle Grandet.Eugenie will belong to the dandy.Unless this cousin is enamoured of some Parisian woman, your son Adolphe will find another rival in—”

zh: “肯定不会的，神父先生。这个年轻人准会看出来，欧仁妮是个小傻瓜——一个姑娘家，一点儿也没有青春活力。今晚您注意看她了没有？她皮肤黄得像个榅桲。”
en: “Not at all, monsieur l’abbe.This young man cannot fail to see that Eugenie is a little fool,—a girl without the least freshness.Did you notice her tonight?She was as yellow as a quince.”

zh: “也许您已经让那个堂弟注意到这一点了吧？”
en: “Perhaps you made the cousin notice it?”

zh: “我可没花那工夫——”
en: “I did not take the trouble—”

zh: “夫人，您可要一直呆在欧仁妮旁边，这样您就根本不用费劲跟那个年轻人说他堂姐的坏话了，他自己会对比的，那——”
en: “Place yourself always beside Eugenie, madame, and you need never take the trouble to say anything to the young man against his cousin; he will make his own comparisons, which—”

zh: “嗯，他已经答应后天和我一起吃晚餐了。”
en: “Well, he has promised to dine with me the day after tomorrow.”

zh: “啊！要是您愿意的话，夫人——”神父说。
en: “Ah! If you only @would@, madame—” said the abbe.

zh: “您想让我做什么，神父先生？您是不是打算给我出些坏点子？我活到三十九岁，一直名声清白，感谢上帝！即使是为了莫卧儿大帝的帝国，我现在也不会糟蹋自己的名声的。你和我都已到了这把年纪，我们都知道说话该有分寸。作为一个牧师，您的想法真是有失身份。呸！可称得上《福勃拉斯》了！”
en: “What is it that you wish me to do, monsieur l’abbe?Do you mean to offer me bad advice?I have not reached the age of thirty-nine, without a stain upon my reputation, thank God! To compromise myself now, even for the empire of the Great Mogul.You and I are of an age when we both know the meaning of words.For an ecclesiastic, you certainly have ideas that are very incongruous.Fie! It is worthy of @Faublas@!”

zh: “您读过《福勃拉斯》？”
en: “You have read @Faublas@?”

zh: “没有，神父先生，我是说《危险的关系》。”
en: “No, monsieur l’abbe; I meant to say the @Liaisons dangereuses@.”

zh: “啊！那本书正经多了，”神父笑着说道，“可是您把我看得和当今的年轻人一样坏，我只不过是想——”
en: “Ah! That book is infinitely more moral,” said the abbe, laughing.“But you make me out as wicked as a young man of the present day; I only meant—”

zh: “您敢说您不是想往我的脑袋里灌些坏水吗？这不是明摆的吗？如果这个年轻人——我承认，他是长得非常英俊——想追求我，他就不会想到他的堂姐了。我知道，在巴黎，善良的母亲们会为了孩子的幸福和财产，以这种方式牺牲自己，但是我们是住在外省，神父先生。”
en: “Do you dare to tell me you were not thinking of putting wicked things into my head?Isn’t it perfectly clear?If this young man—who I admit is very good-looking—were to make love to me, he would not think of his cousin.In Paris, I know, good mothers do devote themselves in this way to the happiness and welfare of their children; but we live in the provinces, monsieur l’abbe.”

zh: “是的，夫人。”
en: “Yes, madame.”

zh: “而且，”她继续说道，“哪怕是一个亿，我和阿道夫本人都不愿意以这样的代价去换。”
en: “And,” she continued, “I do not want, and Adolphe himself would not want, a hundred millions brought at such a price.”

zh: “夫人，我没说什么一个亿，那个诱惑可能太大了，我们谁也抵挡不住的。只是，我以为一个正派女人不失体面、毫无恶意地稍稍调调情，倒是无妨，这实际上是她社交责任的一部分，而且——”
en: “Madame, I said nothing about a hundred millions; that temptation might be too great for either of us to withstand.Only, I do think that an honest woman may permit herself, in all honor, certain harmless little coquetries, which are, in fact, part of her social duty and which—”

zh: “您是这样想的？”
en: “Do you think so?”

zh: “夫人，难道我们不应当彼此相处得愉快些吗？——请允许我擤一下鼻子。——我向您保证，夫人，”他接着说，“那个年轻的绅士拿着眼镜瞟您时的神态，比看我时的神态要谄媚得多，不过，我原谅他爱美胜于敬老——”
en: “Are we not bound, madame, to make ourselves agreeable to each other?—Permit me to blow my nose.—I assure you, madame,” he resumed, “that the young gentleman ogled you through his glass in a more flattering manner than he put on when he looked at me; but I forgive him for doing homage to beauty in preference to old age—”

zh: “很明显，”庭长大声说道，“巴黎的葛朗台先生派他儿子来索米尔，绝对是出于结婚的打算。”
en: “It is quite apparent,” said the president in his loud voice, “that Monsieur Grandet of Paris has sent his son to Saumur with extremely matrimonial intentions.”

zh: “但要是那样的话，那位堂弟不会像炮弹一样突然降临到我们中间的。”公证人答道。
en: “But in that case the cousin wouldn’t have fallen among us like a cannon-ball,” answered the notary.

zh: “那说明不了什么，”德格拉桑先生说，“那个老守财奴总是神神秘秘的。”
en: “That doesn’t prove anything,” said Monsieur des Grassins, “the old miser is always making mysteries.”

zh: “德格拉桑，我的朋友，我已经邀请那个年轻人来吃晚餐了。你得去请上德拉索尼埃夫妇和杜奥图瓦一家，当然还有那位漂亮的杜奥图瓦小姐。我希望她会穿得体面一些，她那个母亲嫉妒心很强，总是把她打扮成一个丑八怪！先生们，我希望你们都能赏光光临。”她停下脚步，对两位克吕绍补充道。
en: “Des Grassins, my friend, I have invited the young man to dinner.You must go and ask Monsieur and Madame de Larsonniere and the du Hautoys, with the beautiful demoiselle du Hautoy, of course.I hope she will be properly dressed; that jealous mother of hers does make such a fright of her!Gentlemen, I trust that you will all do us the honor to come,” she added, stopping the procession to address the two Cruchots.

zh: “你们到家了，夫人。”公证人说。
en: “Here you are at home, madame,” said the notary.

zh: 向三位德格拉桑躬身道别后，三位克吕绍便回家了，他们拿出外省人善于分析的天赋，对这一晚的重大事件从各个方面进行了研究，这一事件无疑改变了格拉桑派和克吕绍派各自的立场。这些伟大的阴谋家做任何事情都有着绝好的判断力，双方都觉得有必要暂时结盟以对付共同的敌人。难道他们不应该联手阻止欧仁妮爱上她的堂弟，并阻止这位堂弟想着欧仁妮吗？那个巴黎人能否抵挡得住含沙射影的恶毒语言、花言巧语的诬陷中伤、貌似恭维的诽谤，以及假装天真的拒绝？这些招数会不断地将他包围，让他上当。
en: After bowing to the three des Grassins, the three Cruchots returned home, applying their provincial genius for analysis to studying, under all its aspects, the great event of the evening, which undoubtedly changed the respective positions of Grassinists and Cruchotines.The admirable common-sense which guided all the actions of these great machinators made each side feel the necessity of a momentary alliance against a common enemy.Must they not mutually hinder Eugenie from loving her cousin, and the cousin from thinking of Eugenie?Could the Parisian resist the influence of treacherous insinuations, soft-spoken calumnies, slanders full of faint praise and artless denials, which should be made to circle incessantly about him and deceive him?

zh: 第四章
en: Chapter IV

zh: 当只剩下他们四个人时，葛朗台先生对他侄子说：“我们该睡觉了。今天太晚了，关于你为什么来这里的事情就不谈了，明天我们再挑个合适的时间。我们八点吃早饭；中午我们吃点儿水果或者吃一点儿面包，喝杯白葡萄酒；我们跟巴黎人一样，五点吃晚饭。这就是一天的安排。如果你想去城里和郊区看看，尽管自便。我事情多，不能陪着你，请原谅。你也许会听到人们说我有钱——葛朗台先生这样呀，葛朗台先生那样呀。我让他们说去，他们的流言蜚语损害不了我的信誉。可是我一个子也没有，我这把年纪还像学徒一样地干活，全部家当就是一把破刨子和两只结实的胳膊。也许，等你不得不自己拼命挣钱的时候，你很快就会明白，挣一个法郎有多辛苦。娜农，蜡烛在哪里？”
en: When the four relations were left alone, Monsieur Grandet said to his nephew,“We must go to bed.It is too late to talk about the matters which have brought you here; tomorrow we will take a suitable moment.We breakfast at eight o’clock; at midday we eat a little fruit or a bit of bread, and drink a glass of white wine; and we dine, like the Parisians, at five o’clock.That’s the order of the day.If you like to go and see the town and the environs you are free to do so.You will excuse me if my occupations do not permit me to accompany you.You may perhaps hear people say that I am rich,—Monsieur Grandet this, Monsieur Grandet that.I let them talk; their gossip does not hurt my credit.But I have not a penny; I work in my old age like an apprentice whose worldly goods are a bad plane and two good arms.Perhaps you’ll soon know yourself what a franc costs when you have got to sweat for it.Nanon, where are the candles?”

zh: “我的侄儿，我相信你需要的东西都备好了，”葛朗台太太说，“不过要是你还需要什么其他的东西，可以喊娜农。”
en: “I trust, my nephew, that you will find all you want,” said Madame Grandet, “but if you should need anything else, you can call Nanon.”

zh: “亲爱的伯母，我不会缺什么的；我想，所有的必需品我都带来了。请允许我向您和我年轻的堂姐道声晚安。”
en: “My dear aunt, I shall need nothing; I have, I believe, brought everything with me.Permit me to bid you good-night, and my young cousin also.”

zh: 夏尔从娜农手里接过一支点燃的白蜡烛——一支安茹蜡烛，颜色很黄，因为很陈旧了，所以看上去像油蜡烛似的，而且竟然骗过了葛朗台先生，他根本不会想到在自己的家里会有白蜡烛出现，也就没有发觉这是一件奢侈品。
en: Charles took a lighted wax candle from Nanon’s hand,—an Anjou candle, very yellow in color, and so shopworn that it looked like tallow and deceived Monsieur Grandet, who, incapable of suspecting its presence under his roof, did not perceive this magnificence.

zh: “我来给你带路。”他说。
en: “I will show you the way,” he said.

zh: 葛朗台没有从拱顶下的那个门出大厅，而是郑重其事地从大厅和厨房中间的过道走了过去。一扇镶着一块椭圆形大玻璃的弹簧门隔开了这个过道和楼梯，这样就挡住了从过道穿过的冷风。可是在冬天，北风依旧呼啸凛冽，而且，尽管起居室的门底包有沙袋，屋内仍然很难保持适宜的温度。娜农去把外面的大门闩上，然后关好大厅门，放出了狼狗，那狼狗的吠声嘶哑得像得了咽喉炎一样。这畜生因凶猛而出名，它只认娜农一个人；这两个小家伙都来自野外，没有受过教化，彼此倒是很相投。
en: Instead of leaving the hall by the door which opened under the archway, Grandet ceremoniously went through the passage which divided the hall from the kitchen.A swing-door, furnished with a large oval pane of glass, shut this passage from the staircase, so as to fend off the cold air which rushed through it.But the north wind whistled none the less keenly in winter, and, in spite of the sand-bags at the bottom of the doors of the living-room, the temperature within could scarcely be kept at a proper height.Nanon went to bolt the outer door; then she closed the hall and let loose a wolf-dog, whose bark was so strangled that he seemed to have laryngitis.This animal, noted for his ferocity, recognized no one but Nanon; the two untutored children of the fields understood each other.

zh: 当夏尔看见楼梯间的墙壁颜色发黄、烟熏斑斑，被虫蛀了的每级台阶在他伯父沉重的脚步下不停地颤抖时，他渐渐从美梦中清醒过来。他觉得自己简直进了一个鸡笼。他转身探询地望了一眼他的伯母和堂姐，她们早已习惯了这种楼梯，所以猜不到他惊讶的原因，还以为他那一眼是表示友好，于是便报以微笑，这令他大失所望。
en: When Charles saw the yellow, smoke-stained walls of the well of the staircase, where each worm-eaten step shook under the heavy foot-fall of his uncle, his expectations began to sober more and more.He fancied himself in a hen-roost.His aunt and cousin, to whom he turned an inquiring look, were so used to the staircase that they did not guess the cause of his amazement, and took the glance for an expression of friendliness, which they answered by a smile that made him desperate.

zh: “我父亲为什么把我打发到这个鬼地方来了？”他心想。
en: “Why the devil did my father send me to such a place?” he said to himself.

zh: 当他们到了第一个楼梯口时，他看见了三扇漆着伊特鲁里亚红色的门，没有门框——门嵌在布满灰尘的墙里，装着铁条，实际上就是门闩，铁条两端有火焰式图案，跟长长的锁眼两头的花纹一样。在楼梯上面的第一个门显然已经给堵死了，门里的房间正好在厨房的上面。实际上，这个房间是他的办公室，只能从葛朗台的卧室进去。唯一采光的窗子临着院子，装有结实的铁条栅格。任何人都不准入内，甚至包括葛朗台太太。老头愿意独自呆在里面，就像一个炼金术师呆在他的实验室里一样。毫无疑问，这里已巧妙地建好了某个暗室，里面藏着地契、房契等，挂着称金路易的天平。夜里，他会偷偷在里面作估算、算利润、开收据，以致生意人看到葛朗台样样都有准备，便猜想他是从鬼神那里得到了启示。无疑，当娜农如雷的鼾声震动着楼板时，当狼狗看护着院子并哈欠连连时，当葛朗台太太和小姐正静悄悄地进入梦乡时，老箍桶匠就来到这里，把他的金子搂住，把玩着、爱抚着、死死抓着、攥着不放。
en: When they reached the first landing he saw three doors painted in Etruscan red and without casings,—doors sunk in the dusty walls and provided with iron bars, which in fact were bolts, each ending with the pattern of a flame, as did both ends of the long sheath of the lock.The first door at the top of the staircase, which opened into a room directly above the kitchen, was evidently walled up.In fact, the only entrance to that room was through Grandet’s bedchamber; the room itself was his office.The single window which lighted it, on the side of the court, was protected by a lattice of strong iron bars.No one, not even Madame Grandet, had permission to enter it.The old man chose to be alone, like an alchemist in his laboratory.There, no doubt, some hiding-place had been ingeniously constructed; there the title-deeds of property were stored; there hung the scales on which to weigh the louis; there were devised, by night and secretly, the estimates, the profits, the receipts, so that business men, finding Grandet prepared at all points, imagined that he got his cue from fairies or demons; there, no doubt, while Nanon’s loud snoring shook the rafters, while the wolf-dog watched and yawned in the courtyard, while Madame and Mademoiselle Grandet were quietly sleeping, came the old cooper to cuddle, to con over, to caress and clutch and clasp his gold.

zh: 墙壁厚实，护窗也很牢固。只有他一个人有这个实验室的钥匙，据人们说，他在那里研究那些标明了他的果树的图纸，核算他的利润，精确到每株葡萄藤，直至差不多精确到每个小细枝。
en: The walls were thick, the screens sure.He alone had the key of this laboratory, where—so people declared—he studied the maps on which his fruit-trees were marked, and calculated his profits to a vine, and almost to a twig.

zh: 欧仁妮卧室的门正对着这间屋子封死的入口。楼梯口的另一头是老夫妇俩的卧室，占了整栋宅子的前半部分。葛朗台太太有一个房间紧邻欧仁妮的卧室，可以穿过一扇玻璃门进去。男主人的卧室和他妻子的卧室由隔板隔开，和那个神秘的密室则隔着一道厚实的墙。葛朗台老头将侄儿安排在三楼那个有高高的复折式房顶的阁楼里，就在他自己卧室的上面，这样，如果那个年轻人突然想在房内来回走动的话，他就可以听得见。当欧仁妮和母亲走到楼梯口中间时，她们相互吻别，道了晚安，又跟夏尔说了几句道别的话，然后就回了各自的卧室，那姑娘嘴上冷淡，但心里当然非常热乎。
en: The door of Eugenie’s chamber was opposite to the walled-up entrance to this room.At the other end of the landing were the appartements of the married pair, which occupied the whole front of the house.Madame Grandet had a room next to that of Eugenie, which was entered through a glass door.The master’s chamber was separated from that of his wife by a partition, and from the mysterious strong-room by a thick wall.Pere Grandet lodged his nephew on the second floor, in the high mansard attic which was above his own bedroom, so that he might hear him if the young man took it into his head to go and come.When Eugenie and her mother reached the middle of the landing they kissed each other for good-night; then with a few words of adieu to Charles, cold upon the lips, but certainly very warm in the heart of the young girl, they withdrew into their own chambers.

zh: “这就是你的房间，侄儿，”葛朗台老头一边开门，一边说道，“如果你要出去，就喊娜农；要是没有她，可要当心！那狗会一声不响地吃了你。睡个好觉。晚安。哈！啊呀，她们给你生了火！”他叫道。
en: “Here you are in your room, my nephew,” said Pere Grandet as he opened the door.“If you need to go out, call Nanon; without her, beware! The dog would eat you up without a word.Sleep well.Good night.Ha! Why, they have made you a fire!” he cried.

zh: 这时娜农拿着暖床炉出现了。
en: At this moment Nanon appeared with the warming pan.

zh: “还有一个东西啊！”葛朗台先生说，“你把我侄儿当成个产妇吗？拿走你的火盆，娜农！”
en: “Here’s something more!” said Monsieur Grandet.“Do you take my nephew for a lying-in woman?Carry off your brazier, Nanon!”

zh: “可是，先生，床单潮着呢，而且这位先生和一个女人一样娇嫩。”
en: “But, monsieur, the sheets are damp, and this gentleman is as delicate as a woman.”

zh: “好吧，得啦，既然你决定这么做，”葛朗台说着，推了推她的肩膀，“不过，别把东西给烧着了。”说着，守财奴下了楼，嘴里嘟嘟囔囔的，不知说了些什么。
en: “Well, go on, as you’ve taken it into your head,” said Grandet, pushing her by the shoulders, “but don’t set things on fire.”So saying, the miser went downstairs, grumbling indistinct sentences.

zh: 夏尔站在他的行李堆中间发愣。阁楼墙上的壁纸，黄底上零星点缀着花丛，花丛是是舞会上常用的那种；石砌的壁炉有凸起的条纹，那样子看着让人心凉；黄木椅子铺着漆过清漆的草垫，看起来似乎不止常见的四个角；开着的床头柜，大得可以容下一个小个子的警卫官；床边是破旧的脚毯，床天盖的布帷幔摇摇晃晃，仿佛被虫咬得都快要掉下来了。他一件件打量完之后，一本正经地转向大个子娜农，说道——
en: Charles stood aghast in the midst of his trunks.After casting his eyes on the attic-walls covered with that yellow paper sprinkled with bouquets so well known in dance-houses, on the fireplace of ribbed stone whose very look was chilling, on the chairs of yellow wood with varnished cane seats that seemed to have more than the usual four angles, on the open night-table capacious enough to hold a small sergeant-at-arms, on the meagre bit of rag-carpet beside the bed, on the tester whose cloth valance shook as if, devoured by moths, it was about to fall, he turned gravely to la Grande Nanon and said,—

zh: “喂！我亲爱的女士，告诉我，我真是在葛朗台先生——前索米尔市长，巴黎葛朗台先生的哥哥——的府上吗？”
en: “Look here! My dear woman, just tell me, am I in the house of Monsieur Grandet, formerly mayor of Saumur, and brother to Monsieur Grandet of Paris?”

zh: “是的，先生，一个非常好、非常仁慈、非常完美的绅士。要我帮您打开行李吗？”
en: “Yes, monsieur; and a very good, a very kind, a very perfect gentleman.Shall I help you to unpack your trunks?”

zh: “好啊！要的，如果你愿意的话，我的兵大爷。你没在帝国近卫团里当过水兵吗？”
en: “Faith! Yes, if you will, my old trooper.Didn’t you serve in the marines of the Imperial Guard?”

zh: “呵，呵，呵！”娜农大笑着，“那是什么呀——近卫团水兵？是咸的吗？在水里游的？”
en: “Ho, ho, ho!” laughed Nanon.“What’s that,—the marines of the guard?Is it salt?Does it go in the water?”

zh: “喂，从那个提箱里给我拿一下我的睡衣，给你钥匙。”
en: “Here, get me my dressing-gown out of that valise; there’s the key.”

zh: 当看到一件金线绣花、古式图案的绿绸睡衣时，娜农惊呆了。
en: Nanon was wonder-struck by the sight of a dressing-gown made of green silk, brocaded with gold flowers of an antique design.

zh: “您要穿这个睡觉？”她问道。
en: “Are you going to put that on to go to bed with?” she asked.

zh: “是啊。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “圣母玛利亚！给教区教堂当祭坛的桌布才叫好看呢！我亲爱的先生，把它捐给教堂吧，那样您会拯救您的灵魂的，不然，您就会失去灵魂。哦，您穿着可真好看呀！我得叫小姐来看看您。”
en: “Holy Virgin! What a beautiful altar-cloth it would make for the parish church!My dear darling monsieur, give it to the church, and you’ll save your soul; if you don’t, you’ll lose it.Oh, how nice you look in it!I must call mademoiselle to see you.”

zh: “得啦，娜农，如果你是娜农，就闭上你的嘴，让我睡觉去。明天我再收拾我的东西。要是你那么喜欢我的睡衣，你就拯救你的灵魂去吧。我是个虔诚的基督徒，走的时候会把它送给你，你爱怎么处理就随便你。”
en: “Come, Nanon, if Nanon you are, hold your tongue; let me go to bed.I’ll arrange my things tomorrow.If my dressing-gown pleases you so much, you shall save your soul.I’m too good a Christian not to give it to you when I go away, and you can do what you like with it.”

zh: 娜农一动不动地站着，呆呆地看着夏尔，不敢相信他的话。
en: Nanon stood rooted to the ground, gazing at Charles and unable to put faith into his words.

zh: “晚安，娜农。”
en: “Good night, Nanon.”

zh: “我干嘛要来这里？”夏尔睡觉时，心里想着，“我父亲不是个傻子，让我来一定有目的。哼！不知哪个希腊白痴说的，等明天再说正经事。”
en: “What in the world have I come here for?” thought Charles as he went to sleep.“My father is not a fool; my journey must have some object.Pshaw! Put off serious thought till the morrow, as some Greek idiot said.”

zh: “圣母玛利亚！我的堂弟，他可真迷人！”欧仁妮说着，停下了祈祷。那天晚上她的祈祷就没有做完。
en: “Blessed Virgin! How charming he is, my cousin!”Eugenie was saying, interrupting her prayers, which that night at least were never finished.

zh: 葛朗台太太上床睡觉时，什么也没想。从隔板中间的通门，她听见了守财奴在他的房间里走来走去的声音。像所有胆小的女人一样，她早摸透了她主人的脾气。如同海燕能预见暴风雨，她也能从微妙莫测的迹象中，知道丈夫的心里正在翻腾着狂风暴雨。在这种时候，用她自己的话说，她就“装死”。
en: Madame Grandet had no thoughts at all as she went to bed.She heard the miser walking up and down his room through the door of communication which was in the middle of the partition.Like all timid women, she had studied the character of her lord.Just as the petrel foresees the storm, she knew by imperceptible signs when an inward tempest shook her husband; and at such times, to use an expression of her own, she “feigned dead.”

zh: 葛朗台最近刚给那扇门钉上了铁皮，他一边瞪着门，一边自言自语道——
en: Grandet gazed at the door lined with sheet-iron which he lately put to his sanctum, and said to himself,—

zh: “真是疯了，我兄弟竟想把他的儿子遗留给我！好大一笔遗产！我可没有五十法郎给他。五十法郎对一个花花公子来说有什么用，他看着我的晴雨表，就好像打算拿它当柴火烧呢！”
en: “What a crazy idea of my brother to bequeath his son to me!A fine legacy!I have not fifty francs to give him.What are fifty francs to a dandy who looked at my barometer as if he meant to make firewood of it!”

zh: 想着那份痛苦的遗嘱会带来的后果，葛朗台的心绪可能比他兄弟写遗嘱的时候还要乱。
en: In thinking over the consequences of that legacy of anguish Grandet was perhaps more agitated than his brother had been at the moment of writing it.

zh: “我要得到那件金袍子啦。”娜农想着，睡着了，在梦中穿上了她的祭坛布，平生第一次梦见了花、刺绣和锦缎，就像欧仁妮正平生第一次梦见爱情一样。
en: “I shall have that golden robe,” thought Nanon, who went to sleep tricked out in her altar-cloth, dreaming for the first time in her life of flowers, embroidery, and damask, just as Eugenie was dreaming of love.

zh: 在少女们纯洁而单调的生活中，必有一个美妙的时刻，阳光会照进她们的灵魂，鲜花会表达她们的思想，心的跳动会把热烈的生机传递到她们的脑海，并把所有意念融化为一种朦胧的渴望——一段充满了天真无邪的忧郁和美妙快乐的时光！当婴儿开始看世界时，他们露出了微笑；当一个少女第一次感觉到大自然的这种情愫时，她也发出了儿时般的微笑。如果光明是生命的初恋，那爱情不就是心灵的光明吗？欧仁妮看清尘世万物的时刻已经来到了。
en: In the pure and monotonous life of young girls there comes a delicious hour when the sun sheds its rays into their soul, when the flowers express their thoughts, when the throbbings of the heart send upward to the brain their fertilizing warmth and melt all thoughts into a vague desire,—day of innocent melancholy and of dulcet joys!When babes begin to see, they smile; when a young girl first perceives the sentiment of nature, she smiles as she smiled when an infant.If light is the first love of life, is not love a light to the heart?The moment to see within the veil of earthly things had come for Eugenie.

zh: 像所有外省姑娘一样，她是个习惯早起的人，她早早起来，做了祷告，然后开始梳洗打扮——这是一件从今以后颇有意义的事情。她先把她那栗色的头发梳得光光的，然后仔仔细细地把粗大的辫子盘到头顶，不让散发掉出来，并使发式对称，这愈发烘托出她一脸的娇羞和纯真来，头饰的简洁与她面部线条的朴实配合得恰到好处。她一遍又一遍地在冷水中洗着她的手，那冷水使她的皮肤粗糙发红，她看着自己漂亮圆润的胳膊，心里纳闷，她的堂弟是怎么把他的双手弄得那么柔软洁白，怎么把指甲修剪得那么精致。　她穿上了新长筒袜和她最漂亮的鞋子。她把紧身胸衣束好，没有漏过一个扣眼。她生平第一次希望自己显得漂亮，她体会到了一件裁剪合身、使她亮丽迷人的新裙子所带来的乐趣。
en: An early riser, like all provincial girls, she was up betimes and said her prayers, and then began the business of dressing,—a business which henceforth was to have a meaning.First she brushed and smoothed her chestnut hair and twisted its heavy masses to the top of her head with the utmost care, preventing the loose tresses from straying, and giving to her head a symmetry which heightened the timid candor of her face; for the simplicity of these accessories accorded well with the innocent sincerity of its lines.As she washed her hands again and again in the cold water which hardened and reddened the skin, she looked at her handsome round arms and asked herself what her cousin did to make his hands so softly white, his nails so delicately curved.She put on new stockings and her prettiest shoes.She laced her corset straight, without skipping a single eyelet.And then, wishing for the first time in her life to appear to advantage, she felt the joy of having a new gown, well made, which rendered her attractive.

zh: 等她梳妆完毕，教区教堂的钟敲响报时了，令她惊讶的是，只敲了七下。她起得实在太早了，因为一心想有足够的时间来精心打扮。欧仁妮不懂得每个发卷可以反复整理并研究每种效果，她只是交叉着手臂，坐在窗前，看着院子、窄小的花园和花园上高高的梯状档土墙：一派视野封闭的凄凉景色，但也不无那种偏僻、荒芜之处所特有的神秘之美。厨房旁边是口井，周围有井栏，轱辘拴在一个弯曲的铁杆上，上面缠着一根葡萄藤，葡萄藤的枝叶在这个季节已干枯，发红，并枯萎掉了。弯弯曲曲的藤蔓从这里爬上了墙，攀附而上，顺着整幢屋子一直爬到了柴堆附近，柴堆的干柴放得像图书馆的书一样整整齐齐。院子的路面长着苔藓和杂草，而且无人走动，时间长了，路面就显得黑迹斑斑了。厚厚的围墙披着一层青苔，夹杂着波浪状的褐色枝条，院子尽头的八级石台阶通向花园门口，已残缺不全，掩埋于高大的植物之下，好似十字军时代一个寡妇埋葬骑士丈夫的坟茔。在长满苔藓、日渐碎裂的石基上是一排腐烂的木栅，因腐朽已坍塌了一半，上面乱七八糟地攀附缠绕着成簇的藤萝。栅门两边，两株矮小的苹果树伸出了弯曲的枝丫。花园里有三条并排的小路，铺着砾石，中间隔有方形花坛，周围种着黄杨，以防泥土流失，在花园尽头、老墙平台的下面是一片椴树。更远处的一头是树莓灌木丛，而靠近屋子的另一头，有一株高大的胡桃树，树枝几乎垂进了守财奴密室的窗子里。
en: As she finished her toilet the clock of the parish church struck the hour; to her astonishment, it was only seven.The desire of having plenty of time for dressing carefully had led her to get up too early.Ignorant of the art of retouching every curl and studying every effect, Eugenie simply crossed her arms, sat down by the window, and looked at the courtyard, the narrow garden, and the high terraced walls that over-topped it: a dismal, hedged-in prospect, yet not wholly devoid of those mysterious beauties which belong to solitary or uncultivated nature.Near the kitchen was a well surrounded by a curb, with a pulley fastened to a bent iron rod clasped by a vine whose leaves were withered, reddened, and shrivelled by the season.From thence the tortuous shoots straggled to the wall, clutched it, and ran the whole length of the house, ending near the wood-pile, where the logs were ranged with as much precision as the books in a library.The pavement of the courtyard showed the black stains produced in time by lichens, herbage, and the absence of all movement or friction.The thick walls wore a coating of green moss streaked with waving brown lines, and the eight stone steps at the bottom of the courtyard which led up to the gate of the garden were disjointed and hidden beneath tall plants, like the tomb of a knight buried by his widow in the days of the Crusades.Above a foundation of moss-grown, crumbling stones was a trellis of rotten wood, half fallen from decay; over them clambered and intertwined at will a mass of clustering creepers.On each side of the latticed gate stretched the crooked arms of two stunted apple-trees.Three parallel walks, gravelled and separated from each other by square beds, where the earth was held in by box-borders, made the garden, which terminated, beneath a terrace of the old walls, in a group of lindens.At the farther end were raspberry-bushes; at the other, near the house, an immense walnut-tree drooped its branches almost into the window of the miser’s sanctum.

zh: 夜间这些美丽的景物上、墙垣上和满院子的植物上都凝结上了白霜，由于天气晴朗，再加上卢瓦尔河畔的秋天常常阳光灿烂，那些白霜正开始融化。从这些不久前还觉得平淡无奇的景物中，欧仁妮发现了一种新的魅力。随着阳光在墙外渐渐照射开去，她的脑海中涌起了万千纷杂的思绪，越想越多。她感到一阵模糊而无法言说的愉悦感把精神包裹住了，就像云雾把物体包裹住一样。她的思绪与这奇特风景的点点滴滴相投相契，心中的和谐与自然界的和谐融成一片。在一个墙角，原产于南方地区的凤尾草垂下浓密的枝叶，闪动着鸽颈般千变万化的颜色，当阳光照到这里时，希望的天光便照亮了她眼中的未来。从此，她就喜欢盯着这堵墙看，看墙上苍白的花朵、蓝色的风信子和枯草，那其中交织着她的回忆，像童年的往事一样甜蜜。
en: A clear day and the beautiful autumnal sun common to the banks of the Loire was beginning to melt the hoar-frost which the night had laid on these picturesque objects, on the walls, and on the plants which swathed the courtyard.Eugenie found a novel charm in the aspect of things lately so insignificant to her.A thousand confused thoughts came to birth in her mind and grew there, as the sunbeams grew without along the wall.She felt that impulse of delight, vague, inexplicable, which wraps the moral being as a cloud wraps the physical body.Her thoughts were all in keeping with the details of this strange landscape, and the harmonies of her heart blended with the harmonies of nature.When the sun reached an angle of the wall where the “Venus-hair” of southern climes drooped its thick leaves, lit with the changing colors of a pigeon’s breast, celestial rays of hope illumined the future to her eyes, and thenceforth she loved to gaze upon that piece of wall, on its pale flowers, its blue harebells, its wilting herbage, with which she mingled memories as tender as those of childhood.

zh: 在这个有回声的院子里，每一片叶子从树枝上掉下时所发出的声响，都是在回答少女秘密的问询，她会整天呆在那里，感觉不到时光的飞逝。接着，她心里出现了一阵骚动不安。她不时地站起来，走到镜子前，看着自己，仿佛有良知的作家在审视自己的作品一样，内心批评着和责备着他自己的作品。
en: The noise made by each leaf as it fell from its twig in the void of that echoing court gave answer to the secret questionings of the young girl, who could have stayed there the livelong day without perceiving the flight of time.Then came tumultuous heavings of the soul.She rose often, went to her glass, and looked at herself, as an author in good faith looks at his work to criticise it and blame it in his own mind.

zh: “我不够漂亮，配不上他！”这就是欧仁妮的想法——一种自卑的念头，充满了痛苦。这可怜的姑娘对自己太不公平了，但是谦虚，说得更确切点，畏惧，可谓爱情的首要美德。欧仁妮属于那种身体结实的孩子，正如我们看到的阶层较低的资产阶级那样，他们的美似乎总是有点俗气。然而，尽管她的相貌像米洛岛的维纳斯，但她的形态却因基督徒更温婉的气质而显得高贵，让她女性的气质纯洁、脱俗，这种特性是古代的雕刻家们没有见识过的。她的头很大，额头像菲迪亚斯的丘比特雕像，有点男子气，却也清秀，灰色的眼睛炯炯有神，充分显示了她贞洁的生活。她的圆脸原本娇嫩红润，因天花而一度肿胀，尽管有幸没有留下痘瘢，却毁掉了皮肤天鹅绒般的质感。不过她的脸颊仍旧那么柔软细嫩，以致她母亲的亲吻都会在上面暂时留下红印。她的鼻子有点大，但同那朱红的嘴唇倒很相配，满是细纹的双唇充满着深情和善意。她的脖子是滚圆的。她胸部的曲线非常优美，遮得严严实实，却引人注目，令人想入非非。毫无疑问，它缺乏得体的服饰所能带来的那种优雅，但是在行家眼里，她刻板的身材自有其魅力。欧仁妮高大健壮，不具备一般人所喜欢的那种漂亮，可是她的美是一望而知的，只有艺术家才会真正为之倾倒。一个画家想在尘世寻找圣母玛利亚那样圣洁的典型，要找到拉斐尔描摹的女性那种不卑不亢的眼神，以及那种虽然往往出自构思的巧合，但却只有基督徒清心寡欲的生活才能培养或保持的处女的线条——这样一个醉心于完美理想的画家，会在欧仁妮的脸上发现那种连她本人都未曾发觉的天生的高贵；他会在那平静的眉宇之下看到一个爱情的世界；他会感觉到，在那眼睛的形状里，在那眼睑的低垂中，有着某种难以名状的东西，我们将其称之为神圣。
en: “I am not beautiful enough for him!”Such was Eugenie’s thought,—a humble thought, fertile in suffering.The poor girl did not do herself justice; but modesty, or rather fear, is among the first of love’s virtues.Eugenie belonged to the type of children with sturdy constitutions, such as we see among the lesser bourgeoisie, whose beauties always seem a little vulgar; and yet, though she resembled the Venus of Milo, the lines of her figure were ennobled by the softer Christian sentiment which purifies womanhood and gives it a distinction unknown to the sculptors of antiquity.She had an enormous head, with the masculine yet delicate forehead of the Jupiter of Phidias, and gray eyes, to which her chaste life, penetrating fully into them, carried a flood of light.The features of her round face, formerly fresh and rosy, were at one time swollen by the small-pox, which destroyed the velvet texture of the skin, though it kindly left no other traces, and her cheek was still so soft and delicate that her mother’s kiss made a momentary red mark upon it.Her nose was somewhat too thick, but it harmonized well with the vermilion mouth, whose lips, creased in many lines, were full of love and kindness.The throat was exquisitely round.The bust, well curved and carefully covered, attracted the eye and inspired reverie.It lacked, no doubt, the grace which a fitting dress can bestow; but to a connoisseur the non-flexibility of her figure had its own charm.Eugenie, tall and strongly made, had none of the prettiness which pleases the masses; but she was beautiful with a beauty which the spirit recognizes, and none but artists truly love.A painter seeking here below for a type of Mary’s celestial purity, searching womankind for those proud modest eyes which Raphael divined, for those virgin lines, often due to chances of conception, which the modesty of Christian life alone can bestow or keep unchanged,—such a painter, in love with his ideal, would have found in the face of Eugenie the innate nobleness that is ignorant of itself; he would have seen beneath the calmness of that brow a world of love; he would have felt, in the shape of the eyes, in the fall of the eyelids, the presence of the nameless something that we call divine.

zh: 她脸部的线条、她头部的轮廓，从未因快乐的表情而有所改变或露出倦容，就像平静的湖面在远方的天水相接处留下的线条一样柔和。那恬静而红润的面容，周边绕着光彩，宛若美丽绽放的花朵，使人心旷神怡、百看不厌，散发着精神折射的魅力。欧仁妮正站在人生的岸边，那里幼稚的幻想如花朵般盛开，采集雏菊占卜爱情时的喜悦之情不久将不复拥有。因此，她还不清楚爱情是什么，只是望着镜子里自己的形象，说道：
en: Her features, the contour of her head, which no expression of pleasure had ever altered or wearied, were like the lines of the horizon softly traced in the far distance across the tranquil lakes.That calm and rosy countenance, margined with light like a lovely full-blown flower, rested the mind, held the eye, and imparted the charm of the conscience that was there reflected.Eugenie was standing on the shore of life where young illusions flower, where daisies are gathered with delights ere long to be unknown; and thus she said, looking at her image in the glass, unconscious as yet of love:

zh: “我太丑了，他不会看上我的。”
en: “I am too ugly; he will not notice me.”

zh: 随后，她打开正对楼梯间的卧室的门，伸出脖子去听屋子里的动静。她听见了娜农早上的咳嗽声，这个好心人走来走去，打扫大厅，生火，拴狗，跟牛圈里的牲口说话。她心想：“他还没有起床。”欧仁妮立刻下楼，跑去找正在挤奶的娜农。
en: Then she opened the door of her chamber which led to the staircase, and stretched out her neck to listen for the household noises.“He is not up,” she thought, hearing Nanon’s morning cough as the good soul went and came, sweeping out the halls, lighting her fire, chaining the dog, and speaking to the beasts in the stable.Eugenie at once went down and ran to Nanon, who was milking the cow.

zh: “娜农，我的好娜农，给我堂弟的早餐弄点奶油吧。”
en: “Nanon, my good Nanon, make a little cream for my cousin’s breakfast.”

zh: “唉，小姐，昨天你就应该想到的，”娜农说着，大声笑了起来，“我可做不出奶油来。你堂弟真可爱，真可爱！哦，他太可爱了！你应该看看他穿着睡衣的样子，全是金线银线！我可是看见他了，真的！他穿的衬衣就跟神父先生的白祭袍一样细洁。”
en: “Why, mademoiselle, you should have thought of that yesterday,” said Nanon, bursting into a loud peal of laughter.“I can’t make cream.Your cousin is a darling, a darling! Oh, that he is!You should have seen him in his dressing-gown, all silk and gold!I saw him, I did!He wears linen as fine as the surplice of monsieur le cure.”

zh: “娜农，请给我们做个烤饼吧。”
en: “Nanon, please make us a @galette@.”

zh: “那谁给我烧炉子的柴火呢，还有做饼子的面粉和黄油？”娜农说道，作为葛朗台家的总管，她有时在欧仁妮和她母亲眼中倒是显得很了不起。“总不成偷老爷的东西来款待你的堂弟吧。你去问他要黄油、面粉，还有木柴：他是你父亲，也许会给你一些的。瞧！他现在正要来分配伙食呢。”
en: “And who’ll give me wood for the oven, and flour and butter for the cakes?” said Nanon, who in her function of prime-minister to Grandet assumed at times enormous importance in the eyes of Eugenie and her mother.“Mustn’t rob the master to feast the cousin.You ask him for butter and flour and wood: he’s your father, perhaps he’ll give you some.See! There he is now, coming to give out the provisions.”

zh: 听见楼梯在父亲的脚步下发出了颤动声，欧仁妮吓坏了，逃进了花园。幸福时，我们会以为——也许不无道理——我们的心思全刻在脑门上，所有人都能一眼看穿，这种处女纯洁的羞怯与特别的感觉产生的作用，欧仁妮已经体会到了。这可怜的姑娘第一次发觉到父亲的屋子太寒酸了，配不上堂弟的高雅，便觉得有些气恼。她觉得有必要为他做点什么——什么呢，她也不知道。她既天真又诚实，听凭自己纯洁的天性尽情发挥，而毫不怀疑她自己的印象或是感觉。一看见堂弟，女性那种自然的渴望就在她心中被唤醒了——那渴望可能会越来越强烈，因为她毕竟已经二十三岁了，正处于智力和欲望的高峰期。　她生平第一次在见到父亲时心里充满了恐惧感，从他身上，她明白了他是她命运的主人，她认为对他隐瞒某些心事是种罪过。她迈着急促的步子走着，很奇怪呼吸到的空气比平时更新鲜，感觉阳光使她的脉搏加速了，她从这暖意中吸取了一种精神上的温暖和一种新的生机。当她正盘算着用什么计策弄到饼子时，大个子娜农和葛朗台吵了起来——这种事跟冬天看见燕子一样稀罕。这位男主人拿着钥匙，来分配当天消费所需的食物。
en: Eugenie escaped into the garden, quite frightened as she heard the staircase shaking under her father’s step.Already she felt the effects of that virgin modesty and that special consciousness of happiness which lead us to fancy, not perhaps without reason, that our thoughts are graven on our foreheads and are open to the eyes of all.Perceiving for the first time the cold nakedness of her father’s house, the poor girl felt a sort of rage that she could not put it in harmony with her cousin’s elegance.She felt the need of doing something for him,—what, she did not know.Ingenuous and truthful, she followed her angelic nature without mistrusting her impressions or her feelings.The mere sight of her cousin had wakened within her the natural yearnings of a woman,—yearnings that were the more likely to develop ardently because, having reached her twenty-third year, she was in the plenitude of her intelligence and her desires.For the first time in her life her heart was full of terror at the sight of her father; in him she saw the master of the fate, and she fancied herself guilty of wrong-doing in hiding from his knowledge certain thoughts.She walked with hasty steps, surprised to breathe a purer air, to feel the sun’s rays quickening her pulses, to absorb from their heat a moral warmth and a new life.As she turned over in her mind some stratagem by which to get the cake, a quarrel—an event as rare as the sight of swallows in winter—broke out between la Grande Nanon and Grandet.Armed with his keys, the master had come to dole out provisions for the day’s consumption.

zh: “有没有昨天剩的面包？”他对娜农说。
en: “Is there any bread left from yesterday?” he said to Nanon.

zh: “连个渣都没有，先生。”
en: “Not a crumb, monsieur.”

zh: 葛朗台拿出一个大圆面包，面包撒满干面，放在一个安茹地区烤面包常用的平底篮里，他正要去切时，娜农对他说——
en: Grandet took a large round loaf, well floured and moulded in one of the flat baskets which they use for baking in Anjou, and was about to cut it, when Nanon said to him,—

zh: “今天咱们是五个人，先生。”
en: “We are five, today, monsieur.”

zh: “没错，”葛朗台说，“可你的面包有六磅重，会有富余的。而且，这些从巴黎来的年轻人不吃面包，你等着瞧吧。”
en: “That’s true,” said Grandet, “but your loaves weigh six pounds; there’ll be some left.Besides, these young fellows from Paris don’t eat bread, you’ll see.”

zh: “那他们一定吃抹酱了？”娜农说。
en: “Then they must eat @frippe@?” said Nanon.

zh: “抹酱”是安茹当地的用词，意思是搭配面包吃的东西，从最普通的抹酱——涂在面包上的黄油，到最高级的抹酱——桃酱，都包括在内。那些小时候舔光抹酱而剩下面包的人会懂得娜农那句话的意思。
en: @Frippe@ is a word of the local lexicon of Anjou, and means any accompaniment of bread, from butter which is spread upon it, the commonest kind of @frippe@, to peach preserve, the most distinguished of all the @frippes@; those who in their childhood have licked the @frippe@ and left the bread, will comprehend the meaning of Nanon’s speech.

zh: “不，”葛朗台答道，“他们既不吃面包，也不吃抹酱，他们有点儿像待嫁的姑娘。”
en: “No,” answered Grandet, “they eat neither bread nor @frippe@; they are something like marriageable girls.”

zh: 老头像平时一样，非常吝啬地拟定了当天的饭菜，然后锁好装食物的柜子，正要往果园走时，娜农拦住他说——
en: After ordering the meals for the day with his usual parsimony, the goodman, having locked the closets containing the supplies, was about to go towards the fruit-garden, when Nanon stopped him to say,—

zh: “先生，给我一些面粉和黄油吧，我要给孩子们做个烤饼。”
en: “Monsieur, give me a little flour and some butter, and I’ll make a @galette@ for the young ones.”

zh: “为了我侄儿，你要打劫我们家吗？”
en: “Are you going to pillage the house on account of my nephew?”

zh: “我为您侄儿操的心没有为您的狗操的心多，也不会比您费的心思多。瞧，还不是因为您只给了六块糖。我想要八块。”
en: “I wasn’t thinking any more of your nephew than I was of your dog,—not more than you think yourself; for, look here, you’ve only forked out six bits of sugar.I want eight.”

zh: “这都是怎么啦，娜农？我以前从来没见过你这个样子。你脑子里想什么呢？你是这里的女主人吗？你最多只能要六块糖。”
en: “What’s all this, Nanon?I have never seen you like this before.What have you got in your head?Are you the mistress here?You sha’n’t have more than six pieces of sugar.”

zh: “好吧，那您的侄儿怎么给咖啡放糖？”
en: “Well, then, how is your nephew to sweeten his coffee?”

zh: “放两块，我可以不要。”
en: “With two pieces; I’ll go without myself.”

zh: “您这个年纪不放糖！我宁愿自己掏钱给您买上一点儿。”
en: “Go without sugar at your age!I’d rather buy you some out of my own pocket.”

zh: “少管闲事。”
en: “Mind your own business.”

zh: 虽然糖价最近跌了，但在葛朗台眼里，糖仍然是最贵重的殖民地产品，对他来说，糖永远是六法郎一磅。帝政时期不得不节省用糖，这对他来说已成了根深蒂固的习惯。所有女人，即使是最愚蠢的，都知道如何巧用算计来达到她们的目，娜农撇开糖的问题来争取烤饼了。
en: In spite of the recent fall in prices, sugar was still in Grandet’s eyes the most valuable of all the colonial products; to him it was always six francs a pound.The necessity of economizing it, acquired under the Empire, had grown to be the most inveterate of his habits.All women, even the greatest ninnies, know how to dodge and dodge to get their ends; Nanon abandoned the sugar for the sake of getting the @galette@.

zh: “小姐！”她隔着窗子喊道，“你想要吃烤饼吗？”
en: “Mademoiselle!” she called through the window, “do you want some @galette@?”

zh: “不，不想。”欧仁妮回答。
en: “No, no,” answered Eugenie.

zh: “得啦，娜农，”葛朗台听到女儿的声音，说道，“给你。”他打开放面粉的柜子，给了她一杯面粉，往他已经切好的黄油上又添了几盎司。
en: “Come, Nanon,” said Grandet, hearing his daughter’s voice.“See here.”He opened the cupboard where the flour was kept, gave her a cupful, and added a few ounces of butter to the piece he had already cut off.

zh: “我需要柴火烧炉子。”得寸进尺的娜农说道。
en: “I shall want wood for the oven,” said the implacable Nanon.

zh: “好吧，你要多少就拿多少，”他伤心地答道，“不过要是那样，你得给我们做个果子馅饼，所有晚饭全都在炉子上做。这下你就不用生两个灶火了。”
en: “Well, take what you want,” he answered sadly, “but in that case you must make us a fruit-tart, and you’ll cook the whole dinner in the oven.In that way you won’t need two fires.”

zh: “天哪！”娜农叫道，“这您不用吩咐。”
en: “Goodness!” cried Nanon, “you needn’t tell me that.”

zh: 葛朗台用近乎慈父般的眼神看了他忠实的副手一眼。
en: Grandet cast a look that was well-nigh paternal upon his faithful deputy.

zh: “小姐，”等他转过了身，她大声喊道，“我们有烤饼吃了。”
en: “Mademoiselle,” she cried, when his back was turned, “we shall have the @galette@.”

zh: 葛朗台老头从园子里拿了水果回来，摆了满满一盘放在厨房的桌子上。
en: Pere Grandet returned from the garden with the fruit and arranged a plateful on the kitchen-table.

zh: “瞧瞧，先生，”娜农说，“您侄儿的靴子可真漂亮。多好的皮子！怎么闻起来这么香！我就纳闷了，他用什么擦的呢？我要不要用您的鸡蛋清调的鞋油给擦擦？”
en: “Just see, monsieur,” said Nanon, “what pretty boots your nephew has.What leather!Why it smells good!What does he clean it with, I wonder?Am I to put your egg-polish on it?”

zh: “娜农，我想鸡蛋会弄坏那种皮子的。告诉他，你不知道怎么擦黑摩洛哥羊皮，对，那是摩洛哥羊皮。他自己会到索米尔给你买回能擦亮那双靴子的油。我听说他们往黑色鞋油里掺上糖来叫它发亮。”
en: “Nanon, I think eggs would injure that kind of leather.Tell him you don’t know how to black morocco; yes, that’s morocco.He will get you something himself in Saumur to polish those boots with.I have heard that they put sugar into the blacking to make it shine.”

zh: “它们看上去真好，简直都能吃了，”这厨子把靴子放到她鼻子上，说道，“我的天哪！它们闻起来简直就跟太太的古龙香水一样。哦！太有趣了！”
en: “They look good to eat,” said the cook, putting the boots to her nose.“Bless me! If they don’t smell like madame’s eau-de-cologne.Ah! How funny!”

zh: “有趣！”她的主人说，“花在靴子上的钱比穿靴子的人的身价还要高，你觉得这有趣？”
en: “Funny!” said her master.“Do you call it funny to put more money into boots than the man who stands in them is worth?”

zh: “先生，”等葛朗台锁上果园，再次返回来时，她说，“您不准备每星期做一两次蔬菜牛肉汤来款待款待您的侄子吗？”
en: “Monsieur,” she said, when Grandet returned the second time, after locking the fruit-garden, “won’t you have the @pot-au-feu@ put on once or twice a week on account of your nephew?”
“Yes.”

zh: “那我就去肉铺了？”
en: “Am I to go to the butcher’s?”

zh: “当然不用。我们要做野鸡汤，佃户们会送来的。我会叫科努瓦耶打几只乌鸦，那东西做汤是最好不过了。”
en: “Certainly not.We will make the broth of fowls; the farmers will bring them.I shall tell Cornoiller to shoot some crows; they make the best soup in the world.”

zh: “真的吗，先生，那些乌鸦可是吃死人的呀？”
en: “Isn’t it true, monsieur, that crows eat the dead?”

zh: “你个蠢货，娜农。它们逮着什么吃什么，跟世上其他东西一样。我们不都是靠死人活着吗？什么叫遗产？”
en: “You are a fool, Nanon.They eat what they can get, like the rest of the world.Don’t we all live on the dead?What are legacies?”

zh: 葛朗台先生再没什么要吩咐的了，便掏出他的表来，看到离早饭还有半小时可以用，他就拿起帽子，走过去吻了一下女儿，对她说：
en: Monsieur Grandet, having no further orders to give, drew out his watch, and seeing that he had half an hour to dispose of before breakfast, he took his hat, went and kissed his daughter, and said to her:

zh: “你想不想到卢瓦尔河边的地里走走？我去那里有点事要办。”
en: “Do you want to come for a walk in the fields, down by the Loire?I have something to do there.”

zh: 欧仁妮拿上她那顶系有粉红缎带的草帽，然后父女俩沿着弯弯曲曲的街道往河岸走去。
en: Eugenie fetched her straw bonnet, lined with pink taffeta; then the father and daughter went down the winding street to the shore.

zh: “这么早你们去哪里呀？”克吕绍公证人碰到了他们，说道。
en: “Where are you going at this early hour?” said Cruchot, the notary, meeting them.

zh: “去办点事。”葛朗台回答道，他很清楚他的朋友为什么清早就出门。
en: “To see something,” answered Grandet, not duped by the matutinal appearance of his friend.

zh: 当葛朗台老头去“办点事”的时候，公证人凭经验知道跟着他准有好处，于是便走上前去。
en: When Pere Grandet went to “see something,” the notary knew by experience there was something to be got by going with him, so he went.

zh: “来吧，克吕绍，”葛朗台说，“您是我的一个朋友。我会让您看看在好地里种杨树是多么愚蠢。”
en: “Come, Cruchot,” said Grandet, “you are one of my friends.I’ll show you what folly it is to plant poplar-trees on good ground.”

zh: “您是说卢瓦尔河边草场的杨树让您赚了六万法郎很愚蠢？”克吕绍公证人说道，惊讶得睁大了眼睛，“您可真走运！就在南特缺白木的时节，您把树砍了，然后一棵三十法郎卖掉！”
en: “Do you call the sixty thousand francs that you pocketed for those that were in your fields down by the Loire, folly?” said Maitre Cruchot, opening his eyes with amazement.“What luck you have had!To cut down your trees at the very time they ran short of white-wood at Nantes, and to sell them at thirty francs!”

zh: 欧仁妮听着，不知道已走近自己一生当中最庄严的时刻，而公证人就要往她的头上加上一个至高无上的父母之命。葛朗台这时已来到卢瓦尔河畔他拥有的那片美丽的草原了，那里有三十个工人被雇来清理、填土和翻整以前种有杨树的地方。
en: Eugenie listened, without knowing that she approached the most solemn moment of her whole life, and that the notary was about to bring down upon her head a paternal and supreme sentence.Grandet had now reached the magnificent fields which he owned on the banks of the Loire, where thirty workmen were employed in clearing away, filling up, and levelling the spots formerly occupied by the poplars.

zh: “克吕绍公证人先生，看看这树曾经占了多大一块地！让，”他冲着一个工人喊道，“拿你的尺-尺-尺子，两-两边都量-量-量一下。”
en: “Maitre Cruchot, see how much ground this tree once took up! Jean,” he cried to a laborer, “m-m-measure with your r-r-rule, b-both ways.”

zh: “四乘八英尺。”那个人说。
en: “Four times eight feet,” said the man.

zh: “糟蹋了三十二英尺，”葛朗台对克吕绍说道，“我这一排有三百棵杨树，是不是？好，那么，三百-百-百乘三-三十二就让我-我-我损失了五百捆干-干-干草，加上两边的两倍，是一千五，中间几排更多。那我们就算-算-算它是一千捆-捆-捆干-干-干草吧——”
