en: “Thirty-two feet lost,” said Grandet to Cruchot.“I had three hundred poplars in this one line, isn’t that so?Well, then, three h-h-hundred times thir-thirty-two lost m-m-me five hundred in h-h-hay; add twice as much for the side rows,—fifteen hundred; the middle rows as much more.So we may c-c-call it a th-thousand b-b-bales of h-h-hay—”

zh: “很好，”克吕绍帮他的朋友算着，说道，“一千捆大概值六百法郎。”
en: “Very good,” said Cruchot, to help out his friend, “a thousand bales are worth about six hundred francs.”

zh: “算一-一千二百，因-因-因为再割一茬还能卖三、四百法郎。好，那么，就算-算-算一-一千二百法郎一年，四-四-四十年加利息，总-总-总共有——”
en: “Say t-t-twelve hundred, be-c-cause there’s three or four hundred francs on the second crop.Well, then, c-c-calculate that t-twelve hundred francs a year for f-f-forty years with interest c-c-comes to—”

zh: “大概六万法郎吧。”公证人说。
en: “Say sixty thousand francs,” said the notary.

zh: “很高兴，总-总-总共有-有-有六-六-六万。非常好，”葛朗台不结巴了，接着说道，“两千棵四十年的杨树只让我赚五万法郎。这就亏了。我自己也发现了这一点。”葛朗台说道，一副自命不凡的样子，“让，把树坑都填上，只留下河岸边的那些，把我买的杨树苗栽到那里。把树栽到那里，它们就会从政府那里吸取营养了。”他说着，转头看着克吕绍，鼻子上的肉瘤微微动了一下，流露出挖苦透顶的冷笑。
en: “I am willing; c-c-comes t-t-to sixty th-th-thousand. Very good,” continued Grandet, without stuttering, “two thousand poplars forty years old will only yield me fifty thousand francs.There’s a loss.I have found that myself,” said Grandet, getting on his high horse.“Jean, fill up all the holes except those at the bank of the river; there you are to plant the poplars I have bought.Plant ’em there, and they’ll get nourishment from the government,” he said, turning to Cruchot, and giving a slight motion to the wen on his nose, which expressed more than the most ironical of smiles.

zh: “的的确确，杨树只该种在贫瘠的土壤里。”克吕绍说道，他对葛朗台的算计大为惊诧。
en: “True enough; poplars should only be planted on poor soil,” said Cruchot, amazed at Grandet’s calculations.

zh: “是-是-是的，先生。”老头讥讽地答道。
en: “Y-y-yes, monsieur,” answered the old man satirically.

zh: 欧仁妮正在欣赏卢瓦尔河的美丽风景，没有注意到她父亲的盘算，可是当听到克吕绍说的话时，她马上侧耳倾听——
en: Eugenie, who was gazing at the sublime scenery of the Loire, and paying no attention to her father’s reckonings, presently turned an ear to the remarks of Cruchot when she heard him say,—

zh: “看来您好像是从巴黎招了个女婿。整个索米尔都在谈论您的侄儿。我马上得立婚约了吧，嘿！葛朗台老头？”
en: “So you have brought a son-in-law from Paris.All Saumur is talking about your nephew.I shall soon have the marriage-contract to draw up, hey!Pere Grandet?”

zh: “您起-起-起得这么早，就是来告-告-告诉我这些，”葛朗台说道，肉瘤也随之一起动了动，“好，老伙-伙-伙计，我就直说吧，把您想-想-想知道的都告-告-告给您。您看着吧，我宁可把-把-把我女儿扔进卢瓦尔河，也不会让-让-让她嫁给她的堂-堂-堂弟。这话您可以到处讲-讲-讲去——不，不用啦，让众人说-说-说去吧。”
en: “You g-g-got up very early to t-t-tell me that,” said Grandet, accompanying the remark with a motion of his wen.“Well, old c-c-comrade, I’ll be frank, and t-t-tell you what you want t-t-to know.I would rather, do you see, f-f-fling my daughter into the Loire than g-g-give her to her c-c-cousin.You may t-t-tell that everywhere,—no, never mind; let the world t-t-talk.”

zh: 这个回答让那个姑娘顿时头晕目眩，两眼发黑。她心头涌出的渺茫的希望突然间就开了花，像一团花一样变得真实而具体，她看着它们被割剪掉后凋落了一地。从前一天晚上开始，她已经寄情于夏尔，那种幸福使他们心心相通，但从此以后，苦难将会牢牢追随着他们。沉重的苦难要由她承担，幸运的光华与她无缘，这不就是女人崇高的命运吗？父爱怎么会在她父亲的心中荡然无存了呢？夏尔到底犯了什么罪呢？真是谜一样的问题！她刚刚萌发的爱情已经是个迷了，而且深不可测，如今又蒙上了一层神秘感。她往回走时，四肢发抖，当走到那阴暗的街道时，她呼吸到了岁月和世事印在那里的凄凉，不久前她还觉得那里喜气洋洋，现在她却伤感不已。爱情的教训一个也少不了。离家门还有几步时，她抢先走在父亲前面，在门槛等着他。但是葛朗台看见公证人手里的报纸，却突然停住，问道——
en: This answer dazzled and blinded the young girl with sudden light.The distant hopes upspringing in her heart bloomed suddenly, became real, tangible, like a cluster of flowers, and she saw them cut down and wilting on the earth.Since the previous evening she had attached herself to Charles by those links of happiness which bind soul to soul; from henceforth suffering was to rivet them.Is it not the noble destiny of women to be more moved by the dark solemnities of grief than by the splendors of fortune?How was it that fatherly feeling had died out of her father’s heart?Of what crime had Charles been guilty?Mysterious questions!Already her dawning love, a mystery so profound, was wrapping itself in mystery.She walked back trembling in all her limbs; and when she reached the gloomy street, lately so joyous to her, she felt its sadness, she breathed the melancholy which time and events had printed there.None of love’s lessons lacked.A few steps from their own door she went on before her father and waited at the threshold.But Grandet, who saw a newspaper in the notary’s hand, stopped short and asked,—

zh: “公债行情怎么样？”
en: “How are the Funds?”

zh: “您从来不听我的建议，葛朗台，”克吕绍答道，“快买吧，除了能拿一笔高额的利息，两年后你会赚百分之二十，——八万法郎零五十生丁的年息是五千。”
en: “You never listen to my advice, Grandet,” answered Cruchot.“Buy soon; you will still make twenty per cent in two years, besides getting an excellent rate of interest,—five thousand a year for eighty thousand francs fifty centimes.”

zh: “我们回头再说吧。”葛朗台一边答道，一边摸着他的下巴。
en: “We’ll see about that,” answered Grandet, rubbing his chin.

zh: “天哪！”公证人叫道。
en: “Good God!” exclaimed the notary.

zh: “哦，什么事？”葛朗台大声叫道，这时克吕绍已经把报纸放到了他的眼前，说道：
en: “Well, what?” cried Grandet; and at the same moment Cruchot put the newspaper under his eyes and said:

zh: “看看这个！”
en: “Read that!”

zh: “葛朗台先生，巴黎最受尊敬的商人之一，昨日循例前往交易所之后，用手枪击中脑部。他已将辞呈递交下议院议长，同时辞去商业法庭法官所兼各职。其破产实受其经纪人罗甘先生和公证人苏谢先生破产所连累。然而，以葛朗台先生享有的威望和信誉而论，本不难从其他商号获得必要资助。令人深感遗憾的是，这样一位德高望重的人士竟于一时绝望之中出此下策。”等等。
en: “Monsieur Grandet, one of the most respected merchants in Paris, blew his brains out yesterday, after making his usual appearance at the Bourse.He had sent his resignation to the president of the Chamber of Deputies, and had also resigned his functions as a judge of the commercial courts.The failures of Monsieur Roguin and Monsieur Souchet, his broker and his notary, had ruined him.The esteem felt for Monsieur Grandet and the credit he enjoyed were nevertheless such that he might have obtained the necessary assistance from other business houses.It is much to be regretted that so honorable a man should have yielded to momentary despair,” etc.

zh: “我早知道了。”老葡萄园主对公证人说。
en: “I knew it,” said the old wine-grower to the notary.

zh: 这句话让公证人克吕绍顿时不寒而栗，虽然当公证人都轻易不会动感情，但想到巴黎的葛朗台可能曾经向索米尔的葛朗台乞求支援几百万却遭到了拒绝时，他不由得感到一股凉气顺着后脊梁贯下去。
en: The words sent a chill of horror through Maitre Cruchot, who, notwithstanding his impassibility as a notary, felt the cold running down his spine as he thought that Grandet of Paris had possibly implored in vain the millions of Grandet of Saumur.

zh: “那他的儿子呢，昨天那么高兴——”
en: “And his son, so joyous yesterday—”

zh: “他还一无所知。”葛朗台答道，依旧很镇定。
en: “He knows nothing as yet,” answered Grandet, with the same composure.

zh: “再见！葛朗台先生。”克吕绍说，他现在已经明白了事情的原委，起身去给德蓬丰先生吃定心丸。
en: “Adieu! Monsieur Grandet,” said Cruchot, who now understood the state of the case, and went off to reassure Monsieur de Bonfons.

zh: 一进屋，葛朗台发现早餐已经准备好了。葛朗台太太坐在她那个带着小脚轮的椅子上，正织着冬天用的袖套。欧仁妮搂着她的脖子，吻着她，那番热烈的情绪往往是内心藏着悲痛才会有的。
en: On entering, Grandet found breakfast ready.Madame Grandet, round whose neck Eugenie had flung her arms, kissing her with the quick effusion of feeling often caused by secret grief, was already seated in her chair on castors, knitting sleeves for the coming winter.

zh: “你们可以开饭啦，”娜农说着，她从楼上下来，一步四个台阶，“那个年轻人睡得像个小娃娃。他两眼闭着，别提多可爱啦！我进去叫他了，但没反应。”
en: “You can begin to eat,” said Nanon, coming downstairs four steps at a time, “the young one is sleeping like a cherub.Isn’t he a darling with his eyes shut?I went in and I called him: no answer.”

zh: “让他睡吧，”葛朗台说，“他什么时候醒都来得及听坏消息的。”
en: “Let him sleep,” said Grandet, “he’ll wake soon enough to hear ill-tidings.”

zh: “什么事？”欧仁妮一边问着，一边把两小块不到半盎司重的糖放入她的咖啡，那是老吝啬鬼闲着没事时自娱自乐切好的。葛朗台太太不敢发问，只是盯着她的丈夫。
en: “What is it?” asked Eugenie, putting into her coffee the two little bits of sugar weighing less than half an ounce which the old miser amused himself by cutting up in his leisure hours.Madame Grandet, who did not dare to put the question, gazed at her husband.

zh: “他父亲开枪打穿了自己的脑袋。”
en: “His father has blown his brains out.”

zh: “我叔父？”欧仁妮说。
en: “My uncle?” said Eugenie.

zh: “可怜的年轻人！”葛朗台太太惊叫了起来。
en: “Poor young man!” exclaimed Madame Grandet.

zh: “确实可怜！”葛朗台说，“他身无分文！”
en: “Poor indeed!” said Grandet, “he isn’t worth a sou!”

zh: “嗯！可怜的孩子，他还睡得像是全世界的国王！”娜农柔声说道。
en: “Eh! Poor boy, and he’s sleeping like the king of the world!” said Nanon in a gentle voice.

zh: 欧仁妮停下来，不吃了。她的心揪紧了，就像一个姑娘初次面对爱人的苦难，溢满全身的痛惜之情会把她年轻的心揪得生疼。可怜的姑娘哭了。
en: Eugenie stopped eating.Her heart was wrung, as the young heart is wrung when pity for the suffering of one she loves overflows, for the first time, the whole being of a woman.The poor girl wept.

zh: “你哭什么呢？你又不认识你的叔父。”她父亲说着，用饿虎般的眼神瞪了她一眼，他瞪着他那成堆的金子时想必也是这个样子。
en: “What are you crying about? You didn’t know your uncle,” said her father, giving her one of those hungry tigerish looks he doubtless threw upon his piles of gold.

zh: “可是，先生，”娜农说，“谁不同情这个可怜的年轻人呢？他睡得像只木鞋一样沉，还不知道发生了什么事呢。”
en: “But, monsieur,” said Nanon, “who wouldn’t feel pity for the poor young man, sleeping there like a wooden shoe, without knowing what’s coming?”

zh: “我没跟你说话，娜农。闭嘴！”
en: “I didn’t speak to you, Nanon.Hold your tongue!”

zh: 欧仁妮那一刻才知道恋爱的女人必须隐瞒自己的感情。她不做声了。
en: Eugenie learned at that moment that the woman who loves must be able to hide her feelings.She did not answer.

zh: “葛朗台太太，在我回来之前，你什么也不要跟他说，”老头说，“我得去整整路边的那排树篱。我中午回来，正好是午餐时间，那时我会跟我侄儿谈谈他的事情。至于你，欧仁妮小姐，如果你是在为那个公子哥哭，那就到此为止，孩子。他马上要去印度。你再也不会看见他了。”
en: “You will say nothing to him about it, Ma’ame Grandet, till I return,” said the old man.“I have to go and straighten the line of my hedge along the highroad.I shall be back at noon, in time for the second breakfast, and then I will talk with my nephew about his affairs.As for you, Mademoiselle Eugenie, if it is for that dandy you are crying, that’s enough, child.He’s going off like a shot to the Indies.You will never see him again.”

zh: 父亲从他的帽子边拿起手套，像平时一样镇定自如地戴上，并交叉两手的手指抻了抻，把手套戴妥帖了，然后就出了门。
en: The father took his gloves from the brim of his hat, put them on with his usual composure, pushed them in place by shoving the fingers of both hands together, and went out.

zh: “妈妈，我要窒息了！”等就剩她和母亲时，欧仁妮大声叫道，“我从来没有这么难受过。”
en: “Mamma, I am suffocating!” cried Eugenie when she was alone with her mother, “I have never suffered like this.”

zh: 葛朗台太太看见她脸色发白，便打开窗子，让她呼吸新鲜空气。
en: Madame Grandet, seeing that she turned pale, opened the window and let her breathe fresh air.

zh: “我觉得好一些了！”过了一会儿，欧仁妮说道。
en: “I feel better!” said Eugenie after a moment.

zh: 女儿平素外表镇定冷静，现在居然如此紧张激动，这让葛朗台太太不安起来，她看着自己的女儿，凭着母亲天生惜子、心灵相通的直觉，她猜出了一切。事实上，匈牙利姐妹的生命只是因天生畸形而被束缚在一起，她们远不及欧仁妮和她母亲的关系亲密——她们总是一起坐在窗洞下，呼吸着同样的空气，睡在一起。
en: This nervous excitement in a nature hitherto, to all appearance, calm and cold, reacted on Madame Grandet; she looked at her daughter with the sympathetic intuition with which mothers are gifted for the objects of their tenderness, and guessed all.In truth the life of the Hungarian sisters, bound together by a freak of nature, could scarcely have been more intimate than that of Eugenie and her mother,—always together in the embrasure of that window, and sleeping together in the same atmosphere.

zh: “我可怜的孩子！”葛朗台太太说着，把欧仁妮的头揽住，并放在她的胸口。
en: “My poor child!” said Madame Grandet, taking Eugenie’s head and laying it upon her bosom.

zh: 听到这句话，年轻的姑娘抬起头打量着母亲，似乎想揣摩出她内心深处的想法。
en: At these words the young girl raised her head, questioned her mother by a look, and seemed to search out her inmost thought.

zh: “为什么送他到印度？”她说，“如果他遭遇不幸，他难道不应该和我们呆在一起吗？难道他不是我们最亲的亲人？”
en: “Why send him to the Indies?” she said.“If he is unhappy, ought he not to stay with us?Is he not our nearest relation?”

zh: “是的，我的孩子，这似乎是理所应当的，可你父亲有他自己的理由：我们必须尊重。”
en: “Yes, my child, it seems natural; but your father has his reasons: we must respect them.”

zh: 母女俩默默地坐下来，母亲坐在她垫高的椅子上，女儿坐在她的小扶手椅里，两个人都干起活来。欧仁妮非常感激母亲能完全理解自己的心意，她吻着母亲的手，说道——
en: The mother and daughter sat down in silence, the former upon her raised seat, the latter in her little armchair, and both took up their work.Swelling with gratitude for the full heart-understanding her mother had given her, Eugenie kissed the dear hand, saying,—

zh: “您真好，我的好妈妈！”
en: “How good you are, my kind mamma!”

zh: 这句话使母亲那张因太多的悲伤而憔悴枯槁的脸上有了光彩。
en: The words sent a glow of light into the motherly face, worn and blighted as it was by many sorrows.

zh: “您喜欢他吗？”欧仁妮问道。
en: “You like him?” asked Eugenie.

zh: 葛朗台太太只是报以微笑。接着，沉默了片刻之后，她低声说：
en: Madame Grandet only smiled in reply.Then, after a moment’s silence, she said in a low voice:

zh: “你已经爱上他了吗？那可不好。”
en: “Do you love him already?That is wrong.”

zh: “不好？”欧仁妮说，“为什么不好？您喜欢他，娜农喜欢他，为什么我就不能喜欢他？喂，妈妈，咱们摆好桌子，等他吃早饭吧。”
en: “Wrong?” said Eugenie.“Why is it wrong?You are pleased with him, Nanon is pleased with him; why should he not please me?Come, mamma, let us set the table for his breakfast.”

zh: 她放下自己手中的活，她母亲也跟着放下，说道：“傻孩子！”但她却和女儿一起犯傻，以此来支持女儿。欧仁妮喊了喊娜农。
en: She threw down her work, and her mother did the same, saying, “Foolish child!”But she sanctioned the child’s folly by sharing it.Eugenie called Nanon.

zh: “你现在要什么，小姐？”
en: “What do you want now, mademoiselle?”

zh: “娜农，到中午我们能吃上奶油吗？”
en: “Nanon, can we have cream by midday?”

zh: “啊！中午，当然可以。”老佣人回答道。
en: “Ah! Midday, to be sure you can,” answered the old servant.

zh: “那好，给他喝的咖啡要特别浓，我听德格拉桑先生说，他们在巴黎都把咖啡做得很浓。多放点。”
en: “Well, let him have his coffee very strong; I heard Monsieur des Grassins say that they make the coffee very strong in Paris.Put in a great deal.”

zh: “我去哪里弄去？”
en: “Where am I to get it?”

zh: “买一点儿。”
en: “Buy some.”

zh: “要是先生碰见我可怎么办？”
en: “Suppose monsieur meets me?”

zh: “他去地里了。”
en: “He has gone to his fields.”

zh: “那我就跑着去。可是昨天我买白蜡烛的时候，费萨尔先生问我，咱家是不是三王来朝了。咱们的一举一动，满城都知道。”
en: “I’ll run, then.But Monsieur Fessard asked me yesterday if the Magi had come to stay with us when I bought the wax candle.All the town will know our goings-on.”

zh: “要是让你父亲发现了，”葛朗台太太说，“他会打咱们的。”
en: “If your father finds it out,” said Madame Grandet, “he is capable of beating us.”

zh: “好啊，让他打吧，咱们就跪着让他打。”
en: “Well, let him beat us; we will take his blows on our knees.”

zh: 葛朗台回答的时候都抬着头望着天。娜农戴上头巾出去了。欧仁妮取出一块干净的桌布，又去拿回了几串葡萄，出于好玩儿，她曾经把葡萄挂在阁楼的一根绳子上，她轻轻地沿着走廊走着，生怕惊醒她的堂弟，却又忍不住贴着房门听他静静的呼吸声。
en: Madame Grandet for all answer raised her eyes to heaven.Nanon put on her hood and went off.Eugenie got out some clean table-linen, and went to fetch a few bunches of grapes which she had amused herself by hanging on a string across the attic; she walked softly along the corridor, so as not to waken her cousin, and she could not help listening at the door to his quiet breathing.

zh: “大祸临头，他还在睡觉。”她想。
en: “Sorrow is watching while he sleeps,” she thought.

zh: 她拿起最新鲜的葡萄叶，像个老道的管家一样，把葡萄果盘摆得十分精美，然后得意洋洋地放上了餐桌。她把父亲已经数好的梨拿来，用叶子搭配，堆成了一个金字塔。她走过来走过去，连跑带跳。她恨不得把父亲家里所有的东西都给摆出来，但可惜钥匙都在父亲的口袋里。娜农拿着两颗鲜鸡蛋回来了。看见鸡蛋，欧仁妮差一点儿要去搂她的脖子。
en: She took the freshest vine-leaves and arranged her dish of grapes as coquettishly as a practised house-keeper might have done, and placed it triumphantly on the table.She laid hands on the pears counted out by her father, and piled them in a pyramid mixed with leaves.She went and came, and skipped and ran.She would have liked to lay under contribution everything in her father’s house; but the keys were in his pocket.Nanon came back with two fresh eggs.At sight of them Eugenie almost hugged her round the neck.

zh: “从朗德来的佃户的篮子里有鲜鸡蛋。我跟他要，他就给了我，那可爱的人，一分没要，就为了讨好我！”
en: “The farmer from Lande had them in his basket.I asked him for them, and he gave them to me, the darling, for nothing, as an attention!”

zh: 第五章
en: Chapter V

zh: 精心准备了两个小时，欧仁妮终于做成了一份简单的午餐，虽然花钱并不多，但还是大大背离了家里根深蒂固的老规矩。在这两个小时里，她曾二十次放下活计跳起来，去看咖啡是否煮开了，或是去听堂弟穿衣打扮的动静。午餐总是站着吃的。每个人吃一片面包，一点儿水果或者一些黄油，还有一杯葡萄酒。桌子被拉到壁炉旁，扶手椅放在了堂弟的餐具前，桌上有两盘水果、一个蛋杯、一瓶白葡萄酒、面包，以及一个放满糖的碟子。欧仁妮望着这些，一想到父亲此时要是进来瞪着她的样子，她的四肢就开始哆嗦。她不时地望望时钟，看堂弟能否在这位主人回来之前吃完早餐。
en: After two hours’ thought and care, during which Eugenie jumped up twenty times from her work to see if the coffee were boiling, or to go and listen to the noise her cousin made in dressing, she succeeded in preparing a simple little breakfast, very inexpensive, but which, nevertheless, departed alarmingly from the inveterate customs of the house.The midday breakfast was always taken standing.Each took a slice of bread, a little fruit or some butter, and a glass of wine.As Eugenie looked at the table drawn up near the fire with an armchair placed before her cousin’s plate, at the two dishes of fruit, the egg-cup, the bottle of white wine, the bread, and the sugar heaped up in a saucer, she trembled in all her limbs at the mere thought of the look her father would give her if he should come in at that moment.She glanced often at the clock to see if her cousin could breakfast before the master’s return.

zh: “别担心，欧仁妮，如果你父亲进来，我来担当一切。”葛朗台太太说。
en: “Don’t be troubled, Eugenie; if your father comes in, I will take it all upon myself,” said Madame Grandet.

zh: 欧仁妮禁不住流下了眼泪。
en: Eugenie could not repress a tear.

zh: “哦，我的好妈妈！”她哭喊道，“我对您永远都爱不够。”
en: “Oh, my good mother!” she cried, “I have never loved you enough.”

zh: 夏尔小声哼着歌，在房内踱来踱去，过了一会儿才下来。还好，才十一点。真正的巴黎人！他竭尽所能打扮出公子哥的派头，仿佛他是呆在此时正在苏格兰旅游的那位贵妇家的城堡里。他走进屋子，带着微笑，彬彬有礼，同他焕发的青春十分相配，这让欧仁妮的心跳着，又悲又喜。他高高兴兴地走向他的伯母，早已把安茹豪门大宅的破灭看作一个玩笑。
en: Charles, who had been tramping about his room for some time, singing to himself, now came down.Happily, it was only eleven o’clock.The true Parisian! He had put as much dandyism into his dress as if he were in the chateau of the noble lady then travelling in Scotland.He came into the room with the smiling, courteous manner so becoming to youth, which made Eugenie’s heart beat with mournful joy.He had taken the destruction of his castles in Anjou as a joke, and came up to his aunt gaily.

zh: “您睡得好吗，亲爱的伯母？还有你，我的堂姐？”
en: “Have you slept well, dear aunt? And you, too, my cousin?”

zh: “非常好，先生，你呢？”葛朗台太太说道。
en: “Very well, monsieur, did you?” said Madame Grandet.

zh: “我？好极了。”
en: “I? Perfectly.”

zh: “你一定饿了，堂弟，”欧仁妮说，“坐下吧？”
en: “You must be hungry, cousin,” said Eugenie, “will you take your seat?”

zh: “中午前我从不吃早点，不到中午我从不起床的。不过，我一路上颠簸，很高兴马上能吃点什么。而且——”说着，他掏出布勒盖制造的精美绝伦的怀表，“哎哟！我起早了，才十一点！”
en: “I never breakfast before midday; I never get up till then.However, I fared so badly on the journey that I am glad to eat something at once.Besides—” here he pulled out the prettiest watch Breguet ever made.“Dear me!I am early, it is only eleven o’clock!”

zh: “早？”葛朗台太太说。
en: “Early?” said Madame Grandet.

zh: “是的，不过，我想整理一下我的东西。好吧，我将很高兴吃点什么——鸡呀，山鹑呀，随便什么都行。”
en: “Yes; but I wanted to put my things in order.Well, I shall be glad to have anything to eat,—anything, it doesn’t matter what, a chicken, a partridge.”

zh: “圣母玛利亚！”娜农无意中听到了这些话，惊叫道。
en: “Holy Virgin!” exclaimed Nanon, overhearing the words.

zh: “一只山鹑！”欧仁妮心里嘀咕着，她倒甘愿用她全部的那点儿私房钱买上一只山鹑。
en: “A partridge!” whispered Eugenie to herself; she would gladly have given the whole of her little hoard for a partridge.

zh: “来，坐下。”他伯母说道。
en: “Come and sit down,” said his aunt.

zh: 这位年轻的公子哥坐进靠椅里，就像一个美貌女子优雅地倚在沙发上一样。欧仁妮和她母亲拿了普通椅子坐在他旁边，挨着壁炉。
en: The young dandy let himself drop into an easy-chair, just as a pretty woman falls gracefully upon a sofa.Eugenie and her mother took ordinary chairs and sat beside him, near the fire.

zh: “你们一直住这里？”夏尔说道，觉得这屋子白天看着比昨晚更难看了。
en: “Do you always live here?” said Charles, thinking the room uglier by daylight than it had seemed the night before.

zh: “一直住在这里，”欧仁妮看着他，回答道，“除了葡萄收获的季节。那时我们去帮娜农，住在努瓦耶修道院。”
en: “Always,” answered Eugenie, looking at him, “except during the vintage.Then we go and help Nanon, and live at the Abbaye des Noyers.”

zh: “你们从不散步吗？”
en: “Don’t you ever take walks?”

zh: “有时候星期天做完晚祷，若是天气晴朗，”葛朗台太太说道，“我们会到桥上走走，或者去看看割草。”
en: “Sometimes on Sunday after vespers, when the weather is fine,” said Madame Grandet, “we walk on the bridge, or we go and watch the haymakers.”

zh: “你们这里有剧院吗？”
en: “Have you a theatre?”

zh: “去剧院！”葛朗台太太惊呼道，“看剧！哎哟，先生，你不知道那是不可饶恕的罪孽吗？”
en: “Go to the theatre!” exclaimed Madame Grandet, “see a play!Why, monsieur, don’t you know it is a mortal sin?”

zh: “喂，先生，”娜农拿进来鸡蛋，说道，“这是给您的鸡——带壳儿的。”
en: “See here, monsieur,” said Nanon, bringing in the eggs, “here are your chickens,—in the shell.”

zh: “哦！新鲜的鸡蛋。”夏尔说道，像所有惯于奢侈的人一样，他早就把他的山鹑忘了，“那可好吃了，现在，我的好姑娘，你能不能给我些黄油。”
en: “Oh! Fresh eggs,” said Charles, who, like all people accustomed to luxury, had already forgotten about his partridge, “that is delicious: now, if you will give me the butter, my good girl.”

zh: “黄油！那你就吃不上烤饼了。”
en: “Butter! Then you can’t have the @galette@.”

zh: “娜农，拿黄油来。”欧仁妮大声喊道。
en: “Nanon, bring the butter,” cried Eugenie.

zh: 在堂弟切面包片的时候，年轻的姑娘瞧着他，看得津津有味，就像一个女工看一出无辜纯洁的人最终得胜的传奇剧一样。夏尔曾得到风度迷人的母亲的调教，受过一位时髦女子的提携和熏陶，有着花花公子那些雅致、娇媚、矫揉造作的形容举止。少女的同情与温柔所具有的力量实际上如磁石一般，以至于夏尔在发现自己成了伯母和堂姐关注的对象时，无法逃避那感情的冲击，那些感情向他汹涌而来的，可以说，是将他淹没的。他向欧仁妮投去灿烂、爱抚的目光，充满善意——那目光似乎本身就是一种微笑。当他的目光停留在她的身上时，他察觉到她那纯洁的脸上，线条和谐到极致，她天真无邪的神态是那么优雅，那双眼睛清澈而有魅力，闪烁着青春洋溢的爱情，不由自主地流露出内心的渴望来。
en: The young girl watched her cousin as he cut his sippets, with as much pleasure as a grisette takes in a melodrama where innocence and virtue triumph.Charles, brought up by a charming mother, improved, and trained by a woman of fashion, had the elegant, dainty, foppish movements of a coxcomb.The compassionate sympathy and tenderness of a young girl possess a power that is actually magnetic, so that Charles, finding himself the object of the attentions of his aunt and cousin, could not escape the influence of feelings which flowed towards him, as it were, and inundated him.He gave Eugenie a bright, caressing look full of kindness,—a look which seemed itself a smile.He perceived, as his eyes lingered upon her, the exquisite harmony of features in the pure face, the grace of her innocent attitude, the magic clearness of the eyes, where young love sparkled and desire shone unconsciously.

zh: “啊！我亲爱的堂姐，如果你穿着盛装出现在歌剧院里，我敢向你保证，我伯母的话将会变成事实——你会让男人艳羡，让女人嫉妒，全得犯不可饶恕的罪孽。”
en: “Ah! My dear cousin, if you were in full dress at the Opera, I assure you my aunt’s words would come true,—you would make the men commit the mortal sin of envy, and the women the sin of jealousy.”

zh: 这番恭维打动了欧仁妮的心，并让它跳个不停，尽管她没有听懂意思。
en: The compliment went to Eugenie’s heart and set it beating, though she did not understand its meaning.

zh: “哦！堂弟，”她说，“你是在笑话一个可怜的乡下丫头吧。”
en: “Oh! Cousin,” she said, “you are laughing at a poor little country girl.”

zh: “堂姐，你要是了解我，就知道我讨厌嘲弄人，它使人心寒，伤害我所有的感情。”说着，他非常优雅地咽下了一块涂着黄油的面包，“不，我的确没有足够的头脑来取笑别人，毫无疑问，这是个大缺陷。在巴黎，当他们想诋毁一个人时，就说：‘他心地善良’。这话的意思是：‘这可怜的家伙笨得像头犀牛’。可是因为我有钱，而且谁都知道，即使是在野外，我都能用任何型号的手枪在三十步开外打中靶心，没人敢取笑我。”
en: “If you knew me, my cousin, you would know that I abhor ridicule; it withers the heart and jars upon all my feelings.”Here he swallowed his buttered sippet very gracefully.“No, I really have not enough mind to make fun of others; and doubtless it is a great defect.In Paris, when they want to disparage a man, they say: ‘He has a good heart.’ The phrase means: ‘The poor fellow is as stupid as a rhinoceros.’ But as I am rich, and known to hit the bull’s-eye at thirty paces with any kind of pistol, and even in the open fields, ridicule respects me.”

zh: “我亲爱的侄子，那证明你的心好。”
en: “My dear nephew, that bespeaks a good heart.”

zh: “你的戒指真漂亮，”欧仁妮说，“给我瞧瞧不碍事吧？”
en: “You have a very pretty ring,” said Eugenie, “is there any harm in asking to see it?”

zh: 夏尔摘下戒指后，伸出手，欧仁妮的指尖碰到了堂弟粉红色的指甲，她的脸红了。
en: Charles held out his hand after loosening the ring, and Eugenie blushed as she touched the pink nails of her cousin with the tips of her fingers.

zh: “看呀，妈妈，多美的做工。”
en: “See, mamma, what beautiful workmanship.”

zh: “哦！得好多金子啊！”娜农端了咖啡进来，说道。
en: “My! There’s a lot of gold!” said Nanon, bringing in the coffee.

zh: “那是什么？”夏尔指着一个长椭圆形的褐色陶壶，笑着叫道。那陶壶里层上了釉，边上有一圈灰土，咖啡渣在煮开的水里冒着泡翻上来，又沉下去。
en: “What is that?” exclaimed Charles, laughing, as he pointed to an oblong pot of brown earthenware, glazed on the inside, and edged with a fringe of ashes, from the bottom of which the coffee-grounds were bubbling up and falling in the boiling liquid.

zh: “这是煮好的咖啡。”娜农说。
en: “It is boiled coffee,” said Nanon.

zh: “啊！我亲爱的伯母，我来这里无论如何得做点好事留个纪念。你们真是太落伍了！我得教你们用双层咖啡壶来煮出优质的咖啡。”
en: “Ah! My dear aunt, I shall at least leave one beneficent trace of my visit here.You are indeed behind the age!I must teach you to make good coffee in a Chaptal coffee-pot.”

zh: 他尽力讲解了双层咖啡壶的用法。
en: He tried to explain the process of a Chaptal coffee-pot.

zh: “老天！如果有那么多事要做，”娜农说道，“我们得花一辈子才能煮好咖啡吧。我才不会那样煮咖啡呢，我可知道那回事！唉，我煮咖啡的时候，谁给牛弄草料呀？”
en: “Gracious! If there are so many things as all that to do,” said Nanon, “we may as well give up our lives to it.I shall never make coffee that way; I know that!Pray, who is to get the fodder for the cow while I make the coffee?”

zh: “我来。”欧仁妮说。
en: “I will make it,” said Eugenie.

zh: “孩子！”葛朗台太太看着女儿，说道。
en: “Child!” said Madame Grandet, looking at her daughter.

zh: 这句话让三个女人想起了这个不幸的年轻人即将大祸临头，她们沉默了，带着怜悯的神情看着他，这引起了他的注意。
en: The word recalled to their minds the sorrow that was about to fall upon the unfortunate young man; the three women were silent, and looked at him with an air of commiseration that caught his attention.

zh: “什么事，堂姐？”他说。
en: “Is anything the matter, my cousin?” he said.

zh: “嘘！”欧仁妮正要回答，葛朗台太太冲她说道，“你知道的，女儿，你父亲叫我们不要跟先生说——”
en: “Hush!” said Madame Grandet to Eugenie, who was about to answer, “you know, my daughter, that your father charged us not to speak to monsieur—”

zh: “叫夏尔。”年轻的葛朗台说。
en: “Say Charles,” said young Grandet.

zh: “啊！你叫夏尔？多美的名字！”欧仁妮叫了起来。
en: “Ah! You are called Charles?What a beautiful name!” cried Eugenie.

zh: 对祸事的预感差不多总是会应验的。娜农、葛朗台太太和欧仁妮三个人一直战战兢兢地想着老头要回来，偏偏这时就听到了他们非常熟悉的敲门声。
en: Presentiments of evil are almost always justified.At this moment Nanon, Madame Grandet, and Eugenie, who had all three been thinking with a shudder of the old man’s return, heard the knock whose echoes they knew but too well.

zh: “是爸爸！”欧仁妮说。
en: “There’s papa!” said Eugenie.

zh: 她拿走了盛满糖的碟子，只在桌布上留了几块；娜农撤走了蛋杯；葛朗台太太像受惊的兔子一样站了起来。明显是一片慌乱，这让夏尔觉得很诧异，弄得他一头雾水。
en: She removed the saucer filled with sugar, leaving a few pieces on the table-cloth; Nanon carried off the egg-cup; Madame Grandet sat up like a frightened hare.It was evidently a panic, which amazed Charles, who was wholly unable to understand it.

zh: “嗨！怎么啦？”他问道。
en: “Why! What is the matter?” he asked.

zh: “我父亲回来了。”欧仁妮答道。
en: “My father has come,” answered Eugenie.

zh: “嗯，那又怎样？”
en: “Well, what of that?”

zh: 葛朗台先生进了屋子，用锐利的目光扫了眼桌子，又看了看夏尔，就明白了是怎么回事。
en: Monsieur Grandet entered the room, threw his keen eye upon the table, upon Charles, and saw the whole thing.

zh: “哈！哈！这么说你是在设宴招待你侄儿呢，非常好，非常好，的确非常好！”他说道，一点儿也不结巴，“猫不在，老鼠玩儿得自在。”
en: “Ha! Ha! So you have been making a feast for your nephew; very good, very good, very good indeed!” he said, without stuttering.“When the cat’s away, the mice will play.”

zh: “设宴！”夏尔心想，猜不出，也想象不出这家人的规矩和习惯。
en: “Feast!” thought Charles, incapable of suspecting or imagining the rules and customs of the household.

zh: “拿我的杯子来，娜农。”这位主人说道。
en: “Give me my glass, Nanon,” said the master.

zh: 欧仁妮拿来了酒杯。葛朗台从马裤口袋里掏出一把宽刃牛角刀，切了片面包，取了点黄油，仔细地抹在了面包上，站着吃了起来。这时，夏尔正往自己的咖啡里放糖。葛朗台老头看到糖块，瞪了眼脸色发白的妻子，朝前走了三步，俯下身凑到那可怜的女人耳边，说道——
en: Eugenie brought the glass.Grandet drew a horn-handled knife with a big blade from his breeches’ pocket, cut a slice of bread, took a small bit of butter, spread it carefully on the bread, and ate it standing.At this moment Charlie was sweetening his coffee.Pere Grandet saw the bits of sugar, looked at his wife, who turned pale, and made three steps forward; he leaned down to the poor woman’s ear and said,—

zh: “你从哪里弄来的糖？”
en: “Where did you get all that sugar?”

zh: “娜农从费萨尔铺子买来的，家里没有了。”
en: “Nanon fetched it from Fessard’s; there was none.”

zh: 简直无法想象这三个女人对这无声的一幕是多么担心。娜农离开厨房，站着往屋里张望，看会发生什么事。夏尔尝了尝他的咖啡，觉得苦，就瞅来瞅去找糖，而葛朗台早已把糖收了起来。
en: It is impossible to picture the profound interest the three women took in this mute scene.Nanon had left her kitchen and stood looking into the room to see what would happen.Charles, having tasted his coffee, found it bitter and glanced about for the sugar, which Grandet had already put away.

zh: “你想要什么？”他伯父问。
en: “What do you want?” said his uncle.
“The sugar.”

zh: “再多加些奶，”这位一家之主答道，“咖啡喝着就不苦了。”
en: “Put in more milk,” answered the master of the house, “your coffee will taste sweeter.”

zh: 欧仁妮把葛朗台收拾走的碟子又放到桌子上，她一边放，一边镇定地看着她的父亲。的的确确，巴黎女人用娇弱的双臂抓住丝绸结成的绳梯来帮助情人逃走时，她显示的勇气也未必胜得过欧仁妮把糖重新放上桌子时的勇气。当她骄傲地给情人看她那带伤的玉臂时，她的情人会报答这个情妇，用眼泪和亲吻来清洗每一道肿起的血管，直到伤痛因幸福而被治愈。可是，堂姐内心正焦虑万分、痛苦至极，在那个老吝啬鬼的逼视下，更是忧心如焚，这个秘密夏尔永远也不会知道。
en: Eugenie took the saucer which Grandet had put away and placed it on the table, looking calmly at her father as she did so.Most assuredly, the Parisian woman who held a silken ladder with her feeble arms to facilitate the flight of her lover, showed no greater courage than Eugenie displayed when she replaced the sugar upon the table.The lover rewarded his mistress when she proudly showed him her beautiful bruised arm, and bathed every swollen vein with tears and kisses till it was cured with happiness.Charles, on the other hand, never so much as knew the secret of the cruel agitation that shook and bruised the heart of his cousin, crushed as it was by the look of the old miser.

zh: “你不吃午饭，太太。”
en: “You are not eating your breakfast, wife.”

zh: 那可怜的女奴一副恭顺的样子走上前来，给自己切了块面包，又拿了一个梨。欧仁妮大着胆子给父亲递了些葡萄，说——
en: The poor helot came forward with a piteous look, cut herself a piece of bread, and took a pear.Eugenie boldly offered her father some grapes, saying,—

zh: “尝尝我存的葡萄，爸爸。堂弟，你也来点儿，好不好？这些葡萄不错，我特地给你摘的。”
en: “Taste my preserves, papa.My cousin, you will eat some, will you not?I went to get these pretty grapes expressly for you.”

zh: “要是没人拦着，她们会为了你，洗劫索米尔城的，侄儿。等你吃完了，我们到花园去，我有事要告诉你，那可不是甜的。”
en: “If no one stops them, they will pillage Saumur for you, nephew.When you have finished, we will go into the garden; I have something to tell you which can’t be sweetened.”

zh: 欧仁妮和母亲瞅了夏尔一眼，那意思这个年轻人是不会弄错的。
en: Eugenie and her mother cast a look on Charles whose meaning the young man could not mistake.

zh: “您的话是什么意思，伯父？自从我可怜的母亲去世以后，”——说到这几个词时，他的声音软了下来——“其他任何不幸都不会让我难过了。”
en: “What is it you mean, uncle?Since the death of my poor mother”—at these words his voice softened—“no other sorrow can touch me.”

zh: “侄儿，谁知道上帝喜欢让咱们遭什么罪呢？”他的伯母说道。
en: “My nephew, who knows by what afflictions God is pleased to try us?” said his aunt.

zh: “得，得，得，得，”葛朗台说，“又开始胡说八道了。看到你这双白白的手，我真难受，侄儿，”说着，他伸出老天爷安在他手臂尽头的拳头，那拳头像羊肩膀似的，“这是双生来抓银子的手。你从小受的教育，是把我们用来做钱包的小山羊皮穿在脚上。这事可太糟糕了！很糟糕！”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta,” said Grandet, “there’s your nonsense beginning.I am sorry to see those white hands of yours, nephew,” and he showed the shoulder-of-mutton fists which Nature had put at the end of his own arms.“There’s a pair of hands made to pick up silver pieces.You’ve been brought up to put your feet in the kid out of which we make the purses we keep our money in.A bad lookout!Very bad!”

zh: “您想说什么，伯父？您说的话，我要是能听懂哪怕一个字，就不得好死。”
en: “What do you mean, uncle?I’ll be hanged if I understand a single word of what you are saying.”

zh: “来吧！”葛朗台说。
en: “Come!” said Grandet.

zh: 这个守财奴啪嗒一声合上刀，把最后一点儿酒喝掉，然后开了门。
en: The miser closed the blade of his knife with a snap, drank the last of his wine, and opened the door.

zh: “堂弟，勇敢点！”
en: “My cousin, take courage!”

zh: 年轻姑娘的语气让夏尔的心感到惊恐，他跟在他那可怕的伯父后面，忐忑不安。欧仁妮、她母亲和娜农去了厨房，按捺不住好奇心，想看看在花园即将上演的那场戏中的两位演员。花园里，一开始，伯父只是默不作声地走在侄子的前面。对夏尔说出他父亲的死讯，葛朗台并不觉得怎么为难，但知道夏尔已经不名一文，他倒生出了几分同情，于是他就寻思着用什么话或者措辞可以把那残酷的事实讲得和缓一些。“你已经失去你的父亲了”，这话对他来说好像没什么大不了的，父亲总是死在孩子的前面。可是“你一点儿家产都没有了”——人世间所有的不幸都概括在这几个词当中了！葛朗台绕着花园走了三圈，砂石在他沉重的脚步下咯咯作响。
en: The tone of the young girl struck terror to Charles’s heart, and he followed his terrible uncle, a prey to disquieting thoughts.Eugenie, her mother, and Nanon went into the kitchen, moved by irresistible curiosity to watch the two actors in the scene which was about to take place in the garden, where at first the uncle walked silently ahead of the nephew.Grandet was not at all troubled at having to tell Charles of the death of his father; but he did feel a sort of compassion in knowing him to be without a penny, and he sought for some phrase or formula by which to soften the communication of that cruel truth.“You have lost your father,” seemed to him a mere nothing to say; fathers die before their children.But “you are absolutely without means,”—all the misfortunes of life were summed up in those words!Grandet walked round the garden three times, the gravel crunching under his heavy step.

zh: 在人生的关键时刻，我们的心总是会对大喜大悲降临的地方念念不忘。夏尔特别细心地注意到小花园的黄杨、那飘然坠落的黄叶、那剥落的墙壁、那奇形怪状的果树——由于强烈的情感会产生特有的记忆功能，这些如画般的细节将永远留在他的记忆深处，和对这个重大时刻的种种回忆交织在一起。
en: In the crucial moments of life our minds fasten upon the locality where joys or sorrows overwhelm us.Charles noticed with minute attention the box-borders of the little garden, the yellow leaves as they fluttered down, the dilapidated walls, the gnarled fruit-trees,—picturesque details which were destined to remain forever in his memory, blending eternally, by the mnemonics that belong exclusively to the passions, with the recollections of this solemn hour.

zh: “天气真好，非常暖和。”葛朗台说着，深深吸了一口气。
en: “It is very fine weather, very warm,” said Grandet, drawing a long breath.

zh: “是的，伯父，可为什么——”
en: “Yes, uncle; but why—”

zh: “好吧，我的孩子，”他的伯父答道，“我有个坏消息要告诉你。你父亲病了——”
en: “Well, my lad,” answered his uncle, “I have some bad news to give you.Your father is ill—”

zh: “那我还在这里干嘛？”夏尔说。“娜农，”他喊道，“订驿站的马！我总该能从哪里弄到一辆马车吧？”他又说着，转向他那站着一动不动的伯父。
en: “Then why am I here?” said Charles.“Nanon,” he cried, “order post-horses!I can get a carriage somewhere?”he added, turning to his uncle, who stood motionless.

zh: “马和车都没用，”葛朗台答道，他看着夏尔，夏尔一言不发，两眼发了呆，“是的，我可怜的孩子，你猜对了——他死了。但那并不算什么，更糟糕的是：他用枪打穿了自己的脑袋。”
en: “Horses and carriages are useless,” answered Grandet, looking at Charles, who remained silent, his eyes growing fixed.“Yes, my poor boy, you guess the truth,—he is dead.But that’s nothing; there is something worse: he blew out his brains.”

zh: “我的父亲呀！”
en: “My father!”

zh: “是啊，可这还不算最糟糕的，报纸上都在说这件事。给，看看吧。”
en: “Yes, but that’s not the worst; the newspapers are all talking about it.Here, read that.”

zh: 葛朗台跟克吕绍借来了那篇要命的文章，他把报纸戳到侄子眼前。那可怜的年轻人还是个孩子，这个年纪还不懂得掩饰感情，他顿时大哭起来。
en: Grandet, who had borrowed the fatal article from Cruchot, thrust the paper under his nephew’s eyes.The poor young man, still a child, still at an age when feelings wear no mask, burst into tears.

zh: “这下好啦！”葛朗台心想，“他的两眼真叫我害怕。哭了他就会好的——这还不算最坏的，我可怜的侄儿，”不管夏尔是否在听，他高声说道，“不要紧，你会挺过去的：但是——”
en: “That’s good!” thought Grandet, “his eyes frightened me.He’ll be all right if he weeps,—that is not the worst, my poor nephew,” he said aloud, not noticing whether Charles heard him, “that is nothing; you will get over it: but—”

zh: “永远不会，永远不会！我的父亲！哦，我的父亲！”
en: “Never, never!My father!Oh, my father!”

zh: “他毁了你，你一个子儿也没了。”
en: “He has ruined you, you haven’t a penny.”

zh: “那有什么关系？我的父亲呀！我的父亲在哪里？”
en: “What does that matter?My father!Where is my father?”

zh: 他的抽泣在那沉闷的院墙内骇人地回荡起来，回音不绝。那三个女人心中充满了怜悯，也哭了，因为哭经常跟笑一样是会传染的。夏尔没有继续听他的伯父说下去，从院子里跑过去，跑到了楼上自己的卧室里。他扑到床上，把脸埋进被单里，躲开众人，为失去的双亲痛哭起来。
en: His sobs resounded horribly against those dreary walls and reverberated in the echoes.The three women, filled with pity, wept also; for tears are often as contagious as laughter.Charles, without listening further to his uncle, ran through the court and up the staircase to his chamber, where he threw himself across the bed and hid his face in the sheets, to weep in peace for his lost parents.

zh: “第一次突如其来的灾难必须要告诉他，”葛朗台说着，进了客厅，欧仁妮和她母亲刚匆匆回到各自的座位，擦了眼泪，用颤抖的双手做着缝补，“可那个年轻人真没出息，他把死人看得比他的钱还重。”
en: “The first burst must have its way,” said Grandet, entering the living-room, where Eugenie and her mother had hastily resumed their seats and were sewing with trembling hands, after wiping their eyes.“But that young man is good for nothing; his head is more taken up with the dead than with his money.”

zh: 当听到父亲对最神圣的悲痛之情说出这样的话来，欧仁妮打了个寒颤。从那一刻起，她开始评判起他来。夏尔的抽噎尽管低沉，仍然在这阴沉的房子里回荡着，他沉痛的哀嚎仿佛来自于地下，慢慢变弱，到傍晚时才停息。
en: Eugenie shuddered as she heard her father’s comment on the most sacred of all griefs.From that moment she began to judge him.Charles’s sobs, though muffled, still sounded through the sepulchral house; and his deep groans, which seemed to come from the earth beneath, only ceased towards evening, after growing gradually feebler.

zh: “可怜的年轻人！”葛朗台太太说。
en: “Poor young man!” said Madame Grandet.

zh: 这感叹简直要命！葛朗台老头看看妻子，又看看欧仁妮和糖碗。他想起了为这个倒霉的年轻人准备的那顿丰盛的午餐，便走到屋子中间。
en: Fatal exclamation!Pere Grandet looked at his wife, at Eugenie, and at the sugar-bowl.He recollected the extraordinary breakfast prepared for the unfortunate youth, and he took a position in the middle of the room.

zh: “听我说，”他保持着往常的镇定，说道，“葛朗台太太，我希望你以后不要再这么铺张了。我把我的钱给你，可不是为了给那个年轻人买糖吃的。”
en: “Listen to me,” he said, with his usual composure.“I hope that you will not continue this extravagance, Madame Grandet.I don’t give you MY money to stuff that young fellow with sugar.”

zh: “那不关我母亲的事，”欧仁妮说，“是我——”
en: “My mother had nothing to do with it,” said Eugenie, “it was I who—”

zh: “是因为你长大了，”葛朗台打断女儿的话，说道，“就想跟我作对？记着，欧仁妮——”
en: “Is it because you are of age,” said Grandet, interrupting his daughter, “that you choose to contradict me?Remember, Eugenie—”

zh: “父亲，您兄弟的儿子应该从我们这里得到——”
en: “Father, the son of your brother ought to receive from us—”

zh: “得，得，得，得！”箍桶匠用四个半音阶喊道，“又是我兄弟的儿子，又是我侄儿的！夏尔跟我们毫不相干，他一个子儿没有，他父亲破产了。等这个公子哥哭够了，他就得从这里滚蛋。我可不能让他把我的家搅得天翻地覆的。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta!” exclaimed the cooper on four chromatic tones, “the son of my brother this, my nephew that!Charles is nothing at all to us; he hasn’t a farthing, his father has failed; and when this dandy has cried his fill, off he goes from here.I won’t have him revolutionize my household.”

zh: “什么是‘破产’，父亲？”欧仁妮问道。
en: “What is ‘failing,’ father?” asked Eugenie.

zh: “破产，”她父亲回答道，“就是干了最可耻的事，让人丢尽脸面。”
en: “To fail,” answered her father, “is to commit the most dishonorable action that can disgrace a man.”

zh: “那一定是很大的罪孽吧，”葛朗台太太说，“我们的兄弟要进地狱吧。”
en: “It must be a great sin,” said Madame Grandet, “and our brother may be damned.”

zh: “得啦，得啦，别唠叨了！”葛朗台说着，耸了耸肩膀，“破产，欧仁妮，”他又说道，“是一种偷窃，很不幸，却受法律保护。人们相信纪尧姆·葛朗台讲信用和诚实的名声，把财产托付给他，他却把那些财产全部给吞了，什么也没给他们留下，只留给他们痛哭的双眼。路上的强盗都比破产者要好：强盗攻击你，你还可以防卫，他有丢掉性命的危险；可是破产者呢——总之，夏尔是名誉扫地了。”
en: “There, there, don’t begin with your litanies!” said Grandet, shrugging his shoulders.“To fail, Eugenie,” he resumed, “is to commit a theft which the law, unfortunately, takes under its protection.People have given their property to Guillaume Grandet trusting to his reputation for honor and integrity; he has made away with it all, and left them nothing but their eyes to weep with.A highway robber is better than a bankrupt: the one attacks you and you can defend yourself, he risks his own life; but the other—in short, Charles is dishonored.”

zh: 这些话在可怜的姑娘心里嗡嗡作响，字字千钧压在她的心头。她正直而又娇嫩，像生在密林深处的一朵花一样，既不谙尘世之道，又不懂骗人的说理和似是而非的诡辩；因而，她就相信了父亲这番可恶的解释，他其实故意掩盖了迫不得已的破产和有计划的破产之间存在的区别。
en: The words rang in the poor girl’s heart and weighed it down with their heavy meaning.Upright and delicate as a flower born in the depths of a forest, she knew nothing of the world’s maxims, of its deceitful arguments and specious sophisms; she therefore believed the atrocious explanation which her father gave her designedly, concealing the distinction which exists between an involuntary failure and an intentional one.

zh: “父亲，您难道不能阻止这场灾祸吗？”
en: “Father, could you not have prevented such a misfortune?”

zh: “我兄弟没找我商量过。而且，他欠了四百万。”
en: “My brother did not consult me.Besides, he owes four millions.”

zh: “什么是‘百万’，父亲？”她带着孩子般的天真问道，以为想知道什么，就马上可以弄清楚。
en: “What is a ‘million,’ father?” she asked, with the simplicity of a child which thinks it can find out at once all that it wants to know.

zh: “百万？”葛朗台说，“嗨，就是一百万个二十苏，五个二十苏才是五法郎。”
en: “A million?” said Grandet, “why, it is a million pieces of twenty sous each, and it takes five twenty sous pieces to make five francs.”

zh: “天哪！”欧仁妮叫了起来，“我叔父怎么可能有四百万呢？法国还有谁有这么多的百万？”葛朗台老头摸了摸他的下巴，笑了笑，他的肉瘤似乎胀大了些，“可是我的堂弟夏尔怎么办？”
en: “Dear me!” cried Eugenie, “how could my uncle possibly have had four millions?Is there any one else in France who ever had so many millions?”Pere Grandet stroked his chin, smiled, and his wen seemed to dilate.“But what will become of my cousin Charles?”

zh: “按照他父亲的要求，他要到西印度去，他要在那里想办法发财。”
en: “He is going off to the West Indies by his father’s request, and he will try to make his fortune there.”

zh: “他有钱去吗？”
en: “Has he got the money to go with?”

zh: “我会给他路费的，一直到——是的，一直到南特的路费。”
en: “I shall pay for his journey as far as—yes, as far as Nantes.”

zh: 欧仁妮跳起来扑进了他的怀里。
en: Eugenie sprang into his arms.

zh: “哦，父亲，您真好！”
en: “Oh, father, how good you are!”

zh: 她吻着他，那亲热劲差一点儿让葛朗台为自己感到羞愧了，因为他的良心有些不安。
en: She kissed him with a warmth that almost made Grandet ashamed of himself, for his conscience galled him a little.

zh: “攒一百万要花费很长时间吗？”她问道。
en: “Will it take much time to amass a million?” she asked.

zh: “注意！”那个老守财奴说，“你知道一个拿破仑金币值多少吧？好，一百万就得五万拿破仑金币。”
en: “Look here!” said the old miser, “you know what a napoleon is?Well, it takes fifty thousand napoleons to make a million.”

zh: “妈妈，我们得替他多念念《九日经》吧。”
en: “Mamma, we must say a great many @neuvaines@ for him.”

zh: “我正这样想呢。”葛朗台太太说。
en: “I was thinking so,” said Madame Grandet.

zh: “又来了，总是花我的钱！”父亲吼道，“你们以为每个灌木枝上都有法郎啊？”
en: “That’s the way, always spending my money!” cried the father.“Do you think there are francs on every bush?”

zh: 这时一声低沉的哭泣声从顶楼传来，格外地凄惨，欧仁妮和她母亲的心打起了寒颤。
en: At this moment a muffled cry, more distressing than all the others, echoed through the garrets and struck a chill to the hearts of Eugenie and her mother.

zh: “娜农，上楼去，看看他不是要自杀吧，”葛朗台说，“喂，我说，”他又说道，一边看着妻子和女儿，她们听到他的话早已脸色发白，“你们俩不要胡说八道！我得走了，我得去应付那些荷兰人，他们今天要走了。接下来，我得去找克吕绍，跟他谈谈这件事。”
en: “Nanon, go upstairs and see that he does not kill himself,” said Grandet.“Now, then,” he added, looking at his wife and daughter, who had turned pale at his words, “no nonsense, you two!I must leave you; I have got to see about the Dutchmen who are going away today.And then I must find Cruchot, and talk with him about all this.”

zh: 他走了。等他一关上门，欧仁妮和她母亲便松了一口气。在这天早上之前，这个年轻的姑娘从没在父亲面前感到拘束过；但是在最近这几个小时里，她的感情和思想每一刻都在发生着变化。
en: He departed.As soon as he had shut the door Eugenie and her mother breathed more freely.Until this morning the young girl had never felt constrained in the presence of her father; but for the last few hours every moment wrought a change in her feelings and ideas.

zh: “妈妈，一桶葡萄酒值多少个金路易？”
en: “Mamma, how many louis are there in a cask of wine?”

zh: “你父亲的酒是卖一百到一百五十法郎，有时两百——至少，我是听人这么说的。”
en: “Your father sells his from a hundred to a hundred and fifty francs, sometimes two hundred,—at least, so I’ve heard say.”

zh: “那爸爸一定很有钱啦？”
en: “Then papa must be rich?”

zh: “也许是的。但是克吕绍先生告诉我，他两年前买了弗罗瓦丰那块地，这一下他手头就紧了。”
en: “Perhaps he is.But Monsieur Cruchot told me he bought Froidfond two years ago; that may have pinched him.”

zh: 欧仁妮弄不明白她父亲财产的问题，她也就只能算到这个程度了。
en: Eugenie, not being able to understand the question of her father’s fortune, stopped short in her calculations.

zh: “他甚至都没看我一眼，那个宝贝儿！”娜农完成了差事返回来，说道，“他像个小牛一样，摊开身子趴在床上，哭得像圣女马德莱娜似的，上帝保佑！！这可怜的年轻人怎么啦！”
en: “He didn’t even see me, the darling!” said Nanon, coming back from her errand.“He’s stretched out like a calf on his bed and crying like the Madeleine, and that’s a blessing!What’s the matter with the poor dear young man!”

zh: “咱们去安慰安慰他，妈妈，如果有人敲门，咱们可以下来。”
en: “Let us go and console him, mamma; if any one knocks, we can come down.”

zh: 葛朗台太太听到女儿悦耳的声音以及劝说的口吻，没了主意。欧仁妮是高尚的：她已经变成得成熟了。两个人上楼去了夏尔的房间，心都怦怦直跳。门开着。那个年轻人什么都没听到，什么也没看到，他沉浸在悲痛之中，只是发着不成调的哭号。
en: Madame Grandet was helpless against the sweet persuasive tones of her daughter’s voice.Eugenie was sublime: she had become a woman.The two, with beating hearts, went up to Charles’s room.The door was open.The young man heard and saw nothing; plunged in grief, he only uttered inarticulate cries.

zh: “他是多么爱他父亲呀！”欧仁妮低声说。
en: “How he loves his father!” said Eugenie in a low voice.

zh: 从这些话语中，不难看出她内心的希望已经不知不觉突然变得强烈起来。葛朗台太太慈爱地看了女儿一眼，然后凑到她耳边低声说，——
en: In the utterance of those words it was impossible to mistake the hopes of a heart that, unknown to itself, had suddenly become passionate.Madame Grandet cast a mother’s look upon her daughter, and then whispered in her ear,—

zh: “当心，你会爱上他的！”
en: “Take care, you will love him!”

zh: “爱上他！”欧仁妮回答，“啊！要是您知道我父亲跟克吕绍先生说的话，就不会这么说了。”
en: “Love him!” answered Eugenie.“Ah! If you did but know what my father said to Monsieur Cruchot.”

zh: 夏尔翻了个身，看见了伯母和堂姐。
en: Charles turned over, and saw his aunt and cousin.

zh: “我失去了我的父亲，我可怜的父亲！要是他把藏在心里的麻烦告诉我，我们可以一起想法子补救的。天哪！我可怜的父亲！我本以为可以再见到他的，现在想起来我当时吻他的时候，真是太冷淡了——”
en: “I have lost my father, my poor father!If he had told me his secret troubles we might have worked together to repair them.My God! My poor father!I was so sure I should see him again that I think I kissed him quite coldly—”

zh: 他哽咽得说不下去了。
en: Sobs cut short the words.

zh: “我们会为他祈祷的。”葛朗台太太说，“服从上帝的旨意吧。”
en: “We will pray for him,” said Madame Grandet.“Resign yourself to the will of God.”

zh: “堂弟，”欧仁妮说，“振作点！你的损失是无法挽回了，所以只能想想如何保全你的名誉吧。”
en: “Cousin,” said Eugenie, “take courage!Your loss is irreparable; therefore think only of saving your honor.”

zh: 凭着女人天生面面俱到、心思细腻的本能，欧仁妮即使在安慰人的时候，也尽力让堂弟多关心他自己，以减轻他的痛苦。
en: With the delicate instinct of a woman who intuitively puts her mind into all things, even at the moment when she offers consolation, Eugenie sought to cheat her cousin’s grief by turning his thoughts inward upon himself.

zh: “我的名誉？”年轻人从床上坐起来，将胳膊交叉在胸前，不耐烦地将头发往一边一甩，高声叫道，“啊！的确。我伯父说我父亲破产了。”他发出撕心裂肺的哭喊，用手蒙住了脸，“走开，走开，堂姐！天哪！天哪！饶恕我的父亲吧，因为他一定也痛苦极了！”
en: “My honor?” exclaimed the young man, tossing aside his hair with an impatient gesture as he sat up on his bed and crossed his arms.“Ah! That is true.My uncle said my father had failed.”He uttered a heart-rending cry, and hid his face in his hands.“Leave me, leave me, cousin!My God! My God! Forgive my father, for he must have suffered sorely!”

zh: 这个年轻人的痛苦如此真诚，没有心计，无所顾忌，真是让人十分感动。心地纯朴的欧仁妮母女完全明白那是一种真正的痛苦，所以当夏尔示意她们离开要独自呆着时，她们服从了。她们默默地下了楼，坐到窗前各自习惯坐的位置上，做了将近一个小时的针线活，期间没有交谈一句。欧仁妮凭着那种少女眨一下眼睛就什么都能看清的眼力，偷偷看了一下那个年轻人的屋子，便瞥见了他那精致的梳洗用品、他的剪子，还有他镶金的剃刀。在堂弟悲痛的气氛中闪现出的这番奢华气派，也许是由于反差太大，只能让她觉得堂弟更值得关心了。过去从来没有一个如此严重的事件，一个如此富于戏剧性的场面，触动过这两个安分守己的人的想象力，她们迄今为止一直生活在平静和孤寂之中。
en: There was something terribly attractive in the sight of this young sorrow, sincere without reasoning or afterthought.It was a virgin grief which the simple hearts of Eugenie and her mother were fitted to comprehend, and they obeyed the sign Charles made them to leave him to himself.They went downstairs in silence and took their accustomed places by the window and sewed for nearly an hour without exchanging a word.Eugenie had seen in the furtive glance that she cast about the young man’s room—that girlish glance which sees all in the twinkling of an eye—the pretty trifles of his dressing-case, his scissors, his razors embossed with gold.This gleam of luxury across her cousin’s grief only made him the more interesting to her, possibly by way of contrast.Never before had so serious an event, so dramatic a sight, touched the imaginations of these two passive beings, hitherto sunk in the stillness and calm of solitude.

zh: “妈妈，”欧仁妮说，“我们应该给我叔父戴孝吧。”
en: “Mamma,” said Eugenie, “we must wear mourning for my uncle.”

zh: “这事由你父亲作主。”葛朗台太太回答。
en: “Your father will decide that,” answered Madame Grandet.

zh: 她们又不做声了。欧仁妮一针一针地缝着，那有规律的动作向旁观者透露出她冥想之中的万千思绪。这姑娘心里的第一个愿望就是跟她堂弟一起服丧。
en: They relapsed into silence.Eugenie drew her stitches with a uniform motion which revealed to an observer the teeming thoughts of her meditation.The first desire of the girl’s heart was to share her cousin’s mourning.

zh: 第六章
en: Chapter VI

zh: 大约四点钟，突然一阵敲门声把葛朗台太太吓得心惊肉跳。
en: About four o’clock an abrupt knock at the door struck sharply on the heart of Madame Grandet.

zh: “你父亲出了什么事？”她对女儿说。
en: “What can have happened to your father?” she said to her daughter.

zh: 葛朗台兴冲冲地走了进来。他把手套摘了下来，用力地搓着手，倘若他的手皮没有像俄罗斯皮革一样上过硝、加工处理过的话，简直都要把皮搓下来了——当然，只差松木香和熏香的味道了。不一会儿，他道出了秘密。
en: Grandet entered joyously.After taking off his gloves, he rubbed his hands hard enough to take off their skin as well, if his epidermis had not been tanned and cured like Russia leather,—saving, of course, the perfume of larch-trees and incense.Presently his secret escaped him.

zh: “太太，”他说，一点儿也不结巴，“我把他们全都骗了！咱们的酒卖掉了！荷兰人和比利时人已经走了。我在他们客栈前的市场上溜达，假装无所事事的样子。那个比利时人——你知道我说的是谁——冲我走过来。那些葡萄成色不错的园主都压着货，打算观望，那好，我不拦着他们。我看得出来，比利时人慌了。很快，买卖成交。他买了我的酒，两百法郎一桶，一半付现。他给我付的是金币，单子签了。这是给你的六个金路易。三个月之内，酒价准跌。”
en: “Wife,” he said, without stuttering, “I’ve trapped them all!Our wine is sold!The Dutch and the Belgians have gone.I walked about the market-place in front of their inn, pretending to be doing nothing.That Belgian fellow—you know who I mean—came up to me.The owners of all the good vineyards have kept back their vintages, intending to wait; well, I didn’t hinder them.The Belgian was in despair; I saw that.In a minute the bargain was made.He takes my vintage at two hundred francs the puncheon, half down.He paid me in gold; the notes are drawn.Here are six louis for you.In three months wines will have fallen.”

zh: 他说这些话时的语气很平静，但带有很强的挖苦意味。索米尔的居民们这时正聚集在市场上，得知葛朗台刚刚将酒抛售的消息，他们都震惊了，倘若听到上面这番话，一定会气得发抖。他们的恐慌可能会使酒价马上下跌百分之五十。
en: These words, uttered in a quiet tone of voice, were nevertheless so bitterly sarcastic that the inhabitants of Saumur, grouped at this moment in the market-place and overwhelmed by the news of the sale Grandet had just effected, would have shuddered had they heard them.Their panic would have brought the price of wines down fifty per cent at once.

zh: “父亲，您今年有一千桶酒吧？”
en: “Did you have a thousand puncheons this year, father?”

zh: “是的，小乖乖。”
en: “Yes, little one.”

zh: 用这个词称呼女儿表示老吝啬鬼高兴到了极点。
en: That term applied to his daughter was the superlative expression of the old miser’s joy.

zh: “那就会赚二十万个二十苏了？”
en: “Then that makes two hundred thousand pieces of twenty sous each?”

zh: “是的，葛朗台小姐。”
en: “Yes, Mademoiselle Grandet.”

zh: “那么，父亲，您很容易就能帮上夏尔了。”
en: “Then, father, you can easily help Charles.”

zh: 当初巴比伦国王伯沙撒看到眼前“算-量-分”几个字时的惊讶、愤怒、愕然都无法跟葛朗台冷淡的恼火相比，他本来早已忘了他的侄子，现在却发现侄子竟盘踞在他女儿的心中，女儿竟然在替他做着打算。
en: The amazement, the anger, the stupefaction of Belshazzar when he saw the @Mene-Tekel-Upharsin@ before his eyes is not to be compared with the cold rage of Grandet, who, having forgotten his nephew, now found him enshrined in the heart and calculations of his daughter.

zh: “这是怎么回事？自从那个公子哥踏进我的家门，就全都乱套了！你们的举动，就好像你们有权去买糖果、摆宴席，甚至操办婚礼似的。我不允许有这种事。到了我这把年纪，我相信我还明白自己的职责！我当然用不着女儿或其他什么人来教训我。为我侄儿该做什么，我自会做的，用不着你们插手。至于你，欧仁妮，”他脸冲着她，又说道，“别再提这个啦，不然我会把你和娜农一起送到努瓦耶修道院，看我做得到还是做不到；如果你不听我的话，最迟明天就把你送走！那小子在哪里，他下楼没有？”
en: “What’s this?Ever since that dandy put foot in my house everything goes wrong!You behave as if you had the right to buy sugar-plums and make feasts and weddings.I won’t have that sort of thing.I hope I know my duty at my time of life!I certainly sha’n’t take lessons from my daughter, or from anybody else.I shall do for my nephew what it is proper to do, and you have no need to poke your nose into it.As for you, Eugenie,” he added, facing her, “don’t speak of this again, or I’ll send you to the Abbaye des Noyers with Nanon, see if I don’t; and no later than to-morrow either, if you disobey me!Where is that fellow, has he come down yet?”

zh: “没有，我的老伴。”葛朗台太太回答。
en: “No, my friend,” answered Madame Grandet.

zh: “那他在干什么？”
en: “What is he doing then?”

zh: “他在为他父亲哭泣呢。”欧仁妮说。
en: “He is weeping for his father,” said Eugenie.

zh: 葛朗台看着女儿，想不出来话说；毕竟，他是个父亲。他在屋子里转了几个来回，然后匆匆去了他的密室，琢磨他正在谋划的投资买公债的事。连根砍掉的那两千英亩林木让他赚了六十万法郎：这个数目再加上卖杨树赚的钱，以及他去年和今年的其他收入，他总收入累计达九十万法郎，这还不算刚刚成交的那笔二十万法郎的买卖。克吕绍向他保证，短期内他就会从公债赚取百分之二十的利息，当时公债报价是七十法郎一股，这对他很有诱惑力。在那张报道他兄弟死讯的报纸的页边上，他做着计算。虽然一直能听到他侄子的呻吟，但他却充耳不闻。娜农来了，敲墙请他吃晚饭。下楼走到最后一级楼梯时，他心里想——
en: Grandet looked at his daughter without finding a word to say; after all, he was a father.He made a couple of turns up and down the room, and then went hurriedly to his secret den to think over an investment he was meditating in the public Funds.The thinning out of his two thousand acres of forest land had yielded him six hundred thousand francs: putting this sum to that derived from the sale of his poplars and to his other gains for the last year and for the current year, he had amassed a total of nine hundred thousand francs, without counting the two hundred thousand he had got by the sale just concluded.The twenty per cent which Cruchot assured him would gain in a short time from the Funds, then quoted at seventy, tempted him.He figured out his calculation on the margin of the newspaper which gave the account of his brother’s death, all the while hearing the moans of his nephew, but without listening to them.Nanon came and knocked on the wall to summon him to dinner.On the last step of the staircase he was saying to himself as he came down,—

zh: “这买卖我要做，我会得到百分之八的利息。两年以后，我就会有一百五十万法郎了，那时我就换成金币取出来——哎，我侄儿在哪里？”
en: “I’ll do it; I shall get eight per cent interest.In two years I shall have fifteen hundred thousand francs, which I will then draw out in good gold,—Well, where’s my nephew?”

zh: “他说他什么也不想吃，”娜农回答，“那对他的身体可不好。”
en: “He says he doesn’t want anything to eat,” answered Nanon, “that’s not good for him.”

zh: “省下不少呢。”她的主人回嘴说。
en: “So much saved,” retorted her master.

zh: “那倒是。”她说。
en: “That’s so,” she said.

zh: “呸！他不会哭多久的。饥饿会把狼赶出树林的。”
en: “Bah! He won’t cry long.Hunger drives the wolves out of the woods.”

zh: 吃晚饭时，静悄悄的。
en: The dinner was eaten in silence.

zh: “我的好老伴，”等桌布撤走后，葛朗台太太说，“咱们得戴孝吧。”
en: “My good friend,” said Madame Grandet, when the cloth was removed, “we must put on mourning.”

zh: “说实在话，葛朗台太太！接下来，你还要想出什么新花样来花钱呢？戴孝在于心，而不在于衣服。”
en: “Upon my word, Madame Grandet! what will you invent next to spend money on?Mourning is in the heart, and not in the clothes.”

zh: “可是为兄弟戴孝是必不可少的；教堂指示我们要——”
en: “But mourning for a brother is indispensable; and the Church commands us to—”

zh: “用你那六个金路易买你的孝服去吧。给我个黑帽带就行了。”
en: “Buy your mourning out of your six louis.Give me a hat-band; that’s enough for me.”

zh: 欧仁妮抬头望着天，一句话不说。她慷慨的本性一直处于休眠中，并长期被压抑着，但是现在突然而且是第一次觉醒了，却时时刻刻都在受着伤害。这一夜表面上和他们单调生活中其他上千个夜晚过得没什么两样，但肯定是最可怕的一夜。欧仁妮头也不抬地做着针线活，没有用前一晚夏尔瞧不上眼的那个针线盒。葛朗台太太织着她的套袖。葛朗台把大拇指晃了四个小时，埋头盘算着，这番盘算的结果第二天会让索米尔人大吃一惊。那天没有人上门拜访。满城都在盛传着葛朗台刚刚玩的生意把戏、他兄弟的破产，还有他侄子的到来。出于就共同利益唠叨一番的愿望，索米尔所有上层和中层阶级的葡萄园主都聚集到德格拉桑先生家，对那位前市长破口大骂，厉声斥责。娜农在纺线，纺轮的嗡嗡声是寂静的大厅那灰色的楼板下仅有的声响。
en: Eugenie raised her eyes to heaven without uttering a word.Her generous instincts, slumbering and long repressed but now suddenly and for the first time awakened, were galled at every turn.The evening passed to all appearance like a thousand other evenings of their monotonous life, yet it was certainly the most horrible.Eugenie sewed without raising her head, and did not use the workbox which Charles had despised the night before.Madame Grandet knitted her sleeves.Grandet twirled his thumbs for four hours, absorbed in calculations whose results were on the morrow to astonish Saumur.No one came to visit the family that day.The whole town was ringing with the news of the business trick just played by Grandet, the failure of his brother, and the arrival of his nephew.Obeying the desire to gossip over their mutual interests, all the upper and middle-class wine-growers in Saumur met at Monsieur des Grassins, where terrible imprecations were being fulminated against the ex-mayor.Nanon was spinning, and the whirr of her wheel was the only sound heard beneath the gray rafters of that silent hall.

zh: “咱们不浪费口舌。”她说着，露出了她的牙齿，那牙齿像剥了皮的杏仁一样，又大又白。
en: “We don’t waste our tongues,” she said, showing her teeth, as large and white as peeled almonds.

zh: “什么都不应该浪费。”葛朗台从沉思中惊醒，回答道。他仿佛远远看到了三年后的八百万，而他正在一大片金子中航行。“咱们去睡吧。我代你们跟我侄儿道声晚安，看看他是不是要吃点东西。”
en: “Nothing should be wasted,” answered Grandet, rousing himself from his reverie.He saw a perspective of eight millions in three years, and he was sailing along that sheet of gold.“Let us go to bed.I will bid my nephew good-night for the rest of you, and see if he will take anything.”

zh: 葛朗台太太一直站在二楼的楼梯口，想听听老头和他侄子会谈些什么。欧仁妮比她母亲胆子大，朝上走了两级楼梯。
en: Madame Grandet remained on the landing of the first storey to hear the conversation that was about to take place between the goodman and his nephew.Eugenie, bolder than her mother, went up two stairs.

zh: “唉，侄儿，你遭遇了不幸。好吧，哭吧，那是人之常情。父亲就是父亲，可是我们必须耐心地忍受我们的苦难。我是你的好伯父，记住这个。来，振作起来！你想喝一小杯葡萄酒吗？”（在索米尔，葡萄酒一钱不值，他们请人喝葡萄酒就像在中国请人喝茶一样。）“嗨！”葛朗台又说，“你没点灯！这不好，很不好，做事情你得看清才行。”说着，他向壁炉台走去。“这是什么？”他叫了起来，“一支白蜡烛！她们是怎么搞来的白蜡烛？为了给这小子煮鸡蛋，那几个败家子简直会拆了我屋子的天花板。”
en: “Well, nephew, you are in trouble.Yes, weep, that’s natural.A father is a father; but we must bear our troubles patiently.I am a good uncle to you, remember that.Come, take courage!Will you have a little glass of wine?”(Wine costs nothing in Saumur, and they offer it as tea is offered in China.)“Why!” added Grandet, “you have got no light!That’s bad, very bad; you ought to see what you are about,” and he walked to the chimney-piece.“What’s this?” he cried.“A wax candle!How the devil did they filch a wax candle?The spendthrifts would tear down the ceilings of my house to boil the fellow’s eggs.”

zh: 听到这句话，母女俩急忙回到她们的房间，钻到床上，速度之快，就好像受惊的耗子跑回洞一样。
en: Hearing these words, mother and daughter slipped back into their rooms and burrowed in their beds, with the celerity of frightened mice getting back to their holes.

zh: “葛朗台太太，你是不是发现了宝藏？”男人说着，进了他妻子的卧室。
en: “Madame Grandet, have you found a mine?” said the man, coming into the chamber of his wife.

zh: “等等，我的朋老伴，我正在做祷告。”那可怜的母亲声音颤抖地说道。
en: “My friend, wait; I am saying my prayers,” said the poor mother in a trembling voice.

zh: “让你仁慈的上帝见鬼去吧！”葛朗台怒冲冲地答道。
en: “The devil take your good God!” growled Grandet in reply.

zh: 守财奴不相信来世，当下就是他们的全部。这种思想反映了我们当今这个时代一个可怕的事实：在这个时代，金钱左右着法律、政治和道德风尚，其程度超过了以往任何一个时代。制度、书籍、人和教条都合谋破坏对来世的信念——一个一千八百年来社会大厦赖以支撑的信念。坟墓作为一个过渡手段，在我们这个时代无人惧怕。未来曾经在安魂弥撒之后向我们敞开，今天已被移放到现在。不管手段是否正当，为了获得穷奢极欲的尘世天堂，为了稍纵即逝的财富，不惜把心肠变硬、把肉体变得消瘦，就像过去的殉道者为了达到极乐世界而受尽苦难一样，如今这是一种很普遍的想法——一种到处写遍的想法，甚至写进了法律，法律问立法者，“你付多少钱？”而不是“你是怎么想的？”
en: Misers have no belief in a future life; the present is their all in all.This thought casts a terrible light upon our present epoch, in which, far more than at any former period, money sways the laws and politics and morals.Institutions, books, men, and dogmas, all conspire to undermine belief in a future life,—a belief upon which the social edifice has rested for eighteen hundred years.The grave, as a means of transition, is little feared in our day.The future, which once opened to us beyond the requiems, has now been imported into the present.To obtain @per fas et nefas@ a terrestrial paradise of luxury and earthly enjoyment, to harden the heart and macerate the body for the sake of fleeting possessions, as the martyrs once suffered all things to reach eternal joys, this is now the universal thought—a thought written everywhere, even in the very laws which ask of the legislator, “What do you pay?” instead of asking him, “What do you think?”

zh: 当这种信条从资产阶级传至平民百姓时，国家将变成什么样？
en: When this doctrine has passed down from the bourgeoisie to the populace, where will this country be?

zh: “葛朗台太太，你做完了吗？”老头问。
en: “Madame Grandet, have you done?” asked the old man.

zh: “我的老伴，我正在为你祈祷。”
en: “My friend, I am praying for you.”

zh: “很好！晚安，明天早上我们再谈。”
en: “Very good!Good night; tomorrow morning we will have a talk.”

zh: 那可怜的女人去睡觉了，像个没有学好功课的学生一样，知道他第二天会看到老师生气的面孔。正当她战战兢兢地用床单蒙上头，好什么也听不到的时候，欧仁妮穿着睡衣，光着脚，跑到她的身边，吻了吻她的额头。
en: The poor woman went to sleep like a schoolboy who, not having learned his lessons, knows he will see his master’s angry face on the morrow.At the moment when, filled with fear, she was drawing the sheet above her head that she might stifle hearing, Eugenie, in her night-gown and with naked feet, ran to her side and kissed her brow.

zh: “哦！我的好妈妈，”她说，“明天我会告诉他是我干的。”
en: “Oh! My good mother,” she said, “tomorrow I will tell him it was I.”

zh: “不，他会把你送到努瓦耶的。让我来对付吧，他总不能吃了我。”
en: “No; he would send you to Noyers.Leave me to manage it; he cannot eat me.”

zh: “您听到了吗，妈妈？”
en: “Do you hear, mamma?”

zh: “什么？”
en: “What?”

zh: “他还在哭呢。”
en: “He is weeping still.”

zh: “去睡吧，女儿，你的脚会着凉的：地板很潮。”
en: “Go to bed, my daughter; you will take cold in your feet: the floor is damp.”

zh: 这阴沉的一天就这样过去了，它注定将会重重压在这位富有而又可怜的女继承人的整个一生当中，从这一刻起，她的睡眠再也不会那么踏实，也不会那么单纯了。实际上，人生的某些行为，虽然千真万确，却往往像是不可能的。这难道不是因为对于我们一时冲动而做出的决定，我们总是不从心理角度加以分析，而没有对那些神秘地促使我们大脑作出决断的微妙原因作出解释吗？也许欧仁妮深层的激情应该从她身体最微妙的品格中去分析。爱挖苦的人可能会说，那激情已变成了一种病态，影响了她的终生。很多人宁可否认结局，而不愿衡量精神现象中事物之间暗中相互关联的关系、环节和结合力的力量有多大。因而，欧仁妮过去的生活将为那些善于观察人类本性的人们提供一种解释，道明她不假思索的天真和突如其来的真情流露的缘由。她过去的生活越平静，她女性的怜悯心就越明显，她灵魂中生发的情感就越纯朴。
en: Thus passed the solemn day which was destined to weight upon the whole life of the rich and poor heiress, whose sleep was never again to be so calm, nor yet so pure, as it had been up to this moment.It often happens that certain actions of human life seem, literally speaking, improbable, though actual.Is not this because we constantly omit to turn the stream of psychological light upon our impulsive determinations, and fail to explain the subtile reasons, mysteriously conceived in our minds, which impelled them?Perhaps Eugenie’s deep passion should be analyzed in its most delicate fibres; for it became, scoffers might say, a malady which influenced her whole existence.Many people prefer to deny results rather than estimate the force of ties and links and bonds, which secretly join one fact to another in the moral order.Here, therefore, Eugenie’s past life will offer to observers of human nature an explanation of her naive want of reflection and the suddenness of the emotions which overflowed her soul.The more tranquil her life had been, the more vivid was her womanly pity, the more simple-minded were the sentiments now developed in her soul.

zh: 她被白天发生的事情搅得焦躁不安，隔一会儿醒一次，聆听堂弟的动静，总觉得听到了哀叹声，那哀叹声仍旧回荡在她的心中。有时，她看见他悲痛欲绝，有时，她梦见他饿晕过去。快天亮的时候，她确信自己听到了一声骇人的哭号。她马上穿上衣服，在熹微的晨光中，快步向堂弟的卧室跑去，他的房门没关。蜡烛已经燃到了烛盘。夏尔疲倦之极，正睡着，他穿着衣服坐在床边一把扶手椅上，头靠着床，像空腹睡觉的人那样在做着梦。欧仁妮尽可以哭个痛快，尽可以欣赏那张年轻而英俊的脸，那张脸印着痛苦留下的痕迹，双眼哭肿了，虽然睡着，却似乎还在流着泪。夏尔心里感应到了姑娘的到来，他睁开双眼，看见她正一脸同情地看着自己。
en: Made restless by the events of the day, she woke at intervals to listen to her cousin, thinking she heard the sighs which still echoed in her heart.Sometimes she saw him dying of his trouble, sometimes she dreamed that he fainted from hunger.Towards morning she was certain that she heard a startling cry.She dressed at once and ran, in the dawning light, with a swift foot to her cousin’s chamber, the door of which he had left open.The candle had burned down to the socket.Charles, overcome by nature, was sleeping, dressed and sitting in an armchair beside the bed, on which his head rested; he dreamed as men dream on an empty stomach.Eugenie might weep at her ease; she might admire the young and handsome face blotted with grief, the eyes swollen with weeping, that seemed, sleeping as they were, to well forth tears.Charles felt sympathetically the young girl’s presence; he opened his eyes and saw her pitying him.

zh: “对不起，堂姐。”他说，显然既不知道时辰，也不知道身在何处。
en: “Pardon me, my cousin,” he said, evidently not knowing the hour nor the place in which he found himself.

zh: “有几颗心听到了你的声音，堂弟，我们觉得你可能需要点什么。你应该上床去睡，这样坐着多累呀。”
en: “There are hearts who hear you, cousin, and @we@ thought you might need something.You should go to bed; you tire yourself by sitting thus.”

zh: “那倒是。”
en: “That is true.”

zh: “那好吧，再见！”
en: “Well, then, adieu!”

zh: 她逃了出去，为自己去了那里又害臊又高兴。只有天真无邪才敢这么冒失。一旦开了窍，美德和邪恶一样会让她工于算计。欧仁妮在堂弟身边没有发抖，等回了自己的卧室，却几乎站都站不住了。她无知的生活突然结束了，她思来想去，把自己着实痛斥了一通。
en: She escaped, ashamed and happy at having gone there.Innocence alone can dare to be so bold.Once enlightened, virtue makes her calculations as well as vice.Eugenie, who had not trembled beside her cousin, could scarcely stand upon her legs when she regained her chamber.Her ignorant life had suddenly come to an end; she reasoned, she rebuked herself with many reproaches.

zh: “他会怎么看我呀？他会以为我爱上了他！”
en: “What will he think of me?He will think that I love him!”

zh: 其实她倒最希望他这样去想。真诚的爱情自有预感，知道爱能产生爱。这个独处闺阁的可怜姑娘就这样跑进了一个青年男子的卧室，这是何等大事啊！在恋爱期间，有些思想和行为对某些心灵而言，不就完全意味着最神圣的婚约吗？一个小时后，她去了母亲那里，和平常一样服侍母亲穿衣。然后她们两人下了楼，坐在窗前的老地方等葛朗台，内心极为焦虑不安，正如一个人在害怕某个场面或是担心受罚时，心里或者发冷，或者发热，或者揪紧，或者膨胀，全看个人的性格而定。这种情绪很自然，甚至连家畜都会有，尽管不小心自己伤了自己时，它们可以一声不哼，但惩罚当中的丝毫疼痛都会让它们哀号起来。
en: That was what she most wished him to think.An honest love has its own prescience, and knows that love begets love.What an event for this poor solitary girl thus to have entered the chamber of a young man!Are there not thoughts and actions in the life of love which to certain souls bear the full meaning of the holiest espousals?An hour later she went to her mother and dressed her as usual.Then they both came down and sat in their places before the window waiting for Grandet, with that cruel anxiety which, according to the individual character, freezes the heart or warms it, shrivels or dilates it, when a scene is feared, a punishment expected,—a feeling so natural that even domestic animals possess it, and whine at the slightest pain of punishment, though they make no outcry when they inadvertently hurt themselves.

zh: 老头下来了，但是他若无其事地跟妻子说着话，吻了吻欧仁妮，然后坐到桌上，看来好像忘了前一晚他威胁的话。
en: The goodman came down; but he spoke to his wife with an absent manner, kissed Eugenie, and sat down to table without appearing to remember his threats of the night before.

zh: “我的侄儿怎么样了？那家伙倒是不烦人。”
en: “What has become of my nephew?The lad gives no trouble.”

zh: “先生，他睡着呢。”娜农回答。
en: “Monsieur, he is asleep,” answered Nanon.

zh: “这样再好不过了；他睡着的话，就用不着白蜡烛了。”葛朗台用讥讽的语气说道。
en: “So much the better; he won’t want a wax candle,” said Grandet in a jeering tone.

zh: 这种反常的宽大，这番挖苦人的高兴劲，让葛朗台太太很是惊讶，她专心地看着丈夫。老头——这里也许有必要解释一下，已经用来称呼葛朗台的“老头”这个词，在图赖讷、安茹、普瓦图和布列塔尼，经常用来指苛刻残忍的人，同样也用于指性情和善的人，只要他们到了一定的年岁，这个称呼和一个人的仁慈的程度毫无关系——老头拿起他的帽子和手套，一边往外走，一边说道——
en: This unusual clemency, this bitter gaiety, struck Madame Grandet with amazement, and she looked at her husband attentively.The goodman—here it may be well to explain that in Touraine, Anjou, Pitou, and Bretagne the word “goodman,” already used to designate Grandet, is bestowed as often upon harsh and cruel men as upon those of kindly temperament, when either have reached a certain age; the title means nothing on the score of individual gentleness—the goodman took his hat and gloves, saying as he went out,—

zh: “我要到市场去转转，找克吕绍。”
en: “I am going to loiter about the market-place and find Cruchot.”

zh: “欧仁妮，你父亲心里一定有事。”
en: “Eugenie, your father certainly has something on his mind.”

zh: 葛朗台是个觉少的人，夜里一半时间都用在初步盘算上，这些盘算使他的见解、观察和计划都惊人地准确，从没失过手，他的同乡们看着都惊叹不已。人类的所有能力都是时间和耐心的混合体。强者既有意志力，又善于等待时机。一个守财奴的生活就是不断地把人类的能力用在为自己服务上。这只依赖于两种情感——自恋和利己主义，但是利己主义在一定程度上就是切切实实而又明智的自恋，是真正优越感的明显的表现，所以说自恋和利己主义是同一整体——以自我为中心的两个方面。也许正因为如此，每当守财奴的生活习惯被展现在世人面前时，人们总是表现出极大的好奇心。每个人的本性都与这些人物一脉相通，他们把全部的感情集中于一种激情之中，向人类所有的情感发出了挑战。哪里有全无欲望的人？哪里有不靠金钱便能满足的社会欲望呢？
en: Grandet, who was a poor sleeper, employed half his nights in the preliminary calculations which gave such astonishing accuracy to his views and observations and schemes, and secured to them the unfailing success at sight of which his townsmen stood amazed.All human power is a compound of time and patience.Powerful beings will and wait.The life of a miser is the constant exercise of human power put to the service of self.It rests on two sentiments only,—self-love and self-interest; but self-interest being to a certain extent compact and intelligent self-love, the visible sign of real superiority, it follows that self-love and self-interest are two parts of the same whole,—egotism.From this arises, perhaps, the excessive curiosity shown in the habits of a miser’s life whenever they are put before the world.Every nature holds by a thread to those beings who challenge all human sentiments by concentrating all in one passion.Where is the man without desire? And what social desire can be satisfied without money?

zh: 用他妻子的话说，葛朗台的确是“心里有事”。像所有的守财奴一样，他内心一直有种强烈的愿望，就是想跟其他人在商业上耍耍花招，并合法地把他们的钱都赚过来。对他来说，欺骗别人就是一种能力的标志，一个永久的证明，证明他赢得了蔑视世上那些任人宰割的弱者的权力。哦！有谁真正理解安静地躺在上帝脚下的羔羊呢？——它是尘世间一切牺牲者的最感人的象征，象征了他们虚幻的未来，以及他们被人歌颂的痛苦和懦弱。这羔羊正是守财奴养肥的，他把羔羊关进他的羊圈，宰杀，烹煮，吃掉，然后又加以蔑视。将金钱和蔑视混合在一起就是守财奴的牧草。夜里，葛朗台改变了主意，这就是他突然宽宏大量的原因。他想出了一个计谋，准备耍弄巴黎人，诱骗他们，愚弄他们，给他们设陷阱，让他们陷入圈套，叫他们跑来跑去、汗流浃背、满怀希望、脸色发白——一个令他这个外省的老箍桶匠开心的计谋，而他要么就坐在他阴暗的房椽下，要么踏着索米尔家中腐朽的楼梯上上下下。他满脑子都是他的侄子。他希望不用花他侄子或他自己一个子儿，就能挽救他亡弟的名声。他马上要放出自己的现金，准备投资三年，因而他只需管理索米尔的地产就可以了。他突然在他兄弟的破产中找到了自己的恶毒行为所需的养分。他觉得自己的利爪之间没有什么可榨取的东西，所以决定以夏尔的名义去压榨巴黎人，以最廉价的方式扮演一个好兄长的角色。家族的名誉在这个计划中一点儿也不重要，他的好意就好比一个赌徒对看一场他没有下注也能赢的赌博的兴趣。克吕绍叔侄是他计划中必不可少的一部分，但是他不愿意找他们——他决意要让他们来找他，并打算当晚上演一场喜剧，他已经构思好了情节，这会让他一分不花就能在第二天成为全城人羡慕的对象。
en: Grandet unquestionably “had something on his mind,” to use his wife’s expression.There was in him, as in all misers, a persistent craving to play a commercial game with other men and win their money legally.To impose upon other people was to him a sign of power, a perpetual proof that he had won the right to despise those feeble beings who suffer themselves to be preyed upon in this world.Oh! Who has ever truly understood the lamb lying peacefully at the feet of God?—Touching emblem of all terrestrial victims, myth of their future, suffering and weakness glorified!This lamb it is which the miser fattens, puts in his fold, slaughters, cooks, eats, and then despises.The pasture of misers is compounded of money and disdain.During the night Grandet’s ideas had taken another course, which was the reason of his sudden clemency.He had hatched a plot by which to trick the Parisians, to decoy and dupe and snare them, to drive them into a trap, and make them go and come and sweat and hope and turn pale,—a plot by which to amuse himself, the old provincial cooper, sitting there beneath his gloomy rafters, or passing up and down the rotten staircase of his house in Saumur.His nephew filled his mind.He wished to save the honor of his dead brother without the cost of a penny to the son or to himself.His own funds he was about to invest for three years; he had therefore nothing further to do than to manage his property in Saumur.He needed some nutriment for his malicious activity, and he found it suddenly in his brother’s failure.Feeling nothing to squeeze between his own paws, he resolved to crush the Parisians in behalf of Charles, and to play the part of a good brother on the cheapest terms.The honor of the family counted for so little in this scheme that his good intentions might be likened to the interest a gambler takes in seeing a game well played in which he has no stake.The Cruchots were a necessary part of his plan; but he would not seek them,—he resolved to make them come to him, and to lead up that very evening to a comedy whose plot he had just conceived, which should make him on the morrow an object of admiration to the whole town without its costing him a single penny.

zh: 父亲不在家，欧仁妮很高兴可以公开为她非常心爱的堂弟忙前忙后，放心大胆地向他倾注满腔的怜悯。怜悯是女性崇高的优点，是唯一女性愿意承认的优点，也是唯一男人让女性发扬，而又不会不受到女性责难的优点。有三四次，这姑娘跑去听她堂弟的呼吸，想知道他是睡着还是醒着。之后，等他起了床，她又把心思转到了奶油、鸡蛋、水果、盘子和杯子上——他早餐中的所有东西都成了她特别关心的事情。最后，她轻捷地蹬着破旧的楼梯跑上去，听堂弟发出的响动。他是在穿衣服吗？他仍在哭吗？她来到了门前。
en: In her father’s absence Eugenie had the happiness of busying herself openly with her much-loved cousin, of spending upon him fearlessly the treasures of her pity,—woman’s sublime superiority, the sole she desires to have recognized, the sole she pardons man for letting her assume.Three or four times the young girl went to listen to her cousin’s breathing, to know if he were sleeping or awake; then, when he had risen, she turned her thoughts to the cream, the eggs, the fruits, the plates, the glasses,—all that was a part of his breakfast became the object of some special care.At length she ran lightly up the old staircase to listen to the noise her cousin made.Was he dressing?Did he still weep?She reached the door.

zh: “堂弟！”
en: “My cousin!”

zh: “怎么了，堂姐。”
en: “Yes, cousin.”

zh: “你早餐是到楼下吃，还是在你的房间吃？”
en: “Will you breakfast downstairs, or in your room?”

zh: “在哪里都行。”
en: “Where you like.”

zh: “你感觉怎么样？”
en: “How do you feel?”

zh: “亲爱的堂姐，很惭愧，我饿了。”
en: “Dear cousin, I am ashamed of being hungry.”

zh: 这番交谈隔着紧闭的房门，在欧仁妮看来，简直就像诗歌中的一个片段。
en: This conversation, held through the closed door, was like an episode in a poem to Eugenie.

zh: “好，那我们就把早餐送到你的房间里，免得惹我父亲生气。”
en: “Well, then, we will bring your breakfast to your own room, so as not to annoy my father.”

zh: 她跑到厨房，像小鸟一样快，一样轻盈。
en: She ran to the kitchen with the swiftness and lightness of a bird.

zh: “娜农，去收拾他的房间！”
en: “Nanon, go and do his room!”

zh: 那楼梯被践踏得太频繁了，一点儿声音都会发出回响，此时在欧仁妮眼里却不再显得破旧了。它变得亮堂堂的，它发出声音，跟她说话，像她一样年轻——像此时它正为之效劳的爱情一样年轻。她的母亲，她慈祥、宽容的母亲，甘愿为这孩子任性的爱情助一臂之力。在房间收拾妥当之后，两人坐到那个不幸的年轻人身边，陪着他。基督教的博爱不是把安慰当作一种职责吗？两个女人从宗教中找到很多似是而非的论点来为她们的行为辩解。夏尔得到了最温柔、最体贴的关怀。他悲伤的心感受到了那温馨的友情和贴心的同情所带来的甜蜜。那两颗灵魂曾长期被束缚压制着，当它们在苦海中——它们天然所属的领域——但凡有片刻自由的时候，便非常清楚如何表达这友情和同情。
en: That staircase, so often traversed, which echoed to the slightest noise, now lost its decaying aspect in the eyes of Eugenie.It grew luminous; it had a voice and spoke to her; it was young like herself,—young like the love it was now serving.Her mother, her kind, indulgent mother, lent herself to the caprices of the child’s love, and after the room was put in order, both went to sit with the unhappy youth and keep him company.Does not Christian charity make consolation a duty?The two women drew a goodly number of little sophistries from their religion wherewith to justify their conduct.Charles was made the object of the tenderest and most loving care.His saddened heart felt the sweetness of the gentle friendship, the exquisite sympathy which these two souls, crushed under perpetual restraint, knew so well how to display when, for an instant, they were left unfettered in the regions of suffering, their natural sphere.

zh: 既然以至亲相称，欧仁妮便开始叠夏尔的内衣，把夏尔带来的洗漱用品都整理好。这样，她就可以尽情地欣赏每一件奢华的东西，以及各种各样镶金镂银的小玩意儿。以察看为借口，她把这些东西握在手里，久久不放。夏尔看到伯母和堂姐对他的盛情不禁深受感动，他非常了解巴黎社会，他敢肯定，以他目前的处境，他会遭到所有人的冷眼相待。于是在他的眼里，欧仁妮显得特别美，楚楚动人。前一天晚上，他还想嘲笑那种生活和风俗，从此以后他却赞赏起它们的纯朴了。所以，当欧仁妮从娜农手中接过盛着咖啡和奶油的碗，开始诚心诚意地为堂弟倒出来，并和蔼地看了他一眼的时候，这个巴黎人热泪盈眶，拉起她的手吻了吻。
en: Claiming the right of relationship, Eugenie began to fold the linen and put in order the toilet articles which Charles had brought; thus she could marvel at her ease over each luxurious bauble and the various knick-knacks of silver or chased gold, which she held long in her hand under a pretext of examining them.Charles could not see without emotion the generous interest his aunt and cousin felt in him; he knew society in Paris well enough to feel assured that, placed as he now was, he would find all hearts indifferent or cold.Eugenie thus appeared to him in the splendor of a special beauty, and from thenceforth he admired the innocence of life and manners which the previous evening he had been inclined to ridicule.So when Eugenie took from Nanon the bowl of coffee and cream, and began to pour it out for her cousin with the simplicity of real feeling, giving him a kindly glance, the eyes of the Parisian filled with tears; he took her hand and kissed it.

zh: “你怎么啦？”她说。
en: “What troubles you?” she said.

zh: “哦！这是感激的泪水。”他回答。
en: “Oh! These are tears of gratitude,” he answered.

zh: 欧仁妮猛地转身走向壁炉台，去拿烛台。
en: Eugenie turned abruptly to the chimney-piece to take the candlesticks.

zh: “嘿，娜农，把它们拿走！”她说。
en: “Here, Nanon, carry them away!” she said.

zh: 当她再看堂弟的时候，她的脸还红着，不过她的样子至少还能瞒过去人，并没有把她满心洋溢的狂喜给泄露出来；但是两个人的眼睛都表达着同样的情感，正如他们的心灵交融在同一个想法之中——未来是属于他们的。这番柔情对大难之中的夏尔来说倍感珍贵，因为它完全出乎意料。门锤的声音把女人们召回了原位。幸运的是，在葛朗台进来的时候，她们能够非常迅速地下楼，坐定，拿起活计；如果他在拱门下碰见了她们，他一定会起疑心的。老头儿站着吃完了午餐，这时弗罗瓦丰田庄的看管人来了，预先说好的津贴还没给他。他带来了园子里打来的一只野兔和几只山鹑，还有磨坊租户捎来抵租子用的几条鳗鱼和两条梭子鱼。
en: When she looked again towards her cousin she was still blushing, but her looks could at least deceive, and did not betray the excess of joy which innundated her heart; yet the eyes of both expressed the same sentiment as their souls flowed together in one thought,—the future was theirs.This soft emotion was all the more precious to Charles in the midst of his heavy grief because it was wholly unexpected.The sound of the knocker recalled the women to their usual station.Happily they were able to run downstairs with sufficient rapidity to be seated at their work when Grandet entered; had he met them under the archway it would have been enough to rouse his suspicions.After breakfast, which the goodman took standing, the keeper from Froidfond, to whom the promised indemnity had never yet been paid, made his appearance, bearing a hare and some partridges shot in the park, with eels and two pike sent as tribute by the millers.

zh: “哈，哈！可怜的科努瓦耶，他来了，像大斋节的鱼。那东西可以吃吗？”
en: “Ha, ha! Poor Cornoiller; here he comes, like fish in Lent.Is all that fit to eat?”

zh: “是的，我厚道的好老爷，两天前打的。”
en: “Yes, my dear, generous master; it has been killed two days.”

zh: “喂，娜农，快点，”葛朗台说，“把这些东西拿去，晚饭时吃。我已经请了两位克吕绍。”
en: “Come, Nanon, bestir yourself,” said Grandet, “take these things, they’ll do for dinner.I have invited the two Cruchots.”

zh: 娜农瞪大眼睛，惊呆了，看了看屋子里的每一个人。
en: Nanon opened her eyes, stupid with amazement, and looked at everybody in the room.

zh: “哎！”她说，“可我去哪里弄来猪油和香料呢？”
en: “Well!” she said, “and how am I to get the lard and the spices?”

zh: “太太，”葛朗台说，“给娜农六法郎，记得提醒我去地窖拿些好酒。”
en: “Wife,” said Grandet, “give Nanon six francs, and remind me to get some of the good wine out of the cellar.”

zh: “嗯，那么，葛朗台先生，”田庄看管人来时已预备好一套话以解决工钱问题，他说，“葛朗台先生——”
en: “Well, then, Monsieur Grandet,” said the keeper, who had come prepared with an harangue for the purpose of settling the question of the indemnity, “Monsieur Grandet—”

zh: “得，得，得，得！”葛朗台说，“我知道你想说什么。你是个好伙计，我们明天再谈那件事，我今天太忙了。太太，给他五法郎。”他一边对葛朗台太太补充道，一边匆忙溜走了。
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta!” said Grandet, “I know what you want to say.You are a good fellow; we will see about it tomorrow; I’m too busy today.Wife, give him five francs,” he added to Madame Grandet as he decamped.

zh: 可怜的女人很高兴能以十一法郎的代价买个清静。她知道，葛朗台把给她的钱一个法郎一个法郎地要回去之后，会让她安生两个星期的。
en: The poor woman was only too happy to buy peace at the cost of eleven francs.She knew that Grandet would let her alone for a fortnight after he had thus taken back, franc by franc, the money he had given her.

zh: “喂，科努瓦耶，”她说着，把十个法郎塞到那男人的手中，“我们以后会给你工酬的。”
en: “Here, Cornoiller,” she said, slipping ten francs into the man’s hand, “some day we will reward your services.”

zh: 科努瓦耶无话可说，便起身走了。
en: Cornoiller could say nothing, so he went away.

zh: “太太，”娜农说，她已经戴上了她的黑头巾，挎上了篮子，“我只要三法郎。余下的您留着吧，总能想法对付过去的。”
en: “Madame,” said Nanon, who had put on her black coif and taken her basket, “I want only three francs.You keep the rest; it’ll go fast enough somehow.”

zh: “晚饭做好点，娜农，我堂弟要下来。”欧仁妮说。
en: “Have a good dinner, Nanon; my cousin will come down,” said Eugenie.

zh: “要出大事了，我敢肯定，”葛朗台太太说，“这是我们结婚以来你父亲第三次请客。”
en: “Something very extraordinary is going on, I am certain of it,” said Madame Grandet.“This is only the third time since our marriage that your father has given a dinner.”

zh: 大约四点，欧仁妮和她母亲已经摆好了六个人吃饭的桌子，那位一家之主也把几瓶外省人特喜欢珍藏的好酒拿了上来后，夏尔下楼进了大厅。这个年轻人脸色苍白，他的姿态、他脸上的表情、他的目光，还有他说话的语气，都带着悲伤，但却不失优雅。他不是假装悲痛，他是实实在在地难过；那笼罩在他面孔上的痛苦使他的神情特别容易打动女人的心。欧仁妮因此更爱他了。或许她觉得是不幸把他拉得离自己更近了。夏尔不再是那个有钱的、高贵的、对她来说简直高不可攀的年轻人了，而是一个落入可怕的苦难之中的穷亲戚。苦难出平等。女人把救苦救难当成己任——在这点上和天使有共同之处。夏尔和欧仁妮彼此心有灵犀，只用眼神来交流，这个可怜的落难公子，没了父母，一贫如洗，他独自远远地坐在一个屋角，一言不发，沉默中透着高傲。不过，那个年轻姑娘温柔而爱抚的目光不时地落在他的身上，迫使他丢开愁绪，随着她一起进入希望和未来的天地，她愿意与他携手同游。
en: About four o’clock, just as Eugenie and her mother had finished setting the table for six persons, and after the master of the house had brought up a few bottles of the exquisite wine which provincials cherish with true affection, Charles came down into the hall.The young fellow was pale; his gestures, the expression of his face, his glance, and the tones of his voice, all had a sadness which was full of grace.He was not pretending grief, he truly suffered; and the veil of pain cast over his features gave him an interesting air dear to the heart of women.Eugenie loved him the more for it.Perhaps she felt that sorrow drew him nearer to her.Charles was no longer the rich and distinguished young man placed in a sphere far above her, but a relation plunged into frightful misery.Misery begets equality.Women have this in common with the angels,—suffering humanity belongs to them.Charles and Eugenie understood each other and spoke only with their eyes; for the poor fallen dandy, orphaned and impoverished, sat apart in a corner of the room, and was proudly calm and silent.Yet, from time to time, the gentle and caressing glance of the young girl shone upon him and constrained him away from his sad thoughts, drawing him with her into the fields of hope and of futurity, where she loved to hold him at her side.

zh: 第七章
en: Chapter VII
