zh: 此时，葛朗台宴请克吕绍叔侄一事轰动了索米尔城，其轰动效应超过了前一晚他出售葡萄酒的消息，尽管这一行为构成了对整个葡萄种植业背信弃义的罪行。如果这个老奸巨猾的守财奴请客吃饭，其目的和亚西比德割掉自家狗的尾巴一样，他也许可称之为一个伟人。可事实是，他自认为比不断被他玩弄于股掌之间的全城人都要高上一头，所以根本不在乎索米尔人会说什么。
en: At this moment the town of Saumur was more excited about the dinner given by Grandet to the Cruchots than it had been the night before at the sale of his vintage, though that constituted a crime of high-treason against the whole wine-growing community.If the politic old miser had given his dinner from the same idea that cost the dog of Alcibiades his tail, he might perhaps have been called a great man; but the fact is, considering himself superior to a community which he could trick on all occasions, he paid very little heed to what Saumur might say.

zh: 德格拉桑家很快知道了纪尧姆·葛朗台破产和惨死的事，他们决定当晚去他们的老主顾家吊唁并慰问一番，目的是为了弄清他宴请克吕绍叔侄的动机。五点整，克·德蓬丰先生和他的公证人叔叔身着节日盛装来了。大家就座，开始津津有味地用起晚餐来。葛朗台很严肃，夏尔沉默着，欧仁妮一声不吭，而葛朗台太太比平时的话更少，如此一来，这顿晚餐倒真成了一个名副其实的丧宴。当他们起身离席时，夏尔对他的伯母和伯父说——
en: The des Grassins soon learned the facts of the failure and the violent death of Guillaume Grandet, and they determined to go to their client’s house that very evening to commiserate his misfortune and show him some marks of friendship, with a view of ascertaining the motives which had led him to invite the Cruchots to dinner.At precisely five o’clock Monsieur C. de Bonfons and his uncle the notary arrived in their Sunday clothes.The party sat down to table and began to dine with good appetites.Grandet was grave, Charles silent, Eugenie dumb, and Madame Grandet did not say more than usual; so that the dinner was, very properly, a repast of condolence.When they rose from table Charles said to his aunt and uncle,—

zh: “能允许我离开吗？我有一封痛苦的长信要写。”
en: “Will you permit me to retire?I am obliged to undertake a long and painful correspondence.”

zh: “当然可以，侄儿。”
en: “Certainly, nephew.”

zh: 等老头确定夏尔大概正在专心写信，什么也听不见的时候，他便用一种狡黠的眼神看着妻子，说道——
en: As soon as the goodman was certain that Charles could hear nothing and was probably deep in his letter-writing, he said, with a dissimulating glance at his wife,—

zh: “葛朗台太太，我们要谈的话对你们来说就是拉丁文；现在七点半，你们可以去把家里的帐清一清。晚安，我的女儿。”
en: “Madame Grandet, what we have to talk about will be Latin to you; it is half past seven; you can go and attend to your household accounts.Good night, my daughter.”

zh: 他吻了吻欧仁妮，然后两个女人就离开了。一场好戏现在开演了，在这场戏里，葛朗台老头施展了比他生平任何时候都用得多的诡计多端、阴险狡诈，那是他与人打交道时学到的，那些被他有时咬得太狠的人因此给他起了个绰号“老狗”。如果这位索米尔市长野心再大点，又赶上好机会，使他能爬到社会上层，奉派出席讨论各国事务的会议，而且他又能把自私自利赋予他的天分用到那里，毫无疑问，他将会为他的祖国立下功勋的。但一离开索米尔，这老头可能就成了一个没用的可怜虫，这种可能同样也有。也许有才智的人们像某些动物一样，一离开生长的水土，便会停止繁殖。
en: He kissed Eugenie, and the two women departed.A scene now took place in which Pere Grandet brought to bear, more than at any other moment of his life, the shrewd dexterity he had acquired in his intercourse with men, and which had won him from those whose flesh he sometimes bit too sharply the nickname of “the old dog.”If the mayor of Saumur had carried his ambition higher still, if fortunate circumstances, drawing him towards the higher social spheres, had sent him into congresses where the affairs of nations were discussed, and had he there employed the genius with which his personal interests had endowed him, he would undoubtedly have proved nobly useful to his native land.Yet it is perhaps equally certain that outside of Saumur the goodman would have cut a very sorry figure.Possibly there are minds like certain animals which cease to breed when transplanted from the climates in which they are born.

zh: “庭-庭-庭长先-先-先生，您说-说破-破-破产——”
en: “M-m-mon-sieur le p-p-president, you said t-t-that b-b-bankruptcy—”

zh: 老守财奴常年来只要需要就装出的结巴，以及他在雨天有时加以抱怨的耳聋，在索米尔被大家认为是个天生的缺陷，但在这样一个危急关头，他的结巴令两位克吕绍非常厌烦，他们边听边下意识地做着鬼脸，动着嘴唇，好像要把他有意停顿和结巴的字眼给发出音来一样。
en: The stutter which for years the old miser had assumed when it suited him, and which, together with the deafness of which he sometimes complained in rainy weather, was thought in Saumur to be a natural defect, became at this crisis so wearisome to the two Cruchots that while they listened they unconsciously made faces and moved their lips, as if pronouncing the words over which he was hesitating and stuttering at will.

zh: 这里不妨交代一下葛朗台先生口吃和耳聋的历史。在安茹，就数这个狡猾的老箍桶匠把法语（带安茹口音的）听得最清楚，说得最利落了，谁也比不上他。几年前，他尽管精明透顶，还是被一个犹太人给骗了。那人在谈生意时，为了听清别人说话，总把手放在耳朵后，说话时结结巴巴，根本表达不清意思，以致葛朗台发了善心，不得不为那个狡猾的犹太人提示他好像要找的字眼和想法，替那个犹太人把理由都补全了，把本该那个该死的犹太人自己说的话都给说了。总之，他成了那个犹太人，而不是葛朗台了。
en: Here it may be well to give the history of this impediment of the speech and hearing of Monsieur Grandet.No one in Anjou heard better, or could pronounce more crisply the French language (with an Angevin accent) than the wily old cooper.Some years earlier, in spite of his shrewdness, he had been taken in by an Israelite, who in the course of the discussion held his hand behind his ear to catch sounds, and mangled his meaning so thoroughly in trying to utter his words that Grandet fell a victim to his humanity and was compelled to prompt the wily Jew with the words and ideas he seemed to seek, to complete himself the arguments of the said Jew, to say what that cursed Jew ought to have said for himself; in short, to be the Jew instead of being Grandet.

zh: 等箍桶匠结束了这场奇特的会面时，他已经达成了在长期的商业生涯中唯一一笔他有理由抱怨的买卖。可是，如果说他当时是金钱上受了损失，他在道德上却获得了一个宝贵的教训，后来，他还从中受了益。实际上，老头最后还感激那个犹太人，因为犹太人教会了他一门艺术，可以使商业对手沉不住气，并使商业对手因不耐烦而忘记自己的想法，反而为折磨他的人在打磕巴的地方作些提示。没有什么事比手头这件更需要耳聋、口吃，以及葛朗台为掩盖其想法而使用的所有那些莫名其妙的拐弯抹角了。首先，他不打算为自己的计划承担责任；其次，他决意要把持谈话的主动权，让人吃不准他的真正意图。
en: When the cooper came out of this curious encounter he had concluded the only bargain of which in the course of a long commercial life he ever had occasion to complain.But if he lost at the time pecuniarily, he gained morally a valuable lesson; later, he gathered its fruits.Indeed, the goodman ended by blessing that Jew for having taught him the art of irritating his commercial antagonist and leading him to forget his own thoughts in his impatience to suggest those over which his tormentor was stuttering.No affair had ever needed the assistance of deafness, impediments of speech, and all the incomprehensible circumlocutions with which Grandet enveloped his ideas, as much as the affair now in hand.In the first place, he did not mean to shoulder the responsibility of his own scheme; in the next, he was determined to remain master of the conversation and to leave his real intentions in doubt.

zh: “德蓬-蓬-蓬丰先-先-先生，”——三年来，葛朗台第二次叫克吕绍的侄子德蓬丰先生；庭长觉得自己可能被这个刁钻古怪的老家伙当作女婿了——“您-您说那-那-那个破-破-破产可-可-可能在某些情-情-情况下，被-被-被阻-阻-阻止，由-由-由——”
en: “M-m-monsieur de B-B-Bonfons,”—for the second time in three years Grandet called the Cruchot nephew Monsieur de Bonfons; the president felt he might consider himself the artful old fellow’s son-in-law,—“you-ou said th-th-that b-b-bankruptcy c-c-could, in some c-c-cases, b-b-be p-p-prevented b-b-by—”

zh: “由商业法庭。这是常有的事，”克·德蓬丰先生顺着葛朗台的意思，或者说自以为猜到了他的意思，便好心好意地想帮他一把，说道，“请听好。”
en: “By the courts of commerce themselves.It is done constantly,” said Monsieur C. de Bonfons, bestriding Grandet’s meaning, or thinking he guessed it, and kindly wishing to help him out with it.“Listen.”

zh: “好-好的。”葛朗台谦恭地说道，带着一副淘气的神色，就像一个小男孩内心里讥笑着他的老师，却在无比专心地听讲。
en: “Y-yes,” said Grandet humbly, with the mischievous expression of a boy who is inwardly laughing at his teacher while he pays him the greatest attention.

zh: “当一个非常受人尊重、非常重要的人物，比方说，您已故的兄弟——”
en: “When a man so respected and important as, for example, your late brother—”

zh: “我-我的兄-兄-兄弟，是的。”
en: “M-my b-b-brother, yes.”

zh: “——有无力清偿债务的危险——”
en: “—is threatened with insolvency—”

zh: “他们把-把-把那个叫做无-无力-力清偿债务？”
en: “They c-c-call it in-ins-s-solvency?”

zh: “是的，在他面临破产时，对他有管辖权的商业法庭（请认真听我说），有权力根据条令任命一位接管人。您知道，债务清偿和破产不一样。当一个人破了产，他就名誉扫地了，可是当他只是清偿债务时，他仍然是个清白的人。”
en: “Yes; when his failure is imminent, the court of commerce, to which he is amenable (please follow me attentively), has the power, by a decree, to appoint a receiver.Liquidation, you understand, is not the same as failure.When a man fails, he is dishonored; but when he merely liquidates, he remains an honest man.”

zh: “那-那-那是太不-不-不一样了，要是不-不-不用花-花-花更-更多的钱的话。”葛朗台说。
en: “T-t-that’s very d-d-different, if it d-d-doesn’t c-c-cost m-m-more,” said Grandet.

zh: “但即使不通过法庭，也可以进行清偿的。因为，”庭长说着，吸了口鼻烟，“您不知道破产怎么宣告吗？”
en: “But a liquidation can be managed without having recourse to the courts at all.For,” said the president, sniffing a pinch of snuff, “don’t you know how failures are declared?”

zh: “不-不-不，我从-从-从没想-想-想过。”葛朗台回答。
en: “N-n-no, I n-n-never t-t-thought,” answered Grandet.

zh: “首先，”法官接着说，“当事人或者他合法登记的代理人在法庭档案室提交一份资产负债表。第二，由债权人出面申报破产。这时如果当事人不提交资产负债表，或者债权人不向法庭要求裁决当事人无力清偿债务，那会怎么样呢？”
en: “In the first place,” resumed the magistrate, “by filing the schedule in the record office of the court, which the merchant may do himself, or his representative for him with a power of attorney duly certified.In the second place, the failure may be declared under compulsion from the creditors.Now if the merchant does not file his schedule, and if no creditor appears before the courts to obtain a decree of insolvency against the merchant, what happens?”

zh: “会-会-会怎-怎-怎么样呢？”
en: “W-w-what h-h-happens?”

zh: “呃，死者的家人，他的代理人，他的继承人，或者当事人自己——如果他没死，如果他只是躲起来了——或者他的朋友可以清偿他的债务。也许您想清偿令弟的债务吧？”
en: “Why, the family of the deceased, his representatives, his heirs, or the merchant himself, if he is not dead, or his friends if he is only hiding, liquidate his business.Perhaps you would like to liquidate your brother’s affairs?”

zh: “啊！葛朗台，”公证人说，“那可是件应该做的事。外省这地方很看重名声。如果您能保住您的名声——因为毕竟你们是同姓——您可真是个男子汉了——”
en: “Ah! Grandet,” said the notary, “that would be the right thing to do.There is honor down here in the provinces.If you save your name—for it is your name—you will be a man—”

zh: “一个高尚的男子汉！”庭长打断了他叔父的话，大声说道。
en: “A noble man!” cried the president, interrupting his uncle.

zh: “当然，”老头回答道，“我的兄-兄-兄弟的名字是葛朗台，和我-我-我的一样。那-那是肯-肯-肯定的，我不-不-不否认这一点。而且这-这-这个债-债-债务清偿可能在许-许-许多方面，对-对-对我-我-我心-心-心爱的侄儿很有-有-有利。不过我得考虑考虑。我不懂-懂-懂巴-巴-巴黎人的把-把-把戏。我生活在-在-在索-索-索米尔，您-您-您没看见吗？我-我-我的葡萄藤，我的水-水-水渠——总之，我有我自己的事-事-事情。我从没开-开-开过期-期-期票。什么是期-期-期票？我收-收-收过很-很-很多，可是我从没签-签-签过一张。我不-不-不懂这些东西。我听-听-听人说，期-期-期票可-可-可以赎-赎-赎回。”
en: “Certainly,” answered the old man, “my b-b-brother’s name was G-G-Grandet, like m-m-mine.Th-that’s c-c-certain; I d-d-don’t d-d-deny it.And th-th-this l-l-liquidation might be, in m-m-many ways, v-v-very advan-t-t-tageous t-t-to the interests of m-m-my n-n-nephew, whom I l-l-love.But I must consider.I don’t k-k-know the t-t-tricks of P-P-Paris.I b-b-belong to Sau-m-mur, d-d-don’t you see?M-m-my vines, my d-d-drains—in short, I’ve my own b-b-business.I never g-g-give n-n-notes.What are n-n-notes?I t-t-take a good m-m-many, but I have never s-s-signed one.I d-d-don’t understand such things.I have h-h-heard say that n-n-notes c-c-can be b-b-bought up.”

zh: “当然，”庭长说，“期票能以百分之几的折扣在市场上买到。您不懂吗？”
en: “Of course,” said the president.“Notes can be bought in the market, less so much per cent.Don’t you understand?”

zh: 葛朗台两手做听筒状，于是庭长又把他的话重复了一遍。
en: Grandet made an ear-trumpet of his hand, and the president repeated his words.

zh: “好，那么，”老头答道，“其-其-其中是有利-利-利可图了？我这把年纪，弄-弄=弄不清这-这-这些事。我住-住-住在这里，要照-照-照看葡-葡-葡萄藤。葡萄藤长-长-长成了，就是用来开-开-开销的酒。照-照-照看收-收-收成，那-那-那就是我的本分。我主-主-主要的收入是在弗罗瓦丰。我不-不-不能抛下我的家-家-家当，去胡-胡-胡乱思考我一点儿也不-不-不了解的邪恶的事。你说我应该清-清-清偿我兄-兄-兄弟的债-债-债务，以避-避免破-破-破产。我没-没-没法分-分-分身，除非我是一只小-小-小鸟，还有——”
en: “Well, then,” replied the man, “there’s s-s-something to be g-g-got out of it?I k-know n-nothing at my age about such th-th-things.I l-l-live here and l-l-look after the v-v-vines.The vines g-g-grow, and it’s the w-w-wine that p-p-pays.L-l-look after the v-v-vintage, t-t-that’s my r-r-rule.My c-c-chief interests are at Froidfond.I c-c-can’t l-l-leave my h-h-house to m-m-muddle myself with a d-d-devilish b-b-business I kn-know n-n-nothing about.You say I ought to l-l-liquidate my b-b-brother’s af-f-fairs, to p-p-prevent the f-f-failure.I c-c-can’t be in two p-p-places at once, unless I were a little b-b-bird, and—”

zh: “我明白，”公证人嚷道，“嗨，我的老朋友，您有的是朋友，能为您的利益尽心尽力的老朋友。”
en: “I understand,” cried the notary.“Well, my old friend, you have friends, old friends, capable of devoting themselves to your interests.”

zh: “好吧！”葛朗台心想，“赶快点，谈正题吧！”
en: “All right!” thought Grandet, “make haste and come to the point!”

zh: “如果有人去巴黎，找令弟纪尧姆最主要的债权人，跟他说——”
en: “Suppose one of them went to Paris and saw your brother Guillaume’s chief creditor and said to him—”

zh: “慢-慢-慢着，”老头打断了他的话，“说什-什-什么？大概是-是-是这样。索米尔的葛-葛朗台先生这样，索米尔的葛朗台先生那样。他爱-爱他的兄-兄-兄弟，他爱他的侄-侄儿。葛朗台是个好-好-好伯父，他心-心-心地好。他把他的收-收-收成卖了。别-别-别宣告破产，召集开-开-开个会，清-清-清偿债务，然后葛-葛-葛朗台就会知道他能-能-能做什么了。清偿债务比让-让法-法-法院插-插-插手要好。嗯？是不是？”
en: “One m-m-moment,” interrupted the goodman, “said wh-wh-what?Something l-l-like this.Monsieur Gr-Grandet of Saumur this, Monsieur Grandet of Saumur that.He l-loves his b-b-brother, he loves his n-nephew.Grandet is a g-g-good uncle; he m-m-means well.He has sold his v-v-vintage.D-d-don’t declare a f-f-failure; c-c-call a meeting; l-l-liquidate; and then Gr-Gr-Grandet will see what he c-c-can do.B-b-better liquidate than l-let the l-l-law st-st-stick its n-n-nose in.Hein? Isn’t it so?”

zh: “的确如此。”庭长说。
en: “Exactly so,” said the president.

zh: “因-因为，德蓬-蓬丰先生，您要知道，凡事都要三-三-三思而后-后-后行。如果不-不-不行，就是不-不-不行。如果不-不-不想倾-倾-倾家荡产的话，就必-必-必须要把所有事-事-事情，所有的资产和债务都弄清。嗯？是不是？”
en: “B-because, don’t you see, Monsieur de B-Bonfons, a man must l-l-look b-b-before he l-leaps.If you c-c-can’t, you c-c-can’t.M-m-must know all about the m-m-matter, all the resources and the debts, if you d-d-don’t want to be r-r-ruined.Hein? Isn’t it so?”

zh: “当然，”庭长说，“我认为几个月内可以用一笔钱赎回债务，然后再通过协议全部偿还。哈！哈！你只要给狗一点儿猪油，就能哄它走好长一段路。只要不宣告破产，把债权握在您的手中，您就能在完事之后，清白得像吹积的雪。”
en: “Certainly,” said the president.“I’m of opinion that in a few months the debts might be bought up for a certain sum, and then paid in full by an agreement.Ha! Ha! You can coax a dog a long way if you show him a bit of lard.If there has been no declaration of failure, and you hold a lien on the debts, you come out of the business as white as the driven snow.”

zh: “雪-雪-雪，”葛朗台说着，把他的手放到耳朵上，“什-什-什么雪？”
en: “Sn-n-now,” said Grandet, putting his hand to his ear, “wh-wh-what about s-now?”

zh: “不过，”庭长大声说道，“请认真听我说。”
en: “But,” cried the president, “do pray attend to what I am saying.”

zh: “我在认真听-听-听着呢。”
en: “I am at-t-tending.”

zh: “期票是一种商品——一件价格有涨有跌的交易品。这是根据杰里米·本瑟姆的高利贷理论得出的推论。这位作者已经证明了对放高利贷者加以谴责的偏见是十分愚蠢的。”
en: “A note is merchandise,—an article of barter which rises and falls in prices.That is a deduction from Jeremy Bentham’s theory about usury.That writer has proved that the prejudice which condemned usurers to reprobation was mere folly.”

zh: “哟！”老头突然喊了起来。
en: “Whew!” ejaculated the goodman.

zh: “根据本瑟姆的理论，既然金钱是一件商品，而且任何代表金钱的东西同样是商品，”庭长接着说，“众所周知，有某人某人签名的商业期票会随着商业价值在市场的上下波动，时而价格不菲，时而一钱不值，所以法庭判决——啊！我可真糊涂，对不起——我还是希望您可以按百分之二十五的价钱全部买下令弟的债券。”
en: “Allowing that money, according to Bentham, is an article of merchandise, and that whatever represents money is equally merchandise,” resumed the president, “allowing also that it is notorious that the commercial note, bearing this or that signature, is liable to the fluctuation of all commercial values, rises or falls in the market, is dear at one moment, and is worth nothing at another, the courts decide—ah! how stupid I am, I beg your pardon—I am inclined to think you could buy up your brother’s debts for twenty-five per cent.”

zh: “您-您-您叫-叫-叫他杰-杰-杰里米·本-本？”
en: “D-d-did you c-c-call him Je-Je-Jeremy B-Ben?”

zh: “本瑟姆，一个英国人。”
en: “Bentham, an Englishman.’

zh: “正是一个叫杰里米的人让我们在生意上不用哭天喊地了。”公证人笑着说道。
en: “That’s a Jeremy who might save us a lot of lamentations in business,” said the notary, laughing.

zh: “那些英国人有-有时候说-说-说的话也有道理，”葛朗台说，“这样，照-照-照本-本瑟姆说，如果我兄-兄-兄弟的期-期票一钱不值，如果杰-杰——我说的对-对-对，是吗？我似乎弄明-明-明白了——债-债-债权人会——不，不会，我明白。”
en: “Those Englishmen s-sometimes t-t-talk sense,” said Grandet.“So, ac-c-cording to Ben-Bentham, if my b-b-brother’s n-notes are worth n-n-nothing; if Je-Je—I’m c-c-correct, am I not?That seems c-c-clear to my m-m-mind—the c-c-creditors would be—no, would not be; I understand.”

zh: “让我来解释吧，”庭长说，“从法律上讲，如果您获得葛朗台商号的所有债券，令弟或者他的继承人就不欠任何人的债了。非常好。”
en: “Let me explain it all,” said the president.“Legally, if you acquire a title to all the debts of the Maison Grandet, your brother or his heirs will owe nothing to any one.Very good.”

zh: “非常好-好。”葛朗台跟着说道。
en: “Very g-good,” repeated Grandet.

zh: “以公道而论，如果令弟的期票在市场上以百分之几的折扣转让——转让，您明白这个词的意思吗？——如果您的一位朋友碰巧在场就买下了，债权人是自愿出售的，没有受任何强迫，那么已故的葛朗台的遗产就光明正大地免除债务了。”
en: “In equity, if your brother’s notes are negotiated—negotiated, do you clearly understand the term?—negotiated in the market at a reduction of so much per cent in value, and if one of your friends happening to be present should buy them in, the creditors having sold them of their own free-will without constraint, the estate of the late Grandet is honorably released.”

zh: “那倒不-不错，生-生-生意就是生-生-生意，”箍桶匠说道，“可-可-可是，还-还有，您知道，那很-很-很难。我没-没钱-钱-钱，也没-没时-时-时间。”
en: “That’s t-true; b-b-business is b-business,” said the cooper.“B-b-but, st-still, you know, it is d-d-difficult.I h-have n-no m-m-money and n-no t-t-time.”

zh: “是的，但是您不需要亲自做。我马上要去巴黎（您给我出费用，费用没多少的）。我去见债权人，跟他们谈谈，争取期限延长。只要您在资产的总数上再加点钱，把债券全都赎回，就全都搞定了。”
en: “Yes, but you need not undertake it.I am quite ready to go to Paris (you may pay my expenses, they will only be a trifle).I will see the creditors and talk with them and get an extension of time, and everything can be arranged if you will add something to the assets so as to buy up all title to the debts.”

zh: “咱-咱们以后再谈这-这个。我不-不-不能，我不-不-不会随便应承，如果没有——不-不-不行，就是不行，您明白吗？”
en: “We-we’ll see about th-that.I c-c-can’t and I w-w-won’t bind myself without—He who c-c-can’t, can’t; don’t you see?”

zh: “那倒是非常正确。”
en: “That’s very true.”

zh: “您对我讲-讲-讲的话把我搞-搞-搞晕了。这是我有生以来第-第一-一-一次得好好想-想-想想——”
en: “I’m all p-p-put ab-b-bout by what you’ve t-t-told me.This is the f-first t-t-time in my life I have b-been obliged to th-th-think—”

zh: “是的，您又不是律师。”
en: “Yes, you are not a lawyer.”

zh: “我只是个穷-穷-穷种-种葡萄的，一点儿也不-不懂您刚才给我讲-讲的那些话，我必-必-必须琢-琢磨琢磨。”
en: “I’m only a p-p-poor wine-g-grower, and know n-nothing about wh-what you have just t-told me; I m-m-must th-think about it.”

zh: “很好。”庭长说道，准备继续他的论证。
en: “Very good,” said the president, preparing to resume his argument.

zh: “侄儿！”公证人用警告的语气打断了他，说道。
en: “Nephew!” said the notary, interrupting him in a warning tone.

zh: “啊，怎么了，叔叔？”庭长答道。
en: “Well, what, uncle?” answered the president.

zh: “让葛朗台先生解释一下他自己的意图。眼下讨论的这件事可是非同小可。我们的好朋友应该把他的意思说清楚，而且——”
en: “Let Monsieur Grandet explain his own intentions.The matter in question is of the first importance.Our good friend ought to define his meaning clearly, and—”

zh: 一声重重的门锤意味着德格拉桑一家的到来，接着他们进了屋并和众人打了招呼，这样克吕绍就没能把话说完。这一打岔，公证人倒觉得高兴，因为葛朗台正开始用怀疑的眼神看着他，那个肉瘤预示着他正在酝酿的一场大阴谋。首先，公证人认为，作为一个民事法庭的庭长，不应该去巴黎蛊惑债权人插手与公正严明的法律相抵触的偷偷摸摸的勾当；其次，由于根本没有听出老葛朗台表示过一点出钱的意思，不管怎样，看到他侄子参与到这件事当中，出于本能，他感到担心。因而趁德格拉桑一家进门时，他拉起侄子的胳膊，把他拉到窗洞下——
en: A loud knock, which announced the arrival of the des Grassins family, succeeded by their entrance and salutations, hindered Cruchot from concluding his sentence.The notary was glad of the interruption, for Grandet was beginning to look suspiciously at him, and the wen gave signs of a brewing storm.In the first place, the notary did not think it becoming in a president of the Civil courts to go to Paris and manipulate creditors and lend himself to an underhand job which clashed with the laws of strict integrity; moreover, never having known old Grandet to express the slightest desire to pay anything, no matter what, he instinctively feared to see his nephew taking part in the affair.He therefore profited by the entrance of the des Grassins to take the nephew by the arm and lead him into the embrasure of the window,—

zh: “你说得已经够多了，侄儿，你已经献够了殷勤。你想得到那个姑娘，这心愿蒙住了你的眼睛。见鬼！你可别没头没脑地乱撞。现在让我来掌舵吧，你可以在旁边帮腔。你认为堂堂一个法官犯得上不顾身份参与这样一桩——”
en: “You have said enough, nephew; you’ve shown enough devotion.Your desire to win the girl blinds you.The devil! You mustn’t go at it tooth and nail.Let me sail the ship now; you can haul on the braces.Do you think it right to compromise your dignity as a magistrate in such a—”

zh: 他停下来，因为他听见德格拉桑先生跟老箍桶匠边握手边说——
en: He stopped, for he heard Monsieur des Grassins saying to the old cooper as they shook hands,—

zh: “葛朗台，我们已经得知府上刚刚遭遇的不幸，令人震惊——令弟纪尧姆·葛朗台的商号破产和他的过世。我们特地前来对上述不幸事件表示哀悼。”
en: “Grandet, we have heard of the frightful misfortunes which have just befallen your family,—the failure of the house of Guillaume Grandet and the death of your brother.We have come to express our grief at these sad events.”

zh: “只有一件让人伤心的事，”公证人打断了银行家的话，说道，“小葛朗台先生的过世；如果他能及时想到向他哥哥求助，就决不会自杀的。我们的老朋友爱惜名誉爱到了指甲尖儿，打算清偿巴黎葛朗台商号的债务。为了让他省掉法律程序上麻烦，我的庭长侄子已经提议要去巴黎和债权人谈判，以求圆满解决。”
en: “There is but one sad event,” said the notary, interrupting the banker,—“the death of Monsieur Grandet, junior; and he would never have killed himself had he thought in time of applying to his brother for help.Our old friend, who is honorable to his finger-nails, intends to liquidate the debts of the Maison Grandet of Paris.To save him the worry of legal proceedings, my nephew, the president, has just offered to go to Paris and negotiate with the creditors for a satisfactory settlement.”

zh: 葛朗台的态度证实了这番话，他正默默站在那里摸着下巴，这令德格拉桑一行三人惊诧不已，他们一路来的时候，还在悠闲地谈论着那老头的贪婪，差不多要指控是他谋杀了他兄弟。
en: These words, corroborated by Grandet’s attitude as he stood silently nursing his chin, astonished the three des Grassins, who had been leisurely discussing the old man’s avarice as they came along, very nearly accusing him of fratricide.

zh: “啊！我早料到了，”银行家一边喊着，一边看着他的妻子，“我刚才跟你说什么了，德格拉桑太太？葛朗台爱惜名誉爱到家了，绝不允许他的名声有丝毫玷污！有钱而没有名誉就是一种病。外省就讲面子！对，很对，葛朗台。我是个老兵，我不会遮掩自己的想法，我就直说了。我的天！真是伟大！”
en: “Ah! I was sure of it,” cried the banker, looking at his wife.“What did I tell you just now, Madame des Grassins?Grandet is honorable to the backbone, and would never allow his name to remain under the slightest cloud!Money without honor is a disease.There is honor in the provinces!Right, very right, Grandet.I’m an old soldier, and I can’t disguise my thoughts; I speak roughly.Thunder! It is sublime!”

zh: “还-还有，伟-伟-伟大的事需要付出很-很-很大的代价。”当银行家热情地紧紧握住老头的手时，老头回答道。
en: “Th-then s-s-sublime th-things c-c-cost d-dear,” answered the goodman, as the banker warmly wrung his hand.

zh: “我亲爱的葛朗台，不过这——请庭长原谅——纯粹是商业上的事，需要一个精明的商人。您的代理人必须是个非常熟悉市场的人——熟悉付款、部分退款和利息计算等等。我有私事要去巴黎，我可以负责——”
en: “But this, my dear Grandet,—if the president will excuse me,—is a purely commercial matter, and needs a consummate businessman.Your agent must be some one fully acquainted with the markets,—with disbursements, rebates, interest calculations, and so forth.I am going to Paris on business of my own, and I can take charge of—”

zh: “咱-咱-咱们俩再看看怎-怎-怎么安-安-安排，在这-这-这种特-特-特殊的情况下，而-而-而又不用我应承我做-做-做不到的事，”葛朗台结结巴巴地说道，“您知道，因为庭长先生自然希望我来出这趟旅费。”
en: “We’ll see about t-t-trying to m-m-manage it b-b-between us, under the p-p-peculiar c-c-circumstances, b-b-but without b-b-binding m-m-myself to anything th-that I c-c-could not do,” said Grandet, stuttering, “because, you see, monsieur le president naturally expects me to pay the expenses of his journey.”

zh: 老头最后一句话没有打磕巴。
en: The goodman did not stammer over the last words.

zh: “啊！”德格拉桑太太喊起来，“去巴黎可是件愉快的事。就是自己掏腰包，我都愿意去呢。”
en: “Eh!” cried Madame des Grassins, “why it is a pleasure to go to Paris.I would willingly pay to go myself.”

zh: 她向她的丈夫示意了一下，好像在鼓励他不惜代价把这个差事从敌人手里抢过来；接着她带着讽刺的表情扫了扫那两位克吕绍，那二人看上去满脸沮丧。葛朗台抓住银行家的一个扣子，把他拽到屋子的一个角落。
en: She made a sign to her husband, as if to encourage him in cutting the enemy out of the commission, @coute que coute@; then she glanced ironically at the two Cruchots, who looked chap-fallen.Grandet seized the banker by a button and drew him into a corner of the room.

zh: “和庭长比起来，我更信任您，”他说，“而且，我另有更重要的事。”他抽动着他的肉瘤，补充道，“我想等公债八十法郎的时候，买上几千法郎的公债。我听人说，公债每个月底会跌价。您对这些事很在行，是不是？”
en: “I have a great deal more confidence in you than in the president,” he said, “besides, I’ve other fish to fry,” he added, wriggling his wen.“I want to buy a few thousand francs in the Funds while they are at eighty.They fall, I’m told, at the end of each month.You know all about these things, don’t you?”

zh: “我的天哪！那么，我每年都得投资足够多的钱，好让您收入几千法郎啰？”
en: “Bless me! Then, am I to invest enough to give you a few thousand francs a year?”

zh: “开始的时候不用太多。嘘！我不想让任何人知道我要搞这玩意。您可以月底投资买进。什么也不要对克吕绍家的人说，那会惹恼他们的。要是您真的要去巴黎，咱们就看看能为我可怜的侄儿做点什么。”
en: “That’s not much to begin with.Hush!I don’t want anyone to know I am going to play that game.You can make the investment by the end of the month.Say nothing to the Cruchots; that’ll annoy them.If you are really going to Paris, we will see if there is anything to be done for my poor nephew.”

zh: “好的，都说定了。我明天就坐驿车动身，”德格拉桑高声说道，“我会来听听您最后有什么要嘱咐的——您看几点合适呢？”
en: “Well, it’s all settled.I’ll start tomorrow by the mail-post,” said des Grassins aloud, “and I will come and take your last directions at—what hour will suit you?”

zh: “五点，晚饭前。”葛朗台一边说着，一边搓着手。
en: “Five o’clock, just before dinner,” said Grandet, rubbing his hands.

zh: 两家人又呆了一小会儿。停了片刻之后，德格拉桑拍拍葛朗台的肩膀，说道——
en: The two parties stayed on for a short time.Des Grassins said, after a pause, striking Grandet on the shoulder,—

zh: “有他这样的亲戚可真是件幸事。”
en: “It is a good thing to have a relation like him.”

zh: “是的，是的，虽然表面看不出，”葛朗台说，“我可是个好-好亲戚。我爱我的兄弟，我会证明这一点的，除非得花-花-花——”
en: “Yes, yes; without making a show,” said Grandet, “I am a g-good relation.I loved my brother, and I will prove it, unless it c-c-costs—”

zh: “我们得告辞了，葛朗台，”银行家不等他说完，就适时地打断了他，说道，“要是提早动身的话，我得马上安排一些事。”
en: “We must leave you, Grandet,” said the banker, interrupting him fortunately before he got to the end of his sentence.“If I hurry my departure, I must attend to some matters at once.”

zh: “非常好，非常好！我自己——因-因为我刚才跟-跟您谈的事——我得回我的房间‘仔-仔-仔细考虑’，照克吕绍庭长的说法。”
en: “Very good, very good!I myself—in c-consequence of what I t-told you—I must retire to my own room and ‘d-d-deliberate,’ as President Cruchot says.”

zh: “该死！我不再是德蓬丰先生了。”法官懊丧地想道，他脸上挂着的表情，就像法官被辩护词搞得不胜其烦一样。
en: “Plague take him!I am no longer Monsieur de Bonfons,” thought the magistrate ruefully, his face assuming the expression of a judge bored by an argument.

zh: 两家人一起离开了。双方不再去想葛朗台早上背叛整个葡萄种植业的罪恶行径了，彼此都想刺探出对方是怎么看待那个狡猾的老头在新近这件事中的真实意图，可是却徒劳无获。
en: The heads of the two factions walked off together.Neither gave any further thought to the treachery Grandet had been guilty of in the morning against the whole wine-growing community; each tried to fathom what the other was thinking about the real intentions of the wily old man in this new affair, but in vain.

zh: “您要不要跟我们一起去多尔松瓦太太家？”德格拉桑对公证人说。
en: “Will you go with us to Madame Dorsonval’s?” said des Grassins to the notary.

zh: “我们过会儿再去，”庭长回答，“我已经答应去德格里博古小姐那里道个晚安，要是我叔叔愿意的话，我们要先去那里。”
en: “We will go there later,” answered the president.“I have promised to say good-evening to Mademoiselle de Gribeaucourt, and we will go there first, if my uncle is willing.”

zh: “那现在就道别了！”德格拉桑太太说。
en: “Farewell for the present!” said Madame des Grassins.

zh: 克吕绍二人走开几步后，阿道夫对他父亲说——
en: When the Cruchots were a few steps off, Adolphe remarked to his father,—

zh: “他们没气得冒了烟吧，嗯？”
en: “Are not they fuming, hein?”

zh: “闭上你的嘴，儿子！”他母亲说道，“他们会听见的。而且，你说的话很没品味——法学院的腔调。”
en: “Hold your tongue, my son!” said his mother, “they might hear you.Besides, what you say is not in good taste,—law-school language.”

zh: “好的，叔叔,”当看到德格拉桑一家的身影消失后，庭长喊道，“我开始是德蓬丰，最后就只是克吕绍了。”
en: “Well, uncle,” cried the president when he saw the des Grassins disappearing, “I began by being de Bonfons, and I have ended as nothing but Cruchot.”

zh: “我看出来那让你不高兴，但是风向对德格拉桑家有利。你可真是聪明一世，糊涂一时！让他们上葛朗台‘咱们以后再谈’的贼船吧，镇定些，年轻人。欧仁妮终究会是你的妻子。”
en: “I saw that that annoyed you; but the wind has set fair for the des Grassins.What a fool you are, with all your cleverness!Let them sail off on Grandet’s ‘We’ll see about it,’ and keep yourself quiet, young man.Eugenie will none the less be your wife.”

zh: 过了一会儿，葛朗台做出高尚决定的消息同时在三家传开了，整个城里都开始谈论他手足情深的义举。大家原谅了葛朗台破坏业界誓约而私自出售的事；他们赞赏他的荣誉感，开始称赞他的慷慨，他们从没有想到他能这样去做。法国人的部分本性就是对昙花一现的事时而热衷，时而愤怒，时而热诚。是不是群众、民族和国民都缺乏记性呢？
en: In a few moments the news of Grandet’s magnanimous resolve was disseminated in three houses at the same moment, and the whole town began to talk of his fraternal devotion.Every one forgave Grandet for the sale made in defiance of the good faith pledged to the community; they admired his sense of honor, and began to laud a generosity of which they had never thought him capable.It is part of the French nature to grow enthusiastic, or angry, or fervent about some meteor of the moment.Can it be that collective beings, nationalities, peoples, are devoid of memory?

zh: 葛朗台老头一关上门，就喊娜农。
en: When Pere Grandet had shut the door he called Nanon.

zh: “别放狗，也别上床睡觉，我们有事要一起干。科努瓦耶从弗罗瓦丰赶马车来，十一点将会到门口。听着他的动静，别让他敲门，告诉他进的时候轻点。警察局规定禁止夜间喧哗。再说，左邻右舍没必要知道我准备出门这件事。”
en: “Don’t let the dog loose, and don’t go to bed; we have work to do together.At eleven o’clock Cornoiller will be at the door with the chariot from Froidfond.Listen for him and prevent his knocking; tell him to come in softly.Police regulations don’t allow nocturnal racket.Besides, the whole neighborhood need not know that I am starting on a journey.”

zh: 说完，葛朗台回到了他的密室。尽管他非常小心，娜农还是听见他在里面又是走动，又是翻找东西，走来走去。他显然是不想吵醒他的妻子和女儿，尤其是不想引起他侄子的注意。当他看见侄子房门下透出的灯光时，他早已开始诅咒侄子了。差不多半夜时，欧仁妮一心惦记着她的堂弟，觉得好像听见了一声哭叫，像是快要死的人发出的声音。她想，那一定是夏尔；她看他最后一眼时，他脸色那么苍白，绝望透顶——他可能已经自杀了？她很快披了一件宽松的衣服——一种有风帽的披风——正要出房间时，一道强光从门缝射了进来，她以为是着了火。可是当听到娜农沉重的脚步声与嘶哑的说话声，中间还夹杂着几匹马的嘶叫声时，她放心了。
en: So saying, Grandet returned to his private room, where Nanon heard him moving about, rummaging, and walking to and fro, though with much precaution, for he evidently did not wish to wake his wife and daughter, and above all not to rouse the attention of his nephew, whom he had begun to anathematize when he saw a thread of light under his door.About the middle of the night Eugenie, intent on her cousin, fancied she heard a cry like that of a dying person.It must be Charles, she thought; he was so pale, so full of despair when she had seen him last,—could he have killed himself?She wrapped herself quickly in a loose garment,—a sort of pelisse with a hood,—and was about to leave the room when a bright light coming through the chinks of her door made her think of fire.But she recovered herself as she heard Nanon’s heavy steps and gruff voice mingling with the snorting of several horses.

zh: “难道我父亲在弄走我的堂弟？”她一边边自言自语，一边非常小心地开了房门，以免发出声响，只开到正好能看得见走廊里。
en: “Can my father be carrying off my cousin?” she said to herself, opening her door with great precaution lest it should creak, and yet enough to let her see into the corridor.

zh: 突然，她的目光碰上了她父亲的目光，父亲的目光尽管茫然，也没有注意到什么，还是把她吓坏了。老头和娜农两人一起抬着一根粗棍子，棍子两头搭在他们的肩膀上；一条结实的绳子拴在棍子上，上面吊着一个小木桶或是小钢桶，很像葛朗台老头闲着没事时在面包房里做的那些桶。
en: Suddenly her eye encountered that of her father; and his glance, vague and unnoticing as it was, terrified her.The goodman and Nanon were yoked together by a stout stick, each end of which rested on their shoulders; a stout rope was passed over it, on which was slung a small barrel or keg like those Pere Grandet still made in his bakehouse as an amusement for his leisure hours.

zh: “圣母玛利亚，这可真重呀！”娜农说道。
en: “Holy Virgin, how heavy it is!” said the voice of Nanon.

zh: “可惜只是些铜钱！”葛朗台答道，“小心，你别把烛台碰翻。”
en: “What a pity that it is only copper sous!” answered Grandet.“Take care you don’t knock over the candlestick.”

zh: 这个场景只靠一支蜡烛照明，那蜡烛放在楼梯的两根栏杆之间。
en: The scene was lighted by a single candle placed between two rails of the staircase.

zh: “科努瓦耶，”葛朗台对他那个有名无实的田庄看管人说道，“你带手枪了吗？”
en: “Cornoiller,” said Grandet to his keeper @in partibus@, “have you brought your pistols?”

zh: “没有，先生。哦！对您的那些铜钱有什么可担心的？”
en: “No, monsieur.Mercy! What’s there to fear for your copper sous?”

zh: “哦！没什么。”葛朗台老头说。
en: “Oh! Nothing,” said Pere Grandet.

zh: “再说，咱们会跑得很快，”那个人又说道，“您的佃户挑的是他们最好的马。”
en: “Besides, we shall go fast,” added the man, “your farmers have picked out their best horses.”

zh: “很好。你没告诉他们我要去哪里吧？”
en: “Very good.You did not tell them where I was going?”

zh: “我不知道去哪里。”
en: “I didn’t know where.”

zh: “很好。车子结实吗？”
en: “Very good.Is the carriage strong?”

zh: “结实？嗨，听这话说的！嘿，它能装三千斤。那个破桶有多重？”
en: “Strong? Hear to that, now!Why, it can carry three thousand weight.How much does that old keg weigh?”

zh: “天哪！”娜农惊呼道，“我可知道！基本差不多有一千八百——”
en: “Goodness!” exclaimed Nanon.“I ought to know!There’s pretty nigh eighteen hundred—”

zh: “能不能闭上你的嘴，娜农！你告诉我太太，说我去乡下了。我会回来吃晚饭的。车赶得快点，科努瓦耶，我九点前必须赶到昂热。”
en: “Will you hold your tongue, Nanon!You are to tell my wife I have gone into the country.I shall be back to dinner.Drive fast, Cornoiller; I must get to Angers before nine o’clock.”

zh: 马车走了。娜农闩上大门，放出狗，带着肿痛的肩膀去睡觉了。街坊四邻没有一个人知道葛朗台走的事，也不知道他此行的目的。老守财奴的谨慎和缄默一刻也没有放松过。尽管屋子里堆满了金子，可是谁也没见过一个子儿。早上，这个老葡萄园主从码头人们的闲谈中听说，由于南特在进行某些军需准备，黄金汇率已经翻了一番，投机商们已经赶到昂热去收购金币了，这个老葡萄种植商便急忙从佃户那里借来了马匹，抓住机会要把他的金子卖掉，再换回国库券，经此交易，这笔款子的数额已剧增，他打算用来买进公债。
en: The carriage drove off.Nanon bolted the great door, let loose the dog, and went off to bed with a bruised shoulder, no one in the neighborhood suspecting either the departure of Grandet or the object of his journey.The precautions of the old miser and his reticence were never relaxed.No one had ever seen a penny in that house, filled as it was with gold.Hearing in the morning, through the gossip of the port, that exchange on gold had doubled in price in consequence of certain military preparations undertaken at Nantes, and that speculators had arrived at Angers to buy coin, the old wine-grower, by the simple process of borrowing horses from his farmers, seized the chance of selling his gold and of bringing back in the form of treasury notes the sum he intended to put into the Funds, having swelled it considerably by the exchange.

zh: 第八章
en: Chapter VIII

zh: “我父亲走了。”欧仁妮心想，她在楼梯顶部听到了所发生的一切。屋子又恢复了寂静；远处马车的隆隆声渐渐消失了，不再在这个沉睡的城市里回荡了。这时，欧仁妮耳朵还没听到，就先在心里听见了一声哭喊，那哭喊声从她堂弟的卧室穿过隔墙传了过来。一道像马刀刀刃一样细的光从门缝射出来，横照在破旧的楼梯的扶手上。
en: “My father has gone,” thought Eugenie, who heard all that took place from the head of the stairs.Silence was restored in the house, and the distant rumbling of the carriage, ceasing by degrees, no longer echoed through the sleeping town.At this moment Eugenie heard in her heart, before the sound caught her ears, a cry which pierced the partitions and came from her cousin’s chamber.A line of light, thin as the blade of a sabre, shone through a chink in the door and fell horizontally on the balusters of the rotten staircase.

zh: “他很难受！”她一边往楼上跑，一边说。听到第二声呻吟时，她已跑到了靠近他房间的楼梯口。门虚掩着，她推开了门。夏尔正睡着，他的头垂在旧扶手椅的一侧，一只手几乎触到了地板，笔已从那只手里掉了下来。这种不舒服的姿势造成他呼吸困难，这让欧仁妮突然害怕起来，她赶紧进了屋子。
en: “He suffers!” she said, springing up the stairs.A second moan brought her to the landing near his room.The door was ajar, she pushed it open.Charles was sleeping; his head hung over the side of the old armchair, and his hand, from which the pen had fallen, nearly touched the floor.The oppressed breathing caused by the strained posture suddenly frightened Eugenie, who entered the room hastily.

zh: “他一定很累。”她自言自语道，瞥见了桌子上放着的十几封已封好的信。她看看信上的地址：
en: “He must be very tired,” she said to herself, glancing at a dozen letters lying sealed upon the table.She read their addresses:

zh: “法里、布雷依曼车行收”；“比松裁缝店收”等等。
en: “To Messrs. Farry, Breilmann, & Co., carriage-makers”; “To Monsieur Buisson, tailor,” etc.

zh: “他一直在处理他的事情，这样就能马上离开法国了。”她想。她的眼睛落在两封打开的信上。信里写道：“我亲爱的安妮特，”一看其中一封的开头，她的两眼瞬间就发黑了。她的心跳加速，脚像被钉在了地板上一样。
en: “He has been settling all his affairs, so as to leave France at once,” she thought.Her eyes fell upon two open letters.The words, “My dear Annette,” at the head of one of them, blinded her for a moment.Her heart beat fast, her feet were nailed to the floor.

zh: “他亲爱的安妮特！他在恋爱！有人爱着他！没有希望了！他对她说了什么？”
en: “His dear Annette!He loves! He is loved!No hope!What does he say to her?”

zh: 这些念头从她的脑海和心里闪过。她到处都能看见这些像火焰一样的字，甚至地板砖上都有。
en: These thoughts rushed through her head and heart.She saw the words everywhere, even on the bricks of the floor, in letters of fire.

zh: “就这样放弃他？不，不！我不看这封信。我应该走开——我要是看了会怎样呢？”
en: “Resign him already?No, no!I will not read the letter.I ought to go away—What if I do read it?”

zh: 她看着夏尔，然后温柔地把他的头托起，并将其靠在椅背上；他任由她摆布着，就像一个孩子，尽管睡着，也知道那是他母亲的爱抚，便继续在梦乡里享受着她的亲吻和小心的呵护。欧仁妮就像母亲一样，拿起他垂下的手，像母亲一样温柔地亲吻着他那栗色的头发——“亲爱的安妮特！”一个魔鬼在她耳边尖声叫着这几个字眼。
en: She looked at Charles, then she gently took his head and placed it against the back of the chair; he let her do so, like a child which, though asleep, knows its mother’s touch and receives, without awaking, her kisses and watchful care.Like a mother Eugenie raised the drooping hand, and like a mother she gently kissed the chestnut hair—“Dear Annette!” a demon shrieked the words in her ear.

zh: “我这么做不对，可是我必须看那封信。”她说。她扭过头去，因为她高尚的正义感在谴责她。生平第一次，善与恶一起在她心里挣扎。直到那一刻，她还从来没有做过任何让她脸红的事。强烈的爱和好奇心胜利了。她一句一句读着，情绪越来越激动，看信时溢满全身的炙热只能让这初恋的快乐变得更加珍贵。
en: “I am doing wrong; but I must read it, that letter,” she said.She turned away her head, for her noble sense of honor reproached her.For the first time in her life good and evil struggled together in her heart.Up to that moment she had never had to blush for any action.Passion and curiosity triumphed.As she read each sentence her heart swelled more and more, and the keen glow which filled her being as she did so, only made the joys of first love still more precious.

zh: 我亲爱的安妮特——除了我现在遭遇的这巨大不幸——这是任何人都无法预料到的——什么也不能把我们分开。我父亲自杀了，他的财产和我的财产都荡然无存，不可挽回了。我这个年龄就成了孤儿，以我所受的教育性质而言，我这个年纪还算是个孩子，但是我必须像个男子汉一样，从我身陷的深渊中爬起来。我刚花了半个晚上的时间琢磨我的处境。
en: My dear Annette,—Nothing could ever have separated us but the great misfortune which has now overwhelmed me, and which no human foresight could have prevented.My father has killed himself; his fortune and mine are irretrievably lost.I am orphaned at an age when, through the nature of my education, I am still a child; and yet I must lift myself as a man out of the abyss into which I am plunged.I have just spent half the night in facing my position.

zh: 如果我希望以一个正人君子的身份离开法国——这一点是毫无疑问的——去西印度群岛或美洲碰碰运气，我连一百法郎都没有。是的，我可怜的安娜，我必须要在那种恶劣的气候条件下寻找发财的机会。他们告诉我，在那些地方，我肯定能成功。至于说继续留在巴黎，我是做不到的。无论我的本性，还是我的脸面，都受不了别人对一个倾家荡产的人——一个破产者的儿子所表示出的那种轻蔑、冷漠和鄙薄！老天啊！想想吧，竟然欠了两百万！我第一个星期就会在决斗中被人杀死，因此我是不会回去的。你的爱——最温柔、最忠贞的爱，曾经使一个男人的心灵得到升华——也是无法把我拉回去的。唉！我的心上人，
en: If I wish to leave France an honest man,—and there is no doubt of that,—I have not a hundred francs of my own with which to try my fate in the Indies or in America.Yes, my poor Anna, I must seek my fortune in those deadly climates.Under those skies, they tell me, I am sure to make it.As for remaining in Paris, I cannot do so.Neither my nature nor my face are made to bear the affronts, the neglect, the disdain shown to a ruined man, the son of a bankrupt!Good God! Think of owing two millions!I should be killed in a duel the first week; therefore I shall not return there.Your love—the most tender and devoted love which ever ennobled the heart of man—cannot draw me back.Alas! My beloved,

zh: 我没钱去找你，好给你最后一吻，或接受你的最后一吻，从亲吻中，我可能会为我那几乎没有成功希望的事业汲取一些力量。
en: I have no money with which to go to you, to give and receive a last kiss from which I might derive some strength for my forlorn enterprise.

zh: “可怜的夏尔！幸亏我读了这封信。我有金子，我会给他的。”欧仁妮心想。
en: “Poor Charles!I did well to read the letter.I have gold; I will give it to him,” thought Eugenie.

zh: 她擦擦眼睛，继续往下看。
en: She wiped her eyes, and went on reading.

zh: 我从没想过贫困的悲惨。我即使有了一百金路易用作必不可少的旅行费，也没有一个子儿用来做本钱。可是，没有，我没有那一百个金路易，甚至连一个都没有。我不知道等我把巴黎的债全都还清后，还能剩下什么。如果我身无分文，我会一声不响地去南特，上船当个普通的水手；我会像其他那些年轻时白手起家的人一样，开始在新世界闯荡，从西印度群岛赚回大笔的财富。在这漫长的一天中，我冷静地考虑了我的前途。我的前途似乎比别人的都更可怕，因为我曾被疼爱我的母亲宠爱过，受过最慈祥的父亲的溺爱，刚一踏入社会，又幸运地得到了一位叫安娜的女士的爱情！我所知道的就只是生活中的鲜花。这样的幸福不可能长久。
en: I have never thought of the miseries of poverty.If I have the hundred louis required for the mere costs of the journey, I have not a sou for an outfit.But no, I have not the hundred louis, not even one louis.I don’t know that anything will be left after I have paid my debts in Paris.If I have nothing, I shall go quietly to Nantes and ship as a common sailor; and I will begin in the new world like other men who have started young without a sou and brought back the wealth of the Indies.During this long day I have faced my future coolly.It seems more horrible for me than for another, because I have been so petted by a mother who adored me, so indulged by the kindest of fathers, so blessed by meeting, on my entrance into life, with the love of an Anna!The flowers of life are all I have ever known.Such happiness could not last.

zh: 可是，我亲爱的安妮特，我感觉有了更多的勇气，超过了一个无忧无虑的年轻人应该有的——尤其是一个习惯了巴黎最迷人的女人的爱抚、享尽家庭幸福的年轻人，他在家里事事顺心，父亲对他则是有求必应——哦，我的父亲呀！安妮特，他死了！
en: Nevertheless, my dear Annette, I feel more courage than a careless young man is supposed to feel,—above all a young man used to the caressing ways of the dearest woman in all Paris, cradled in family joys, on whom all things smiled in his home, whose wishes were a law to his father—oh, my father!Annette, he is dead!

zh: 唉，我反复考虑了我的处境，还有你的处境。一天之内，我就变老了。亲爱的安娜，如果让我和你一起留在巴黎，你就要放弃你的奢华、你的衣着、你的歌剧院包厢，我们甚至都没有足够的钱来维持我挥霍的生活。再说，我决不会让你放弃这些的。不，咱们现在就得永别了——
en: Well, I have thought over my position, and yours as well.I have grown old in twenty-four hours.Dear Anna, if in order to keep me with you in Paris you were to sacrifice your luxury, your dress, your opera-box, we should even then not have enough for the expenses of my extravagant ways of living.Besides, I would never accept such sacrifices.No, we must part now and forever—

zh: “他放弃了她！圣母玛利亚！太幸福了！”
en: “He gives her up!Blessed Virgin!What happiness!”

zh: 欧仁妮高兴得直发抖。夏尔动了一下，吓得她浑身一阵寒战。所幸，他没有醒来，于是她接着看下去。
en: Eugenie quivered with joy.Charles made a movement, and a chill of terror ran through her.Fortunately, he did not wake, and she resumed her reading.

zh: 我什么时候会回来？我不知道。据他们说，西印度群岛的气候会让一个欧洲人变老，尤其是一个辛苦劳作的欧洲人。让我们想想十年后可能会发生什么吧。十年后，你的女儿就十八岁了，她将成为你的伙伴，你的密探。对你来说，社会将是残酷的，而你的女儿也许更为残酷。严厉的社会评判和女儿们忘恩负义的例子屡见不鲜，我们要引以为戒。请像我一样，把这四年幸福的回忆珍藏在你的心灵深处吧，再有，如果可能的话，一定要将你这可怜的朋友铭记在心，并对他忠诚不渝。你知道吗，亲爱的安妮特，我不能强求这份忠诚，因为我必须适应我新生活中的种种突变；我必须用平常的眼光来看待它们，并尽力而为。所以我必须考虑结婚，这成了我未来生活中一件必须做的事；我要向你承认，就在索米尔这里，在我伯父的家中，我遇到了一位堂姐，她的容貌、举止、头脑和心地都会让你喜欢的，而且在我看来，她似乎——
en: When shall I return?I do not know.The climate of the West Indies ages a European, so they say, especially a European who works hard.Let us think what may happen ten years hence.In ten years your daughter will be eighteen; she will be your companion, your spy.To you society will be cruel, and your daughter perhaps more cruel still.We have seen cases of the harsh social judgment and ingratitude of daughters; let us take warning by them.Keep in the depths of your soul, as I shall in mine, the memory of four years of happiness, and be faithful, if you can, to the memory of your poor friend.I cannot exact such faithfulness, because, do you see, dear Annette, I must conform to the exigencies of my new life; I must take a commonplace view of them and do the best I can.Therefore I must think of marriage, which becomes one of the necessities of my future existence; and I will admit to you that I have found, here in Saumur, in my uncle’s house, a cousin whose face, manners, mind, and heart would please you, and who, besides, seems to me—

zh: “他一定是太累了，才停下笔来。”当欧仁妮看到信的最后一句话戛然停到半中间时，心里这样想。
en: “He must have been very weary to have ceased writing to her,” thought Eugenie, as she gazed at the letter which stopped abruptly in the middle of the last sentence.

zh: 她已经在为他辩护了。一个天真无邪的姑娘怎么可能察觉出信中所流露的冷漠无情呢？对于在宗教气氛中长大的少女来说，她们的思想无知而纯洁，一旦涉足那迷人的爱情世界，便把一切都看作爱情了。她们漫步其中，沐浴在天国的光辉里，这圣光从她们的灵魂中散发出来，又映照到她们所爱的人身上；她们用自己感情的火焰点燃一切，并把自己崇高的思想归于爱人的功劳。一个女人的错误几乎总是来自于她对善的信仰或是她对真理的信任。“我亲爱的安妮特，我的心上人”这几个字就像是爱情最甜美的语言，在欧仁妮单纯的内心里回响着；它们轻抚着她的心灵，仿佛儿时听的“来吧，让我们一起赞美”，那美妙的音符被风琴反复弹奏着，悦耳动听。而且，仍旧挂在那个年轻人睫毛上的泪水显示出了那种心灵的高贵，少女们自然而然会为之动情。夏尔尽管爱着他的父亲并真诚地在悼念他，这与其说是出于他的心地善良，倒不如说是为父爱所感动，她又怎么会知道这个呢？纪尧姆·葛朗台先生和夫人总是满足儿子的所有愿望，给他大笔的钱财去随意挥霍，使得夏尔不会去做些可怕的算计，这是巴黎很多的少爷们或多或少都会有的罪孽。那些少爷们在面对花花世界时，他们便产生了欲念，心怀鬼胎。他们痛苦地看到，在父母的有生之年，这些欲念和阴谋都必须推后或暂时放到一边。
en: Already she defended him.How was it possible that an innocent girl should perceive the cold-heartedness evinced by this letter?To young girls religiously brought up, whose minds are ignorant and pure, all is love from the moment they set their feet within the enchanted regions of that passion.They walk there bathed in a celestial light shed from their own souls, which reflects its rays upon their lover; they color all with the flame of their own emotion and attribute to him their highest thoughts.A woman’s errors come almost always from her belief in good or her confidence in truth.In Eugenie’s simple heart the words, “My dear Annette, my loved one,” echoed like the sweetest language of love; they caressed her soul as, in childhood, the divine notes of the @Venite adoremus@, repeated by the organ, caressed her ear.Moreover, the tears which still lingered on the young man’s lashes gave signs of that nobility of heart by which young girls are rightly won.How could she know that Charles, though he loved his father and mourned him truly, was moved far more by paternal goodness than by the goodness of his own heart?Monsieur and Madame Guillaume Grandet, by gratifying every fancy of their son, and lavishing upon him the pleasures of a large fortune, had kept him from making the horrible calculations of which so many sons in Paris become more or less guilty when, face to face with the enjoyments of the world, they form desires and conceive schemes which they see with bitterness must be put off or laid aside during the lifetime of their parents.

zh: 在这种情况下，父亲的慷慨在儿子的心中撒下了真爱，这真爱中没有任何自私自利、有所保留的念头。
en: The liberality of the father in this instance had shed into the heart of the son a real love, in which there was no afterthought of self-interest.

zh: 可是，夏尔是个真正的巴黎孩子，在社会风气和安妮特亲身的调教下，他凡事都要盘算一番，虽然脸上还洋溢着年轻气，但他已经是个世故的人了。他曾经历过社会生活的可怕教育，在那个社会生活圈子里，一个晚上，在思想和言语上所犯的罪比法官在巡回审判庭所判罚的罪行还要多；打趣和俏皮话在诋毁最高尚的思想；只有目光准确的人才可谓强者：在那个圈子里，目光准确就是一概不信，既不相信感情，也不相信人，甚至也不相信事实——因为事实是捏造的。
en: Nevertheless, Charles was a true child of Paris, taught by the customs of society and by Annette herself to calculate everything; already an old man under the mask of youth.He had gone through the frightful education of social life, of that world where in one evening more crimes are committed in thought and speech than justice ever punishes at the assizes; where jests and clever sayings assassinate the noblest ideas; where no one is counted strong unless his mind sees clear: and to see clear in that world is to believe in nothing, neither in feelings, nor in men, nor even in events,—for events are falsified.

zh: 在那个圈子里，要想“目光准确”，我们就必须每天都掂掂朋友钱包的分量，学会如何巧妙地使自己保持上风；还要谨慎小心，不赞赏任何东西，不管是艺术作品，还是值得称颂的行为；并牢记自身的利益是尘世间一切事物的主要动力。在数番风流放纵之后，那个贵妇——美丽的安妮特——迫使夏尔进行了认真的思考；她把散发着香气的手放进他的卷发，跟他谈论着他将来的地位；当她重新梳理他的一绺绺头发时，她教给他精明处世的经验；她使他变得女性化、物质化——这是一种双重的腐蚀，却又是一种细腻而优雅的腐蚀，十分高雅得体。
en: There, to “see clear” we must weigh a friend’s purse daily, learn how to keep ourselves adroitly on the top of the wave, cautiously admire nothing, neither works of art nor glorious actions, and remember that self-interest is the mainspring of all things here below.After committing many follies, the great lady—the beautiful Annette—compelled Charles to think seriously; with her perfumed hand among his curls, she talked to him of his future position; as she rearranged his locks, she taught him lessons of worldly prudence; she made him effeminate and materialized him,—a double corruption, but a delicate and elegant corruption, in the best taste.

zh: “你很傻，夏尔，”她会对他说，“我得费好大劲来教你懂得世道。你对德吕伯克斯先生的态度很糟糕。我很清楚他不是个正人君子，可是你得等到他失势的时候，才可以随心所欲地鄙薄他。你知道康庞夫人是怎么对我们说的？——‘亲爱的，只要一个人还在台上，就敬爱他；等他下了台，就帮着把他拖到阴沟里。有权时，他是个神；倒台时，他比阴沟里的马拉还要低等，因为他还活着，而马拉死了。人生就是一系列的暗码，要想使自己一直处于有利的位置，你就必须研究它们，理解它们。’”
en: “You are very foolish, Charles,” she would say to him.“I shall have a great deal of trouble in teaching you to understand the world.You behaved extremely ill to Monsieur des Lupeaulx.I know very well he is not an honorable man; but wait till he is no longer in power, then you may despise him as much as you like.Do you know what Madame Campan used to tell us?—‘My dears, as long as a man is a minister, adore him; when he falls, help to drag him in the gutter.Powerful, he is a sort of god; fallen, he is lower than Marat in the sewer, because he is living, and Marat is dead.Life is a series of combinations, and you must study them and understand them if you want to keep yourselves always in good position.’”

zh: 夏尔老于世故，他的父母让他过得太幸福了，在社交中，他又曾受到太多的阿谀奉承，他是不会拥有高尚的情感的。母亲在他心中播下的金粒子已经在巴黎社会的锻造中被敲打得薄之又薄。他把金子撒在表面，而金子在生活的摩擦下被慢慢磨蚀掉了。夏尔只有二十一岁。在这个年纪，青春的朝气似乎和心灵的直率和真诚是分不开的。那声音、那目光、那面容本身似乎都是和感情协调一致的。所以即使是最严厉的法官、最不轻信的律师、最不通融的高利贷者都总是不会贸然相信：一个人的眼睛仍旧明亮清澈，额头也没有一道皱纹，内心却老于世故或是心术不正。迄今为止，夏尔还没有机会去应用巴黎式的道德准则。直至此时，他的美还美在缺乏经验。然而，他不知不觉就已经被灌输了自私的思想。巴黎人政治经济的胚芽在他心里潜伏着，一旦悠然自得的旁观者变成了现实生活戏剧中的演员，迟早那胚芽一定会开花的。
en: Charles was too much a man of the world, his parents had made him too happy, he had received too much adulation in society, to be possessed of noble sentiments.The grain of gold dropped by his mother into his heart was beaten thin in the smithy of Parisian society; he had spread it superficially, and it was worn away by the friction of life.Charles was only twenty-one years old.At that age the freshness of youth seems inseparable from candor and sincerity of soul.The voice, the glance, the face itself, seem in harmony with the feelings; and thus it happens that the sternest judge, the most sceptical lawyer, the least complying of usurers, always hesitate to admit decrepitude of heart or the corruption of worldly calculation while the eyes are still bathed in purity and no wrinkles seam the brow.Charles, so far, had had no occasion to apply the maxims of Parisian morality; up to this time he was still endowed with the beauty of inexperience.And yet, unknown to himself, he had been inoculated with selfishness.The germs of Parisian political economy, latent in his heart, would assuredly burst forth, sooner or later, whenever the careless spectator became an actor in the drama of real life.

zh: 几乎所有的少女都会被这种外表所预示的温柔所迷惑：即使欧仁妮也像外省姑娘一样谨慎，并且善于察言观色，但是在堂弟的举止、言辞及行为还和年轻人内心的憧憬相一致的时候，她是不可能怀疑他的。只是一个偶然的机会——一个致命的机会——让她看到了激荡在那个年轻人心中的最后一次真情流露；她似乎听到了他良心最后的呼吸声。她把那封在她看来情意绵绵的信放下，开始微笑着端详起她熟睡的堂弟；至少在她眼里，对人生充满朝气的幻想依旧还停留在他的脸上；她暗暗发誓要永远爱他。接着，她把目光投向另外一封信，不再觉得这第二次鲁莽之举有多么严重了；尽管她在看着信，但她唯一的目的却是为了找到品格高尚的新证据，像所有女人一样，她认为这是她心仪的男人所具有的品质。
en: Nearly all young girls succumb to the tender promises such an outward appearance seems to offer: even if Eugenie had been as prudent and observing as provincial girls are often found to be, she was not likely to distrust her cousin when his manners, words, and actions were still in unison with the aspirations of a youthful heart.A mere chance—a fatal chance—threw in her way the last effusions of real feeling which stirred the young man’s soul; she heard as it were the last breathings of his conscience.She laid down the letter—to her so full of love—and began smilingly to watch her sleeping cousin; the fresh illusions of life were still, for her at least, upon his face; she vowed to herself to love him always.Then she cast her eyes on the other letter, without attaching much importance to this second indiscretion; and though she read it, it was only to obtain new proofs of the noble qualities which, like all women, she attributed to the man her heart had chosen.

zh: 我亲爱的阿方斯——当你收到这封信时，我已经没有朋友了；可是我向你保证，尽管我怀疑这世上的友谊，却从没有怀疑过你的友情。因此，我求你来料理我的所有事情，并且指望你竭尽所能把我的财物卖个好价。现在，你已经知道了我的处境。我一无所有，打算马上去印度。我已经写信给所有我认为是债主的人，你会看到随信附上的名单，凭记忆我尽量做到准确无误。我想，我的书籍、我的家具、我的画、我的马匹等等，应该可以抵清我的债务。也许，除了一些可以用作我创业本钱的小玩意儿，我不想保留任何东西。我亲爱的阿方斯，我将给你邮寄一份正式授权书，你可以凭此出售这些东西。请将我所有的武器都寄给我。你留着布里顿吧，没有人会为那匹骏马出高价的，所以我宁可把它给了你——好像一个临死之人把纪念死者的戒指赠予遗嘱执行人一样。法里、布雷依曼车行给我造了一量非常舒适的旅行马车，他们还没有送货；请说服他们将车留下，别要我作任何赔付。如果他们拒绝了，尽你所能去处理吧，以我目前的处境，有损名誉之事应尽量避免。我欠那个英国岛民六个金路易，我打牌输的，别忘了还他——
en: My dear Alphonse,—When you receive this letter I shall be without friends; but let me assure you that while I doubt the friendship of the world, I have never doubted yours.I beg you therefore to settle all my affairs, and I trust to you to get as much as you can out of my possessions.By this time you know my situation.I have nothing left, and I intend to go at once to the Indies.I have just written to all the people to whom I think I owe money, and you will find enclosed a list of their names, as correct as I can make it from memory.My books, my furniture, my pictures, my horses, etc., ought, I think, to pay my debts.I do not wish to keep anything, except, perhaps, a few baubles which might serve as the beginning of an outfit for my enterprise.My dear Alphonse, I will send you a proper power of attorney under which you can make these sales.Send me all my weapons.Keep Briton for yourself; nobody would pay the value of that noble beast, and I would rather give him to you—like a mourning-ring bequeathed by a dying man to his executor.Farry, Breilmann, & Co. built me a very comfortable travelling-carriage, which they have not yet delivered; persuade them to keep it and not ask for any payment on it.If they refuse, do what you can in the matter, and avoid everything that might seem dishonorable in me under my present circumstances.I owe the British Islander six louis, which I lost at cards; don’t fail to pay him—

zh: “亲爱的堂弟！”欧仁妮一边悄声说着，一边扔下信，轻手轻脚地跑回自己的房间，拿起了一支点燃的蜡烛。当她打开一个旧橡木柜的抽屉时，一阵愉悦的兴奋感传遍了她的全身。那柜子是文艺复兴时期的精品，尽管有部分磨损，上面仍旧可以看见著名的蝾螈王室的徽号。她从抽屉里拿出一个带金坠子的红丝绒大钱袋，边上是失去光泽的金线流苏——那是她祖母留下一个遗物。她骄傲地把它放在手里掂掂分量，兴冲冲地开始数起她那很少的私房钱来，她已经忘了数目是多少了。她先拿出二十枚葡萄牙金币，仍旧很新，一七二五年约翰五世在位时铸造，按她父亲告诉她的，兑换率是每枚五葡币，或是每枚一百六十八法郎六十四生丁；不过，因为这些硬币稀少而且漂亮，闪着小太阳似的光泽，它们的常规市价是一枚一百八十法郎。其次，五枚各值一百法郎的热那亚金币，是另一种非常稀罕的硬币，市值八十七法郎，而收藏家出价是一百法郎。这些东西过去都是属于老德拉贝尔特利耶先生的。其次，三枚一七二九年菲利普五世时铸造的西班牙金币，是让蒂耶夫人一枚一枚交给她的，当让蒂耶夫人赠送礼物的时候，总是用相同的字眼说道：“这个可爱的小金丝雀，这个黄澄澄的小东西，值九十八法郎呢！收着它，我的好乖乖，它将来就是你金库里的一宝。”其次（这些硬币中的纯金，二十三克拉挂零，是她父亲最珍视的），一百枚荷兰达克特，一七五六年铸造，每枚值十三法郎。其次，一批罕见的古玩，是守财奴们最珍爱的一种纪念章——三枚卢比刻有天平图案，五枚卢比刻着圣母像，全是二十四克拉的纯金，是莫卧儿大帝时的精美钱币，每一枚仅按重量算就值三十七法郎四十生丁，但对喜欢玩赏金币的行家来说，至少值五十法郎。
en: “Dear cousin!” whispered Eugenie, throwing down the letter and running softly back to her room, carrying one of the lighted candles.A thrill of pleasure passed over her as she opened the drawer of an old oak cabinet, a fine specimen of the period called the Renaissance, on which could still be seen, partly effaced, the famous royal salamander.She took from the drawer a large purse of red velvet with gold tassels, edged with a tarnished fringe of gold wire,—a relic inherited from her grandmother.She weighed it proudly in her hand, and began with delight to count over the forgotten items of her little hoard.First she took out twenty @portugaises@, still new, struck in the reign of John V., 1725, worth by exchange, as her father told her, five @lisbonnines@, or a hundred and sixty-eight francs, sixty-four centimes each; their conventional value, however, was a hundred and eighty francs apiece, on account of the rarity and beauty of the coins, which shone like little suns.Item, five @genovines@, or five hundred-franc pieces of Genoa; another very rare coin worth eighty-seven francs on exchange, but a hundred francs to collectors.These had formerly belonged to old Monsieur de la Bertelliere.Item, three gold @quadruples@, Spanish, of Philip V., struck in 1729, given to her one by one by Madame Gentillet, who never failed to say, using the same words, when she made the gift, “This dear little canary, this little yellow-boy, is worth ninety-eight francs!Keep it, my pretty one, it will be the flower of your treasure.”Item (that which her father valued most of all, the gold of these coins being twenty-three carats and a fraction), a hundred Dutch ducats, made in the year 1756, and worth thirteen francs apiece.Item, a great curiosity, a species of medal precious to the soul of misers,—three rupees with the sign of the Scales, and five rupees with the sign of the Virgin, all in pure gold of twenty-four carats; the magnificent money of the Great Mogul, each of which was worth by mere weight thirty-seven francs, forty centimes, but at least fifty francs to those connoisseurs who love to handle gold.

zh: 其次，前一天拿到的四十法郎拿破仑金币，她忘记收拾到丝绒钱袋里了。这些珍宝都是全新的硬币，是真正的艺术品，葛朗台不时会问到，让拿出来看看，并给女儿指出它们内在的优点——比如，抛光边缘的做工多么精美，平滑的表面多么光亮，字体多么饱满，字体笔划的棱角也没有磨掉。
en: Item, the napoleon of forty francs received the day before, which she had forgotten to put away in the velvet purse.This treasure was all in virgin coins, true works of art, which Grandet from time to time inquired after and asked to see, pointing out to his daughter their intrinsic merits,—such as the beauty of the milled edge, the clearness of the flat surface, the richness of the lettering, whose angles were not yet rubbed off.

zh: 欧仁妮根本不考虑这些奇珍异品，也没有顾及她父亲对这些东西的迷恋，更没有去想抢走父亲心爱的宝贝会招来什么样的危险；没有，她只想着她的堂弟。在算错几次之后，她很快弄清楚她大约拥有五千八百法郎的实际财产，如果卖给收藏家，还有一定的附加值，价值差不多就是六千法郎。
en: Eugenie gave no thought to these rarities, nor to her father’s mania for them, nor to the danger she incurred in depriving herself of a treasure so dear to him; no, she thought only of her cousin, and soon made out, after a few mistakes of calculation, that she possessed about five thousand eight hundred francs in actual value, which might be sold for their additional value to collectors for nearly six thousand.

zh: 她看着自己的财产，拍起了手，好像一个高兴的孩子必须手舞足蹈才能释放那抑制不住的喜悦。父亲和女儿这晚各自清点了自己的财产——他，要卖他的金子；欧仁妮，要把她的金币投入到爱情的海洋中。她把金币放回了旧钱袋，拿到手中，毫不犹豫地跑上了楼。她堂弟暗中的窘境让她忘记了时间和体统；她的良心、她的献身精神和她的快乐给她壮了胆。
en: She looked at her wealth and clapped her hands like a happy child forced to spend its overflowing joy in artless movements of the body.Father and daughter had each counted up their fortune this night,—he, to sell his gold; Eugenie, to fling hers into the ocean of affection.She put the pieces back into the old purse, took it in her hand, and ran upstairs without hesitation.The secret misery of her cousin made her forget the hour and conventional propriety; she was strong in her conscience, in her devotion, in her happiness.

zh: 当她一只手拿着蜡烛，另一只手拿着钱袋，站在门槛上时，夏尔醒了，看见了她，惊讶得说不出话来。欧仁妮走上前，把蜡烛放在桌子上，声音颤抖着说道：
en: As she stood upon the threshold of the door, holding the candle in one hand and the purse in the other, Charles woke, caught sight of her, and remained speechless with surprise.Eugenie came forward, put the candle on the table, and said in a quivering voice:

zh: “堂弟，我必须请你原谅，我做了一件对不起你的事；不过，上帝会宽恕我的——如果你——帮我把它一笔勾销的话。”
en: “My cousin, I must beg pardon for a wrong I have done you; but God will pardon me—if you—will help me to wipe it out.”

zh: “是什么事？”夏尔揉了揉眼睛，问道。
en: “What is it?” asked Charles, rubbing his eyes.

zh: “我看了那些信。”
en: “I have read those letters.”

zh: 夏尔脸红了。
en: Charles colored.

zh: “怎么回事？”她接着说，“我为什么到这里来？真的，我不知道。我并不怎么后悔看过那些信；它们让我明白了你的心，你的灵魂，还有——”
en: “How did it happen?” she continued, “how came I here?Truly, I do not know.I am tempted not to regret too much that I have read them; they have made me know your heart, your soul, and—”

zh: “还有什么？”夏尔问。
en: “And what?” asked Charles.

zh: “你的计划，你需要一笔——”
en: “Your plans, your need of a sum—”

zh: “我亲爱的堂姐——”
en: “My dear cousin—”

zh: “嘘，嘘！堂弟，别这么大声，我们可不能吵醒了别人。看，”她一边说着，一边打开她的钱袋，“这是一个可怜姑娘的积蓄，她什么都不需要。夏尔，收下它们吧！今天早上，我还不知道钱的价值，是你教会了我。它终究只是个工具。堂弟差不多就是亲弟弟，你完全可以借你姐姐的钱袋用的。”
en: “Hush, hush! My cousin, not so loud; we must not wake others.See,” she said, opening her purse, “here are the savings of a poor girl who wants nothing.Charles, accept them!This morning I was ignorant of the value of money; you have taught it to me.It is but a means, after all.A cousin is almost a brother; you can surely borrow the purse of your sister.”

zh: 欧仁妮半是成年女子，半是小姑娘，从没想过会被人拒绝，可是她的堂弟却一直保持沉默。
en: Eugenie, as much a woman as a young girl, never dreamed of refusal; but her cousin remained silent.

zh: “哦！你不会拒绝吧？”欧仁妮大声说道，在那沉寂中都可以听见她的心跳声。
en: “Oh! You will not refuse?” cried Eugenie, the beatings of whose heart could be heard in the deep silence.

zh: 她堂弟的迟疑让她感到窘迫，可是他身无分文的窘境在她脑海里变得更加清晰了，她便跪了下来。
en: Her cousin’s hesitation mortified her; but the sore need of his position came clearer still to her mind, and she knelt down.

zh: “你不拿那金子，我就永远不起来！”她说，“堂弟，我求求你，回答我！让我知道你是否尊重我，是否慷慨大度，是否——”
en: “I will never rise till you have taken that gold!” she said.“My cousin, I implore you, answer me! Let me know if you respect me, if you are generous, if—”

zh: 当听到这高尚的心灵发出这样悲痛的哭喊时，年轻人的眼泪落在了他堂姐的手上，他握住了她的手，不让她跪下。热泪洒落到欧仁妮身上时，她跳起来抓住钱袋，把里面的东西倒在桌上。
en: As he heard this cry of noble distress the young man’s tears fell upon his cousin’s hands, which he had caught in his own to keep her from kneeling.As the warm tears touched her, Eugenie sprang to the purse and poured its contents upon the table.

zh: “啊！是的，是的，你同意了？”她说着，高兴地流出了眼泪，“什么也别怕，堂弟，你会有钱的。这金子会给你带来幸福的，总有一天你会还给我的——那我们不就成了合伙人了？我会服从所有条件的。可是你不要把这份礼物看得太重了。”
en: “Ah! Yes, yes, you consent?” she said, weeping with joy.“Fear nothing, my cousin, you will be rich.This gold will bring you happiness; some day you shall bring it back to me,—are we not partners?I will obey all conditions.But you should not attach such value to the gift.”

zh: 夏尔终于能够表达自己的感受了。
en: Charles was at last able to express his feelings.

zh: “是的，欧仁妮，如果我不接受的话，确实我就会显得太小气了。不过——礼物换礼物，信任换信任。”
en: “Yes, Eugenie; my soul would be small indeed if I did not accept.And yet,—gift for gift, confidence for confidence.”

zh: “你是什么意思？”她有些害怕，说道。
en: “What do you mean?” she said, frightened.

zh: “听着，亲爱的堂姐，我这里有——”他停了下来，指着五斗橱上一个外面包着皮套的方盒子。他接着说，“里面有个东西，对我来说，它和我的生命一样宝贵。这个盒子是我母亲送我的一件礼物。整整一天，我都在想，我母亲因为爱我而在这只梳妆箱上用掉了很多金子，如果她从坟墓里走出来，她会亲自把这些金子卖掉的；但要是我这么去做的话，这种行为在我看来就是大逆不道。”当听见最后几个字时，欧仁妮紧紧抓住了他的手。“不，”他们彼此眼含泪水深情地对望着，稍过片刻，他又说道，“不，我既不会卖了它，也不会冒险带着它上路。亲爱的欧仁妮，你将是它的守护者。朋友之间从来不会相互托付比这更神圣的东西了。我拿来给你看看吧。”
en: “Listen, dear cousin; I have here—” He interrupted himself to point out a square box covered with an outer case of leather which was on the drawers.“There,” he continued, “is something as precious to me as life itself.This box was a present from my mother.All day I have been thinking that if she could rise from her grave, she would herself sell the gold which her love for me lavished on this dressing-case; but were I to do so, the act would seem to me a sacrilege.”Eugenie pressed his hand as she heard these last words.“No,” he added, after a slight pause, during which a liquid glance of tenderness passed between them, “no, I will neither sell it nor risk its safety on my journey.Dear Eugenie, you shall be its guardian.Never did friend commit anything more sacred to another.Let me show it to you.”

zh: 他走过去，从封套中拿出盒子并打开，让他那快乐的堂姐看一个梳妆箱，其精美的工艺使这些金质装饰品的价值远远超过了它们的重量。
en: He went to the box, took it from its outer coverings, opened it, and showed his delighted cousin a dressing-case where the rich workmanship gave to the gold ornaments a value far above their weight.

zh: “你正欣赏的这个东西算不得什么，”他说着，按了一个隐藏的弹簧，打开了一个夹层，“这才是我眼里价值连城的东西。”他抽出两幅肖像，是米贝尔夫人的杰作，镶满了珍珠。
en: “What you admire there is nothing,” he said, pushing a secret spring which opened a hidden drawer.“Here is something which to me is worth the whole world.”He drew out two portraits, masterpieces of Madame Mirbel, richly set with pearls.

zh: “哦，太美了！你就是给这位夫人写信吧——”
en: “Oh, how beautiful!Is it the lady to whom you wrote that—”

zh: “不，”他微笑着说，“这是我的母亲，这是我的父亲，你的婶婶和叔父。欧仁妮，我要跪下求你，好好保管我的宝贝。如果我死了，你的私房钱也没了，这金子和这些珍珠会补偿你的。这两幅肖像我只肯给你，你有资格保管它们。不过宁可最后把它们毁掉，也不要让它们落入别人的手中。”欧仁妮沉默了。“啊，是的，说是的！你同意了？”他神采动人地补充道。
en: “No,” he said, smiling, “this is my mother, and here is my father, your aunt and uncle.Eugenie, I beg you on my knees, keep my treasure safely.If I die and your little fortune is lost, this gold and these pearls will repay you.To you alone could I leave these portraits; you are worthy to keep them.But destroy them at last, so that they may pass into no other hands.”Eugenie was silent.“Ah, yes, say yes!You consent?” he added with winning grace.

zh: 听到堂弟现在把她刚刚说的话又说给自己听，她深情地朝他看了一眼，那是她用恋爱女子的眼神看的第一眼——这一眼差不多既有妩媚，又有深情。他拉起她的手，吻了一下。
en: Hearing the very words she had just used to her cousin now addressed to herself, she turned upon him a look of love, her first look of loving womanhood,—a glance in which there is nearly as much of coquetry as of inmost depth.He took her hand and kissed it.

zh: “纯洁的天使！钱在我们两人之间是无所谓的，永远都不重要。感觉和情感从今以后就是一切。”
en: “Angel of purity! Between us two money is nothing, never can be anything.Feeling, sentiment, must be all henceforth.”

zh: “你像你的母亲——她的声音跟你一样温柔吗？”
en: “You are like your mother,—was her voice as soft as yours?”

zh: “哦！温柔多了——”
en: “Oh! Much softer—”

zh: “是的，对你当然是啦，”她说着，垂下了眼睑，“去吧，夏尔，上床睡去吧，我希望你睡一会儿，你肯定累了。晚安。”她轻轻把手从堂弟手里抽出来，堂弟正用灯照着路，跟着她往她的房间走去。他们两人走到了门槛时——
en: “Yes, for you,” she said, dropping her eyelids.“Come, Charles, go to bed; I wish it; you must be tired.Good night.”She gently disengaged her hand from those of her cousin, who followed her to her room, lighting the way.When they were both upon the threshold,—

zh: “啊！”他说，“为什么我会倾家荡产呢？”
en: “Ah!” he said, “why am I ruined?”

zh: “有什么关系？——我父亲有钱，我想是这样的。”她答道。
en: “What matter?—My father is rich; I think so,” she answered.

zh: “可怜的孩子！”夏尔迈步进了她的房间，背靠着墙，说道，“要是那样的话，他决不会让我父亲死的，他也不会让你过得这么穷困，他会过另外一种生活的。”
en: “Poor child!” said Charles, making a step into her room and leaning his back against the wall, “if that were so, he would never have let my father die; he would not let you live in this poor way; he would live otherwise himself.”

zh: “可是他拥有弗罗瓦丰。”
en: “But he owns Froidfond.”

zh: “弗罗瓦丰值多少钱？”
en: “What is Froidfond worth?”

zh: “我不知道，不过他还有努瓦耶。”
en: “I don’t know; but he has Noyers.”

zh: “那只不过是个穷田庄！”
en: “Nothing but a poor farm!”

zh: “他有葡萄园和草场。”
en: “He has vineyards and fields.”

zh: “不值什么钱的，”夏尔鄙夷地说道，“就算你父亲每年只有两万四千法郎，你觉得你会住在这么阴冷寒酸的房子里吗？”他往前迈了一步，接着说道，“啊！你是要把我的宝贝放在那里。”他一边说，一边瞥了一眼那个旧柜子，似乎想掩饰自己的想法。
en: “Mere nothing,” said Charles disdainfully.“If your father had only twenty-four thousand francs a year do you suppose you would live in this cold, barren room?” he added, making a step in advance.“Ah! There you will keep my treasures,” he said, glancing at the old cabinet, as if to hide his thoughts.

zh: “去睡吧。”她说道，不让他进自己凌乱的房间，。
en: “Go and sleep,” she said, hindering his entrance into the disordered room.

zh: 夏尔退了出去，他们相互微笑着道了晚安。
en: Charles stepped back, and they bid each other goodnight with a mutual smile.

zh: 两个人都睡着了，做着同样的梦；从那时起，这个年轻人的丧服上仿佛开始戴上了玫瑰。第二天早饭前，葛朗台太太发现女儿在花园里陪着夏尔。那个年轻人仍旧很悲伤，正如一个坠入不幸的可怜人估量到他掉进的苦海有多深，便明白他整个的未来生活会有可怕的重负那样。
en: Both fell asleep in the same dream; and from that moment the youth began to wear roses with his mourning.The next day, before breakfast, Madame Grandet found her daughter in the garden in company with Charles.The young man was still sad, as became a poor fellow who, plunged in misfortune, measures the depths of the abyss into which he has fallen, and sees the terrible burden of his whole future life.

zh: 欧仁妮觉察到母亲脸上有不安的神情，便说道：“我父亲晚饭时才回家。”
en: “My father will not be home till dinner-time,” said Eugenie, perceiving the anxious look on her mother’s face.

zh: 从这个年轻姑娘的面容、举止，以及她声音的异常柔美中，很容易看出她和她堂弟之间有一种思想上的默契。也许他们甚至还没有感觉出把他们连结到一起的那份感情的力量，就已经心心相印了。夏尔整个早晨都呆在大厅里，他暗自忧伤，谁也没去打搅他。三个女人各忙各的事。葛朗台忘了把事情交代好，结果许多人跑来干活——有管子工、砖瓦匠、铺石板的工匠、木匠、挖沟工人、装饰橱窗的人，还有佃户；有的来商谈维修费，有的来交租金，还有的来拿工钱。葛朗台太太和欧仁妮不得不跑来跑去，听所有这些工人和乡下人没完没了的唠叨。娜农把他们拿来抵租的农产品收拾到了厨房。她总要等她的主人发了令，才知道哪些要留在家里用，哪些要拿到市场上去卖。老头的习惯跟很多乡绅一样，就是喝劣质酒，吃烂水果。
en: It was easy to trace in the face and manners of the young girl and in the singular sweetness of her voice a unison of thought between her and her cousin.Their souls had espoused each other, perhaps before they even felt the force of the feelings which bound them together.Charles spent the morning in the hall, and his sadness was respected.Each of the three women had occupations of her own.Grandet had left all his affairs unattended to, and a number of persons came on business,—the plumber, the mason, the slater, the carpenter, the diggers, the dressers, the farmers; some to drive a bargain about repairs, others to pay their rent or to be paid themselves for services.Madame Grandet and Eugenie were obliged to go and come and listen to the interminable talk of all these workmen and country folk.Nanon put away in her kitchen the produce which they brought as tribute.She always waited for her master’s orders before she knew what portion was to be used in the house and what was to be sold in the market.It was the goodman’s custom, like that of a great many country gentlemen, to drink his bad wine and eat his spoiled fruit.

zh: 下午快五点时，葛朗台从昂热回来了，他用他的金子换了一万四千法郎，用皮夹子揣回了王家债券，在他拿去投资购买公债之前，这些债券一直还有利息。他把科努瓦耶留在昂热照料那几匹差不多快要累死的马，他嘱咐科努瓦耶，等马歇过来之后再慢慢赶回家。
en: Towards five in the afternoon Grandet returned from Angers, having made fourteen thousand francs by the exchange on his gold, bringing home in his wallet good treasury-notes which bore interest until the day he should invest them in the Funds.He had left Cornoiller at Angers to look after the horses, which were well-nigh foundered, with orders to bring them home slowly after they were rested.

zh: “我从昂热回来了，太太，”他说，“我饿了。”
en: “I have got back from Angers, wife,” he said, “I am hungry.”

zh: 娜农在厨房冲他大声喊道：
en: Nanon called out to him from the kitchen:

zh: “打昨天起您就没吃过东西吧？”
en: “Haven’t you eaten anything since yesterday?”

zh: “什么也没吃。”老头答道。
en: “Nothing,” answered the old man.

zh: 娜农端上来汤。就在一家人坐下来要吃晚饭时，德格拉桑来了，要听取他主顾的指示。葛朗台连看都没看他侄子一眼。
en: Nanon brought in the soup.Des Grassins came to take his client’s orders just as the family sat down to dinner.Grandet had not even observed his nephew.

zh: “接着吃，葛朗台，”银行家说，“我们能说话。你知道昂热的金价吗？他们从南特赶来要收买呢？我要拿一些我们的金子去抛售。”
en: “Go on eating, Grandet,” said the banker, “we can talk.Do you know what gold is worth in Angers?They have come from Nantes after it?I shall send some of ours.”

zh: “别去，”葛朗台说，“他们拿的已经够多了。我们是老朋友了，我不能让你白白浪费时间。”
en: “Don’t send any,” said Grandet, “they have got enough.We are such old friends, I ought to save you from such a loss of time.”

zh: “可金价是十三法郎五十生丁呢。”
en: “But gold is worth thirteen francs fifty centimes.”

zh: “应该说‘曾经是’——”
en: “Say @was@ worth—”

zh: “他们究竟是从哪里搞到的？”
en: “Where the devil have they got any?”

zh: “我昨晚去昂热了。”葛朗台低声回答。
en: “I went to Angers last night,” answered Grandet in a low voice.

zh: 银行家惊得一哆嗦。接着两个人悄声交谈了一番，其间葛朗台和德格拉桑频频地看着夏尔。不一会儿，德格拉桑显得十分惊诧，大概是葛朗台当时让他投资购买一年十万法郎的公债。
en: The banker shook with surprise.Then a whispered conversation began between the two, during which Grandet and des Grassins frequently looked at Charles.Presently des Grassins gave a start of astonishment; probably Grandet was then instructing him to invest the sum which was to give him a hundred thousand francs a year in the Funds.

zh: “葛朗台先生，”银行家对夏尔说，“我要去巴黎，如果你有事相托——”
en: “Monsieur Grandet,” said the banker to Charles, “I am starting for Paris; if you have any commissions—”

zh: “没什么事，先生，谢谢您。”夏尔答道。
en: “None, monsieur, I thank you,” answered Charles.

zh: “要多谢谢他，侄儿。先生要去处理纪尧姆·葛朗台商号的事情。”
en: “Thank him better than that, nephew.Monsieur is going to settle the affairs of the house of Guillaume Grandet.”

zh: “有希望吗？”夏尔急切地说。
en: “Is there any hope?” said Charles eagerly.

zh: “唉！”他伯父装着自豪的样子，感叹道，“你不是我侄儿吗？你的名誉就是我们的名誉。你不是也姓葛朗台吗？”
en: “What!” exclaimed his uncle, with well-acted pride, “are you not my nephew?Your honor is ours.Is not your name Grandet?”

zh: 夏尔站起来，抱住葛朗台老头，吻了吻他，然后夏尔脸色变得很苍白，离开了房间。欧仁妮钦佩地看着她的父亲。
en: Charles rose, seized Pere Grandet, kissed him, turned pale, and left the room.Eugenie looked at her father with admiration.

zh: “好吧，再见，德格拉桑，一切都拜托你了。尽可能好好诓诓那些人，牵住他们的鼻子。”
en: “Well, goodby, des Grassins; it is all in your hands.Decoy those people as best you can; lead ’em by the nose.”

zh: 两个能说会道的人握了握手。老箍桶匠陪着银行家走到前门。接着，他关上门，走回来，一屁股坐进了他的扶手椅，对娜农说——
en: The two diplomatists shook hands.The old cooper accompanied the banker to the front door.Then, after closing it, he came back and plunged into his armchair, saying to Nanon,—

zh: “给我拿点黑藨子果仁甜酒。”
en: “Get me some black-currant ratafia.”

zh: 但是，他实在是太兴奋了，在一个地方坐不住，便站起身来，看着德拉贝尔特利耶先生的肖像，开始一边做着被娜农叫做舞步的动作，一边唱起来——
en: Too excited, however, to remain long in one place, he got up, looked at the portrait of Monsieur de la Bertelliere, and began to sing, doing what Nanon called his dancing steps,—

zh: “在法国的近卫团里
en: “Dans les gardes francaises

zh: 我有一个好爸爸。”
en: J’avais un bon papa.”

zh: 娜农、葛朗台太太和欧仁妮相互看着，沉默不语。当这位男主人高兴到极点时，那高兴劲儿总是让她们感到害怕。晚会很快结束了。葛朗台老头决定早点上床睡觉，他一睡，其他人都得去睡，如同奥古斯塔斯一喝酒，整个波兰都要醉一样。这时，娜农、夏尔和欧仁妮三人疲惫的程度不亚于这位一家之主。至于葛朗台太太，她睡觉、吃喝，还有走路都是随着丈夫的意愿进行的。但是，在饭后消化的两个小时中，箍桶匠一辈子都没这么滑稽过，说了一大通他自己独有的格言警句——单单其中一句便显出了他的心有几寸几尺。他喝完果仁甜酒后，看着杯子，说道——
en: Nanon, Madame Grandet, and Eugenie looked at each other in silence.The hilarity of the master always frightened them when it reached its climax.The evening was soon over.Pere Grandet chose to go to bed early, and when he went to bed, everybody else was expected to go too; like as when Augustus drank, Poland was drunk.On this occasion Nanon, Charles, and Eugenie were not less tired than the master.As for Madame Grandet, she slept, ate, drank, and walked according to the will of her husband.However, during the two hours consecrated to digestion, the cooper, more facetious than he had ever been in his life, uttered a number of his own particular apothegms,—a single one of which will give the measure of his mind.When he had drunk his ratafia, he looked at his glass and said,—

zh: “你的嘴刚放到杯子上，杯子就空了。这就是人生。你不可能有了。金子不会一边流通，一边还呆在你的钱包里。要不是这样的话，生活就太美好了。”
en: “You have no sooner put your lips to a glass than it is empty!Such is life.You can’t have and hold.Gold won’t circulate and stay in your purse.If it were not for that, life would be too fine.”

zh: 他友善快活、仁慈宽厚。当娜农搬着她的纺车进来时，“你一定累了，”他说，“把你的麻收拾起来吧。”
en: He was jovial and benevolent.When Nanon came with her spinning-wheel, “You must be tired,” he said, “put away your hemp.”

zh: “啊，不行！那样我会瞌睡的。”她答道。
en: “Ah, bah! Then I shall get sleepy,” she answered.

zh: “可怜的娜农！你要不要喝点果仁甜酒？”
en: “Poor Nanon!Will you have some ratafia?”

zh: “我不会拒绝一个善意的邀请，太太做的酒比药剂师做的强多了。他们卖的都是药。”
en: “I won’t refuse a good offer; madame makes it a deal better than the apothecaries.What they sell is all drugs.”

zh: “他们放的糖太多，”这位主人说，“你就品不出别的味来了。”
en: “They put too much sugar,” said the master, “you can’t taste anything else.”

zh: 第九章
en: Chapter IX

zh: 第二天八点，全家人聚在一起吃早饭，家里真正呈现了一幅和睦融洽的画面。悲痛已经把葛朗台太太、欧仁妮和夏尔连在了一起，甚至连娜农也不知不觉地同情起来。这四个人现在成了一家人。至于那老头，他的贪欲得到了满足，并且确信很快就能摆脱那个花花公子，除了去南特的费用外，不用多花一分钱，所以虽然那个花花公子仍在家住着，他也不怎么在意了。他让那两个孩子——他称作夏尔和欧仁妮——在葛朗台太太的监督下，爱干什么就干什么。在公共和宗教道德方面，他是绝对信任太太的。他忙着修整路边草场和地沟的边界，在卢瓦尔河边种杨树，安排葡萄园冬天的活，还要操心弗罗瓦丰的事。所有这些事情占了他全部的时间。
en: The following day the family, meeting at eight o’clock for the early breakfast, made a picture of genuine domestic intimacy.Grief had drawn Madame Grandet, Eugenie, and Charles @en rapport@; even Nanon sympathized, without knowing why.The four now made one family.As to the old man, his satisfied avarice and the certainty of soon getting rid of the dandy without having to pay more than his journey to Nantes, made him nearly indifferent to his presence in the house.He left the two children, as he called Charles and Eugenie, free to conduct themselves as they pleased, under the eye of Madame Grandet, in whom he had implicit confidence as to all that concerned public and religious morality.He busied himself in straightening the boundaries of his fields and ditches along the high-road, in his poplar-plantations beside the Loire, in the winter work of his vineyards, and at Froidfond.All these things occupied his whole time.

zh: 对于欧仁妮来说，爱情的春天已经来了。那天晚上她把自己的私房钱交给了堂弟，从这一幕发生之后，她的心就随着她的私房钱走了。作为保守同一个秘密的盟友，他们看着彼此，心领神会，这让他们的情感加深了，关系更默契、更亲密了，可以说，使他们置身于日常生活的范围之外。他们是近亲关系，他们不就理应语气柔和些、目光温柔些吗？欧仁妮乐于用对新生儿的爱来抚平她堂弟的痛苦。爱情的开始和生命的开始难道不是有着动人的相似之处吗？我们不是用最温柔的歌声和最柔和的目光来摇着婴儿吗？我们不是给他讲一些有关金灿灿的前程的美妙故事吗？她不是希望自己在他的头顶展开她那光辉灿烂的翅膀吗？难道他不是有着婴儿的喜怒无常，时而流下悲伤的泪水，时而流下喜悦的泪水吗？他不是为了琐碎之事而发愁，为了用于建造活动宫殿的美丽石子、为了摘下后就被遗忘的花朵而哭泣吗？他不是急切地想抓住时间，快步踏入人生吗？爱情是我们的第二次脱胎换骨。童年和爱情对欧仁妮和夏尔来说是一回事；它是第一次激情，带着种种的天真幼稚——让他们的心灵更觉得抚慰，因为他们的内心此时正被哀伤包裹着。　　他们的爱情从诞生起就在丧服的阴云下挣扎，倒是和这栋灰暗破败的宅子那朴素的外省风格更为协调了。他们在寂静的院子里靠着井边交谈，或者日落时在花园里徘徊，坐在长有青苔的凳子上互相不停地说着无关紧要的情话，或者在屋子和城墙间宁静的气氛中默想，就像在教堂的拱门下一样。这时夏尔才懂得了爱情的圣洁，因为他的贵妇，他亲爱的安妮特，只让他领略了爱情暴风雨般的骚动。此刻，他远离了世俗的情欲，那种卖弄风情、虚荣和艳丽俗气的情欲，转而追求真诚而纯洁的爱情。他甚至连这房子都喜欢上了，这里的生活习俗对他来说似乎也不再那么荒唐可笑了。他一大早就起了床，好在欧仁妮的父亲来分配粮食之前能跟她说一会儿话；当老头的脚步声在楼梯上响起来时，他便溜进花园。娜农装着没看见这天早上的约会，那小小的犯罪感给他们纯洁的爱情平添了诱人的魅力，有一种偷尝禁果的乐趣。
en: For Eugenie the springtime of love had come.Since the scene at night when she gave her little treasure to her cousin, her heart had followed the treasure.Confederates in the same secret, they looked at each other with a mutual intelligence which sank to the depth of their consciousness, giving a closer communion, a more intimate relation to their feelings, and putting them, so to speak, beyond the pale of ordinary life.Did not their near relationship warrant the gentleness in their tones, the tenderness in their glances?Eugenie took delight in lulling her cousin’s pain with the pretty childish joys of a new-born love.Are there no sweet similitudes between the birth of love and the birth of life?Do we not rock the babe with gentle songs and softest glances?Do we not tell it marvellous tales of the golden future?Hope herself, does she not spread her radiant wings above its head?Does it not shed, with infant fickleness, its tears of sorrow and its tears of joy?Does it not fret for trifles, cry for the pretty pebbles with which to build its shifting palaces, for the flowers forgotten as soon as plucked?Is it not eager to grasp the coming time, to spring forward into life?Love is our second transformation.Childhood and love were one and the same thing to Eugenie and to Charles; it was a first passion, with all its childlike play,—the more caressing to their hearts because they now were wrapped in sadness.Struggling at birth against the gloom of mourning, their love was only the more in harmony with the provincial plainness of that gray and ruined house.As they exchanged a few words beside the well in the silent court, or lingered in the garden for the sunset hour, sitting on a mossy seat saying to each other the infinite nothings of love, or mused in the silent calm which reigned between the house and the ramparts like that beneath the arches of a church, Charles comprehended the sanctity of love; for his great lady, his dear Annette, had taught him only its stormy troubles.At this moment he left the worldly passion, coquettish, vain, and showy as it was, and turned to the true, pure love.He loved even the house, whose customs no longer seemed to him ridiculous.He got up early in the mornings that he might talk with Eugenie for a moment before her father came to dole out the provisions; when the steps of the old man sounded on the staircase he escaped into the garden.The small criminality of this morning @tete-a-tete@ which Nanon pretended not to see, gave to their innocent love the lively charm of a forbidden joy.

zh: 吃完早餐，等葛朗台去了他的草场和其他产业后，夏尔便跟母女俩呆在一起，为她们挽线，看她们做活，听她们轻声细语地闲谈，他从中体会到了从未有过的快乐。这种近乎修道院生活般的简朴向他展示了她们不谙尘世的灵魂之美，深深地打动了他。他原以为在法国不可能有这种品行，认为只在德国才有；而且即使有，在他看来，似乎也跟寓言似的，只存在于奥古斯特·拉方丹的小说里。很快，欧仁妮对他来说变成了歌德笔下的玛格丽特——是堕落之前的玛格丽特。一天又一天，他的话语、他的模样令这可怜的姑娘着迷，她愉快地任由爱河的波流摆布，毫无反抗；她抓住自己的幸福，就像游泳的人抓住一根悬伸的柳枝，好把自己从河里拉出来，上岸躺下休息一样。因担忧即将到来的离别，那飞逝而去的快乐时光不是也显得忧伤了吗？每一天，总有一些小事提醒他们分别即将到来。
en: After breakfast, when Grandet had gone to his fields and his other occupations, Charles remained with the mother and daughter, finding an unknown pleasure in holding their skeins, in watching them at work, in listening to their quiet prattle.The simplicity of this half-monastic life, which revealed to him the beauty of these souls, unknown and unknowing of the world, touched him keenly.He had believed such morals impossible in France, and admitted their existence nowhere but in Germany; even so, they seemed to him fabulous, only real in the novels of Auguste Lafontaine.Soon Eugenie became to him the Margaret of Goethe—before her fall.Day by day his words, his looks enraptured the poor girl, who yielded herself up with delicious non-resistance to the current of love; she caught her happiness as a swimmer seizes the overhanging branch of a willow to draw himself from the river and lie at rest upon its shore.Did no dread of a coming absence sadden the happy hours of those fleeting days?Daily some little circumstance reminded them of the parting that was at hand.

zh: 德格拉桑走了三天后，葛朗台把他侄子带到了民事法庭，以庄重的形式——乡下人对所有法律事务一向如此——签一份放弃对他父亲财产继承权的契约。可怕的放弃声明书！简直就是一种背叛家门的行为！夏尔还去了克吕绍公证人那里办了两份授权书——一份给德格拉桑，另一份是给受托代售其财物的朋友。之后，他办理了领取出国护照所需的所有手续；最后，等收到了从巴黎定制的简单孝服后，他派人叫来了索米尔的裁缝，把没用的衣服都卖给了他。最后这一做法让葛朗台极为高兴。
en: Three days after the departure of des Grassins, Grandet took his nephew to the Civil courts, with the solemnity which country people attach to all legal acts, that he might sign a deed surrendering his rights in his father’s estate.Terrible renunciation!
