Species of domestic apostasy!Charles also went before Maitre Cruchot to make two powers of attorney,—one for des Grassins, the other for the friend whom he had charged with the sale of his belongings.After that he attended to all the formalities necessary to obtain a passport for foreign countries; and finally, when he received his simple mourning clothes from Paris, he sent for the tailor of Saumur and sold to him his useless wardrobe.This last act pleased Grandet exceedingly.

zh: “啊！现在你看着像个准备闯荡一番发大财的人了，”当夏尔穿着一件纯黑布的礼服出现时，他说，“好！很好！”
en: “Ah! Now you look like a man prepared to embark and make your fortune,” he said, when Charles appeared in a surtout of plain black cloth.“Good! Very good!”

zh: “我希望您能相信，先生，”他侄子答道，“我会一直努力去适应我的处境的。”
en: “I hope you will believe, monsieur,” answered his nephew, “that I shall always try to conform to my situation.”

zh: “那是什么？”当看见夏尔拿着一把金子时，他伯父的眼睛一亮，说道。
en: “What’s that?” said his uncle, his eyes lighting up at a handful of gold which Charles was carrying.

zh: “先生，我把我所有的纽扣、戒指和其他值点钱的小零碎都收集到一起了，可是我在索米尔谁也不认识，我想请您——”
en: “Monsieur, I have collected all my buttons and rings and other superfluities which may have some value; but not knowing any one in Saumur, I wanted to ask you to—”

zh: “买下这些东西？”葛朗台打断他，说道。
en: “To buy them?” said Grandet, interrupting him.

zh: “不，伯父，您只要给介绍我一个诚实的人——”
en: “No, uncle; only to tell me of an honest man who—”

zh: “把那些东西给我，我要上楼去估算一下它们的价值，我会回来告诉你个数，分毫不差。首饰金，”他仔细查看着一条长项链，“十八或者十九克拉。”
en: “Give me those things, I will go upstairs and estimate their value; I will come back and tell you what it is to a fraction.Jeweller’s gold,” examining a long chain, “eighteen or nineteen carats.”

zh: 老头伸出他的大手，接过那把金子，并拿走了。
en: The goodman held out his huge hand and received the mass of gold, which he carried away.

zh: “堂姐，”葛朗台说，“我能把这两颗纽扣送给你吗？它们可以用来系戴在你手腕上的丝带，这种手镯现在很流行。”
en: “Cousin,” said Grandet, “may I offer you these two buttons?They can fasten ribbons round your wrists; that sort of bracelet is much the fashion just now.”

zh: “那就不客气了，我收下。”她会意地望了他一眼，回答道。
en: “I accept without hesitation,” she answered, giving him an understanding look.

zh: “伯母，这是我母亲的顶针，我一直小心地珍藏在我的梳妆箱里。”夏尔说着，把一个漂亮的金顶针送给葛朗台太太，她很多年来都盼望着能有这么一个金顶针。
en: “Aunt, here is my mother’s thimble; I have always kept it carefully in my dressing-case,” said Charles, presenting a pretty gold thimble to Madame Grandet, who for many years had longed for one.

zh: “我不知道该怎么谢你，什么话都表达不了，我的侄子，”可怜的母亲眼里满含着泪水，说道，“早晚祷告时，我会为你多做一个祷告，是最真诚的祈祷——祝出门在外的人平安。如果我死了，欧仁妮会为你保管这个宝贝的。”
en: “I cannot thank you; no words are possible, my nephew,” said the poor mother, whose eyes filled with tears.“Night and morning in my prayers I shall add one for you, the most earnest of all—for those who travel.If I die, Eugenie will keep this treasure for you.”

zh: “这些东西值九百八十九法郎七十五生丁，”葛朗台推开门，说道，“我先垫上钱——用里弗赫，省得你还得费事拿去卖。”
en: “They are worth nine hundred and eighty-nine francs, seventy-five centimes,” said Grandet, opening the door.“To save you the pain of selling them, I will advance the money—in @livres@.”

zh: 里弗赫这个词在卢瓦尔河沿岸是指面值六里弗赫的克朗硬币算作六法郎，不打折扣。
en: The word @livres@ on the littoral of the Loire signifies that crown prices of six @livres@ are to be accepted as six francs without deduction.

zh: “我不敢开口请您买下，”夏尔回答，“可是要在您住的城里把我的首饰变卖给二手商，我觉得很难堪。拿破仑说过，脏衣服应该在家里洗。我感谢您的好意。”
en: “I dared not propose it to you,” answered Charles, “but it was most repugnant to me to sell my jewels to some second-hand dealer in your own town.People should wash their dirty linen at home, as Napoleon said.I thank you for your kindness.”

zh: 葛朗台挠挠耳朵，一时间谁也没说话。
en: Grandet scratched his ear, and there was a moment’s silence.

zh: “我亲爱的伯父，”夏尔用一副不安的神情看着他，好像担心会伤害到他的感情，继续说道，“我的伯母和堂姐已经赏脸收下了我的小纪念品。能允许我把这些袖扣送给您吗？这些东西现在对我来说没用了。它们会让您想起一个可怜的男孩，他远在异乡，将时刻惦念着那些从今以后就是他的亲人的人们。”
en: “My dear uncle,” resumed Charles, looking at him with an uneasy air, as if he feared to wound his feelings, “my aunt and cousin have been kind enough to accept a trifling remembrance of me.Will you allow me to give you these sleeve-buttons, which are useless to me now?They will remind you of a poor fellow who, far away, will always think of those who are henceforth all his family.”

zh: “我的孩子，我的孩子，你可不能就这样送个精光！让我看看，太太，你拿了什么？”他急切地转向她，又说道，“啊！一个金顶针。还有你，小姑娘？啊！钻石扣子？是的，我会收下你的礼物的，侄儿，”他一边回答，一边握住了夏尔的手，“但是——你一定要让我——付给——你——是的，你到西印度的路费。是的，我想给你出路费，因为——你知道吗，我的孩子——在给你的珠宝估价时，我只估算了金子的重量，那工艺很有可能也值些钱的。所以咱们这么办吧，我给你一千五百法郎——用里弗赫，克吕绍会借给我钱的。我这儿一个铜子儿也没有——除非佩罗泰把钱还上，他还欠着租金呢。顺便提一句，我这就去见他。”
en: “My lad, my lad, you mustn’t rob yourself this way!Let me see, wife, what have you got?” he added, turning eagerly to her.“Ah! A gold thimble.And you, little girl?What! Diamond buttons?Yes, I’ll accept your present, nephew,” he answered, shaking Charles by the hand.“But—you must let me—pay—your—yes, your passage to the Indies.Yes, I wish to pay your passage because—d’ye see, my boy?—in valuing your jewels I estimated only the weight of the gold; very likely the workmanship is worth something.So let us settle it that I am to give you fifteen hundred francs—in @livres@; Cruchot will lend them to me.I haven’t got a copper farthing here,—unless Perrotet, who is behindhand with his rent, should pay up.By the bye, I’ll go and see him.”

zh: 他拿起他的帽子，戴上手套，出去了。
en: He took his hat, put on his gloves, and went out.

zh: “这么说，你真的要走了？”欧仁妮对她的堂弟说道，神情既忧伤又钦佩。
en: “Then you are really going?” said Eugenie to her cousin, with a sad look, mingled with admiration.

zh: “我必须走。”他说着，低下了头。
en: “I must,” he said, bowing his head.

zh: 几天来，夏尔整个人的态度、举止和言谈都变了，好像一个人尽管悲痛万分，却感到责任重大，并拥有了从不幸中汲取勇气的力量。他不再抱怨了；他已成了一个男子汉。当看到堂弟穿着与他苍白的脸色和忧郁的面容十分相称的纯黑礼服下楼时，欧仁妮对他的性格更加了解了。那天，两个女人穿上了她们各自的丧服，然后三人一起参加了在教区教堂为已故的纪尧姆·葛朗台举行的追思弥撒。
en: For some days past, Charles’s whole bearing, manners, and speech had become those of a man who, in spite of his profound affliction, feels the weight of immense obligations and has the strength to gather courage from misfortune.He no longer repined; he became a man.Eugenie never augured better of her cousin’s character than when she saw him come down in the plain black clothes which suited well with his pale face and sombre countenance.On that day the two women put on their own mourning, and all three assisted at a Requiem celebrated in the parish church for the soul of the late Guillaume Grandet.

zh: 午饭时，夏尔收到了从巴黎来的信，开始读起来。
en: At the second breakfast Charles received letters from Paris and began to read them.

zh: “喂，堂弟，你对事情的处理还满意吧？”欧仁妮低声说。
en: “Well, cousin, are you satisfied with the management of your affairs?” said Eugenie in a low voice.

zh: “千万别问这种问题，我的女儿，”葛朗台说，“见鬼！我给你讲过我的事吗？你干嘛要管你堂弟的事？别打扰那孩子！”
en: “Never ask such questions, my daughter,” said Grandet.“What the devil! Do I tell you my affairs?Why do you poke your nose into your cousin’s?Let the lad alone!”

zh: “哦！我没什么秘密。”夏尔说。
en: “Oh! I haven’t any secrets,” said Charles.

zh: “得，得，得，得，侄儿，你很快就会发现，做生意你一定要管住嘴。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta, nephew; you’ll soon find out that you must hold your tongue in business.”

zh: 当两个情人单独呆在花园里时，夏尔拉着欧仁妮坐在胡桃树下的旧长凳上，对她说——
en: When the two lovers were alone in the garden, Charles said to Eugenie, drawing her down on the old bench beneath the walnut-tree,—

zh: “我委托阿方斯是对的，他干得很棒。他很谨慎、很忠诚地处理了我的事。现在我在巴黎没债务了。我所有的东西都卖掉了。他告诉我，他听取了一位老船长的建议，花三千法郎买了一批欧洲的稀罕小玩意儿，将来卖到西印度肯定会畅销的。他已经把我的行李寄到了南特，在那里有一艘货船驶往圣多明各。欧仁妮，五天后，我们就要道别了——也许是永别，至少也要好多年。我的那批货，还有两个朋友寄给我的一万法郎，算是一笔小小的本钱。我看得好多年以后才能回来。亲爱的堂姐，不要把你的一生和我的一生放在一个秤盘里，我可能会死，别人会给你提门好亲事的——”
en: “I did right to trust Alphonse; he has done famously.He has managed my affairs with prudence and good faith.I now owe nothing in Paris.All my things have been sold; and he tells me that he has taken the advice of an old sea-captain and spent three thousand francs on a commercial outfit of European curiosities which will be sure to be in demand in the Indies.He has sent my trunks to Nantes, where a ship is loading for San Domingo.In five days, Eugenie, we must bid each other farewell—perhaps forever, at least for years.My outfit and ten thousand francs, which two of my friends send me, are a very small beginning.I cannot look to return for many years.My dear cousin, do not weight your life in the scales with mine; I may perish; some good marriage may be offered to you—”

zh: “你爱我吗？”她说。
en: “Do you love me?” she said.

zh: “哦，是的！的确，是的！”他语重心长地答道。
en: “Oh, yes! Indeed, yes!” he answered, with a depth of tone that revealed an equal depth of feeling.

zh: “我会等的，夏尔——天哪！我父亲在他的窗口呢。”她说着，推开了她的堂弟，他正凑过来要吻她。
en: “I shall wait, Charles—Good heavens!There is my father at his window,” she said, repulsing her cousin, who leaned forward to kiss her.

zh: 她很快跑到拱门下。夏尔跟着她跑过来。欧仁妮看见他，便退到楼梯脚下，打开了那个弹簧门；接着她漫无目的地来到了娜农的小屋附近的角落——过道里最黑暗的尽头。到了那里，夏尔抓住了她的手，把她拉进了怀里。他伸出胳膊搂住她的腰，让她轻轻地靠在自己的身上。欧仁妮不再抗拒，她接受并且给予了最纯洁、最甜蜜，而且也是最倾心相与的亲吻。
en: She ran quickly under the archway.Charles followed her.When she saw him, she retreated to the foot of the staircase and opened the swing-door; then, scarcely knowing where she was going, Eugenie reached the corner near Nanon’s den, in the darkest end of the passage.There Charles caught her hand and drew her to his heart.Passing his arm about her waist, he made her lean gently upon him.Eugenie no longer resisted; she received and gave the purest, the sweetest, and yet, withal, the most unreserved of kisses.

zh: “亲爱的欧仁妮，堂兄弟比亲兄弟要好，因为他可以娶你。”夏尔说。
en: “Dear Eugenie, a cousin is better than a brother, for he can marry you,” said Charles.

zh: “一言为定！”娜农推开了她那黑屋子的门，大声喊道。
en: “So be it!” cried Nanon, opening the door of her lair.

zh: 这对情侣吃了一惊，逃进了大厅，欧仁妮拿起了她的活计，夏尔开始读起葛朗台太太的祈祷书中《圣母经》的祷告词。
en: The two lovers, alarmed, fled into the hall, where Eugenie took up her work and Charles began to read the litanies of the @Virgin@ in Madame Grandet’s prayer-book.

zh: “哟！”娜农大声说，“现在他们正在祷告呢。”
en: “Mercy!” cried Nanon, “now they’re saying their prayers.”

zh: 夏尔一宣布他即将动身，葛朗台便忙活起来，以证明他对侄子有多关心。凡是不用他花钱的事他都变得很大方。他煞费苦心找来一个装箱工人，又说那个人的箱子要价太高，于是决定自己动手用旧木板做箱子。他一大早就起了床，把板条校准、刨平、钉好，做成了几个让他满意的结实箱子。他把夏尔的东西全装进去，然后亲自张罗着把箱子送上卢瓦尔河上的船，给它们上了保险，以便把它们准时送达南特。
en: As soon as Charles announced his immediate departure, Grandet bestirred himself to testify much interest in his nephew.He became very liberal of all that cost him nothing; took pains to find a packer; declared the man asked too much for his cases; insisted on making them himself out of old planks; got up early in the morning to fit and plane and nail together the strips, out of which he made, to his own satisfaction, some strong cases, in which he packed all Charles’s effects; he also took upon himself to send them by boat down the Loire, to insure them, and get them to Nantes in proper time.

zh: 自从过道里的一吻之后，对欧仁妮来说，时间过得快得吓人。有时她想跟着堂弟走。凡是领略过最难舍难分的爱情的人——那爱情的持续期因时间、年龄、不治之症、机缘和厄运而一天短似一天——他们会理解这可怜的姑娘有多苦恼。她在花园里边走边哭，如今这花园，实际上还有院子、房子、城市，对她来说，都好像太狭窄了。她想象自己已经起航驶入了他即将横渡的那片浩瀚的海洋。终于到了他出发的前夜。那天早晨，趁葛朗台和娜农都不在，他们把装着那两张肖像的宝贝箱子郑重其事地安放进旧衣柜唯一能锁住的抽屉里，那里面放着现在已经空了的丝绒钱袋。存放时，他们哭了又哭，吻了又吻。当欧仁妮把钥匙放进她的胸口时，她已没有勇气阻止夏尔贴上去的亲吻。
en: After the kiss taken in the passage, the hours fled for Eugenie with frightful rapidity.Sometimes she thought of following her cousin.Those who have known that most endearing of all passions,—the one whose duration is each day shortened by time, by age, by mortal illness, by human chances and fatalities,—they will understand the poor girl’s tortures.She wept as she walked in the garden, now so narrow to her, as indeed the court, the house, the town all seemed.She launched in thought upon the wide expanse of the ocean he was about to traverse.At last the eve of his departure came.That morning, in the absence of Grandet and of Nanon, the precious case which contained the two portraits was solemnly installed in the only drawer of the old cabinet which could be locked, where the now empty velvet purse was lying.This deposit was not made without a goodly number of tears and kisses.When Eugenie placed the key within her bosom she had no courage to forbid the kiss with which Charles sealed the act.

zh: “它永远不会离开那个地方的，我的朋友。”她说。
en: “It shall never leave that place, my friend,” she said.

zh: “那我的心将一直留在那里。”
en: “Then my heart will be always there.”

zh: “啊！夏尔，这样不好。”她说，仿佛是在责备他。
en: “Ah! Charles, it is not right,” she said, as though she blamed him.

zh: “我们不是结婚了吗？”他说，“我已经有了你的许诺——那么请接受我的许诺吧。”
en: “Are we not married?” he said.“I have thy promise,—then take mine.”

zh: “你的，我永远是你的！”他们二人把这句话都连说了两遍。
en: “Thine; I am thine forever!” they each said, repeating the words twice over.

zh: 世上没有比这更纯洁的誓言了。欧仁妮的纯真诚挚刹那间使这个年轻人的爱情变得神圣了。
en: No promise made upon this earth was ever purer.The innocent sincerity of Eugenie had sanctified for a moment the young man’s love.

zh: 第二天，早餐的气氛很悲伤。尽管收下了夏尔赠送的绣金睡袍和挂在胸前的让内特十字架，娜农还是热泪盈眶。
en: On the morrow the breakfast was sad.Nanon herself, in spite of the gold-embroidered robe and the Jeannette cross bestowed by Charles, had tears in her eyes.

zh: “可怜的好先生，要漂洋过海了——哦，但愿上帝能指引他！”
en: “The poor dear monsieur who is going on the seas—oh, may God guide him!”

zh: 十点半，全家人出门送夏尔去乘坐到南特的驿车。娜农放了狗，锁上门，坚持要拿上年轻人的旅行包。曲曲折折的老街上，所有的商人都站在他们的店铺门口看这一行人。到了市场时，克吕绍公证人也加入了他们的行列。
en: At half-past ten the whole family started to escort Charles to the diligence for Nantes.Nanon let loose the dog, locked the door, and insisted on carrying the young man’s carpet-bag.All the tradesmen in the tortuous old street were on the sill of their shop-doors to watch the procession, which was joined in the market-place by Maitre Cruchot.

zh: “欧仁妮，一定不要哭。”她母亲说道。
en: “Eugenie, be sure you don’t cry,” said her mother.

zh: “侄儿，”葛朗台站在驿车出发的客栈门口，吻了吻夏尔的两颊，说道，“穷着走，富着回，你会发现你父亲的名誉完好无损。我向你保证这一点，我——葛朗台，因为将来只能靠你来——”
en: “Nephew,” said Grandet, in the doorway of the inn from which the coach started, kissing Charles on both cheeks, “depart poor, return rich; you will find the honor of your father safe.I answer for that myself, I—Grandet; for it will only depend on you to—”

zh: “啊！伯父，您减轻了我离别的伤心。这不就是您送给我的最好的礼物吗？”
en: “Ah! My uncle, you soften the bitterness of my departure.Is it not the best gift that you could make me?”

zh: 夏尔就这样打断了他伯父的话，根本没听懂话里的意思。他在那个老守财奴深褐色的脸颊上滴下了感激的泪水，而欧仁妮则用尽全力握紧了她堂弟和她父亲的手。公证人露出了微笑，很佩服那老头狡诈的一番话，只有他一个人听明白了意思。一家人站在驿车四周，直到车子出发；接着，等到驿车在桥上消失，那隆隆声在远处变得越来越小的时候，葛朗台说：
en: Not understanding his uncle’s words which he had thus interrupted, Charles shed tears of gratitude upon the tanned cheeks of the old miser, while Eugenie pressed the hand of her cousin and that of her father with all her strength.The notary smiled, admiring the sly speech of the old man, which he alone had understood.The family stood about the coach until it started; then as it disappeared upon the bridge, and its rumble grew fainter in the distance, Grandet said:

zh: “再见了！”
en: “Goodby to you!”

zh: 幸而只有克吕绍公证人听到了这声欢呼。欧仁妮和她母亲已经去了码头一个还能看见驿车的角落，挥着她们的白手绢，夏尔也挥着自己的手绢做出回应。
en: Happily no one but Maitre Cruchot heard the exclamation.Eugenie and her mother had gone to a corner of the quay from which they could still see the diligence and wave their white handkerchiefs, to which Charles made answer by displaying his.

zh: “啊！母亲，我真希望能有上帝的法力，哪怕就一会儿。”当再也看不到爱人的手绢时，欧仁妮说。
en: “Ah! Mother, would that I had the power of God for a single moment,” said Eugenie, when she could no longer see her lover’s handkerchief.

zh: 为了能一口气把葛朗台家里接二连三要发生的事件讲完，有必要先交待一下老头委托德格拉桑先生在巴黎所办理的各种事宜。德格拉桑先生离开索米尔一个月之后，葛朗台从投资公债中拿到了一年十万法郎的登记证，那公债是以净价八十法郎一股买的。在他死后，财产清单所列的明细表没有解释这个生性多疑的人是如何把买公债的钱拨去，又是如何由此拿到登记证的。克吕绍公证人认为，娜农不知不觉地成了可靠的运款工具；因为就在这段时间，她有五天不在家，借口是去弗罗瓦丰收拾东西——倒好像那老头真能把东西乱丢乱放似的！
en: Not to interrupt the current of events which are about to take place in the bosom of the Grandet family, it is necessary to cast a forestalling eye upon the various operations which the goodman carried on in Paris by means of Monsieur des Grassins.A month after the latter’s departure from Saumur, Grandet, became possessed of a certificate of a hundred thousand francs a year from his investment in the Funds, bought at eighty francs net.The particulars revealed at his death by the inventory of his property threw no light upon the means which his suspicious nature took to remit the price of the investment and receive the certificate thereof.Maitre Cruchot was of opinion that Nanon, unknown to herself, was the trusty instrument by which the money was transported; for about this time she was absent five days, under a pretext of putting things to rights at Froidfond,—as if the goodman were capable of leaving anything lying about or out of order!

zh: 至于所有涉及纪尧姆·葛朗台商号的事，全都是不折不扣按照老箍桶匠的打算进行的。众所周知，法兰西银行对巴黎及外省的巨富提供有准确的信息。德格拉桑和索米尔的费利克斯·葛朗台的名字都榜上有名，而且他们像那些拥有大片地产而没有抵押出去的金融界名人一样，很受敬重。索米尔银行家的到来，据说是为了体面地清偿巴黎葛朗台的债务，这足以使那位已故商人的名声免受被债权人签署拒付通知书的羞辱。财产上的封条当着债权人的面被撕了下来，葛朗台雇用的公证人马上着手开列财产清单。不久之后，德格拉桑召集债权人开会，他们一致推举他，连同一家大银行的老板，同时也是主要债权人之一的弗朗索瓦·凯勒为清算人，全权负责保护葛朗台家族的名誉和债权人的利益。索米尔葛朗台的信誉，加上通过德格拉桑之口在所有相关人员头脑中散播的希望，使得处理过程极为顺利。没有一个债权人表示异议，也没有人想过要把债权放到盈亏帐上算一算，所有人都很有信心地说：“索米尔的葛朗台会偿还的。”
en: In all that concerned the business of the house of Guillaume Grandet the old cooper’s intentions were fulfilled to the letter.The Bank of France, as everybody knows, affords exact information about all the large fortunes in Paris and the provinces.The names of des Grassins and Felix Grandet of Saumur were well known there, and they enjoyed the esteem bestowed on financial celebrities whose wealth comes from immense and unencumbered territorial possessions.The arrival of the Saumur banker for the purpose, it was said, of honorably liquidating the affairs of Grandet of Paris, was enough to avert the shame of protested notes from the memory of the defunct merchant.The seals on the property were taken off in presence of the creditors, and the notary employed by Grandet went to work at once on the inventory of the assets.Soon after this, des Grassins called a meeting of the creditors, who unanimously elected him, conjointly with Francois Keller, the head of a rich banking-house and one of those principally interested in the affair, as liquidators, with full power to protect both the honor of the family and the interests of the claimants.The credit of Grandet of Saumur, the hopes he diffused by means of des Grassins in the minds of all concerned, facilitated the transactions.Not a single creditor proved recalcitrant; no one thought of passing his claim to his profit-and-loss account; each and all said confidently, “Grandet of Saumur will pay.”

zh: 六个月过去了。那些巴黎人已经把到期的流通债券赎了回来，放到他们的书桌里，并锁了起来。这是老箍桶匠要达到的第一个目的！第一次集会九个月之后，两位清算人给每个债权人发放了百分之四十七的债款。这笔钱是靠变卖已故的纪尧姆·葛朗台所拥有的证券、资产及其他所有物获得的，偿还手续严谨诚实。清算办理得无可指摘，极为公正。债权人非常感谢葛朗台家族所展示的杰出的、无可置疑的信誉。这番赞美之词传颂了一段时间之后，债权人要求偿还余下的债款。必须集体写封信给索米尔的葛朗台。
en: Six months went by.The Parisians had redeemed the notes in circulation as they fell due, and held them under lock and key in their desks.First result aimed at by the old cooper!Nine months after this preliminary meeting, the two liquidators distributed forty-seven per cent to each creditor on his claim.This amount was obtained by the sale of the securities, property, and possessions of all kinds belonging to the late Guillaume Grandet, and was paid over with scrupulous fidelity.Unimpeachable integrity was shown in the transaction.The creditors gratefully acknowledged the remarkable and incontestable honor displayed by the Grandets.When these praises had circulated for a certain length of time, the creditors asked for the rest of their money.It became necessary to write a collective letter to Grandet of Saumur.

zh: “终于来了！”老头一边把信扔到火里，一边说道，“要有耐心，我的好朋友们！”
en: “Here it comes!” said the old man as he threw the letter into the fire.“Patience, my good friends!”

zh: 对信中所提的建议，索米尔葛朗台的答复是要求所有他兄弟遗产的债权凭单，连同抵付的百分之四十七的清欠收据，都应存放到一个公证人那里；他提这个要求的借口是要核对账目，弄清遗产的确切状况。这立刻引发了各种争议。一般来讲，债权人是一种性情古怪的家伙，今天准备签协议了，第二天又嚷着烧呀杀呀的，再后来，他又变得友善而随和了。今天，他的妻子心情愉快，他最小的婴儿长了第一颗牙，家里一切顺利，他便决心一个子儿也不让；第二天下了雨，他出不了门，心里烦闷，只要能让事情有个了结，任何一个要求他都会答应；第三天，他宣布他必须要担保；到月底，他想要欠债人的脑袋，在心里头已变成了个刽子手。
en: In answer to the proposals contained in the letter, Grandet of Saumur demanded that all vouchers for claims against the estate of his brother should be deposited with a notary, together with acquittances for the forty-seven per cent already paid; he made this demand under pretence of sifting the accounts and finding out the exact condition of the estate.It roused at once a variety of difficulties.Generally speaking, the creditor is a species of maniac, ready to agree to anything one day, on the next breathing fire and slaughter; later on, he grows amicable and easygoing.Today his wife is good-humored, his last baby has cut its first tooth, all is well at home, and he is determined not to lose a sou; on the morrow it rains, he can’t go out, he is gloomy, he says yes to any proposal that is made to him, so long as it will put an end to the affair; on the third day he declares he must have guarantees; by the end of the month he wants his debtor’s head, and becomes at heart an executioner.

zh: 债权人很像麻雀，易于相信别人的孩子们会被怂恿往它的尾巴上放盐——区别是，债权人把债权看成那个麻雀，结果永远无利可图。葛朗台早已研究过债权人的情绪变化，而他兄弟的债主们证实了他的种种推测没有错。有些人生气了，断然拒绝交出他们的债权凭单。
en: The creditor is a good deal like the sparrow on whose tail confiding children are invited to put salt,—with this difference, that he applies the image to his claim, the proceeds of which he is never able to lay hold of.Grandet had studied the atmospheric variations of creditors, and the creditors of his brother justified all his calculations.Some were angry, and flatly refused to give in their vouchers.

zh: “很好，再好不过了。”葛朗台一边说，一边用手搓着德格拉桑写明此事的那封信。
en: “Very good; so much the better,” said Grandet, rubbing his hands over the letter in which des Grassins announced the fact.

zh: 还有些人同意这个要求，但条件是他们的权利要得到充分保障；他们声明不放弃任何权利，甚至保留最终强制破产的权力。就此事开始了长时间的书信往来，最后索米尔的葛朗台同意了所有的条件。凭借这一让步，宽容的债主们说服了那些持反对意见的债主。然后，尽管仍有各种不满的声音，债券还是被存放了。
en: Others agreed to the demand, but only on condition that their rights should be fully guaranteed; they renounced none, and even reserved the power of ultimately compelling a failure.On this began a long correspondence, which ended in Grandet of Saumur agreeing to all conditions.By means of this concession the placable creditors were able to bring the dissatisfied creditors to reason.The deposit was then made, but not without sundry complaints.

zh: “你那个老头，”他们对德格拉桑说，“在哄骗我们。”
en: “Your goodman,” they said to des Grassins, “is tricking us.”

zh: 纪尧姆·葛朗台死后二十三个月，许多债主被巴黎市场更繁忙的业务搞得晕头转向，早已忘掉了葛朗台的债务，有的只是在想起来时说：
en: Twenty-three months after the death of Guillaume Grandet many of the creditors, carried away by more pressing business in the markets of Paris, had forgotten their Grandet claims, or only thought of them to say:

zh: “我开始相信，百分之四十七就是我能拿到的全部债款了。”
en: “I begin to believe that forty-seven per cent is all I shall ever get out of that affair.”

zh: 老箍桶匠早就对时间的能力做过计算，正如他过去常说的，时间真是个不错的魔鬼。到了第三年年底，德格拉桑写信给葛朗台说，他已经让债权人同意放弃葛朗台商号仍然结欠的两百四十万法郎中的百分之十。葛朗台回信说，因可耻的破产而害死他兄弟的那个公证人和经纪人仍然活着，他们现在可能已恢复了信用，应该起诉他们，这样就可以让他们拿出些钱来减少拖欠的总数目。
en: The old cooper had calculated on the power of time, which, as he used to say, is a pretty good devil after all.By the end of the third year des Grassins wrote to Grandet that he had brought the creditors to agree to give up their claims for ten per cent on the two million four hundred thousand francs still due by the house of Grandet.Grandet answered that the notary and the broker whose shameful failures had caused the death of his brother were still living, that they might now have recovered their credit, and that they ought to be sued, so as to get something out of them towards lessening the total of the deficit.

zh: 第四年年末，债务的总数被确切地估算为一百二十万法郎。债权人和清算人之间、清算人和葛朗台之间进行了多次谈判，历时六个多月。长话短说，大约在第四年的第九个月，索米尔的葛朗台这时急于摆脱这件事，便告诉清算人，他的侄子在西印度发了财，愿意还清他父亲的全部债务；因而，他不能事先不跟侄子商量就擅自了结；他已经给他侄子写了信，正等着回信呢。
en: By the end of the fourth year the liabilities were definitely estimated at a sum of twelve hundred thousand francs.Many negotiations, lasting over six months, took place between the creditors and the liquidators, and between the liquidators and Grandet.To make a long story short, Grandet of Saumur, anxious by this time to get out of the affair, told the liquidators, about the ninth month of the fourth year, that his nephew had made a fortune in the Indies and was disposed to pay his father’s debts in full; he therefore could not take upon himself to make any settlement without previously consulting him; he had written to him, and was expecting an answer.

zh: 直到第五年年中，债权人还是被“全部还清”这几个字搪塞着，奸诈的老守财奴不时地把这几个字说出来，同时暗暗觉得好笑，他带着微笑咒骂道：“那些巴黎人！”
en: The creditors were held in check until the middle of the fifth year by the words, “payment in full,” which the wily old miser threw out from time to time as he laughed in his beard, saying with a smile and an oath, “Those Parisians!”

zh: 可是债权人的命运却是商业年鉴里从未有过的例子。这段历史事件让他们再一次出现在人们的视线中时，人们发现他们仍旧处在葛朗台最初就决意给他们安排的位置上。
en: But the creditors were reserved for a fate unexampled in the annals of commerce.When the events of this history bring them once more into notice, they will be found still in the position Grandet had resolved to force them into from the first.

zh: 等公债一涨到一百一十五，葛朗台老头抛出了他的股权，收回了两百四十万法郎的黄金，他把这笔钱，连同从本金获取的六十万法郎复利，一起都放进了他的金库。德格拉桑现在生活在巴黎。首先，他当选为众议员；其次，他迷上了（尽管是一家之父，他却对索米尔的外省生活极为厌倦）夫人剧院一个漂亮的女演员，名叫弗洛丽娜，他现在又染上了当兵时的旧习气。他的行径不用多提，索米尔人认为那真是伤风败俗。他的妻子还算走运，争取到了她自己的财产，也有足够的能力继续维持索米尔的银行，银行在她的名下进行管理，并且补上了她丈夫挥霍所致的亏空。克吕绍派四处散播这个活寡妇处境艰难的流言蜚语，说她没把女儿嫁好，还说她被迫放弃了她儿子和欧仁妮·葛朗台联姻的所有希望。阿道夫跟他父亲一起呆在巴黎，据说，变成了一个窝囊废。克吕绍家胜利了。
en: As soon as the Funds reached a hundred and fifteen, Pere Grandet sold out his interests and withdrew two million four hundred thousand francs in gold, to which he added, in his coffers, the six hundred thousand francs compound interest which he had derived from the capital.Des Grassins now lived in Paris.In the first place he had been made a deputy; then he became infatuated (father of a family as he was, though horribly bored by the provincial life of Saumur) with a pretty actress at the Theatre de Madame, known as Florine, and he presently relapsed into the old habits of his army life.It is useless to speak of his conduct; Saumur considered it profoundly immoral.His wife was fortunate in the fact of her property being settled upon herself, and in having sufficient ability to keep up the banking-house in Saumur, which was managed in her name and repaired the breach in her fortune caused by the extravagance of her husband.The Cruchotines made so much talk about the false position of the quasi-widow that she married her daughter very badly, and was forced to give up all hope of an alliance between Eugenie Grandet and her son.Adolphe joined his father in Paris and became, it was said, a worthless fellow.The Cruchots triumphed.

zh: “您丈夫真糊涂，”当葛朗台借给德格拉桑太太一些钱，并让她在票据上签字时，他说，“我很同情您，因为您是个好妻子。”
en: “Your husband hasn’t common sense,” said Grandet as he lent Madame des Grassins some money on a note securely endorsed.“I am very sorry for you, for you are a good little woman.”

zh: “啊，先生，”可怜的女人说，“谁能想到他离开索米尔去巴黎给您办差，竟会走上绝路呢？”
en: “Ah, monsieur,” said the poor lady, “who could have believed that when he left Saumur to go to Paris on your business he was going to his ruin?”

zh: “老天作证，夫人，直到最后一刻，我都在拼命拦着他，不让他去呢。庭长先生非常想替代他，可是他打定主意要去，现在我们都知道是什么原因了。”
en: “Heaven is my witness, madame, that up to the last moment I did all I could to prevent him from going.Monsieur le president was most anxious to take his place; but he was determined to go, and now we all see why.”

zh: 这样一来，葛朗台就说得很清楚，他不欠德格拉桑的人情。在任何情况下，女人痛苦的理由总是比男人多，而且痛苦的程度也更深。男人有力气，而且有能力去施展力气；他活动，奔走，思考，忙碌；他展望未来，在未来里看到慰籍。夏尔就是这样。但是女人是呆在家里的，她总是面对悲伤而无以排遣。她深深陷于冲她张开大嘴的深渊中，测量它的深度，经常用眼泪和祈祷来填满它。这就是欧仁妮。她开始认识自己的命运。去感受，去爱，去受苦，去奉献自己——不就是女人生命的全部吗？欧仁妮各方面都可算作一个女人，只缺乏一个可资慰籍的东西。她的幸福像布满墙的钉子，拔起来——用波舒哀精彩的比喻来说——却永远无法填满她的手心。悲伤从不会姗姗来迟，对她来说，它们来得很快。夏尔走后第二天，葛朗台先生的家在大家眼里又恢复了原样，只有欧仁妮不这样看，对她来说，屋子突然一下子变空了。如果能瞒过她父亲的话，她希望夏尔的房间还可以保留他走时的样子。葛朗台太太和娜农很乐于帮她维持原状。
en: In this way Grandet made it quite plain that he was under no obligation to des Grassins.In all situations women have more cause for suffering than men, and they suffer more.Man has strength and the power of exercising it; he acts, moves, thinks, occupies himself; he looks ahead, and sees consolation in the future.It was thus with Charles.But the woman stays at home; she is always face to face with the grief from which nothing distracts her; she goes down to the depths of the abyss which yawns before her, measures it, and often fills it with her tears and prayers.Thus did Eugenie.She initiated herself into her destiny.To feel, to love, to suffer, to devote herself,—is not this the sum of woman’s life?Eugenie was to be in all things a woman, except in the one thing that consoles for all.Her happiness, picked up like nails scattered on a wall—to use the fine simile of Bossuet—would never so much as fill even the hollow of her hand.Sorrows are never long in coming; for her they came soon.The day after Charles’s departure the house of Monsieur Grandet resumed its ordinary aspect in the eyes of all, except in those of Eugenie, to whom it grew suddenly empty.She wished, if it could be done unknown to her father, that Charles’s room might be kept as he had left it.Madame Grandet and Nanon were willing accomplices in this @statu quo@.

zh: “谁知道他会不会比我们预想的要回来得早呢？”她说。
en: “Who knows but he may come back sooner than we think for?” she said.

zh: “啊，我真希望能看见他回来！”娜农回答道，“我喜欢他！他是这样一个可爱、讨人喜欢的年轻人——又漂亮，头发还卷卷的。”欧仁妮看着娜农。“圣母玛利亚！别那样看着我，小姐，你的眼睛像失了魂似的。”
en: “Ah, don’t I wish I could see him back!” answered Nanon.“I took to him!He was such a dear, sweet young man,—pretty too, with his curly hair.”Eugenie looked at Nanon.“Holy Virgin! Don’t look at me that way, mademoiselle; your eyes are like those of a lost soul.”

zh: 从那天起，葛朗台小姐的美有了新的特点。对爱情认真的思考慢慢填满了她的灵魂，再加上有了爱情的女人所具有的那种尊贵，她的眉目间平添了一种画家用光环来表现的光辉。在她堂弟到来之前，欧仁妮可以比作是没有受孕的圣女；在他走后，她就像圣母玛利亚——她孕育出了爱情。这两个截然不同的玛利亚，被西班牙艺术表现得栩栩如生，体现了基督教文化众多光辉的形象之一。
en: From that day the beauty of Mademoiselle Grandet took a new character.The solemn thoughts of love which slowly filled her soul, and the dignity of the woman beloved, gave to her features an illumination such as painters render by a halo.Before the coming of her cousin, Eugenie might be compared to the Virgin before the conception; after he had gone, she was like the Virgin Mother,—she had given birth to love.These two Marys so different, so well represented by Spanish art, embody one of those shining symbols with which Christianity abounds.

zh: 夏尔走后第二天早上，欧仁妮听完弥撒回来——她发誓要天天听——她买了一张世界地图，钉到了她的镜子旁边，这样她就能跟着堂弟一路西去，就能让自己天天置身于他坐的船上，即使船很小也不怕，她就能看见他，问他上千个问题——“你好吗？
en: Returning from Mass on the morning after Charles’s departure,—having made a vow to hear it daily,—Eugenie bought a map of the world, which she nailed up beside her looking-glass, that she might follow her cousin on his westward way, that she might put herself, were it ever so little, day by day into the ship that bore him, and see him and ask him a thousand questions,—“Art thou well?

zh: 你受苦了吗？你曾教我知道了那颗星星的美丽和用途，当那颗星星在你头顶闪烁的时候，你想我了没有？”早上，她坐在胡桃树下那个虫蚀斑斑、覆盖着灰色苔藓的长凳上沉思，在这里他们曾经互诉衷肠、甜言蜜语，在这里他们曾经构想着他们未来家园的美丽城堡。此刻，当她抬头仰望着高高的围墙上留出的一角天空时，她遥想着将来；接着，她把目光转到阳光影影绰绰照到的一个角落，又转到夏尔卧室的屋顶。她的爱是孤独的爱，是持久的爱，渐渐浸入她的每一个思想，变成了生命的本质，或者像我们的先辈们曾说过的，变成了生命的组织。当那些自称是葛朗台老头的朋友晚上来打牌时，她做出高兴的样子，掩饰着自己；而整整一个早上，她都在跟她母亲和娜农谈着夏尔。娜农已经懂得，她可以对她小主人的痛苦表示同情，而并不有愧于她对老主人的职责，她对欧仁妮说——
en: Dost thou suffer?Dost thou think of me when the star, whose beauty and usefulness thou hast taught me to know, shines upon thee?”In the mornings she sat pensive beneath the walnut-tree, on the worm-eaten bench covered with gray lichens, where they had said to each other so many precious things, so many trifles, where they had built the pretty castles of their future home.She thought of the future now as she looked upward to the bit of sky which was all the high walls suffered her to see; then she turned her eyes to the angle where the sun crept on, and to the roof above the room in which he had slept.Hers was the solitary love, the persistent love, which glides into every thought and becomes the substance, or, as our fathers might have said, the tissue of life.When the would-be friends of Pere Grandet came in the evening for their game at cards, she was gay and dissimulating; but all the morning she talked of Charles with her mother and Nanon.Nanon had brought herself to see that she could pity the sufferings of her young mistress without failing in her duty to the old master, and she would say to Eugenie,—

zh: “如果我有了自己的心上人，我会——我会跟着他到地狱，真的，我会为他去死的，可是我没有心上人。我到死也永远不会知道人生是怎么回事。你相信吗，小姐，那个老科努瓦耶（倒是个好人）总是围着我的裙子转，他是为了我的钱——就像全世界那些来嗅着主人的奶酪、向你献殷勤的耗子？我什么都明白，我的眼光敏锐，尽管我高得像塔顶。唉，小姐，这挺让我高兴，但那不是爱情。”
en: “If I had a man for myself I’d—I’d follow him to hell, yes, I’d exterminate myself for him; but I’ve none.I shall die and never know what life is.Would you believe, mamz’elle, that old Cornoiller (a good fellow all the same) is always round my petticoats for the sake of my money,—just for all the world like the rats who come smelling after the master’s cheese and paying court to you?I see it all; I’ve got a shrewd eye, though I am as big as a steeple.Well, mamz’elle, it pleases me, but it isn’t love.”

zh: 第十章
en: Chapter X

zh: 两个月过去了。这家人的生活曾经那么单调，现在因为这些女人都密切关心着一个秘密而有了生气，这个秘密把她们紧紧地连在了一起。对她们来说，夏尔还在大厅那阴森的灰色椽木下生活着，并走来走去。一早一晚，欧仁妮都会打开梳妆箱，凝视她婶婶的肖像。一个星期天的早晨，正当她全神贯注地在婶婶的脸上揣摩堂弟本人的面貌时，被母亲撞见了。葛朗台太太这时才第一次知道了那个可怕的秘密，夏尔换取了她女儿的宝物。
en: Two months went by.This domestic life, once so monotonous, was now quickened with the intense interest of a secret that bound these women intimately together.For them Charles lived and moved beneath the grim gray rafters of the hall.Night and morning Eugenie opened the dressing-case and gazed at the portrait of her aunt.One Sunday morning her mother surprised her as she stood absorbed in finding her cousin’s features in his mother’s face.Madame Grandet was then for the first time admitted into the terrible secret of the exchange made by Charles against her daughter’s treasure.

zh: “你全都给了他！”可怜的母亲吓坏了，大声说道，“等新年你父亲要看你的金子时，你可怎么跟他说？”
en: “You gave him all!” cried the poor mother, terrified.“What will you say to your father on New Year’s Day when he asks to see your gold?”

zh: 欧仁妮两眼发了直，两个女人大半个早上都惶恐得要命。她们脑子里乱糟糟的，以致于错过了大弥撒，只听到了结尾的弥撒曲。再有三天，一八一九年就要过完了。三天后，一场可怕的戏剧就要开演了，这是一个资产阶级的悲剧，没有毒药，没有匕首，也没有鲜血四溅；可是——对于剧中的所有演员来说——却要比神话中阿特里得斯家族所发生的一切惨剧还要残酷。
en: Eugenie’s eyes grew fixed, and the two women lived through mortal terror for more than half the morning.They were so troubled in mind that they missed high Mass, and only went to the military service.In three days the year 1819 would come to an end.In three days a terrible drama would begin, a bourgeois tragedy, without poison, or dagger, or the spilling of blood; but—as regards the actors in it—more cruel than all the fabled horrors in the family of the Atrides.

zh: “我们怎么办？”葛朗台太太把毛线活放在膝盖上，对女儿说道。
en: “What will become of us?” said Madame Grandet to her daughter, letting her knitting fall upon her knees.

zh: 这可怜的母亲在过去的两个月中经历了这么多的焦虑，竟连过冬要用的毛线袖套都还没织好。这件家务事尽管表面上无关紧要，却产生了可悲的后果。由于没有那副袖套，她丈夫大发雷霆时，她出了身冷汗，结果竟中了恶寒。
en: The poor mother had gone through such anxiety for the past two months that the woollen sleeves which she needed for the coming winter were not yet finished.This domestic fact, insignificant as it seems, bore sad results.For want of those sleeves, a chill seized her in the midst of a sweat caused by a terrible explosion of anger on the part of her husband.

zh: “我可怜的孩子，我一直在想，如果你早跟我透露你的秘密，我们应该还有时间写信给在巴黎的德格拉桑先生。他或许能给我们寄一些和你的金子相仿的金币,尽管葛朗台很熟悉它们，也许——”
en: “I have been thinking, my poor child, that if you had confided your secret to me we should have had time to write to Monsieur des Grassins in Paris.He might have sent us gold pieces like yours; though Grandet knows them all, perhaps—”

zh: “我们到哪里去弄到钱呢？”
en: “Where could we have got the money?”

zh: “我会把我自己的财产抵押出去。此外，德格拉桑先生会——”
en: “I would have pledged my own property.Besides, Monsieur des Grassins would have—”

zh: “太晚了，”欧仁妮声音嘶哑空洞地说道，“明天早晨我们得去他的卧室给他拜年。”
en: “It is too late,” said Eugenie in a broken, hollow voice.“Tomorrow morning we must go and wish him a happy New Year in his chamber.”

zh: “可是，我的女儿，为什么我不能去问问克吕绍呢？”
en: “But, my daughter, why should I not consult the Cruchots?”

zh: “不，不，那是把我送到他们那里去，由着他们摆布我们了。而且，我已经拿定主意了。我做得对，我没什么可后悔的。上帝会保佑我的。愿他保佑我！啊！母亲，如果您看过他的信，您也会一心只想着他的。”
en: “No, no; it would be delivering me up to them, and putting ourselves in their power.Besides, I have chosen my course.I have done right; I repent of nothing.God will protect me.His will be done!Ah! mother, if you had read his letter, you, too, would have thought only of him.”

zh: 第二天早上，也就是一八二零年一月一日，母女俩在极度的恐惧下，想出了一个很自然的借口，可以不用郑重其事地到葛朗台的卧室了。一八一九至一八二零年的冬天是那个时代最寒冷的一个冬天。屋顶堆满了积雪。
en: The next morning, January 1, 1820, the horrible fear to which mother and daughter were a prey suggested to their minds a natural excuse by which to escape the solemn entrance into Grandet’s chamber.The winter of 1819-1820 was one of the coldest of that epoch.The snow encumbered the roofs.

zh: 葛朗台太太一听到她丈夫的房间有响动，就叫了叫他，并说道——
en: Madame Grandet called to her husband as soon as she heard him stirring in his chamber, and said,—

zh: “葛朗台，你叫娜农在我这里生个火吧？太冷了，我在被窝里都冻僵了。到我这个年纪，我就需要舒适的环境了。而且，”稍停了一下，她又说道，“欧仁妮要来穿衣服，这种天气，可怜的孩子在她冰冷的屋子里穿衣会得病的。之后我们会去大厅的壁炉边给你拜年的。”
en: “Grandet, will you let Nanon light a fire here for me?The cold is so sharp that I am freezing under the bedclothes.At my age I need some comforts.Besides,” she added, after a slight pause, “Eugenie shall come and dress here; the poor child might get an illness from dressing in her cold room in such weather.Then we will go and wish you a happy New Year beside the fire in the hall.”

zh: “得，得，得，得，真会说！新年的好开头，葛朗台太太！你以前从没说过这么多的话，我想，你该不是把面包浸到酒里了吧。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta, what a tongue! A pretty way to begin the new year, Madame Grandet!You never talked so much before; but you haven’t been sopping your bread in wine, I know that.”

zh: 一时都沉默了。
en: There was a moment’s silence.

zh: “好吧，”老头同意了妻子的要求，毫无疑问，他自有道理，他继续说道，“我会按你的意思做的，葛朗台太太。你是个好女人，我不想让你在这把年纪还有什么闪失——尽管一般而言，贝尔特利耶家的人身体都很棒。嗯！是不是这样？”他停了一下，又说道，“算了，咱们最后拿了他们的遗产，我原谅他们。”说完，他咳嗽了起来。
en: “Well,” resumed the goodman, who no doubt had some reason of his own for agreeing to his wife’s request, “I’ll do what you ask, Madame Grandet.You are a good woman, and I don’t want any harm to happen to you at your time of life,—though as a general thing the Bertellieres are as sound as a roach.Hein! Isn’t that so?” he added after a pause.“Well, I forgive them; we got their property in the end.”And he coughed.

zh: “你今天早上很开心，先生。”可怜的女人口气严肃地说道。
en: “You are very gay this morning, monsieur,” said the poor woman gravely.

zh: “我一直很开心——
en: “I’m always gay,—

zh: ‘开心，开心，开心，箍桶匠，
en: ‘Gai, gai, gai, le tonnelier,

zh: 快补你的洗衣桶！’”他一边答着，一边衣着齐整地进了妻子的房间。“是的，说实话，真是够冷的，能把你冻僵。咱们今天早餐吃好的，太太。德格拉桑给我送来了蘑菇鹅肝酱！我现在就到驿站取去。包裹里还会有给欧仁妮的一枚面值四十法郎的金币，”他在葛朗台太太的耳边低声说道，“我没金子了，太太。我本来有几个零碎钱——我不怕告诉你——可是我必须要用到生意上。”
en: Raccommodez votre cuvier!’” he answered, entering his wife’s room fully dressed.“Yes, on my word, it is cold enough to freeze you solid.We shall have a fine breakfast, wife.Des Grassins has sent me a pate-de-foie-gras truffled!I am going now to get it at the coach-office.There’ll be a double napoleon for Eugenie in the package,” he whispered in Madame Grandet’s ear.“I have no gold left, wife.I had a few stray pieces—I don’t mind telling you that—but I had to let them go in business.”

zh: 接着，为祝贺新年，他吻了吻她的额头。
en: Then, by way of celebrating the new year, he kissed her on the forehead.

zh: “欧仁妮，”等葛朗台的身影完全消失后，母亲大声叫着，“我不知道你父亲是从床的哪边起的身，他今天早上脾气非常好。也许我们最后会平安无事呢？”
en: “Eugenie,” cried the mother, when Grandet was fairly gone, “I don’t know which side of the bed your father got out of, but he is good-tempered this morning.Perhaps we shall come out safe after all?”

zh: “老爷怎么啦？”娜农说着，进了女主人的房间来生火，“首先，他说，‘早上好，新年快乐，你个大笨蛋！去给我太太生火去，她冷’；接着，当他伸出手给了我一枚一点儿没磨损过的六法郎的硬币时，我能不发傻吗？看看这个，太太！哦，好心人！他是个好人，那是事实。有些人是越老心肠越硬，可是他——他为什么就会越变越温和，越来越好，就像您的果味甜酒一样呢！他是个非常非常好的人——”
en: “What’s happened to the master?” said Nanon, entering her mistress’s room to light the fire.“First place, he said, ‘Good-morning; happy New Year, you big fool!Go and light my wife’s fire, she’s cold’; and then, didn’t I feel silly when he held out his hand and gave me a six-franc piece, which isn’t worn one bit?Just look at it, madame!Oh, the kind man!He is a good man, that’s a fact.There are some people who the older they get the harder they grow; but he,—why he’s getting soft and improving with time, like your ratafia!He is a good, good man—”

zh: 葛朗台高兴的秘密在于他的投机生意大获成功。德格拉桑先生在扣除了老箍桶匠欠他的十五万法郎荷兰债券的贴现折扣，以及为他买进每年十万法郎的公债垫付的盈余之后，现在通过驿车给他送来了他头半年的利息余额，三万法郎的银币，同时通知他公债已经开始升值。
en: The secret of Grandet’s joy lay in the complete success of his speculation.Monsieur des Grassins, after deducting the amount which the old cooper owed him for the discount on a hundred and fifty thousand francs in Dutch notes, and for the surplus which he had advanced to make up the sum required for the investment in the Funds which was to produce a hundred thousand francs a year, had now sent him, by the diligence, thirty thousand francs in silver coin, the remainder of his first half-year’s interest, informing him at the same time that the Funds had already gone up in value.

zh: 那时公债报价是八十九，到一月底，最精明的资本家们还是以九十三买进的。这样，葛朗台的投资在两个月内赚了百分之十二；他已经核算过账目，将来每六个月能获得五万法郎的利息，无须缴纳税费或者维修费。他终于明白了投资公债的好处——外省人对这个体系一向深恶痛绝——不出五年，不用他费多少力，资本就会增长，他就会成为六百万资本的主人，这些钱，再加上他的地产价值和收益，会让他拥有一笔绝对巨大无比的财富。
en: They were then quoted at eighty-nine; the shrewdest capitalists bought in, towards the last of January, at ninety-three.Grandet had thus gained in two months twelve per cent on his capital; he had simplified his accounts, and would in future receive fifty thousand francs interest every six months, without incurring any taxes or costs for repairs.He understood at last what it was to invest money in the public securities,—a system for which provincials have always shown a marked repugnance,—and at the end of five years he found himself master of a capital of six millions, which increased without much effort of his own, and which, joined to the value and proceeds of his territorial possessions, gave him a fortune that was absolutely colossal.

zh: 也许是对这个可怜的佣人不自觉帮了主人某个大忙，她的主人才给了她六法郎作为奖赏吧。
en: The six francs bestowed on Nanon were perhaps the reward of some great service which the poor servant had rendered to her master unawares.

zh: “哦！哦！葛朗台老头要去哪里呀？从太阳升起来，他就一直到处乱转，好像去救火似的。”生意人们当天一边开着铺门，一边互相谈论着。
en: “Oh! Oh! Where’s Pere Grandet going?He has been scurrying about since sunrise as if to a fire,” said the tradespeople to each other as they opened their shops for the day.

zh: 当看见他从码头回来，后面跟着一个驿站的脚夫，脚夫推着一辆装满袋子的独轮车时，他们各抒己见——
en: When they saw him coming back from the wharf, followed by a porter from the coach-office wheeling a barrow which was laden with sacks, they all had their comments to make:—

zh: “水往河里流，老家伙在追着金子跑。”一个人说。
en: “Water flows to the river; the old fellow was running after his gold,” said one.

zh: “他从巴黎、弗罗瓦丰，还有荷兰往回捞钱呢。”另一个人说。
en: “He gets it from Paris and Froidfond and Holland,” said another.

zh: “他最后会把索米尔都买下来呢。”第三个人大声说道。
en: “He’ll end by buying up Saumur,” cried a third.

zh: “他不怕冷，他忙着赚钱呢。”一位妻子对她的丈夫说道。
en: “He doesn’t mind the cold, he’s so wrapped up in his gains,” said a wife to her husband.

zh: “嘿！嘿！葛朗台先生，如果您拿着太重，”他最近的邻居——一个卖布的商人说道，“我替您拿着。”
en: “Hey! Hey!Monsieur Grandet, if that’s too heavy for you,” said a cloth-dealer, his nearest neighbor, “I’ll take it off your hands.”

zh: “重？”箍桶匠说，“我倒想这样，都是铜钱而已！”
en: “Heavy?” said the cooper, “I should think so; it’s all sous!”

zh: “银子的苏。”脚夫低声说道。
en: “Silver sous,” said the porter in a low voice.

zh: “要是想让我关照你，就闭上你的嘴。”等他们到了门口，老头对脚夫说。
en: “If you want me to take care of you, keep your tongue between your teeth,” said the goodman to the porter as they reached the door.

zh: “老狐狸！我以为他耳朵聋呢，看来在冷天里他倒是听得清。”
en: “The old fox!I thought he was deaf; seems he can hear fast enough in frosty weather.”

zh: “这是给你过年的二十个苏，别乱讲！”葛朗台说，“滚蛋！娜农会把你的独轮车还回去的。娜农，母女俩都去教堂了？”
en: “Here’s twenty sous for your New Year, and @mum@!” said Grandet.“Be off with you!Nanon shall take back your barrow.Nanon, are the linnets at church?”

zh: “是的，先生。”
en: “Yes, monsieur.”

zh: “那搭把手！去干活！”他嚷嚷着，把袋子堆到她身上。不一会儿，东西都搬进了他的内屋，他进去关上了门。“等早饭好了，敲敲墙。”他进去的时候说道，“把独轮车还回驿站去。”
en: “Then lend a hand! Go to work!” he cried, piling the sacks upon her.In a few moments all were carried up to his inner room, where he shut himself in with them.“When breakfast is ready, knock on the wall,” he said as he disappeared.“Take the barrow back to the coach-office.”

zh: 一家人那天直到十点才吃早饭。
en: The family did not breakfast that day until ten o’clock.

zh: “你父亲不会在楼下问你要金子看的，”当她们望完弥撒回来时，葛朗台太太说道，“你一定要假装很冷。在你生日前，我们可能还有时间来把那笔钱补上。”
en: “Your father will not ask to see your gold downstairs,” said Madame Grandet as they got back from Mass.“You must pretend to be very chilly.We may have time to replace the treasure before your fete-day.”

zh: 葛朗台一边下楼，一边想着他那笔成功的政府公债投机生意，考虑怎么样才能把他在巴黎赚的银子变成纯金；他决定以这种方法把所有收入投资进去，直到行情涨到一百法郎为止。对欧仁妮来说，这真是致命的盘算！他一进来，两个女人就给他拜年——他的女儿搂着他的脖子，抚摸着他；葛朗台太太则是很严肃、很庄重的样子。
en: Grandet came down the staircase thinking of his splendid speculation in government securities, and wondering how he could metamorphose his Parisian silver into solid gold; he was making up his mind to invest in this way everything he could lay hands on until the Funds should reach a par value.Fatal reverie for Eugenie!As soon as he came in, the two women wished him a happy New Year,—his daughter by putting her arms round his neck and caressing him; Madame Grandet gravely and with dignity.

zh: “哈！哈！我的孩子，”他吻了吻女儿的两颊，说道，“我是为你操劳的，瞧见没？我是为你的幸福着想的。要幸福，就得有钱。没有钱，不会有一丁点儿幸福的。喏！给你一个新拿破仑币。我让人从巴黎捎的。我以名誉担保，我所有的金子就是这个了，你是家里唯一有金子的人。我要看看你的金子，小乖乖。”
en: “Ha! Ha! My child,” he said, kissing his daughter on both cheeks.“I work for you, don’t you see?I think of your happiness.Must have money to be happy.Without money there’s not a particle of happiness.Here! There’s a new napoleon for you.I sent to Paris for it.On my word of honor, it’s all the gold I have; you are the only one that has got any gold.I want to see your gold, little one.”

zh: “哦！太冷了，咱们吃早饭吧。”欧仁妮回答道。
en: “Oh! It is too cold; let us have breakfast,” answered Eugenie.

zh: “好的，那就等早饭后再说，有助于消化。德格拉桑那个胖子送了我肉酱。想吃多少，就吃多少，我的孩子们，又不花一分钱。德格拉桑干得不错。我对他很满意。这老家伙在帮夏尔的大忙，而且还是免费。他把那个可怜的、已故的葛朗台的事处理得很妥当。呜！呜！”他嘴里塞得满满的，停了一下，嘟哝着，“太好吃了！吃点吧，太太，这东西至少让你饱上两天。”
en: “Well, after breakfast, then; it will help the digestion.That fat des Grassins sent me the pate.Eat as much as you like, my children, it costs nothing.Des Grassins is getting along very well.I am satisfied with him.The old fish is doing Charles a good service, and gratis too.He is making a very good settlement of that poor deceased Grandet’s business.Hoo! Hoo!” he muttered, with his mouth full, after a pause, “how good it is!Eat some, wife; that will feed you for at least two days.”

zh: “我不饿。我身体很不舒服，你知道的。”
en: “I am not hungry.I am very poorly; you know that.”

zh: “啊，呸！你尽可以吃得饱饱的，撑不死，你是贝尔特利耶家的人，他们身子骨都很结实。你皮肤是有点黄，的确如此，不过我本人喜欢黄色。”
en: “Ah, bah! You can stuff yourself as full as you please without danger, you’re a Bertelliere; they are all hearty.You are a bit yellow, that’s true; but I like yellow, myself.”

zh: 一个等着蒙受耻辱、当众处死的死囚也许都不会比等着早饭后出事的葛朗台太太和欧仁妮更为惊恐。老头边讲边吃，他越高兴，她们的心就揪得越厉害。不过，女儿在这场危机面前有个内在的支柱——她从爱情中汲取了力量。
en: The expectation of ignominious and public death is perhaps less horrible to a condemned criminal than the anticipation of what was coming after breakfast to Madame Grandet and Eugenie.The more gleefully the old man talked and ate, the more their hearts shrank within them.The daughter, however, had an inward prop at this crisis,—she gathered strength through love.

zh: “为了他！为了他！”她在心里呐喊着，“我愿意死上一千次。”
en: “For him! For him!” she cried within her, “I would die a thousand deaths.”

zh: 这样想着，她朝母亲望去，眼里闪烁着勇敢无畏的神采。
en: At this thought, she shot a glance at her mother which flamed with courage.

zh: “收拾走，”大约十一点，早饭吃完后，葛朗台对娜农说道，“不过，把桌子留下。我们可以把你的小金库摆在上面，”他一边说，一边看着欧仁妮，“小？千真万确！不，它不小。你拥有的实际价值是五千九百五十九法郎，还有我刚刚给你的四十法郎。差一个，就是六千法郎。好的，现在看看这儿，小乖乖！我要给你一个法郎，好凑个整数。嘿！你听什么呢，娜农？少管闲事，干你自己的活去。”
en: “Clear away,” said Grandet to Nanon when, about eleven o’clock, breakfast was over, “but leave the table.We can spread your little treasure upon it,” he said, looking at Eugenie.“Little?Faith! No; it isn’t little.You possess, in actual value, five thousand nine hundred and fifty-nine francs and the forty I gave you just now.That makes six thousand francs, less one.Well, now see here, little one!I’ll give you that one franc to make up the round number.Hey! What are you listening for, Nanon?Mind your own business; go and do your work.”

zh: 娜农走了。
en: Nanon disappeared.

zh: “现在听着，欧仁妮，你必须把你的金子还给我。你不会拒绝你父亲的，我的小姑娘，嗯？”
en: “Now listen, Eugenie; you must give me back your gold.You won’t refuse your father, my little girl, hein?”

zh: 两个女人都不说话。
en: The two women were dumb.

zh: “我没金子。我曾经有一些，不过都没了。我会还给你六千法郎里弗赫的，而且你要按我说的把这笔钱放出去。你千万别再想着你的什么‘压箱钱’了。等我把你嫁出去的时候（那会很快的），我会给你找个丈夫，他能给你外省所见过的最体面的‘压箱钱’的。现在听我的，小姑娘。有个好机会等着你，你可以把你那六千法郎投进政府公债里，然后你每六个月就会得到差不多两百法郎的利息，没有税费，没有维修费，也没有什么霜呀、冰雹呀、洪水呀，没有任何东西会把钱给吞噬掉。也许你不想和你的金子分开，嘿，我的小姑娘？别担心，只管拿给我。像那样的金子，我会给你更多——比如荷兰硬币和葡萄牙币、莫卧儿卢比、热那亚金币——在你生日那天，我会再多给你一些的，三年以后，你就会拿回一半你的小金库。你看那怎么样？现在把头抬起来。来吧，去把它拿来，那些宝贵的金属。你应该吻吻我的眼睑，因为我告诉了你金钱生死的诀窍和奥秘。是的，银子和金子像人一样有生命，会成群地活动，它们来了，又去了，会出汗，能繁殖——”
en: “I have no gold myself.I had some, but it is all gone.I’ll give you in return six thousand francs in @livres@, and you are to put them just where I tell you.You mustn’t think anything more about your ‘dozen.’ When I marry you (which will be soon) I shall get you a husband who can give you the finest ‘dozen’ ever seen in the provinces.Now attend to me, little girl.There’s a fine chance for you; you can put your six thousand francs into government funds, and you will receive every six months nearly two hundred francs interest, without taxes, or repairs, or frost, or hail, or floods, or anything else to swallow up the money.Perhaps you don’t like to part with your gold, hey, my girl?Never mind, bring it to me all the same.I’ll get you some more like it,—like those Dutch coins and the @portugaises@, the rupees of Mogul, and the @genovines@,—I’ll give you some more on your fete-days, and in three years you’ll have got back half your little treasure.What’s that you say?Look up, now.Come, go and get it, the precious metal.You ought to kiss me on the eyelids for telling you the secrets and the mysteries of the life and death of money.Yes, silver and gold live and swarm like men; they come, and go, and sweat, and multiply—”

zh: 欧仁妮站了起来，但是朝门口走了几步之后，她突然转过身来，当面直视着父亲，说道——
en: Eugenie rose; but after making a few steps towards the door she turned abruptly, looked her father in the face, and said,—

zh: “我的金子没了。”
en: “I have not got @my@ gold.”

zh: “你的金子没了！”葛朗台一边高声叫着，一边像一匹听到旁边有大炮在发射的马一样，直挺挺地站了起来。
en: “You have not got your gold!” cried Grandet, starting up erect, like a horse that hears a cannon fired beside him.

zh: “是的，我没金子了。”
en: “No, I have not got it.”

zh: “你搞错了吧，欧仁妮。”
en: “You are mistaken, Eugenie.”

zh: “没有。”
en: “No.”

zh: “凭我老父的剪刀作证！”
en: “By the shears of my father!”

zh: 每当老头骂出这句咒语时，房梁都会颤起来。
en: Whenever the old man swore that oath the rafters trembled.

zh: “圣母玛利亚！太太的脸都白了。”娜农叫道。
en: “Holy Virgin!Madame is turning pale,” cried Nanon.

zh: “葛朗台，你的火气会吓死我的。”可怜的母亲说道。
en: “Grandet, your anger will kill me,” said the poor mother.

zh: “得，得，得，得！胡说八道，你永远都不会死在家里！欧仁妮，你拿你的金子干什么去了？”他向她冲过来，喊道。
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta! Nonsense; you never die in your family!Eugenie, what have you done with your gold?” he cried, rushing upon her.

zh: “先生，”女儿趴在葛朗台太太的膝上，说道，“我母亲病了。看看她，别逼死她。”
en: “Monsieur,” said the daughter, falling at Madame Grandet’s knees, “my mother is ill.Look at her; do not kill her.”

zh: 看到妻子平时泛黄的脸色发了白，葛朗台害怕了。
en: Grandet was frightened by the pallor which overspread his wife’s face, usually so yellow.

zh: “娜农，把我扶上床，”可怜的女人声音微弱地说道，“我要死了——”
en: “Nanon, help me to bed,” said the poor woman in a feeble voice, “I am dying—”

zh: 娜农扶住她的女主人一只胳膊，欧仁妮扶住了她的另一只；但是她们费尽力气才把她扶上楼，她每走一步都精疲力尽地要跌倒。葛朗台独自呆着。可是不一会儿，他走上六级或是八级楼梯，大声喊着——
en: Nanon gave her mistress an arm, Eugenie gave her another; but it was only with infinite difficulty that they could get her upstairs, she fell with exhaustion at every step.Grandet remained alone.However, in a few moments he went up six or eight stairs and called out,—

zh: “欧仁妮，等你母亲躺到了床上，你就下来。”
en: “Eugenie, when your mother is in bed, come down.”

zh: “是，父亲。”
en: “Yes, father.”

zh: 安抚了母亲之后，她很快就来了。
en: She soon came, after reassuring her mother.

zh: “女儿，”葛朗台说，“现在，你要告诉我，你用金子做什么了。”
en: “My daughter,” said Grandet, “you will now tell me what you have done with your gold.”

zh: “父亲，如果你送了我礼物，我却不是唯一的主人，那就把它们拿回去。”她一边冷冷地回答道，一边从壁炉台上拿起那个拿破仑币，递给了他。
en: “My father, if you make me presents of which I am not the sole mistress, take them back,” she answered coldly, picking up the napoleon from the chimney-piece and offering it to him.

zh: 葛朗台抓住那枚硬币，塞进他的裤子兜里。
en: Grandet seized the coin and slipped it into his breeches’ pocket.

zh: “我肯定再也不给你任何东西了。连那个也不给！”他把大拇指的指甲往一颗前门牙上一磕，说道，“你竟敢蔑视你的父亲？你不信任他？你难道不知道什么叫做父亲吗？要是他对你来说什么都不是，他就什么都不是。你的金子到哪里去了？”
en: “I shall certainly never give you anything again.Not so much as that!” he said, clicking his thumb-nail against a front tooth.“Do you dare to despise your father? Have you no confidence in him?Don’t you know what a father is?If he is nothing for you, he is nothing at all.Where is your gold?”

zh: “父亲，尽管您生了气，我还是爱您，尊重您的，可是我要斗胆提醒您，我已经二十三岁了。您经常告诉我，我已经成年了，我没有忘记这句话。我已经按照我自己的意愿用了我的钱，您尽可以放心，钱用在正经地方了——”
en: “Father, I love and respect you, in spite of your anger; but I humbly ask you to remember that I am twenty-three years old.You have told me often that I have attained my majority, and I do not forget it.I have used my money as I chose to use it, and you may be sure that it was put to a good use—”

zh: “干什么用了？”
en: “What use?”

zh: “那是个秘密，不能泄露，”她回答道，“您就没有秘密吗？”
en: “That is an inviolable secret,” she answered.“Have you no secrets?”

zh: “我是一家之长，我有自己的事。”
en: “I am the head of the family; I have my own affairs.”

zh: “那这就是我的事。”
en: “And this is mine.”

zh: “要是连你父亲也不能告诉，那就不是什么好事，葛朗台小姐。”
en: “It must be something bad if you can’t tell it to your father, Mademoiselle Grandet.”

zh: “是好事，不过我不能告诉父亲。”
en: “It is good, and I cannot tell it to my father.”

zh: “至少你可以告诉我，你是什么时候没有金子的？”
en: “At least you can tell me when you parted with your gold?”

zh: 欧仁妮摇摇头，表示拒绝。
en: Eugenie made a negative motion with her head.

zh: “你过生日的时候，金子还在你手里，嗯？”
en: “You had it on your birthday, hein?”

zh: 她因为爱情而变得很狡猾，就像她父亲因为贪婪而狡猾一样，她一再摇头拒绝。
en: She grew as crafty through love as her father was through avarice, and reiterated the negative sign.

zh: “竟然这么顽固！那就是偷盗。”葛朗台大叫着，他的声音越来越大，渐渐地在整幢房子里都回响起来，“什么！在这儿，在我自己的家里，在我的眼皮子底下，有人拿走了你的金子！——我们仅有的金子！——而我还不能知道是谁拿的！金子是珍贵的东西。老实姑娘有时也会犯错，会给——我不知道是什么；在大户人家，甚至在平民百姓家，她们都会做这种事。可是竟然把她们的金子送人！——因为你已经给了什么人，嗯？——”
en: “Was there ever such obstinacy!It’s a theft,” cried Grandet, his voice going up in a crescendo which gradually echoed through the house.“What! Here, in my own home, under my very eyes, somebody has taken your gold!—The only gold we have!—And I’m not to know who has got it!Gold is a precious thing.Virtuous girls go wrong sometimes, and give—I don’t know what; they do it among the great people, and even among the bourgeoisie.But give their gold!—For you have given it to someone, hein?—”

zh: 欧仁妮沉默着，不动声色。
en: Eugenie was silent and impassive.

zh: “竟然会有这么一个女儿？我到底还是不是你的父亲？如果你把金子投资到什么地方，你应该有个收据——”
en: “Was there ever such a daughter?Is it possible that I am your father?If you have invested it anywhere, you must have a receipt—”

zh: “我有没有自由——有还是没有——用我的钱去做我想做的事？那钱难道不是我的吗？”
en: “Was I free—yes or no—to do what I would with my own?Was it not mine?”

zh: “你还是个孩子。”
en: “You are a child.”

zh: “成年了。”
en: “Of age.”

zh: 被女儿的逻辑驳得哑口无言，葛朗台脸色发白，跺着脚咒骂起来。等他最终要说话时，他大声嚷道：
en: Dumbfounded by his daughter’s logic, Grandet turned pale and stamped and swore.When at last he found words, he cried:

zh: “毒蛇！该死的丫头！啊，骗子！你知道我是疼爱你的，你就利用这一点。她是要割断她父亲的喉咙！老天爷！你把我们的家产给了那个游手好闲的家伙——那个穿摩洛哥羊皮靴的花花公子！　凭我老父的剪刀作证！我不能剥夺你的继承权，可是我要诅咒你——你和你的堂弟，还有你们的孩子！那不会有好结果的！你听见了吗？要是钱给了夏尔——不过，不，那不可能。什么！是那个恶棍抢劫了我吗？——”
en: “Serpent!Cursed girl!Ah, deceitful creature!You know I love you, and you take advantage of it.She’d cut her father’s throat!Good God! You’ve given our fortune to that ne’er-do-well,—that dandy with morocco boots!By the shears of my father!I can’t disinherit you, but I curse you,—you and your cousin and your children!Nothing good will come of it!Do you hear?If it was to Charles—but, no; it’s impossible.What! Has that wretched fellow robbed me?—”

zh: 他看着他的女儿，她仍旧神情冷漠，一声不吭。
en: He looked at his daughter, who continued cold and silent.

zh: “她动也不动；她不会退缩！她比我这个葛朗台还葛朗台！哈！你不会是白白把金子给出去的吧？喂，说真话！”
en: “She won’t stir; she won’t flinch!She’s more Grandet than I’m Grandet!Ha! You have not given your gold for nothing?Come, speak the truth!”

zh: 欧仁妮带着挖苦的神气看着她的父亲，这惹恼了他。
en: Eugenie looked at her father with a sarcastic expression that stung him.

zh: “欧仁妮，你是在这里，在我的家里——在你父亲的家里。如果你想呆在这儿，你就必须听我的话。神父告诫你要服从我。”欧仁妮低下了头。“你在我最心疼的事情上伤了我的心。你要是不屈服，我就不想再看见你。去你的卧室去。没有我的许可，你就别出来。娜农会给你送面包和水的。你听见我的话没有——走！”
en: “Eugenie, you are here, in my house,—in your father’s house.If you wish to stay here, you must submit yourself to me.The priests tell you to obey me.”Eugenie bowed her head.“You affront me in all I hold most dear.I will not see you again until you submit.Go to your chamber.You will stay there till I give you permission to leave it.Nanon will bring you bread and water.You hear me—go!”

zh: 欧仁妮嚎啕大哭起来，急忙跑到她母亲那里。葛朗台在雪地里绕着花园转了两三圈，也不觉得冷。突然，他疑心女儿跑到了她母亲那里；很高兴能揪住她违抗自己的命令，他便像只猫一样敏捷地爬上楼梯，到了葛朗台太太的屋子里。这时欧仁妮正把脸埋在她母亲的怀里，而葛朗台太太在抚摸着女儿的头发。
en: Eugenie burst into tears and fled up to her mother.Grandet, after marching two or three times round the garden in the snow without heeding the cold, suddenly suspected that his daughter had gone to her mother; only too happy to find her disobedient to his orders, he climbed the stairs with the agility of a cat and appeared in Madame Grandet’s room just as she was stroking Eugenie’s hair, while the girl’s face was hidden in her motherly bosom.

zh: “别伤心，我可怜的孩子，”她正说道，“你父亲会消气的。”
en: “Be comforted, my poor child,” she was saying, “your father will get over it.”

zh: “她没有父亲！”老头说，“葛朗台太太，难道你和我能生出个这么不听话的孩子吗？教育得真好——还信教呢！哎！你为什么不呆在你的卧室里？来吧，去牢房，去牢房，小姐！”
en: “She has no father!” said the old man.“Can it be you and I, Madame Grandet, who have given birth to such a disobedient child?A fine education,—religious, too!Well! Why are you not in your chamber?Come, to prison, to prison, mademoiselle!”

zh: “你要把我女儿从我身边夺走吗？”葛朗台太太说着，转头看着他，一张脸此时烧得通红。
en: “Would you deprive me of my daughter, monsieur?” said Madame Grandet, turning towards him a face that was now red with fever.

zh: “要是你想留她，把她带走！滚——滚出我的家，你们两个！遭雷劈的！金子在哪儿？金子怎么啦？”
en: “If you want to keep her, carry her off!Clear out—out of my house, both of you!Thunder! Where is the gold? What’s become of the gold?”

zh: 欧仁妮站起来，高傲地看了看她的父亲，回了自己的房间。葛朗台用钥匙锁上了门。
en: Eugenie rose, looked proudly at her father, and withdrew to her room.Grandet turned the key of the door.

zh: “娜农，”他大声喊道，“把大厅的火灭了。”
en: “Nanon,” he cried, “put out the fire in the hall.”

zh: 接着，他坐到妻子屋里壁炉边的扶手椅上，对她说——
en: Then he sat down in an armchair beside his wife’s fire and said to her,—

zh: “毫无疑问，她把金子给了那个勾引她的卑鄙家伙——夏尔，他一心就想着咱们的钱。”
en: “Undoubtedly she has given the gold to that miserable seducer, Charles, who only wanted our money.”

zh: “我对这件事一无所知，”她朝床的另一边翻过身，躲开丈夫凶狠的目光，回答道，“我对你的残暴受得够多了，如果我相信自己的预感，我可能再也不会离开这间屋子了，除非被棺材抬出去。你应该饶过我，不要让我遭这个罪，先生——我可从来没有让你难受过，是的，我想是这样。你的女儿是爱你的。我相信她和胎儿一样清白。别难为她。收回你的成命。天冷得厉害，你会害她生大病的。”
en: “I knew nothing about it,” she answered, turning to the other side of the bed, that she might escape the savage glances of her husband.“I suffer so much from your violence that I shall never leave this room, if I trust my own presentiments, till I am carried out of it in my coffin.You ought to have spared me this suffering, monsieur,—you, to whom I have caused no pain; that is, I think so.Your daughter loves you.I believe her to be as innocent as the babe unborn.Do not make her wretched.Revoke your sentence.The cold is very severe; you may give her some serious illness.”

zh: “我不会见她，也不会跟她说话。她得呆在她的屋子里，吃面包，喝水，直到她向她父亲屈服为止。见鬼！一个父亲难道不该知道家里的金子去了哪儿吗？她拥有的卢比是法国仅有的几个，也许，还有荷兰达克特和热那亚金币——”
en: “I will not see her, neither will I speak to her.She shall stay in her room, on bread and water, until she submits to her father.What the devil! Shouldn’t a father know where the gold in his house has gone to?She owned the only rupees in France, perhaps, and the Dutch ducats and the @genovines@—”

zh: “先生，欧仁妮是我们独生女，即使她把金币都扔进了水里——”
en: “Monsieur, Eugenie is our only child; and even if she had thrown them into the water—”

zh: “扔进水里！”她丈夫大叫道，“扔进水里！你疯了，葛朗台太太！我说话算数的，你很清楚这一点。如果你想要这个家太平，就让你的女儿坦白，全都说出来。女人们比我们更清楚该怎么办比较好。不管她干了什么，我不会吃了她的。她怕不怕我？即使她把夏尔从头到脚都抹上了金子，他也正呆在公海上，谁也抓不到他，对吧！”
en: “Into the water!” cried her husband, “into the water!You are crazy, Madame Grandet!What I have said is said; you know that well enough.If you want peace in this household, make your daughter confess, pump it out of her.Women understand how to do that better than we do.Whatever she has done, I sha’n’t eat her.Is she afraid of me?Even if she has plastered Charles with gold from head to foot, he is on the high seas, and nobody can get at him, hein!”

zh: “可是，先生——”由于精神过度紧张以及惦念女儿的命运，葛朗台太太的心肠变软了，脑子变得更灵了，她突然发觉丈夫的肉瘤在可怕地抽动着，于是在回答时，她语气没变，话锋一转——“可是，先生，在她面前，我的威信可不如你。她什么都没跟我说，她像你。”
en: “But, monsieur—” Excited by the nervous crisis through which she had passed, and by the fate of her daughter, which brought forth all her tenderness and all her powers of mind, Madame Grandet suddenly observed a frightful movement of her husband’s wen, and, in the very act of replying, she changed her speech without changing the tones of her voice,—“But, monsieur, I have not more influence over her than you have.She has said nothing to me; she takes after you.”

zh: “啧，啧！你今天早上可真会说话。得，得，得，得！你就没把我放在眼里，我知道。我猜你跟她是串通一气的。”
en: “Tut, tut!Your tongue is hung in the middle this morning.Ta, ta, ta, ta!You are setting me at defiance, I do believe.I daresay you are in league with her.”

zh: 他定睛盯着自己的妻子。
en: He looked fixedly at his wife.

zh: “葛朗台先生，如果你想杀了我，你就只管来杀吧。我告诉你，先生——即使要了我的命，我也要说——你不该这么对女儿，她比你占理。那钱是属于她的，她绝对能把钱用在正道上，只有上帝才有权力知道我们的善事。先生，我求求你，饶了欧仁妮吧，原谅她吧。如果你这样做了，就会减轻你的怒气给我造成的伤害，也许你能救了我的命。我的女儿！哦，先生，把我的女儿还给我吧！”
en: “Monsieur Grandet, if you wish to kill me, you have only to go on like this.I tell you, monsieur,—and if it were to cost me my life, I would say it,—you do wrong by your daughter; she is more in the right than you are.That money belonged to her; she is incapable of making any but a good use of it, and God alone has the right to know our good deeds.Monsieur, I implore you, take Eugenie back into favor; forgive her.If you will do this you will lessen the injury your anger has done me; perhaps you will save my life.My daughter! Oh, monsieur, give me back my daughter!”

zh: “我要走了，”他说，“家里没法呆了。妈妈和女儿竟然这个样子讲话，这个样子争辩！呸——！噗！这就是你们新年给我送的大礼，欧仁妮，”他高声喊道，“好，好，哭去吧！你会为你做的事后悔的，你听到没？要是你把你父亲的金子都偷偷给了一个游手好闲的家伙，每三个月领六次圣餐又有什么用？等你没东西可给的时候，他会让你悲痛欲绝的。总有一天，你会发现你那个穿着摩洛哥皮靴、目空一切的夏尔是个什么货色。如果不经姑娘父母的同意，他就敢拿走她的私房钱，那他真是既没心肝，也没灵魂。”
en: “I shall decamp,” he said, “the house is not habitable.A mother and daughter talking and arguing like that!Broooouh!Pouah!A fine New Year’s present you’ve made me, Eugenie,” he called out.“Yes, yes, cry away!What you’ve done will bring you remorse, do you hear?What’s the good of taking the sacrament six times every three months, if you give away your father’s gold secretly to an idle fellow who’ll eat your heart out when you’ve nothing else to give him?You’ll find out some day what your Charles is worth, with his morocco boots and supercilious airs.He has got neither heart nor soul if he dared to carry off a young girl’s treasure without the consent of her parents.”

zh: 当街门关上后，欧仁妮从屋子出来去找她母亲。
en: When the street-door was shut, Eugenie came out of her room and went to her mother.

zh: “为了女儿，您可真有勇气！”她说。
en: “What courage you have had for your daughter’s sake!” she said.

zh: “啊！我的孩子，看看做了违禁的事，我们会有什么样的结果。你逼我撒了谎。”
en: “Ah! My child, see where forbidden things may lead us.You forced me to tell a lie.”

zh: “我会请求上帝只惩罚我一个人。”
en: “I will ask God to punish only me.”

zh: “是真的吗，”娜农惊慌地冲进来，嚷道，“小姐后半生就只能吃面包、喝水啦？”
en: “Is it true,” cried Nanon, rushing in alarmed, “that mademoiselle is to be kept on bread and water for the rest of her life?”

zh: “那有什么，娜农？”欧仁妮平静地说道。
en: “What does that signify, Nanon?” said Eugenie tranquilly.

zh: “天哪！你的意思是我吃抹酱，而家里的小姐倒要吃干面包？不，不！”
en: “Goodness! Do you suppose I’ll eat @frippe@ when the daughter of the house is eating dry bread?No, no!”

zh: “这件事一个字也别提了，娜农。”欧仁妮说。
en: “Don’t say a word about all this, Nanon,” said Eugenie.

zh: “我会默不作声的，不过，你们等着瞧吧！”
en: “I’ll be as mute as a fish; but you’ll see!”

zh: 二十四年来，葛朗台第一次单独吃晚饭。
en: Grandet dined alone for the first time in twenty-four years.

zh: “那么您成了鳏夫了，先生，”娜农说，“家里有两个女人，却成了鳏夫，一定不好受。”
en: “So you’re a widower, monsieur,” said Nanon, “it must be disagreeable to be a widower with two women in the house.”

zh: “我没跟你说话。闭上你的嘴，不然我就把你赶走！我听到炉子上你的蒸锅煮着东西，那是什么？”
en: “I did not speak to you.Hold your jaw, or I’ll turn you off!What is that I hear boiling in your saucepan on the stove?”

zh: “是我熬的油。”
en: “It is grease I’m trying out.”

zh: “今天晚上有客。生上火。”
en: “There will be some company tonight.Light the fire.”

zh: 克吕绍一家、德格拉桑太太和她的儿子像往常一样，八点钟来了，他们既没看到葛朗台太太，也没看到她的女儿，感到很奇怪。
en: The Cruchots, Madame des Grassins, and her son arrived at the usual hour of eight, and were surprised to see neither Madame Grandet nor her daughter.

zh: “我的太太不太舒服，欧仁妮跟她在一起。”老葡萄园主说道，脸上没露出一丝破绽。
en: “My wife is not very well, and Eugenie is with her,” said the old wine-grower, whose face betrayed no emotion.

zh: 闲聊了将近一个小时后，上楼去看葛朗台太太的德格拉桑太太下来了，大家都问道——
en: At the end of an hour spent in idle conversation, Madame des Grassins, who had gone up to see Madame Grandet, came down, and every one inquired,—

zh: “葛朗台太太怎么样？”
en: “How is Madame Grandet?”

zh: “很不好，”她答道，“我看她的状况似乎很让人担心。她这个年纪，您应该特别当心，葛朗台老爹。”
en: “Not at all well,” she answered, “her condition seems to me really alarming.At her age you ought to take every precaution, Papa Grandet.”

zh: “我们会留心的。”老头漫不经心地说道。
en: “We’ll see about it,” said the old man in an absent way.

zh: 他们都跟他道了晚安。等克吕绍一家走到大街上，德格拉桑太太对他们说——
en: They all wished him good-night.When the Cruchots got into the street Madame des Grassins said to them,—

zh: “葛朗台家出事啦。母亲病得很厉害，而她自己并不知道。那姑娘两眼通红，好像一整天都在哭。难道是他们要违背她的意愿把她嫁出去？”
en: “There is something going on at the Grandets.The mother is very ill without her knowing it.The girl’s eyes are red, as if she had been crying all day.Can they be trying to marry her against her will?”

zh: 等葛朗台上了床，娜农没有穿鞋，只穿着袜子轻手轻脚来到了欧仁妮的房间，给了她一个用煎锅烤好的馅饼。
en: When Grandet had gone to bed Nanon came softly to Eugenie’s room in her stockinged feet and showed her a pate baked in a saucepan.

zh: “看，小姐，”这个好心人说，“科努瓦耶给了我一只野兔。你饭量小，这个馅饼够你吃上一个星期的；这么冷的天气，坏不了的。我是下定决心了，你可不能光吃干面包，那对身体不好。”
en: “See, mademoiselle,” said the good soul, “Cornoiller gave me a hare.You eat so little that this pate will last you full a week; in such frosty weather it won’t spoil.You sha’n’t live on dry bread, I’m determined; it isn’t wholesome.”

zh: “可怜的娜农！”欧仁妮说着，握紧了她的手。
en: “Poor Nanon!” said Eugenie, pressing her hand.

zh: “我做得好极了，很香的，他一点儿没发觉。我用我那六法郎买了猪油和香料：我自个儿的钱，我做主。”说着，她觉得似乎听到了葛朗台的声音，便迅速离开了。
en: “I’ve made it downright good and dainty, and @he@ never found it out.I bought the lard and the spices out of my six francs: I’m the mistress of my own money,” and she disappeared rapidly, fancying she heard Grandet.

zh: 第十一章
en: Chapter XI

zh: 几个月来，老葡萄园主白天经常不定时地来到他妻子的房间，他从不提女儿的名字，也不去看她，连半点儿提及她的话都没有。葛朗台太太没有离开过她的卧室，状态一天比一天糟。无论什么也无法让老头的心肠变软，他一直无动于衷、严厉、冷漠，像块花岗石一样。他像平时一样继续进进出出，忙着他的事；不过他不再结巴了，话也少了，在买卖交易上比以前更苛刻了。他经常会加错数。
en: For several months the old wine-grower came constantly to his wife’s room at all hours of the day, without ever uttering his daughter’s name, or seeing her, or making the smallest allusion to her.Madame Grandet did not leave her chamber, and daily grew worse.Nothing softened the old man; he remained unmoved, harsh, and cold as a granite rock.He continued to go and come about his business as usual; but ceased to stutter, talked less, and was more obdurate in business transactions than ever before.Often he made mistakes in adding up his figures.

zh: “葛朗台家出事了。”格拉桑派和克吕绍派都说道。
en: “Something is going on at the Grandets,” said the Grassinists and the Cruchotines.

zh: “葛朗台家里出了什么事？”这变成了一个固定的问题，在索米尔晚上的小聚会上，人人都会这样问。欧仁妮去望弥撒都是由娜农陪着。从教堂出来时，如果德格拉桑太太跟她搭上几句话，她的回答总是躲躲闪闪，无法满足对方的好奇心。但是两个月后，欧仁妮被幽禁的事实再也不可能瞒过三位克吕绍以及德格拉桑太太了。这个时候，所有的借口都无法成为她总是不露面的托辞了。接着，尽管无法找出是谁泄露了秘密，全城的人都知道了从新年那天开始，葛朗台小姐就被她父亲下令关在她的房间里，没有生火，只能吃面包、喝水，娜农会做点好吃的，夜里偷偷给她送去。大家甚至知道，那个姑娘不能去看望和照顾自己的母亲，只能等她父亲偶尔不在家时才行。
en: “What has happened in the Grandet family?” became a fixed question which everybody asked everybody else at the little evening-parties of Saumur.Eugenie went to Mass escorted by Nanon.If Madame des Grassins said a few words to her on coming out of church, she answered in an evasive manner, without satisfying any curiosity.However, at the end of two months, it became impossible to hide, either from the three Cruchots or from Madame des Grassins, the fact that Eugenie was in confinement.There came a moment when all pretexts failed to explain her perpetual absence.Then, though it was impossible to discover by whom the secret had been betrayed, all the town became aware that ever since New Year’s day Mademoiselle Grandet had been kept in her room without fire, on bread and water, by her father’s orders, and that Nanon cooked little dainties and took them to her secretly at night.It was even known that the young woman was not able to see or take care of her mother, except at certain times when her father was out of the house.

zh: 葛朗台的行为受到了严厉的谴责。可以说，全城人都视他为不法之徒；他们想起了他的背信弃义、他的冷酷心肠，并把他逐出了教会。当他在街上经过时，人们对他指指点点，小声议论着。当他的女儿由娜农陪着，走过弯弯曲曲的街道，去望弥撒或者做晚祷时，居民们跑到窗前，非常好奇地打量着这个富家女的一举一动和她那张带着忧郁和天使般温柔的面孔。她根本不在乎自己被幽禁和她父亲所受的谴责。她不是有一张世界地图，有小长凳、花园和围墙拐角吗？她不是总在回味爱情之吻留在她唇间的甜蜜吗？正如葛朗台一样，她一度根本不知道全城人都在议论她。在上帝面前，她心地虔诚而纯洁，她的良知和她的爱情帮助她耐心地忍受着她父亲的愤怒和报复。
en: Grandet’s conduct was severely condemned.The whole town outlawed him, so to speak; they remembered his treachery, his hard-heartedness, and they excommunicated him.When he passed along the streets, people pointed him out and muttered at him.When his daughter came down the winding street, accompanied by Nanon, on her way to Mass or Vespers, the inhabitants ran to the windows and examined with intense curiosity the bearing of the rich heiress and her countenance, which bore the impress of angelic gentleness and melancholy.Her imprisonment and the condemnation of her father were as nothing to her.Had she not a map of the world, the little bench, the garden, the angle of the wall?Did she not taste upon her lips the honey that love’s kisses left there?She was ignorant for a time that the town talked about her, just as Grandet himself was ignorant of it.Pious and pure in heart before God, her conscience and her love helped her to suffer patiently the wrath and vengeance of her father.

zh: 一种深深的痛苦压过了其他一切痛苦。她的母亲，那个温柔慈祥的人，在接近生命的尽头时，由内而外散发的光辉使她显得很美——她的母亲正在一天一天地枯槁。欧仁妮经常责备自己无意中给母亲带来这场疾病，它正慢慢地、残忍地耗尽母亲的生命。这种悔恨，虽然有母亲的宽慰，却把她和她的爱情联系得更紧密了。每天早上，等她父亲一出门，她就来到母亲床边，娜农给她把早点端到那里。可怜的姑娘很伤心，为了母亲的痛苦而痛苦，她哭着把脸转向老佣人默默示意，但是也不敢提起她的堂弟。是葛朗台太太首先鼓起勇气，开口说道——
en: One deep grief silenced all others.Her mother, that gentle, tender creature, made beautiful by the light which shone from the inner to the outer as she approached the tomb,—her mother was perishing from day to day.Eugenie often reproached herself as the innocent cause of the slow, cruel malady that was wasting her away.This remorse, though her mother soothed it, bound her still closer to her love.Every morning, as soon as her father left the house, she went to the bedside of her mother, and there Nanon brought her breakfast.The poor girl, sad, and suffering through the sufferings of her mother, would turn her face to the old servant with a mute gesture, weeping, and yet not daring to speak of her cousin.It was Madame Grandet who first found courage to say,—

zh: “他在哪里？他为什么不写信？”
en: “Where is @he@?Why does @he@ not write?”

zh: “咱们就心里想想他吧，母亲，但是别提他。您在生病——您比一切都重要。”
en: “Let us think about him, mother, but not speak of him.You are ill—you, before all.”

zh: “一切”的意思是“他”。
en: “All” meant “him.”

zh: “我的孩子，”葛朗台太太说，“我对活着不抱希望。上帝保佑我，让我能够高高兴兴地看到我的苦难要结束了。”
en: “My child,” said Madame Grandet, “I do not wish to live.God protects me and enables me to look with joy to the end of my misery.”

zh: 这个女人的每一句话总是虔诚而富于基督精神的。在那一年的头几个月，有时，当她的丈夫来和她共进早餐，并在屋子里踱来踱去的时候，她会对他说些充满宗教精神的话，她说话时总是如天使般温柔，但是口气坚决，对一个女人来说，即将到来的死亡赋予了她平生所没有的勇气。
en: Every utterance of this woman was unfalteringly pious and Christian.Sometimes, during the first months of the year, when her husband came to breakfast with her and tramped up and down the room, she would say to him a few religious words, always spoken with angelic sweetness, yet with the firmness of a woman to whom approaching death lends a courage she had lacked in life.

zh: “先生，我很感谢你对我的健康这么关心，”每当他循例问候时，她会回答道，“不过，你如果真的想让我在最后的时日里少一点痛苦，让我的悲伤减轻些，那就饶了你的女儿吧：做个真正的基督徒，做得像个丈夫和父亲的样子。”
en: “Monsieur, I thank you for the interest you take in my health,” she would answer when he made some commonplace inquiry, “but if you really desire to render my last moments less bitter and to ease my grief, take back your daughter: be a Christian, a husband, and a father.”

zh: 每当听到这番话时，葛朗台就会坐在床边，那神情就好像一个人看见大雨将至而静静地躲在门洞下直至雨停的样子。等她说完这些动人、温柔，而且虔诚的恳求后，他会说道——
en: When he heard these words, Grandet would sit down by the bed with the air of a man who sees the rain coming and quietly gets under the shelter of a gateway till it is over.When these touching, tender, and religious supplications had all been made, he would say,—

zh: “你今天脸色很苍白，我可怜的太太。”
en: “You are rather pale today, my poor wife.”

zh: 彻底忘掉女儿这个打算似乎刻在了他紧绷的额头和紧闭的嘴唇上。当可怜的妻子听到他这番不着边际的回答时，她苍白的面颊上淌下了泪水，他也不为之所动。
en: Absolute forgetfulness of his daughter seemed graven on his stony brow, on his closed lips.He was unmoved by the tears which flowed down the white cheeks of his unhappy wife as she listened to his meaningless answers.

zh: “愿上帝原谅你，”她说，“就像我原谅你一样！你总有一天会需要宽恕的。”
en: “May God pardon you,” she said, “even as I pardon you!You will some day stand in need of mercy.”

zh: 自从葛朗台太太病倒后，他还没敢用过他那可怕的“得、得、得、得！”呢。可尽管如此，他暴虐的本性并没有被这个温柔的天使给感化掉。这个天使外貌的丑陋在一天天减少，取而代之的是辉映在她脸上的那难以形容的精神之美。她的灵魂一片纯净。祈祷的灵性似乎净化了她，让她其貌不扬的相貌变得优雅，而且焕发起光彩来。圣洁的脸庞上，灵魂的习性战胜了最平凡的相貌，由于纯洁而高尚的内心思想而给相貌平添了精神上的光彩，这类脱胎换骨的现象谁没有见过呢？这个女人在挣扎中耗尽生命，而使容貌大变的景象，确实让这个老箍桶匠有所触动，不过，影响甚微，因为他的本性像铁一样硬。如果说他的用语不再那么轻蔑了，那沉着静默则取而代之，并成了他的行为准则，这也保全了他作为一家之主的尊严。
en: Since Madame Grandet’s illness he had not dared to make use of his terrible “Ta, ta, ta, ta!”Yet, for all that, his despotic nature was not disarmed by this angel of gentleness, whose ugliness day by day decreased, driven out by the ineffable expression of moral qualities which shone upon her face.She was all soul.The spirit of prayer seemed to purify her and refine those homely features and make them luminous.Who has not seen the phenomenon of a like transfiguration on sacred faces where the habits of the soul have triumphed over the plainest features, giving them that spiritual illumination whose light comes from the purity and nobility of the inward thought?The spectacle of this transformation wrought by the struggle which consumed the last shreds of the human life of this woman, did somewhat affect the old cooper, though feebly, for his nature was of iron; if his language ceased to be contemptuous, an imperturbable silence, which saved his dignity as master of the household, took its place and ruled his conduct.

zh: 当忠心耿耿的娜农出现在市场上时，许多针对她主子的挖苦话、俏皮话和埋怨会传到她耳朵里；不过不管公众舆论谴责葛朗台先生的声音有多大，这个老佣人为了东家的荣誉，总要替他辩护。
en: When the faithful Nanon appeared in the market, many quips and quirks and complaints about the master whistled in her ears; but however loudly public opinion condemned Monsieur Grandet, the old servant defended him, for the honor of the family.

zh: “好吧！”她会对诋毁他的人说，“等我们老了，我们的心肠不都会变硬吗？为什么他就不应该也变得硬些？别胡说八道。小姐过得像个王后一样。不错，她是单独呆着，不过，她喜欢那样。还有，我家主人自有他们的道理。”
en: “Well!” she would say to his detractors, “don’t we all get hard as we grow old?Why shouldn’t he get horny too?Stop telling lies.Mademoiselle lives like a queen.She’s alone, that’s true; but she likes it.Besides, my masters have good reasons.”

zh: 终于，等春天快过完的时候，葛朗台太太被疾病，甚至可以说是被痛苦折磨得虚弱不堪，尽管她苦苦祈祷，也没能让父女俩和解，于是她把心里的烦恼吐露给了克吕绍叔侄。
en: At last, towards the end of spring, Madame Grandet, worn out by grief even more than by illness, having failed, in spite of her prayers, to reconcile the father and daughter, confided her secret troubles to the Cruchots.

zh: “让一个二十三岁的姑娘光吃面包、喝水！”德蓬丰先生叫了起来，“而且还毫无道理！唉呀，那构成了非法虐待罪，她可以上告，理由是——”
en: “Keep a girl of twenty-three on bread and water!” cried Monsieur de Bonfons, “without any reason, too!Why, that constitutes wrongful cruelty; she can contest, as much in as upon—”

zh: “得啦，侄儿，别给我们讲你那些法律术语了，”公证人说，“您放心，夫人，明天我就会终止这种虐待的。”
en: “Come, nephew, spare us your legal jargon,” said the notary.“Set your mind at ease, madame; I will put a stop to such treatment tomorrow.”

zh: 欧仁妮听见他们提到自己，便从她的房间里走了出来。
en: Eugenie, hearing herself mentioned, came out of her room.

zh: “先生们，”她高傲地一步走上前来，说道，“我求你们不要插手这件事。我父亲是他自己家的主人。只要我生活在他的屋檐下，我就必须服从他。他的行为无须得到别人的赞成或者反对，他只对上帝负责。我请求你们以友谊为重，在这件事上保持完全的沉默。责备我的父亲就是攻击我们家族的名誉。我非常感谢你们对我的关心；我偶尔听到城里正流传的一些令人不快的流言蜚语，如果你们能制止的话，那算是又帮了我一个忙了。”
en: “Gentlemen,” she said, coming forward with a proud step, “I beg you not to interfere in this matter.My father is master in his own house.As long as I live under his roof I am bound to obey him.His conduct is not subject to the approbation or the disapprobation of the world; he is accountable to God only.I appeal to your friendship to keep total silence in this affair.To blame my father is to attack our family honor.I am much obliged to you for the interest you have shown in me; you will do me an additional service if you will put a stop to the offensive rumors which are current in the town, of which I am accidentally informed.”

zh: “她说得对。”葛朗台太太说。
en: “She is right,” said Madame Grandet.

zh: “小姐，阻止流言最好的方法是获取你的自由。”老公证人被那幽居、忧伤和爱情印在她脸上的美丽打动了，他恭敬地答道。
en: “Mademoiselle, the best way to stop such rumors is to procure your liberty,” answered the old notary respectfully, struck with the beauty which seclusion, melancholy, and love had stamped upon her face.

zh: “好的，孩子，既然克吕绍先生这么有把握成功，就让他处理这件事吧。他了解你的父亲，知道怎么应付他。如果你希望看到我在所剩无几的余生里活得快乐，无论如何，你必须跟你父亲和解。”
en: “Well, my daughter, let Monsieur Cruchot manage the matter if he is so sure of success.He understands your father, and how to manage him.If you wish to see me happy for my few remaining days, you must, at any cost, be reconciled to your father.”

zh: 第二天，按照自从欧仁妮被禁闭后就开始养成的习惯，葛朗台在小花园里来来回回走了好几圈，他挑的是欧仁妮梳理头发的时间。当老头走到胡桃树下时，他躲到树干后面，盯着女儿的一举一动看了好一会儿，或许，他在服从他固执的本性和拥抱孩子这种出于天性的愿望之间犹豫不决。有时候，他坐在那条破旧的长凳上，夏尔和欧仁妮曾经在那里立下海誓山盟；而这时，欧仁妮也会站在镜子前，偷偷地看着父亲。要是他站起来，继续散步，她就饶有兴味地坐到窗前，看着那挂着淡色花朵的围墙角，在那里，铁线蕨、蔓藤和景天草从缝隙里长了出来——景天草是一种白色或者黄色的景天植物，索米尔和图尔的葡萄园里有很多。克吕绍公证人很早就来了，发现老葡萄园主在这晴好的六月天里坐在小长凳上，背靠着花园的隔墙，专注地望着自己的女儿。
en: On the morrow Grandet, in pursuance of a custom he had begun since Eugenie’s imprisonment, took a certain number of turns up and down the little garden; he had chosen the hour when Eugenie brushed and arranged her hair.When the old man reached the walnut-tree he hid behind its trunk and remained for a few moments watching his daughter’s movements, hesitating, perhaps, between the course to which the obstinacy of his character impelled him and his natural desire to embrace his child.Sometimes he sat down on the rotten old bench where Charles and Eugenie had vowed eternal love; and then she, too, looked at her father secretly in the mirror before which she stood.If he rose and continued his walk, she sat down obligingly at the window and looked at the angle of the wall where the pale flowers hung, where the Venus-hair grew from the crevices with the bindweed and the sedum,—a white or yellow stone-crop very abundant in the vineyards of Saumur and at Tours.Maitre Cruchot came early, and found the old wine-grower sitting in the fine June weather on the little bench, his back against the division wall of the garden, engaged in watching his daughter.

zh: “您有什么事吗，克吕绍公证人先生？”他看见了公证人，说道。
en: “What may you want, Maitre Cruchot?” he said, perceiving the notary.

zh: “我是来和您谈正事的。”
en: “I came to speak to you on business.”

zh: “啊！啊！您是拿了些金子来换我的银子吗？”
en: “Ah! Ah! Have you brought some gold in exchange for my silver?”

zh: “不，不，我来不是为了钱，是为了您的女儿欧仁妮。整个城里都在议论她和您。”
