en: “No, no, I have not come about money; it is about your daughter Eugenie.All the town is talking of her and you.”

zh: “城里人管得着吗？一个人的家就是他的城堡。”
en: “What does the town meddle for?A man’s house is his castle.”

zh: “非常正确，只要愿意，一个人可以去自杀，或者更糟糕一些，他可以把自己的钱扔到阴沟里。”
en: “Very true; and a man may kill himself if he likes, or, what is worse, he may fling his money into the gutter.”

zh: “您是什么意思？”
en: “What do you mean?”

zh: “嗨，您的妻子病得很厉害，我的朋友。您应该请贝日冷先生来看看，她可能要死了。如果她因为得不到应有的医治而死，我想您的内心会非常不安的。”
en: “Why, your wife is very ill, my friend.You ought to consult Monsieur Bergerin; she is likely to die.If she does die without receiving proper care, you will not be very easy in mind, I take it.”

zh: “得，得，得，得！您很清楚我妻子的事！这些医生，他们一旦踏进了你的家门，一天就会来上五六趟。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta! You know a deal about my wife!These doctors, if they once get their foot in your house, will come five and six times a day.”

zh: “当然，您觉得怎么做最好就怎么做吧。我们是老朋友，在索米尔，没有谁比我更关心您的事了。所以我一定要把这件事告诉您。不过，不管怎么样，您有权做您想做的事，您可以选择您自己的做法。再有，那并不是我此行的目的。还有一件事对您来说可能会有严重的后果。毕竟，您不可能希望害死自己的妻子，她的命对于您可是太重要了。要是葛朗台太太死了，想想您在您女儿面前的处境。您必须把账目交给欧仁妮，因为您只在您妻子的有生之年才享有她的财产。她一死，您的女儿就可以申请分割财产，她可能会迫使您卖掉弗罗瓦丰的。简而言之，她是她母亲的继承人，而您不是。”
en: “Of course you will do as you think best.We are old friends; there is no one in all Saumur who takes more interest than I in what concerns you.Therefore, I was bound to tell you this.However, happen what may, you have the right to do as you please; you can choose your own course.Besides, that is not what brings me here.There is another thing which may have serious results for you.After all, you can’t wish to kill your wife; her life is too important to you.Think of your situation in connection with your daughter if Madame Grandet dies.You must render an account to Eugenie, because you enjoy your wife’s estate only during her lifetime.At her death your daughter can claim a division of property, and she may force you to sell Froidfond.In short, she is her mother’s heir, and you are not.”

zh: 这番话对老头来说简直像晴天霹雳一样，他对法律可没有对做生意那么在行。他从来没想过财产的法律分割问题。
en: These words fell like a thunderbolt on the old man, who was not as wise about law as he was about business.He had never thought of a legal division of the estate.

zh: “因此，我建议您要善待她。”克吕绍最后又说道。
en: “Therefore I advise you to treat her kindly,” added Cruchot, in conclusion.

zh: “但是您知道她做了什么吗，克吕绍？”
en: “But do you know what she has done, Cruchot?”

zh: “什么？”公证人问道，他好奇地想听听事实的真相，并搞清这次争吵的缘由。
en: “What?” asked the notary, curious to hear the truth and find out the cause of the quarrel.

zh: “她把她的金子给了别人！”
en: “She has given away her gold!”

zh: “那么，金子不是她的吗？”公证人说。
en: “Well, wasn’t it hers?” said the notary.

zh: “他们都是这样跟我说的！”老头把他的胳膊垂到身体两侧，做了个很悲痛的动作，大声嚷道。
en: “They all tell me that!” exclaimed the old man, letting his arms fall to his sides with a movement that was truly tragic.

zh: “难道就为了一件微不足道的小事，”克吕绍接着说，“您就不打算请求女儿在她母亲死后对您做出让步吗？”
en: “Are you going—for a mere nothing,”resumed Cruchot, “to put obstacles in the way of the concessions which you will be obliged to ask from your daughter as soon as her mother dies?”

zh: “您把六千法郎叫做一件微不足道的小事？”
en: “Do you call six thousand francs a mere nothing?”

zh: “嘿！我的老朋友，您知道要是欧仁妮要求分割财产的话，您妻子的财产造表要花多少钱吗？”
en: “Hey! My old friend, do you know what the inventory of your wife’s property will cost, if Eugenie demands the division?”

zh: “多少？”
en: “How much?”

zh: “两千，或者三千，甚至四千法郎！财产要进行拍卖和出售，以便获知它的实际价值。要不想这样，如果你们处好了关系——”
en: “Two, three, four thousand francs, perhaps!The property would have to be put up at auction and sold, to get at its actual value.Instead of that, if you are on good terms with—”

zh: “凭我老父的剪刀作证！”葛朗台大声叫了起来，他猛地坐下，脸色苍白，“这个我们以后再谈，克吕绍。”
en: “By the shears of my father!” cried Grandet, turning pale as he suddenly sat down, “we will see about it, Cruchot.”

zh: 沉默了一会儿之后，老头似乎内心满是痛苦，他看着公证人，说道——
en: After a moment’s silence, full of anguish perhaps, the old man looked at the notary and said,—

zh: “人生是非常艰难的！有很多痛苦！克吕绍，”他严肃地接着说道，“您不会骗我吧？以您的名誉跟我发誓，您跟我讲的所有话都是有法律依据的。给我看看那条法律，我必须要看到那条法律！”
en: “Life is very hard!It has many griefs!Cruchot,” he continued solemnly, “you would not deceive me?Swear to me upon your honor that all you’ve told me is legally true.Show me the law; I must see the law!”

zh: “我可怜的朋友，”公证人说，“我会不清楚自己的本行吗？”
en: “My poor friend,” said the notary, “don’t I know my own business?”

zh: “这么说，就是真的了！我要被我自己的女儿抢劫、背叛、杀死、毁灭了！”
en: “Then it is true!I am robbed, betrayed, killed, destroyed by my own daughter!”

zh: “您的女儿是她母亲的继承人，的确如此。”
en: “It is true that your daughter is her mother’s heir.”

zh: “要子女有什么用？啊！我的妻子，我爱她！幸亏她身体很健康，她是贝尔特利耶家的人。”
en: “Why do we have children?Ah! My wife, I love her!Luckily she’s sound and healthy; she’s a Bertelliere.”

zh: “她活不过一个月了。”
en: “She has not a month to live.”

zh: 葛朗台拍拍脑门，走了几步，又走回来，恶狠狠地看着克吕绍，说道——
en: Grandet struck his forehead, went a few steps, came back, cast a dreadful look on Cruchot, and said,—

zh: “怎么办？”
en: “What can be done?”

zh: “欧仁妮可以放弃对她母亲财产的继承权。如果她这样做的话，我猜您不会剥夺她的继承权吧？——不过您要是想这样解决的话，您就一定不要亏待她。老头，我跟您说的话对我是不利的。要不是有债务清偿、财产造表、产权转让、财产分割——我靠什么活呢？”
en: “Eugenie can relinquish her claim to her mother’s property.Should she do this you would not disinherit her, I presume?—But if you want to come to such a settlement, you must not treat her harshly.What I am telling you, old man, is against my own interests.What do I live by, if it isn’t liquidations, inventories, conveyances, divisions of property?—”

zh: “我们以后再说，以后再说！别再说它了，克吕绍，这件事搞得我心神不宁。您收到金子了吗？”
en: “We’ll see, we’ll see!Don’t let’s talk any more about it, Cruchot; it wrings my vitals.Have you received any gold?”

zh: “没有，不过我有几个旧金路易，十二个左右，可以给您。我的好朋友，跟欧仁妮和解吧。您难道不知道整个索米尔都在攻击您吗？”
en: “No; but I have a few old louis, a dozen or so, which you may have.My good friend, make it up with Eugenie.Don’t you know all Saumur is pelting you with stones?”

zh: “那些无赖！”
en: “The scoundrels!”

zh: “喂，公债是九十九啦。您一辈子总可以满意一次啦。”
en: “Come, the Funds are at ninety-nine.Do be satisfied for once in your life.”

zh: “九十九！是吗，克吕绍？”
en: “At ninety-nine!Are they, Cruchot?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “嘿，嘿！九十九！”老头一边反复念叨着，一边陪着公证人走到了街门。刚才听到的那番话让他激动得在屋子里呆不住，于是，他便去了妻子的房间，说道——
en: “Hey, hey!Ninety-nine!” repeated the old man, accompanying the notary to the street-door.Then, too agitated by what he had just heard to stay in the house, he went up to his wife’s room and said,—

zh: “嘿，孩子她妈，你白天可以让女儿陪着你。我要去弗罗瓦丰。祝你们俩过得愉快。今天是咱们的结婚纪念日，太太。看看！这是给你的圣体瞻礼节搭祭坛用的六十法郎，这事你想了很久了。得啦，高兴点，过得开心，早日康复！快乐万岁！”
en: “Come, mother, you may have your daughter to spend the day with you.I’m going to Froidfond.Enjoy yourselves, both of you.This is our wedding-day, wife.See! Here are sixty francs for your altar at the Fete-Dieu; you’ve wanted one for a long time.Come, cheer up, enjoy yourself, and get well!Hurrah for happiness!”

zh: 他把十枚六法郎的银币扔到床上，用手捧起他妻子的头，吻了吻她的前额。
en: He threw ten silver pieces of six francs each upon the bed, and took his wife’s head between his hands and kissed her forehead.

zh: “我的好太太，你会好起来的，是不是？”
en: “My good wife, you are getting well, are not you?”

zh: “你连你的女儿都不肯原谅，又怎么能指望在家里接待慈悲的上帝呢？”她激动地说道。
en: “How can you think of receiving the God of mercy in your house when you refuse to forgive your daughter?” she said with emotion.

zh: “得，得，得，得！”葛朗台哄着她说道，“我们以后再说。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta!” said Grandet in a coaxing voice.“We’ll see about that.”

zh: “仁慈的上帝呀！欧仁妮，”母亲高兴得满脸通红，大声喊道，“来吻一吻你的父亲，他原谅你了！”
en: “Merciful heaven!Eugenie,” cried the mother, flushing with joy, “come and kiss your father; he forgives you!”

zh: 但是，老头已经不见了身影。他甩开两腿，尽力快步地跑向他的葡萄园，想把他混乱的思绪理清。葛朗台已经七十六岁。在最近这两年里，他的贪婪变本加厉，就像人到了一定岁数，所有长年累月的癖好都会有增无减一样。似乎是为了印证一项对守财奴、野心家和那些一辈子死抱着一种想法的人的观察，他的感情已牢牢拴在象征他的嗜好的某件东西上了。看见金子、拥有金子已经成了他的一种狂热追求。他专制的思想随着他的贪婪成比例地增长，要他在妻子死后放弃哪怕最小一部分财产的支配权，对他来说，似乎都是一件“违背天理”的事情。要向他的女儿公布财产，要把他的不动产和动产的资产造表做出登记，好分割财产——
en: But the old man had disappeared.He was going as fast as his legs could carry him towards his vineyards, trying to get his confused ideas into order.Grandet had entered his seventy-sixth year.During the last two years his avarice had increased upon him, as all the persistent passions of men increase at a certain age.As if to illustrate an observation which applies equally to misers, ambitious men, and others whose lives are controlled by any dominant idea, his affections had fastened upon one special symbol of his passion.The sight of gold, the possession of gold, had become a monomania.His despotic spirit had grown in proportion to his avarice, and to part with the control of the smallest fraction of his property at the death of his wife seemed to him a thing “against nature.”To declare his fortune to his daughter, to give an inventory of his property, landed and personal, for the purposes of division—

zh: “唉呀，”他在一个园子里假装查看一株葡萄藤，在园子中间，他高声喊道，“那简直就是割断我的喉咙！”
en: “Why,” he cried aloud in the midst of a field where he was pretending to examine a vine, “it would be cutting my throat!”

zh: 最后，他拿定了主意，晚饭时回到索米尔，决心向欧仁妮屈服，爱抚她，哄骗她，以便他死时还能像帝王一样，只要有一口气在，他就得掌握那百万家产的大权。老头碰巧口袋里装着他的百宝钥匙，他开了门，蹑手蹑脚地爬上楼，进了他妻子的房间。这时，欧仁妮已经从橡木柜子里拿出那个漂亮的梳妆箱，放在了她母亲的床上。母女二人趁葛朗台不在，喜滋滋地端详着夏尔母亲的肖像，想找出她和夏尔相像的地方。
en: He came at last to a decision, and returned to Saumur in time for dinner, resolved to unbend to Eugenie, and pet and coax her, that he might die regally, holding the reins of his millions in his own hands so long as the breath was in his body.At the moment when the old man, who chanced to have his pass-key in his pocket, opened the door and climbed with a stealthy step up the stairway to go into his wife’s room, Eugenie had brought the beautiful dressing-case from the oak cabinet and placed it on her mother’s bed.Mother and daughter, in Grandet’s absence, allowed themselves the pleasure of looking for a likeness to Charles in the portrait of his mother.

zh: “这不正是他的额头和他的嘴嘛。”欧仁妮正说时，老头推开了门。一看到丈夫看着金子的目光，葛朗台太太大叫起来——
en: “It is exactly his forehead and his mouth,” Eugenie was saying as the old man opened the door.At the look which her husband cast upon the gold, Madame Grandet cried out,—

zh: “哦，上帝啊，可怜可怜我们吧！”
en: “O God, have pity upon us!”

zh: 老头纵身向箱子扑去，就像一只饿虎扑向一个熟睡的孩子一样。
en: The old man sprang upon the box as a famished tiger might spring upon a sleeping child.

zh: “这是什么？”他说着，一把抓住了宝贝，拿着它跑到了窗边。“金子，真金！”他叫着，“纯金的——足有两磅重！哈，哈！夏尔用这个换走了你的钱，是不是？嗯！你为什么没跟我说？这笔买卖可真划算，小乖乖！是的，你是我的女儿，我看出来了——”欧仁妮四肢都在颤抖。“这是夏尔的，当然是他的，是不是？”老头接着说。
en: “What’s this?” he said, snatching the treasure and carrying it to the window.“Gold, good gold!” he cried.“All gold,—it weighs two pounds!Ha, ha!Charles gave you that for your money, did he?Hein!Why didn’t you tell me so?It was a good bargain, little one!Yes, you are my daughter, I see that—” Eugenie trembled in every limb.“This came from Charles, of course, didn’t it?” continued the old man.

zh: “是的，父亲，这不是我的东西。这是神圣的托付。”
en: “Yes, father; it is not mine.It is a sacred trust.”

zh: “得，得，得，得！他拿走了你的钱，现在你可以拿回来了。”
en: “Ta, ta, ta, ta!He took your fortune, and now you can get it back.”

zh: “父亲！”
en: “Father!”

zh: 葛朗台拿起他的刀子要撬下一些金子，为了方便，他把梳妆箱放在了一把椅子上。欧仁妮冲上前想夺回来，可她的父亲一直在盯着她和那宝贝，他用胳膊狠狠推了她一把，她便摔倒在母亲的床上。
en: Grandet took his knife to pry out some of the gold; to do this, he placed the dressing-case on a chair.Eugenie sprang forward to recover it; but her father, who had his eye on her and on the treasure too, pushed her back so violently with a thrust of his arm that she fell upon her mother’s bed.

zh: “先生，先生！”母亲坐起身来，喊道。
en: “Monsieur, monsieur!” cried the mother, lifting herself up.

zh: 葛朗台已拔出了刀子，正准备用它撬金子。
en: Grandet had opened his knife, and was about to apply it to the gold.

zh: “父亲！”欧仁妮大声叫着，她跪下来，握紧两手，爬到他的身边，“父亲，看在所有的圣徒和圣母的份上！看在死在十字架上的基督的份上！看在您将永远得到救赎的份上，父亲！为了我的性命，父亲！——别去动那箱子！它既不是您的，也不是我的。它是一个不幸的亲人托付到我手中的：我一定要完好无损地还给他！”
en: “Father!” cried Eugenie, falling on her knees and dragging herself close to him with clasped hands, “Father, in the name of all the saints and the Virgin! In the name of Christ who died upon the cross! In the name of your eternal salvation, father! For my life’s sake, father!—do not touch that!It is neither yours nor mine.It is a trust placed in my hands by an unhappy relation: I must give it back to him uninjured!”

zh: “如果是托你代管的东西，你为什么还要看？看它和动它一样恶劣。”
en: “If it is a trust, why were you looking at it?To look at it is as bad as touching it.”

zh: “父亲，别弄坏了它，否则您会让我丢尽脸的！父亲，您听见了吗？”
en: “Father, don’t destroy it, or you will disgrace me!Father, do you hear?”

zh: “哦，发发慈悲吧！”母亲说。
en: “Oh, have pity!” said the mother.

zh: “父亲！”欧仁妮大声叫道，声音骇人，吓得娜农跑上了楼。欧仁妮扑向手边的一把刀子。
en: “Father!” cried Eugenie in so startling a voice that Nanon ran upstairs terrified.Eugenie sprang upon a knife that was close at hand.

zh: “好吧，现在要怎么样？”葛朗台冷笑一声，冷冷地说道。
en: “Well, what now?” said Grandet coldly, with a callous smile.

zh: “哦，你是要我的命啊！”母亲说。
en: “Oh, you are killing me!” said the mother.

zh: “父亲，如果您的刀子割下哪怕一丁点金子，我就把这把刀刺向我自己！您已经把我母亲逼得快要死了，现在又要杀死自己的孩子！随您的便！一命换一命！”
en: “Father, if your knife so much as cuts a fragment of that gold, I will stab myself with this one!You have already driven my mother to her death; you will now kill your child!Do as you choose!Wound for wound!”

zh: 葛朗台一边举刀对着梳妆箱，一边看着女儿，犹豫着。
en: Grandet held his knife over the dressing-case and hesitated as he looked at his daughter.

zh: “你真会那么做吗，欧仁妮？”他说。
en: “Are you capable of doing it, Eugenie?” he said.

zh: “是的，是的！”母亲说道。
en: “Yes, yes!” said the mother.

zh: “她会说到做到的！”娜农喊道，“讲点道理，先生，一辈子就讲这一次理吧。”
en: “She’ll do it if she says so!” cried Nanon.“Be reasonable, monsieur, for once in your life.”

zh: 老头看看金子，然后又看看他的女儿，来来回回看了一会儿。葛朗台太太晕了过去。
en: The old man looked at the gold and then at his daughter alternately for an instant.Madame Grandet fainted.

zh: “瞧瞧！先生，您看见没？太太快死了！”娜农大喊着。
en: “There! Don’t you see, monsieur, that madame is dying?” cried Nanon.

zh: “得啦，得啦，我的女儿，咱们别为了一个箱子吵架！得啦，拿走吧！”他一边把箱子往床上一扔，一边急忙喊道，“娜农，去叫贝日冷先生！喂，孩子她妈，”他一边说，他一边吻着妻子的手，“一切都过去了！你看！我们和好了——不是吗，小乖乖？不要再吃干面包了，你想吃什么就吃什么——啊，她睁开眼睛了！好的，孩子她妈，孩子她妈，得啦！瞧，我正在吻欧仁妮哪！她爱她的堂弟，她要是愿意，就嫁给他吧，她就保管他的箱子好了。可千万别死，孩子她妈；要活得长寿，我可怜的太太！嗨，试着动动！听着！你会有索米尔最好的祭坛。”
en: “Come, come, my daughter, we won’t quarrel for a box!Here, take it!” he cried hastily, flinging the case upon the bed.“Nanon, go and fetch Monsieur Bergerin!Come, mother,” said he, kissing his wife’s hand, “it’s all over!There! We’ve made up—haven’t we, little one?No more dry bread; you shall have all you want—Ah, she opens her eyes!Well, mother, little mother, come!See, I’m kissing Eugenie!She loves her cousin, and she may marry him if she wants to; she may keep his case.But don’t die, mother; live a long time yet, my poor wife!Come, try to move!Listen! You shall have the finest altar that ever was made in Saumur.”

zh: “哦，你怎么能这样对待你的妻子和女儿！”葛朗台太太声音微弱地说道。
en: “Oh, how can you treat your wife and daughter so!” said Madame Grandet in a feeble voice.

zh: “我不会再那样了，永远不会，”她的丈夫大声说道，“你就瞧着吧，我可怜的太太！”他去了他的密室，拿了一把金路易回来，撒到床上。“瞧瞧，欧仁妮！看看，太太！这些都是给你们的，”他一边说着，一边摆弄着那些硬币，“喂，高兴点，太太！心情好些，身体就能好，你要什么就有什么，欧仁妮也一样。这是给她的一百个金路易。你不会把这些东西送人的，对吧，欧仁妮，嗯？”
en: “I won’t do so again, never again,” cried her husband, “you shall see, my poor wife!”He went to his inner room and returned with a handful of louis, which he scattered on the bed.“Here, Eugenie! See, wife! All these are for you,” he said, fingering the coins.“Come, be happy, wife! Feel better, get well; you sha’n’t want for anything, nor Eugenie either.Here’s a hundred @louis d’or@ for her.You won’t give these away, will you, Eugenie, hein?”

zh: 葛朗台太太和女儿面面相觑，惊呆了。
en: Madame Grandet and her daughter looked at each other in astonishment.

zh: “父亲，把您的钱拿回去吧，我们只需要您的慈爱。”
en: “Take back your money, father; we ask for nothing but your affection.”

zh: “好吧，好吧，完全正确！”说着，他把硬币放进了口袋，“咱们就是好朋友啦！咱们今天下楼去吃晚饭，而且咱们要每天晚上都玩两个苏的摸彩。你们俩会开心的。嘿，太太？”
en: “Well, well, that’s right!” he said, pocketing the coins, “let’s be good friends!We will all go down to dinner today, and we’ll play loto every evening for two sous.You shall both be happy.Hey, wife?”

zh: “唉！要是这能让你高兴，我倒是巴不得，”奄奄一息的女人说道，“可我起不了床。”
en: “Alas! I wish I could, if it would give you pleasure,” said the dying woman, “but I cannot rise from my bed.”

zh: “可怜的孩子她妈，”葛朗台说，“你不知道我有多爱你！还有你，我的女儿！”他搂住女儿，吻了吻。“哦，生完气再吻女儿可真好！瞧，孩子她妈，你没看见现在一切都过去了吗？去把那东西收拾起来，欧仁妮，”他指指箱子，又说道，“去吧，别怕！我以后再也不会提它了，永远不会！”
en: “Poor mother,” said Grandet, “you don’t know how I love you! And you too, my daughter!”He took her in his arms and kissed her.“Oh, how good it is to kiss a daughter when we have been angry with her!There, mother, don’t you see it’s all over now?Go and put that away, Eugenie,” he added, pointing to the case.“Go, don’t be afraid!I shall never speak of it again, never!”

zh: 贝日冷先生很快就到了，他是索米尔有名的医生。检查完之后，他语气肯定地告诉葛朗台，他妻子病得很厉害；但是心境平和、饮食得当，再加上精心的照料，可能会让她活到秋天。
en: Monsieur Bergerin, the celebrated doctor of Saumur, presently arrived.After an examination, he told Grandet positively that his wife was very ill; but that perfect peace of mind, a generous diet, and great care might prolong her life until the autumn.

zh: “那会花很多钱吗？”老头说，“她需要吃药吗？”
en: “Will all that cost much?” said the old man.“Will she need medicines?”

zh: “药不用多吃，但是要多加照顾。”医生忍不住微微一笑，回答道。
en: “Not much medicine, but a great deal of care,” answered the doctor, who could scarcely restrain a smile.

zh: “喏，贝日冷先生，”葛朗台说，“您是个正直的人，是不是？我信得过您！您觉得怎样做合适，什么时候该来看我的太太，就只管来吧。救救我的好太太！我爱她——您没看到吗？——尽管我嘴上从来不说，但我心里一直这样想。我很苦恼。从我兄弟死时，麻烦就开始了，我不得不为他在巴黎的事花大笔大笔的钱。唉，我可是花了很多钱了，这还没完呢。再见，先生！如果您能救我的太太，就救救她吧。我会不惜一切代价的，哪怕花上我一二百法郎都行。”
en: “Now, Monsieur Bergerin,” said Grandet, “you are a man of honor, are not you?I trust to you!Come and see my wife how and when you think necessary.Save my good wife!I love her,—don’t you see?—though I never talk about it; I keep things to myself.I’m full of trouble.Troubles began when my brother died; I have to spend enormous sums on his affairs in Paris.Why, I’m paying through my nose; there’s no end to it.Adieu, monsieur!If you can save my wife, save her.I’ll spare no expense, not even if it costs me a hundred or two hundred francs.”

zh: 尽管葛朗台强烈地盼望他的妻子能康复，妻子的死对他的威胁远远不止死亡那么简单；尽管他对受宠若惊的母女俩百依百顺；尽管欧仁妮竭尽全力去悉心照料她的母亲——葛朗台太太还是很快走到了生命的尽头。她一天比一天虚弱，明显地越来越憔悴，像她这个年纪的女人，在患了重病之后，往往都会如此。她脆弱得就像秋天的叶子，天国的光辉照在她的身上，仿佛太阳照射着枯萎的叶子，给它们镀上了金光。她的死无愧于她的一生——这是一个基督徒的死，很崇高，不是吗？一八二二年十月，她的美德、她天使般的耐心、她对女儿的爱似乎都表现得格外显著；然后她就离开了人世，没有一句怨言。好像白璧无瑕的羔羊，她去了天国，唯一割舍不下的，就是她凄凉惨淡的人生中那个温柔的伴侣，她最后看女儿的那一眼，仿佛是预言了女儿充满苦难的命运。想到要把和自己一样洁白的小羊羔独自留在一个自私自利的世界中，那世界就是要剥掉她的羊毛，抢走她的财宝，她便瑟瑟发抖。
en: In spite of Grandet’s fervent wishes for the health of his wife, whose death threatened more than death to him; in spite of the consideration he now showed on all occasions for the least wish of his astonished wife and daughter; in spite of the tender care which Eugenie lavished upon her mother,—Madame Grandet rapidly approached her end.Every day she grew weaker and wasted visibly, as women of her age when attacked by serious illness are wont to do.She was fragile as the foliage in autumn; the radiance of heaven shone through her as the sun strikes athwart the withering leaves and gilds them.It was a death worthy of her life,—a Christian death; and is not that sublime?In the month of October, 1822, her virtues, her angelic patience, her love for her daughter, seemed to find special expression; and then she passed away without a murmur.Lamb without spot, she went to heaven, regretting only the sweet companion of her cold and dreary life, for whom her last glance seemed to prophesy a destiny of sorrows.She shrank from leaving her ewe-lamb, white as herself, alone in the midst of a selfish world that sought to strip her of her fleece and grasp her treasures.

zh: “我的孩子，”她咽气时说道，“只有天国才有幸福，你总有一天会知道的。”
en: “My child,” she said as she expired, “there is no happiness except in heaven; you will know it some day.”

zh: 第十二章
en: Chapter XII

zh: 母亲死后第二天，欧仁妮觉得有了一个新的理由让她眷恋这个宅子，她在这里出生，在这里经受了这么多痛苦，而且她母亲刚刚在这里去世。一看见那扇窗子和装有小脚轮的椅子，她就不禁落泪。当发现老父亲对自己关怀备至时，她想过去是误解了父亲的心思。他早上过来扶着她去吃早餐；他一连几个小时看着她，目光几乎可算是慈祥的；他不离她的左右，仿佛她是金子一般。老头判若两人，他时常在女儿跟前发抖，所以娜农和克吕绍派的人在目睹了他的老态之后，把这归结于他年事已高，并担心他的身体的机能正在退化。但是在家里办丧事的那天，克吕绍公证人（唯一知道他秘密的人）应邀在座，晚饭后，老守财奴的行为得到了解释。
en: On the morrow of this death Eugenie felt a new motive for attachment to the house in which she was born, where she had suffered so much, where her mother had just died.She could not see the window and the chair on its castors without weeping.She thought she had mistaken the heart of her old father when she found herself the object of his tenderest cares.He came in the morning and gave her his arm to take her to breakfast; he looked at her for hours together with an eye that was almost kind; he brooded over her as though she had been gold.The old man was so unlike himself, he trembled so often before his daughter, that Nanon and the Cruchotines, who witnessed his weakness, attributed it to his great age, and feared that his faculties were giving away.But the day on which the family put on their mourning, and after dinner, to which meal Maitre Cruchot (the only person who knew his secret) had been invited, the conduct of the old miser was explained.

zh: “我亲爱的孩子，”等饭桌收拾完，门也被小心地关上以后，他对欧仁妮说，“你现在是你母亲的继承人，我们之间有些小事要处理一下。是不是，克吕绍？”
en: “My dear child,” he said to Eugenie when the table had been cleared and the doors carefully shut, “you are now your mother’s heiress, and we have a few little matters to settle between us.Isn’t that so, Cruchot?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “非要今天谈那些事吗，父亲？”
en: “Is it necessary to talk of them today, father?”

zh: “是的，是的，小乖乖，我受不了这没着没落的处境。我想，你不想让我痛苦吧？”
en: “Yes, yes, little one; I can’t bear the uncertainty in which I’m placed.I think you don’t want to give me pain?”
“Oh! Father—”

zh: “那好！咱们今晚就把所有事都解决了吧。”
en: “Well, then! Let us settle it all tonight.”

zh: “您想让我做什么？”
en: “What is it you wish me to do?”

zh: “我的小姑娘，这不该由我来说。告诉她，克吕绍。”
en: “My little girl, it is not for me to say.Tell her, Cruchot.”

zh: “小姐，你父亲不愿分割财产，也不愿卖掉产业，更不愿意因他拥有的现款而缴纳巨额的税费。因此，为了避免上述情形，他只能不对他所有的财产进行登记造册，这其中一部分是你从你母亲那里继承的，而现在你和你父亲之间还没有进行分割——”
en: “Mademoiselle, your father does not wish to divide the property, nor sell the estate, nor pay enormous taxes on the ready money which he may possess.Therefore, to avoid all this, he must be released from making the inventory of his whole fortune, part of which you inherit from your mother, and which is now undivided between you and your father—”

zh: “克吕绍，你在跟一个还是孩子的人讲话之前，对你要说的话很有把握吗？”
en: “Cruchot, are you quite sure of what you are saying before you tell it to a mere child?”

zh: “让我按我自己的方式来讲吧，葛朗台。”
en: “Let me tell it my own way, Grandet.”

zh: “好的，好的，我的朋友。不管是你，还是我女儿，都不想抢劫我——是吧，小乖乖？”
en: “Yes, yes, my friend.Neither you nor my daughter wish to rob me,—do you, little one?”

zh: “不过，克吕绍先生，我该做什么呢？”欧仁妮不耐烦地说道。
en: “But, Monsieur Cruchot, what am I to do?” said Eugenie impatiently.

zh: “好的，”公证人说，“你必须在这张契约上签字，声明放弃对你母亲遗产的继承权，在你父亲的有生之年，将你们未进行分割的全部财产交给他使用和配置，他保证你的资产净值。”
en: “Well,” said the notary, “it is necessary to sign this deed, by which you renounce your rights to your mother’s estate and leave your father the use and disposition, during his lifetime, of all the property undivided between you, of which he guarantees you the capital.”

zh: “您说的话，我一句也听不懂，”欧仁妮回答道，“给我契约，告诉我在哪里签字。”
en: “I do not understand a word of what you are saying,” returned Eugenie, “give me the deed, and show me where I am to sign it.”

zh: 葛朗台老头看看契约，又看看女儿，看了女儿，又看看契约，这么看了个来回，在这期间，他心里激动得厉害，便擦了擦脑门上淌下的汗。
en: Pere Grandet looked alternately at the deed and at his daughter, at his daughter and at the deed, undergoing as he did so such violent emotion that he wiped the sweat from his brow.

zh: “我的小姑娘，”他说，“契约归档会花很多钱的，如果你不签这份契约，只是同意放弃对你那亲爱的已故母亲的遗产继承权，并将你的前途托付给我，我会更满意的。那样的话，我就每月给你至少整整一百法郎。看看，这下子，你要给谁做弥撒，做多少次都付得起了——嗯！一个月一百法郎——按里弗赫给？”
en: “My little girl,” he said, “if, instead of signing this deed, which will cost a great deal to record, you would simply agree to renounce your rights as heir to your poor dear, deceased mother’s property, and would trust to me for the future, I should like it better.In that case I will pay you monthly the good round sum of a hundred francs.See, now, you could pay for as many masses as you want for anybody—Hein! A hundred francs a month—in @livres@?”

zh: “我全按您的意愿办，父亲。”
en: “I will do all you wish, father.”

zh: “小姐，”公证人说，“我有责任向你说明，你会一无所有，没有任何保障——”
en: “Mademoiselle,” said the notary, “it is my duty to point out to you that you are despoiling yourself without guarantee—”

zh: “天哪！那跟我有什么关系？”
en: “Good heavens! What is all that to me?”

zh: “闭上你的嘴，克吕绍！一言为定，就这么定了。”葛朗台一边喊着，一边抓住他女儿的手，用自己的手拍着，“欧仁妮，你不会出尔反尔的？——你是个诚实的姑娘，嗯？”
en: “Hold your tongue, Cruchot!It’s settled, all settled,” cried Grandet, taking his daughter’s hand and striking it with his own.“Eugenie, you won’t go back on your word?—you are an honest girl, hein?”
“Oh! Father!—”

zh: 他热情地吻了她一下，把她搂得紧紧的，弄得她几乎喘不过气来。
en: He kissed her effusively, and pressed her in his arms till he almost choked her.

zh: “走，我的好孩子，你救了你父亲一命；不过，你只是把他给你的东西还给了他：我们两清了。买卖就应该这样做。人生就是笔买卖。我祝福你！你是个品德高尚的姑娘，你是爱你父亲的。以后你想做什么就做什么。明天，克吕绍，”他看着惊骇不已的公证人，补充道，“你要着手准备做欧仁妮放弃继承权的契约，然后交到法庭归档。”
en: “Go, my good child, you restore your father’s life; but you only return to him that which he gave you: we are quits.This is how business should be done.Life is a business.I bless you! You are a virtuous girl, and you love your father.Do just what you like in future.Tomorrow, Cruchot,” he added, looking at the horrified notary, “you will see about preparing the deed of relinquishment, and then enter it on the records of the court.”

zh: 第二天早上，欧仁妮在契约上签了字，完成了弃权声明。尽管有协议，老头曾正经八百地起誓要给女儿一百法郎，然而，第一年年底，他连一个子儿都没给她。当欧仁妮和和气气地提醒他这件事时，他禁不住红了脸，急忙去了他的密室，拿下来大约三分之一从侄子那里搞到的珠宝，给了她。
en: The next morning Eugenie signed the papers by which she herself completed her spoliation.At the end of the first year, however, in spite of his bargain, the old man had not given his daughter one sou of the hundred francs he had so solemnly pledged to her.When Eugenie pleasantly reminded him of this, he could not help coloring, and went hastily to his secret hiding-place, from whence he brought down about a third of the jewels he had taken from his nephew, and gave them to her.

zh: “瞧，小乖乖，”他用挖苦的语调说道，“你想不想用这些东西来抵你那一千二百法郎？”
en: “There, little one,” he said in a sarcastic tone, “do you want those for your twelve hundred francs?”

zh: “哦！父亲，真的吗？您真的要把它们给了我？”
en: “Oh! Father, truly? Will you really give them to me?”

zh: “我明年再多给你点儿，”说着，他把那些东西扔进了她的围裙，“这样，用不了多久，你就会把他的所有玩意儿都拿到手了。”他一边补充道，一边搓着手，很高兴能利用女儿的感情占到便宜。
en: “I’ll give you as many more next year,” he said, throwing them into her apron.“So before long you’ll get all his gewgaws,” he added, rubbing his hands, delighted to be able to speculate on his daughter’s feelings.

zh: 可是，老头尽管身体还结实，但还是觉得有必要把他节俭持家的秘诀传授给女儿。连着两年，他让女儿当着他的面安排家里的饭菜，并让她收取租金。他慢慢地、逐一地把他的葡萄园和农庄的名称以及收益能力都教给了她。大约第三年，他已经让她完全适应了他的贪婪作风，贪婪已经变成她固定的生活习惯，于是他总算可以放心地把家里的钥匙交给她掌管，让她当家了。
en: Nevertheless, the old man, though still robust, felt the importance of initiating his daughter into the secrets of his thrift and its management.For two consecutive years he made her order the household meals in his presence and receive the rents, and he taught her slowly and successively the names and remunerative capacity of his vineyards and his farms.About the third year he had so thoroughly accustomed her to his avaricious methods that they had turned into the settled habits of her own life, and he was able to leave the household keys in her charge without anxiety, and to install her as mistress of the house.

zh: 五年过去了，没有发生一件能让欧仁妮和她父亲的单调生活有所调剂的事情。他们每天总是做同样的事情，就像钟一样机械规律。葛朗台小姐深切的愁苦人尽皆知；可是虽然别人都在推测其中的原因，她自己却从不吐露一个字，让索米尔上上下下对这位富家女的内心感受所作的种种猜测有所证实。与她交往的只有三位克吕绍和几个他们逐渐引荐到葛朗台家的朋友。他们教她打惠斯特牌，而且他们每晚都要来玩一玩。一八二七年这一年，她父亲感到自己已虚弱不堪，不得不让她更进一步地了解他那些不动产的秘密，并且告诉她，但凡有了困难，可以向克吕绍公证人求助，克吕绍的忠实可靠，他是非常了解的。
en: Five years passed away without a single event to relieve the monotonous existence of Eugenie and her father.The same actions were performed daily with the automatic regularity of clockwork.The deep sadness of Mademoiselle Grandet was known to every one; but if others surmised the cause, she herself never uttered a word that justified the suspicions which all Saumur entertained about the state of the rich heiress’s heart.Her only society was made up of the three Cruchots and a few of their particular friends whom they had, little by little, introduced into the Grandet household.They had taught her to play whist, and they came every night for their game.During the year 1827 her father, feeling the weight of his infirmities, was obliged to initiate her still further into the secrets of his landed property, and told her that in case of difficulty she was to have recourse to Maitre Cruchot, whose integrity was well known to him.

zh: 将近这一年年底时，老头那时已八十二岁，他得了瘫痪症，病情迅速恶化。贝日冷医生对他放弃了医治。欧仁妮想到自己将要独自留在人世，便好像离父亲更亲近了，把这份尚存的亲情的最后一环握得更紧了。在她看来，爱就是生命的全部，在这点上，所有恋爱中的都女人一样。夏尔不在身边，她就把全部的体贴和关心都放在了老父亲的身上，老父亲的身体机能已经开始衰退，尽管他的贪婪吝啬仍旧本能地十分强烈。这个男人的死和他的生没有显出什么差别。早上，他让她们把他推到他卧室的壁炉和密室的门中间的一个地方。毫无疑问，密室里堆满了金子。他对听到的任何声响，哪怕是最轻微的，都要问个明白；让公证人大为惊讶的是，他甚至连看门狗在院子里打呵欠都听得见。每当到了租金到期、跟葡萄园艺工结账，或是开收据的日子和时刻，他就会从貌似昏迷的状态中清醒过来。这时候，他便会推动带有小脚轮的椅子，来到密室的门前。他让女儿打开门，看着她把一袋又一袋的钱放进他秘密的储藏室里，然后再锁好门。接着，等把钥匙给了他之后，她就默默地回到自己的座位上，而他则把钥匙放回他的马甲口袋里，还不时地用手摸摸。他的老朋友公证人确信，假如夏尔·葛朗台不回来，这个富有的女继承人肯定会嫁给他的庭长侄子的，于是他就变得倍加殷勤；他每天都来听葛朗台的吩咐，去弗罗瓦丰、农庄、草场和葡萄园替他办差，把葡萄收成卖掉，将一切所得换成金银，再装成一袋一袋，放进那个密室。
en: Towards the end of this year the old man, then eighty-two, was seized by paralysis, which made rapid progress.Dr. Bergerin gave him up.Eugenie, feeling that she was about to be left alone in the world, came, as it were, nearer to her father, and clasped more tightly this last living link of affection.To her mind, as in that of all loving women, love was the whole of life.Charles was not there, and she devoted all her care and attention to the old father, whose faculties had begun to weaken, though his avarice remained instinctively acute.The death of this man offered no contrast to his life.In the morning he made them roll him to a spot between the chimney of his chamber and the door of the secret room, which was filled, no doubt, with gold.He asked for an explanation of every noise he heard, even the slightest; to the great astonishment of the notary, he even heard the watchdog yawning in the courtyard.He woke up from his apparent stupor at the day and hour when the rents were due, or when accounts had to be settled with his vine-dressers, and receipts given.At such times he worked his chair forward on its castors until he faced the door of the inner room.He made his daughter open it, and watched while she placed the bags of money one upon another in his secret receptacles and relocked the door.Then she returned silently to her seat, after giving him the key, which he replaced in his waistcoat pocket and fingered from time to time.His old friend the notary, feeling sure that the rich heiress would inevitably marry his nephew the president, if Charles Grandet did not return, redoubled all his attentions; he came every day to take Grandet’s orders, went on his errands to Froidfond, to the farms and the fields and the vineyards, sold the vintages, and turned everything into gold and silver, which found their way in sacks to the secret hiding-place.

zh: 终于，最后的挣扎来临了，老头结实的身板奄奄待毙。他决意要坐到壁炉边正对着密室房门的地方。他把身上盖的东西都拉起来，裹紧了，对娜农说，“把它们收拾好，锁起来，以免被人偷了。”
en: At length the last struggle came, in which the strong frame of the old man slowly yielded to destruction.He was determined to sit at the chimney-corner facing the door of the secret room.He drew off and rolled up all the coverings which were laid over him, saying to Nanon, “Put them away, lock them up, for fear they should be stolen.”

zh: 他的全部生命力现在都退守在双眼中，只要能够睁开眼睛，他就会把目光转向那扇后面藏着他的财宝的门，他跟女儿说：“它们在那里吗？它们在那里吗？”语调里透着一种惶恐不安。
en: So long as he could open his eyes, in which his whole being had now taken refuge, he turned them to the door behind which lay his treasures, saying to his daughter, “Are they there? Are they there?” in a tone of voice which revealed a sort of panic fear.

zh: “是的，父亲。”她会回答道。
en: “Yes, my father,” she would answer.

zh: “看好金子——把金子放到我面前。”
en: “Take care of the gold—put gold before me.”

zh: 于是，欧仁妮就会把硬币摊放在他面前的一张桌子上，而他会一连坐上好几个小时，两眼盯着硬币，好像一个刚刚开始看的孩子一样，老是盯着同一件东西发呆，他还会像个孩子一样，脸上闪现出一丝微笑，但看起来有点儿痛苦。
en: Eugenie would then spread coins on a table before him, and he would sit for hours together with his eyes fixed upon them, like a child who, at the moment it first begins to see, gazes in stupid contemplation at the same object, and like the child, a distressful smile would flicker upon his face.

zh: 有时他会说：“这东西让我觉得暖和！”这时他的脸上就掠过一种无比幸福的表情。
en: “It warms me!” he would sometimes say, as an expression of beatitude stole across his features.

zh: 当教区的神父来主持临终圣礼时，老头那双明显已失明了几个小时的眼睛，一看见十字架、烛台和银圣水壶，就放出了光；他目不转睛地盯着那些东西，他的肉瘤动了最后一次。当神父把镀银的十字架放到他的唇边，让他亲吻基督时，他做了一个可怕的手势，仿佛要抓住十字架，这最后一使劲要了他的命。他叫着欧仁妮，尽管她就跪在他的边上，他却看不见。欧仁妮的泪水洒落在他僵硬的手上，那手已经冰凉了。
en: When the cure of the parish came to administer the last sacraments, the old man’s eyes, sightless, apparently, for some hours, kindled at the sight of the cross, the candlesticks, and the holy-water vessel of silver; he gazed at them fixedly, and his wen moved for the last time.When the priest put the crucifix of silver-gilt to his lips, that he might kiss the Christ, he made a frightful gesture, as if to seize it; and that last effort cost him his life.He called Eugenie, whom he did not see, though she was kneeling beside him bathing with tears his stiffening hand, which was already cold.

zh: “父亲，祝福我吧！”她恳求道。
en: “My father, bless me!” she entreated.

zh: “把所有事都照管好。你要到那边给我交账！”他说道，用这最后几个字证明了基督教应该永远是守财奴的宗教。
en: “Take care of it all.You will render me an account yonder!” he said, proving by these last words that Christianity must always be the religion of misers.

zh: 欧仁妮·葛朗台现在独自留在世间，住在那座灰色的宅子里，只有娜农一个人能够确定无疑地听懂她的话，并理解她——娜农是唯一为爱她而爱她的人，唯一她能与之倾诉悲痛的人。对欧仁妮来说，大个子娜农就是个守护神。她不是佣人，而是个谦卑的朋友。父亲死后，欧仁妮从克吕绍公证人那里得知，她在索米尔郡因不动产和动产而拥有三十万法郎的收入，另有以年息百分之三投资公债的六百万法郎（六十法郎买进，现在值七十六法郎），还有两百万的金币和十万法郎的克朗银币，以及日后待入的利息。
en: Eugenie Grandet was now alone in the world in that gray house, with none but Nanon to whom she could turn with the certainty of being heard and understood,—Nanon the sole being who loved her for herself and with whom she could speak of her sorrows.La Grande Nanon was a providence for Eugenie.She was not a servant, but a humble friend.After her father’s death Eugenie learned from Maitre Cruchot that she possessed an income of three hundred thousand francs from landed and personal property in the arrondissement of Saumur; also six millions invested at three per cent in the Funds (bought at sixty, and now worth seventy-six francs); also two millions in gold coin, and a hundred thousand francs in silver crown-pieces, besides all the interest which was still to be collected.

zh: 她的财产总数达到了一千七百万。
en: The sum total of her property reached seventeen millions.

zh: “我的堂弟在哪里呢？”这是她心里想的一件事。
en: “Where is my cousin?” was her one thought.

zh: 那天，克吕绍公证人给他的委托人送来了一份清楚准确的全部遗产的清单，欧仁妮正孤零零地和娜农坐在壁炉旁，大厅空荡荡的，如今，从她母亲曾坐过的带小脚轮的椅子，到她堂弟用过的玻璃杯，这大厅的所有东西都已成了回忆。
en: The day on which Maitre Cruchot handed in to his client a clear and exact schedule of the whole inheritance, Eugenie remained alone with Nanon, sitting beside the fireplace in the vacant hall, where all was now a memory, from the chair on castors which her mother had sat in, to the glass from which her cousin drank.

zh: “娜农，就剩下咱们了——”
en: “Nanon, we are alone—”

zh: “是的，小姐，要是我知道他在哪里，那个宝贝，我就是走着也要找着他。”
en: “Yes, mademoiselle; and if I knew where he was, the darling, I’d go on foot to find him.”

zh: “我们中间隔着大洋呢。”她说。
en: “The ocean is between us,” she said.

zh: 这幢阴冷黑暗的房子就是可怜的女继承人的整个世界，当她在里面由老佣人陪着哭泣的时候，从南特到奥尔良，整个省都在盛传着葛朗台小姐有一千七百万的事。她做的第一件事情就是给了娜农一千二百法郎的年金，连上原先已有的六百多法郎，娜农成了一个有钱的、令人羡慕的结婚对象。不到一个月，这个好心人就由单身步入了婚姻生活，嫁给了安托万·科努瓦耶，科努瓦耶被任命为葛朗台小姐全部产业的总管。科努瓦耶太太和她的同龄人相比，有个明显的优势。她虽然五十九岁了，但看上去还不过四十岁。她粗糙的容貌经得起岁月的摧残。由于半修道院式的健康的生活习惯，凭着红润的皮肤和铁打般的体格这样的有利条件，她一点儿都不显老。也许在一生当中，她从没有像结婚那天那么好看过。她沾了生得丑陋的光，她又高、又胖、又结实，还有毫不见老的脸上一副幸福的神情，这让好多人羡慕起科努瓦耶来。
en: While the poor heiress wept in company of an old servant, in that cold dark house, which was to her the universe, the whole province rang, from Nantes to Orleans, with the seventeen millions of Mademoiselle Grandet.Among her first acts she had settled an annuity of twelve hundred francs on Nanon, who, already possessed of six hundred more, became a rich and enviable match.In less than a month that good soul passed from single to wedded life under the protection of Antoine Cornoiller, who was appointed keeper of all Mademoiselle Grandet’s estates.Madame Cornoiller possessed one striking advantage over her contemporaries.Although she was fifty-nine years of age, she did not look more than forty.Her strong features had resisted the ravages of time.Thanks to the healthy customs of her semi-conventual life, she laughed at old age from the vantage-ground of a rosy skin and an iron constitution.Perhaps she never looked as well in her life as she did on her marriage-day.She had all the benefits of her ugliness, and was big and fat and strong, with a look of happiness on her indestructible features which made a good many people envy Cornoiller.

zh: “气色真好！”卖布的说。
en: “Fast colors!” said the draper.

zh: “很能生孩子呢，”卖盐的商人说，“她简直是在卤水里腌过，恕我冒昧。”
en: “Quite likely to have children,” said the salt merchant.“She’s pickled in brine, saving your presence.”

zh: “她有钱，科努瓦耶那小子可是给自己办了件好事。”第三个人说道。
en: “She is rich, and that fellow Cornoiller has done a good thing for himself,” said a third man.

zh: 娜农在街坊四邻间人缘很好，她从老房子里出来去往教区的教堂，在走过曲曲折折的街道时，受到了很多人的祝贺。欧仁妮送给她三打银叉子和勺子作为结婚贺礼。科努瓦耶没有想到女主人竟如此慷慨，提起他的女主人便热泪盈眶，他甘愿为她粉身碎骨。科努瓦耶太太被任命为葛朗台小姐的管家，她从她的新职位中得到的快乐不亚于有了一个丈夫所得到的快乐。她负责每周的账务；她学着已故男主人的做派，把食物锁起来，再每天发放出去；她管着两个佣人——一个厨子和一个负责补衣服被褥和缝制小姐衣裙的女佣。科努瓦耶兼任看守和总管。不用说，由娜农挑来的女佣是“绝佳的珍品”。葛朗台小姐于是便有了四个忠心耿耿的佣人。佃户们在葛朗台先生死后并没有觉出有什么变化；他严格制定的规矩章程都被科努瓦耶先生和太太一丝不苟地执行着。
en: When she came forth from the old house on her way to the parish church, Nanon, who was loved by all the neighborhood, received many compliments as she walked down the tortuous street.Eugenie had given her three dozen silver forks and spoons as a wedding present.Cornoiller, amazed at such magnificence, spoke of his mistress with tears in his eyes; he would willingly have been hacked in pieces in her behalf.Madame Cornoiller, appointed housekeeper to Mademoiselle Grandet, got as much happiness out of her new position as she did from the possession of a husband.She took charge of the weekly accounts; she locked up the provisions and gave them out daily, after the manner of her defunct master; she ruled over two servants,—a cook, and a maid whose business it was to mend the house-linen and make mademoiselle’s dresses.Cornoiller combined the functions of keeper and bailiff.It is unnecessary to say that the women-servants selected by Nanon were “perfect treasures.”Mademoiselle Grandet thus had four servants, whose devotion was unbounded.The farmers perceived no change after Monsieur Grandet’s death; the usages and customs he had sternly established were scrupulously carried out by Monsieur and Madame Cornoiller.

zh: 到了三十岁，欧仁妮还没有体会到人生的任何乐趣。她暗淡悲凉的童年是在一个心灵总是被误解和伤害、永远总在痛苦的母亲身边度过的。这位母亲在高高兴兴离开人世时，可怜女儿还必须得活下去；她给她孩子的心里留下了些许短暂的自责和许多永久的遗憾。欧仁妮的第一次也是仅有的一次爱情是她内心愁苦的根源。和情人相处了短短几天，她便在两次秘密的接吻中把心交给了他；后来他走了，他们中间隔着整个世界。这场被她父亲诅咒的爱情，夺走了她母亲的生命，给她带来的只有悲痛，中间夹杂着几分渺茫的希望。所以，她对幸福奋力的追求耗尽了她的力量，但没有给她任何回报。精神生活和肉体生活一样，有呼有吸；一个灵魂需要吸收另一个灵魂的情感并加以融合，才可能以更丰富的形式回报对方。要是没有人类这种美妙的现象，心灵就会没有生机；就会缺乏空气；就会遭受苦痛，然后凋亡。欧仁妮已经开始痛苦了。对她来说，财富既不是权力，也不是慰籍；她只能靠爱情、宗教和对未来的信念而活着。爱情向她阐明了永恒的秘密。她的心灵和福音书让她知道了两个世界；她日日夜夜都沉浸在两种无限的思想深处，这两种思想对她来说也许只有一个含义。她回到自己的内心世界中，爱着别人，并相信自己也被人爱着。七年来，她强烈的感情渗透进了一切当中。她的财富并不是收益不断增长的百万家产，而是夏尔的梳妆箱，是挂在她床头的那两张肖像，是从她父亲那里赎回并自豪地珍藏于橡木柜子抽屉中一层毛毡子上的首饰，还有她母亲曾一度用过的她婶婶的顶针。她一做刺绣的时候，就虔诚地戴上那只顶针——好像珀涅罗珀织布一样，仅仅是为了把那满载回忆的金器戴在她的手指上。
en: At thirty years of age Eugenie knew none of the joys of life.Her pale, sad childhood had glided on beside a mother whose heart, always misunderstood and wounded, had known only suffering.Leaving this life joyfully, the mother pitied the daughter because she still must live; and she left in her child’s soul some fugitive remorse and many lasting regrets.Eugenie’s first and only love was a wellspring of sadness within her.Meeting her lover for a few brief days, she had given him her heart between two kisses furtively exchanged; then he had left her, and a whole world lay between them.This love, cursed by her father, had cost the life of her mother and brought her only sorrow, mingled with a few frail hopes.Thus her upward spring towards happiness had wasted her strength and given her nothing in exchange for it.In the life of the soul, as in the physical life, there is an inspiration and a respiration; the soul needs to absorb the sentiments of another soul and assimilate them, that it may render them back enriched.Were it not for this glorious human phenomenon, there would be no life for the heart; air would be wanting; it would suffer, and then perish.Eugenie had begun to suffer.For her, wealth was neither a power nor a consolation; she could not live except through love, through religion, through faith in the future.Love explained to her the mysteries of eternity.Her heart and the Gospel taught her to know two worlds; she bathed, night and day, in the depths of two infinite thoughts, which for her may have had but one meaning.She drew back within herself, loving, and believing herself beloved.For seven years her passion had invaded everything.Her treasuries were not the millions whose revenues were rolling up; they were Charles’s dressing-case, the portraits hanging above her bed, the jewels recovered from her father and proudly spread upon a bed of wool in a drawer of the oaken cabinet, the thimble of her aunt, used for a while by her mother, which she wore religiously as she worked at a piece of embroidery,—a Penelope’s web, begun for the sole purpose of putting upon her finger that gold so rich in memories.

zh: 看来葛朗台小姐是不大可能在服丧期间结婚的。她真挚的虔诚之心人尽皆知。结果，克吕绍一家在老神父的高明筹划下，暂时心满意足地围绕在这位有钱的女继承人左右，并给予她最殷勤的照顾。每天晚上，大厅里满是克吕绍家忠诚的拥趸，他们用各种声调对女主人大唱赞歌。她有常任的侍医，有大司祭，有内侍，有梳妆女官，有首相；最重要的是，她有总理大臣，一个乐意对她大胆进言的大臣。如果这位女继承人想要个挽裙裾的人，她立刻就能找出一位来。她俨然是个女王，被人谄媚阿谀。阿谀奉承从不会出自高贵的灵魂，它是小人的伎俩，那些小人卑躬屈膝，千方百计接近他们要趋炎附势的大人物。阿谀奉承意在为自己谋利。所以，那些每天晚上聚集在葛朗台小姐家（他们称她为德弗罗瓦丰小姐）的人在赞美之词上相互争胜。这番异口同声的赞颂，欧仁妮以前从来没有领受过，初听时她还脸红；可是不知不觉地，她的耳朵听惯了这种声音，不管这些赞美之词是多么刺耳，她很快就适应了听别人称赞她的美貌，如果有某个新来的人好像有认为她丑陋的意思，她会觉得极为羞辱，程度远胜于八年前。她最终喜欢上了恭维话，那是她从前暗中对她膜拜的偶像说的。渐渐地，她习惯了被人捧得像个君主的生活，习惯了看着她的上下朝臣每晚紧紧地围着她转。
en: It seemed unlikely that Mademoiselle Grandet would marry during the period of her mourning.Her genuine piety was well known.Consequently the Cruchots, whose policy was sagely guided by the old abbe, contented themselves for the time being with surrounding the great heiress and paying her the most affectionate attentions.Every evening the hall was filled with a party of devoted Cruchotines, who sang the praises of its mistress in every key.She had her doctor in ordinary, her grand almoner, her chamberlain, her first lady of honor, her prime minister; above all, her chancellor, a chancellor who would fain have said much to her.If the heiress had wished for a train-bearer, one would instantly have been found.She was a queen, obsequiously flattered.Flattery never emanates from noble souls; it is the gift of little minds, who thus still further belittle themselves to worm their way into the vital being of the persons around whom they crawl.Flattery means self-interest.So the people who, night after night, assembled in Mademoiselle Grandet’s house (they called her Mademoiselle de Froidfond) outdid each other in expressions of admiration.This concert of praise, never before bestowed upon Eugenie, made her blush under its novelty; but insensibly her ear became habituated to the sound, and however coarse the compliments might be, she soon was so accustomed to hear her beauty lauded that if any new-comer had seemed to think her plain, she would have felt the reproach far more than she might have done eight years earlier.She ended at last by loving the incense, which she secretly laid at the feet of her idol.By degrees she grew accustomed to be treated as a sovereign and to see her court pressing around her every evening.

zh: 德蓬丰先生是这个小圈子的男主角，他的风趣、他的人品、他的学问和他的和蔼可亲在这个圈子里不断受到赞扬。有人说，七年来，他的财富已大大增加，蓬丰那块产业每年至少能带来一万法郎的收入，而且和克吕绍家的其他财产一样，四周都是那位女继承人的广阔地产。
en: Monsieur de Bonfons was the hero of the little circle, where his wit, his person, his education, his amiability, were perpetually praised.One or another would remark that in seven years he had largely increased his fortune, that Bonfons brought in at least ten thousand francs a year, and was surrounded, like the other possessions of the Cruchots, by the vast domains of the heiress.

zh: “你知道吗，小姐，”一个常客说道，“克吕绍家有四万法郎的收入！”
en: “Do you know, mademoiselle,” said an habitual visitor, “that the Cruchots have an income of forty thousand francs among them!”

zh: “还有他们的积蓄！”克吕绍派一个名叫德格里博古的老妇人大声喊道。
en: “And then, their savings!” exclaimed an elderly female Cruchotine, Mademoiselle de Gribeaucourt.

zh: “一位巴黎来的先生最近出价二十万法郎要把事务所盘给克吕绍先生，”另一个人说道，“他如果被任命为治安法官，就会把事务所盘出去。”
en: “A gentleman from Paris has lately offered Monsieur Cruchot two hundred thousand francs for his practice,” said another.“He will sell it if he is appointed @juge de paix@.”

zh: “他想接替德蓬丰先生当民事法庭的庭长，正在采取措施，”多尔松瓦太太回应道，“庭长先生肯定会被选为政务委员的。”
en: “He wants to succeed Monsieur de Bonfons as president of the civil courts, and is taking measures,” replied Madame d’Orsonval.“Monsieur le president will certainly be made councillor.”

zh: “是的，他是个非常出色的人才，”另一位说道，“您不这样认为吗，小姐？”
en: “Yes, he is a very distinguished man,” said another,“don’t you think so, mademoiselle?”

zh: 德蓬丰先生竭力要和自己想扮演的角色般配起来。虽然年已四十，而且面色黝黑、相貌可憎，跟多数司法人员一样长着一张干瘪的脸，他却穿得年轻时髦，舞弄着一根竹子手杖。他在德弗罗瓦丰小姐府上从不吸鼻烟，来时总系一条白领带，穿一件衬衣，衬衣上的褶皱饰边让他看上去像是跟火鸡同族。他跟美丽的女继承人说话时，态度亲昵，称她为“我们亲爱的欧仁妮”。总之，除了客人的数目，除了摸彩变成了惠斯特牌，除了葛朗台先生和太太的缺席，那场面和这段历史开头的情景差不多完全一样。那群猎犬仍在追逐欧仁妮和她的百万家产；可是猎犬的数量越多，嗅觉越灵敏，包围起猎物来也更加团结。要是夏尔从西印度群岛跑回来，他会发现还是同样的人和同样的利益。欧仁妮对德格拉桑太太非常友好，非常谦恭，德格拉桑太太仍然在不断地折磨克吕绍家。和从前一样，欧仁妮是画面的中心人物，而夏尔也像过去一样，仍旧还是所有人的领袖。不过，倒是还有一些进步。庭长以前每逢欧仁妮生日和命名日才给她送鲜花，而现在，鲜花已成了每天的定例。每天晚上，他都给富有的女继承人送来一大束富丽堂皇的鲜花，科努瓦耶太太总是当众把它插入花瓶，等客人离开后，就偷偷扔到院子的一个角落。
en: Monsieur de Bonfons endeavored to put himself in keeping with the role he sought to play.In spite of his forty years, in spite of his dusky and crabbed features, withered like most judicial faces, he dressed in youthful fashions, toyed with a bamboo cane, never took snuff in Mademoiselle de Froidfond’s house, and came in a white cravat and a shirt whose pleated frill gave him a family resemblance to the race of turkeys.He addressed the beautiful heiress familiarly, and spoke of her as “Our dear Eugenie.”In short, except for the number of visitors, the change from lotto to whist, and the disappearance of Monsieur and Madame Grandet, the scene was about the same as the one with which this history opened.The pack were still pursuing Eugenie and her millions; but the hounds, more in number, lay better on the scent, and beset the prey more unitedly.If Charles could have dropped from the Indian Isles, he would have found the same people and the same interests.Madame des Grassins, to whom Eugenie was full of kindness and courtesy, still persisted in tormenting the Cruchots.Eugenie, as in former days, was the central figure of the picture; and Charles, as heretofore, would still have been the sovereign of all.Yet there had been some progress.The flowers which the president formerly presented to Eugenie on her birthdays and fete-days had now become a daily institution.Every evening he brought the rich heiress a huge and magnificent bouquet, which Madame Cornoiller placed conspicuously in a vase, and secretly threw into a corner of the courtyard when the visitors had departed.

zh: 初春时，德格拉桑太太不想让克吕绍派过得太安生，就跟欧仁妮谈起德弗罗瓦丰侯爵，如果女继承人和他结了婚，把他原先的田产给他带回去，那他可能会重振早先破产的家业。德格拉桑太太翻来复去地讲着侯爵夫人的贵族爵位和头衔，当把欧仁妮轻蔑的微笑误以为是默许后，她便到处扬言说，欧仁妮跟“克吕绍先生”的婚姻远不像人们想的那样确定。
en: Early in the spring, Madame des Grassins attempted to trouble the peace of the Cruchotines by talking to Eugenie of the Marquis de Froidfond, whose ancient and ruined family might be restored if the heiress would give him back his estates through marriage.Madame des Grassins rang the changes on the peerage and the title of marquise, until, mistaking Eugenie’s disdainful smile for acquiescence, she went about proclaiming that the marriage with “Monsieur Cruchot” was not nearly as certain as people thought.

zh: “尽管德弗罗瓦丰先生五十岁了，”她说，“但他看上去没有克吕绍先生老。他是个鳏夫，有孩子，那倒是真的。不过他可是个侯爵，将来是法国的贵族院议员，这年头，你到哪里能找到比这更好的亲事呀？我确确实实知道，葛朗台老头在把所有钱投进弗罗瓦丰的时候，就是打算跟这个家族结亲的，他经常跟我说起这个。他是个狡猾的家伙，那个老头子！”
en: “Though Monsieur de Froidfond is fifty,” she said, “he does not look older than Monsieur Cruchot.He is a widower, and he has children, that’s true.But then he is a marquis; he will be peer of France; and in times like these where you will find a better match?I know it for a fact that Pere Grandet, when he put all his money into Froidfond, intended to graft himself upon that stock; he often told me so.He was a deep one, that old man!”

zh: “啊！娜农，”一天晚上临睡觉时，欧仁妮说道，“都七年了，他怎么从没给我写过一封信？”
en: “Ah! Nanon,” said Eugenie, one night as she was going to bed, “how is it that in seven years he has never once written to me?”

zh: 第十三章
en: Chapter XIII

zh: 在索米尔发生这些事件的时候，夏尔在西印度群岛发了财。他的那批货卖得很好。他一开始就挣到了六千美元。一过赤道，他便丢掉了脑子里许多陈腐的观念；他发现，和欧洲一样，热带地区最好的发财办法是买卖人口。他去非洲海岸买了一些黑人，在贩卖人口的同时，他还贩运其他一些同样有利可图的货物。他把全部精力投入到生意当中，没有片刻闲暇。他一心想发了大财，好风风光光地重返巴黎，并希望重新获得一个比他落魄前还要显耀的地位。
en: While these events were happening in Saumur, Charles was making his fortune in the Indies.His commercial outfit had sold well.He began by realizing a sum of six thousand dollars.Crossing the line had brushed a good many cobwebs out of his brain; he perceived that the best means of attaining fortune in tropical regions, as well as in Europe, was to buy and sell men.He went to the coast of Africa and bought Negroes, combining his traffic in human flesh with that of other merchandise equally advantageous to his interests.He carried into this business an activity which left him not a moment of leisure.He was governed by the desire of reappearing in Paris with all the prestige of a large fortune, and by the hope of regaining a position even more brilliant than the one from which he had fallen.

zh: 由于在人堆里混，在多个地方跑，还见识了各种迥异的风俗，他的观念改变了，变得爱猜疑了。他不再有一成不变的是非原则，因为他看到在一个国家被称为犯罪的事情，在另一个国家却被赞为美德。在为谋私利不断进行的搏斗中，他的心变冷酷了，然后又变得狭小，再后来就干枯了。葛朗台家族的血统没有失传；夏尔变得冷酷无情、贪得无厌。他贩卖中国人、黑人、燕窝、儿童和艺人；他大范围地放高利贷；他惯于欺诈海关，这很快就让他不怎么把人权当回事了。他到圣托马斯岛贱价收购海盗掠取的货物，然后再运到能卖个好价钱的港口。如果说在他初次出海时，他还想着欧仁妮纯洁而高贵的面容，就像西班牙水手把圣母像挂在桅杆上一样，如果说他把开始的成功还归功于他温柔的情人所做的祈祷和祝福的魔力上，那后来，他到处跟其他各种女人——黑人、穆拉托人、白人和印度舞女——花天酒地、放浪形骸，便把他对堂姐、索米尔、那座宅子、长凳和黑暗过道里的匆匆一吻这所有的回忆都抹得一干二净了。
en: By dint of jostling with men, travelling through many lands, and studying a variety of conflicting customs, his ideas had been modified and had become sceptical.He ceased to have fixed principles of right and wrong, for he saw what was called a crime in one country lauded as a virtue in another.In the perpetual struggle of selfish interests his heart grew cold, then contracted, and then dried up.The blood of the Grandets did not fail of its destiny; Charles became hard, and eager for prey.He sold Chinamen, Negroes, birds’ nests, children, artists; he practised usury on a large scale; the habit of defrauding custom-houses soon made him less scrupulous about the rights of his fellow men.He went to the Island of St. Thomas and bought, for a mere song, merchandise that had been captured by pirates, and took it to ports where he could sell it at a good price.If the pure and noble face of Eugenie went with him on his first voyage, like that image of the Virgin which Spanish mariners fastened to their masts, if he attributed his first success to the magic influence of the prayers and intercessions of his gentle love, later on women of other kinds,—blacks, mulattoes, whites, and Indian dancing-girls,—orgies and adventures in many lands, completely effaced all recollection of his cousin, of Saumur, of the house, the bench, the kiss snatched in the dark passage.

zh: 他只记得围在破旧墙垣里的小花园，因为正是在那里，他得知了突如其来的命运；但是他拒绝一切跟他的家族有关联的东西。他的伯父是只老狗，偷走了他的首饰；欧仁妮不管是在他的心里，还是在他的思想上都没有地位，尽管在他的账目里，她确实占着个六千法郎的债主的位置。
en: He remembered only the little garden shut in with crumbling walls, for it was there he learned the fate that had overtaken him; but he rejected all connection with his family.His uncle was an old dog who had filched his jewels; Eugenie had no place in his heart nor in his thoughts, though she did have a place in his accounts as a creditor for the sum of six thousand francs.

zh: 这种行为和这些想法便是夏尔·葛朗台杳无音信的原因。在西印度群岛、圣托马斯、非洲海岸、里斯本和美国，这个投机家取了个假名字——谢泼德，这样就不会连累他的本姓了。夏尔·谢泼德可以毫无风险、不知疲倦地大胆捞钱，贪图利益了，就像一个人决心不择手段地狠捞一把，以便早日金盆洗手，好在余生里做得像个正人君子。
en: Such conduct and such ideas explain Charles Grandet’s silence.In the Indies, at St. Thomas, on the coast of Africa, at Lisbon, and in the United States the adventurer had taken the pseudonym of Shepherd, that he might not compromise his own name.Charles Shepherd could safely be indefatigable, bold, grasping, and greedy of gain, like a man who resolves to snatch his fortune @quibus cumque viis@, and makes haste to have done with villainy, that he may spend the rest of his life as an honest man.

zh: 靠这种做法，他发迹又快又显赫；一八二七年，夏尔·葛朗台乘坐一艘隶属于保王党商号的豪华双桅横帆船——“玛丽·卡罗琳”号，返回了波尔多。他随身带有价值一百九十万法郎的金砂，希望换成法币时能从中获取百分之七或百分之八的利。在船上，他遇到了一位国王查理十世陛下的御用侍从——德奥布里翁先生，这位值得尊敬的老人一时糊涂娶了个上流社会的女人，而他的财产都是在西印度群岛赚来的。为了补上德奥布里翁太太挥霍的亏空，他去西印度群岛变卖了产业，此时正和家人返回法国。
en: With such methods, prosperity was rapid and brilliant; and in 1827 Charles Grandet returned to Bordeaux on the “Marie Caroline,” a fine brig belonging to a royalist house of business.He brought with him nineteen hundred thousand francs worth of gold-dust, from which he expected to derive seven or eight per cent more at the Paris mint.On the brig he met a gentleman-in-ordinary to His Majesty Charles X., Monsieur d’Aubrion, a worthy old man who had committed the folly of marrying a woman of fashion with a fortune derived from the West India Islands.To meet the costs of Madame d’Aubrion’s extravagance, he had gone out to the Indies to sell the property, and was now returning with his family to France.

zh: 德奥布里翁先生和太太是法国南部的一个家族——德奥布里翁·德比什家族的后裔，其家族最后一位领主，或者说首领，一七八九年以前就死了，他们现在家境衰落，收入大约仅为两万法郎。他们有个长相丑陋的女儿，做母亲的打算不给嫁妆就把她嫁出去——因为家里的财产只够勉强维持她在巴黎的生活需求。尽管交际场中的多数人都认为，一个交际花总是机灵过人，但他们也觉得这似乎是一番难于成功的事业；实际上，德奥布里翁太太本人每当看着自己的女儿，也差不多对她嫁人不抱任何希望了，哪怕是嫁给一个一心想跟贵族攀亲的人。德奥布里翁小姐很像跟她同名的昆虫，仿佛一个又高又瘦、又细又长的蜻蜓；她的嘴一副鄙夷的样子，上面长着个过于长的鼻子，鼻头很厚，平时是灰黄色的，可是吃过饭后，就变得非常红——当这种植物现象出现在一张苍白、沮丧而且乏味的脸上时，就会令人极为厌恶。从某种意义上说，她正是一个三十八岁，却风韵犹存、老于世故的母亲所希望的那样。不过，为了弥补女儿的个人缺陷，侯爵夫人教给了女儿一种雍容华贵的姿态，让她养成了良好的卫生习惯，使她的鼻子暂时保持着正常的肤色；她教给女儿穿着得体的技巧，使她拥有迷人的举止；向她展示做出忧郁眼神的诀窍，以打动男人，让那男人相信他已经找到了寻觅已久的天使；她还教给女儿如何抬足迈步——以便在鼻子肆无忌惮发红的时候，使纤足在裙裾下若隐若现，露出其娇小的尺寸。总之，德奥布里翁太太已经巧妙地将自己的后代精心打造了一番。
en: Monsieur and Madame d’Aubrion, of the house of d’Aubrion de Buch, a family of southern France, whose last @captal@, or chief, died before 1789, were now reduced to an income of about twenty thousand francs, and they possessed an ugly daughter whom the mother was resolved to marry without a @dot@,—the family fortune being scarcely sufficient for the demands of her own life in Paris.This was an enterprise whose success might have seemed problematical to most men of the world, in spite of the cleverness with which such men credit a fashionable woman; in fact, Madame d’Aubrion herself, when she looked at her daughter, almost despaired of getting rid of her to any one, even to a man craving connection with nobility.Mademoiselle d’Aubrion was a long, spare, spindling demoiselle, like her namesake the insect; her mouth was disdainful; over it hung a nose that was too long, thick at the end, sallow in its normal condition, but very red after a meal,—a sort of vegetable phenomenon which is particularly disagreeable when it appears in the middle of a pale, dull, and uninteresting face.In one sense she was all that a worldly mother, thirty-eight years of age and still a beauty with claims to admiration, could have wished.However, to counterbalance her personal defects, the marquise gave her daughter a distinguished air, subjected her to hygienic treatment which provisionally kept her nose at a reasonable flesh-tint, taught her the art of dressing well, endowed her with charming manners, showed her the trick of melancholy glances which interest a man and make him believe that he has found a long-sought angel, taught her the manoeuvre of the foot,—letting it peep beneath the petticoat, to show its tiny size, at the moment when the nose became aggressively red; in short, Madame d’Aubrion had cleverly made the very best of her offspring.

zh: 凭借宽大的袖子、掩人耳目的衬垫、裁剪宽松的蓬蓬长裙，还有紧绷绷的紧身胸衣，她居然拥有了一些精致的女性特点，简直应该把它们都放到博物馆中去展览，以供母亲们借鉴。
en: By means of full sleeves, deceptive pads, puffed dresses amply trimmed, and high-pressure corsets, she had obtained such curious feminine developments that she ought, for the instruction of mothers, to have exhibited them in a museum.

zh: 夏尔之所以跟德奥布里翁太太套近乎，正是因为这位太太很想跟他接近。船上的人声称，美丽的德奥布里翁太太用尽了所有手段来俘虏这个有钱的女婿。一八二七年六月，在波尔多下船时，德奥布里翁先生、太太、小姐，和夏尔住进了同一家旅店，并一起动身去往巴黎。德奥布里翁府邸早已被抵押出去，指定夏尔去赎回来。那位母亲告诉他，把底楼让给当女婿的住，她会有多么高兴。她不像德奥布里翁先生那样对贵族门第怀有偏见，她答应夏尔·葛朗台，要向查理十世请道御旨，恩准他——葛朗台改姓德奥布里翁，并使用德奥布里翁的爵徽，而且只要一年出三万六千法郎，就能购买下限嗣继承的不动产，承袭德比什领主和德奥布里翁侯爵的头衔。这样，通过将他们的财产合并起来，相互处得又融洽，再加上白拿的俸禄，两家人就可以住在德奥布里翁府邸，拥有超过十几万法郎的收入。
en: Charles became very intimate with Madame d’Aubrion precisely because she was desirous of becoming intimate with him.Persons who were on board the brig declared that the handsome Madame d’Aubrion neglected no means of capturing so rich a son-in-law.On landing at Bordeaux in June, 1827, Monsieur, Madame, Mademoiselle d’Aubrion, and Charles lodged at the same hotel and started together for Paris.The hotel d’Aubrion was hampered with mortgages; Charles was destined to free it.The mother told him how delighted she would be to give up the ground-floor to a son-in-law.Not sharing Monsieur d’Aubrion’s prejudices on the score of nobility, she promised Charles Grandet to obtain a royal ordinance from Charles X. which would authorize him, Grandet, to take the name and arms of d’Aubrion and to succeed, by purchasing the entailed estate for thirty-six thousand francs a year, to the titles of Captal de Buch and Marquis d’Aubrion.By thus uniting their fortunes, living on good terms, and profiting by sinecures, the two families might occupy the hotel d’Aubrion with an income of over a hundred thousand francs.

zh: “等一个人一年有了十万法郎，有了姓氏，有了门第，有了宫廷职位——因为我会让你当个王室侍从的——他就可以做他喜欢做的事了，”她对夏尔说道，　“这样，你就可以想当什么就当什么——政务院的审查官、省长、大使馆秘书、大使本人，由你挑。查理十世很喜欢德奥布里翁，他们从小就认识。”
en: “And when a man has a hundred thousand francs a year, a name, a family, and a position at court,—for I will get you appointed as gentleman-of-the-bedchamber,—he can do what he likes,” she said to Charles.“You can then become anything you choose,—master of the rolls in the council of State, prefect, secretary to an embassy, the ambassador himself, if you like.Charles X. is fond of d’Aubrion; they have known each other from childhood.”

zh: 夏儿陶醉于野心当中，他对这番巧妙地扮成个人隐私话的痴心妄想竟沉迷起来。他满以为他父亲的事已经由伯父料理完毕，便觉得可以一步踏进圣－日耳曼区——那个人人向往的上流社会，在那里，在玛蒂尔德小姐紫色鼻子的庇护下，他要以德奥布里翁伯爵的身份再度现身，好似德勒一家摇身一变，成了布雷兹一样。在他离开法国时，王政复辟还摇摇欲坠，现在却一派繁荣，令他眼花缭乱，贵族思想的光辉让他着迷，从船上就开始有的醉意，等他到了巴黎后更是有增无减。最后，他决心采取行动，把他那未来的岳母出于自私的愿望而指给他的高官厚禄弄到手。他的堂姐在这个光辉灿烂的远景中只不过是个小点子而已。不过，他去见了安妮特。作为真正的交际花，安妮特建议她的老朋友结这个婚，还向他许诺，她会支持他所有那些雄心勃勃的计划。在她的内心，她非常乐意把一个又丑又无趣的姑娘和夏尔夏尔栓到一起，因为西印度群岛的生活使夏尔变得非常有魅力。他的肤色变成了古铜色，他的举手投足变得坚定而果敢，好似那些惯于当机立断、支配一切，并获得成功的人一样。夏尔意识到自己现在可以有所作为了，他在巴黎活得更自在了。
en: Intoxicated with ambition, Charles toyed with the hopes thus cleverly presented to him in the guise of confidences poured from heart to heart.Believing his father’s affairs to have been settled by his uncle, he imagined himself suddenly anchored in the Faubourg Saint-Germain,—that social object of all desire, where, under shelter of Mademoiselle Mathilde’s purple nose, he was to reappear as the Comte d’Aubrion, very much as the Dreux reappeared in Breze.Dazzled by the prosperity of the Restoration, which was tottering when he left France, fascinated by the splendor of aristocratic ideas, his intoxication, which began on the brig, increased after he reached Paris, and he finally determined to take the course and reach the high position which the selfish hopes of his would-be mother-in-law pointed out to him.His cousin counted for no more than a speck in this brilliant perspective; but he went to see Annette.True woman of the world, Annette advised her old friend to make the marriage, and promised him her support in all his ambitious projects.In her heart she was enchanted to fasten an ugly and uninteresting girl on Charles, whose life in the West Indies had rendered him very attractive.His complexion had bronzed, his manners had grown decided and bold, like those of a man accustomed to make sharp decisions, to rule, and to succeed.Charles breathed more at his ease in Paris, conscious that he now had a part to play.

zh: 德格拉桑听说他回来了，而且即将结婚，还发了大财，就跑来见他，想打听了结他父亲债务还需要的那三十万法郎。他看到葛朗台正在和一个金器商商议事情，从这个金器商那里，夏尔定制了首饰给德奥布里翁小姐做聘礼，当时金器商正在向他提交图样。夏尔带回了精美的钻石，那镶嵌式样的价值，连同新居所需的金银餐具和首饰，合计达二十多万法郎。他没有认出德格拉桑来，自以为曾在西印度群岛的多次决斗中杀死过四个人，他接待德格拉桑时，带着一副时髦青年的傲慢劲。德格拉桑先生已经来过几次了。夏尔冷冷地听着他说话，还没完全听懂他的意思，就回答道——
en: Des Grassins, hearing of his return, of his approaching marriage and his large fortune, came to see him, and inquired about the three hundred thousand francs still required to settle his father’s debts.He found Grandet in conference with a goldsmith, from whom he had ordered jewels for Mademoiselle d’Aubrion’s @corbeille@, and who was then submitting the designs.Charles had brought back magnificent diamonds, and the value of their setting, together with the plate and jewelry of the new establishment, amounted to more than two hundred thousand francs.He received des Grassins, whom he did not recognize, with the impertinence of a young man of fashion conscious of having killed four men in as many duels in the Indies.Monsieur des Grassins had already called several times.Charles listened to him coldly, and then replied, without fully understanding what had been said to him,—

zh: “我父亲的事不是我的事。先生，我很感谢您这样费心——不过，对此，我确实无法领情。我汗流满面地挣来了两百万，不是为了把它们扔到我父亲的债主头上的。”
en: “My father’s affairs are not mine.I am much obliged, monsieur, for the trouble you have been good enough to take,—by which, however, I really cannot profit.I have not earned two millions by the sweat of my brow to fling them at the head of my father’s creditors.”

zh: “可要是令尊的财产几天之内就要宣告破产呢？”
en: “But suppose that your father’s estate were within a few days to be declared bankrupt?”

zh: “先生，再过几天，我就要被称作德奥布里翁伯爵了；因此，你会明白你的威胁对我毫无影响。而且你和我一样清楚，当一个人有十万法郎的收入时，他的父亲是决不会破产的。”这样说着，他客气地把德格拉桑先生推到了门口。
en: “Monsieur, in a few days I shall be called the Comte d’Aubrion; you will understand, therefore, that what you threaten is of no consequence to me.Besides, you know as well as I do that when a man has an income of a hundred thousand francs his father has @never failed@.”So saying, he politely edged Monsieur des Grassins to the door.

zh: 当年八月初，欧仁妮正坐在堂弟曾发誓永远爱她的那个小木凳上，如果天气好的话，她通常就在这里用早餐。此时，在这清新、舒适的夏日空气里，这可怜的姑娘心情愉快，她回忆起爱情中的大小往事和随之而来的灾难。太阳刚刚晒到了破败的墙角，墙上布满了裂缝，尽管科努瓦耶经常跟他妻子说：“早晚有一天，它会倒下来砸着人的。”可是由于女主人的怪癖，谁也不许碰。这时，邮差敲响门，给了科努瓦耶太太一封信，她一边往花园跑，一边大声喊着：
en: At the beginning of August in the same year, Eugenie was sitting on the little wooden bench where her cousin had sworn to love her eternally, and where she usually breakfasted if the weather were fine.The poor girl was happy, for the moment, in the fresh and joyous summer air, letting her memory recall the great and the little events of her love and the catastrophes which had followed it.The sun had just reached the angle of the ruined wall, so full of chinks, which no one, through a caprice of the mistress, was allowed to touch, though Cornoiller often remarked to his wife that “it would fall and crush somebody one of these days.”At this moment the postman knocked, and gave a letter to Madame Cornoiller, who ran into the garden, crying out:

zh: “小姐，信！”她把信给了女主人，又说道，“是你等的那封吧？”
en: “Mademoiselle, a letter!”She gave it to her mistress, adding, “Is it the one you expected?”

zh: 这几个字在欧仁妮的心头大声回响，强度不亚于回荡在院子和花园的墙壁之间的回声。
en: The words rang as loudly in the heart of Eugenie as they echoed in sound from wall to wall of the court and garden.

zh: “巴黎——他写的——他回来了！”
en: “Paris—from him—he has returned!”

zh: 欧仁妮脸色变得苍白，举着信呆了一会儿。她颤抖得厉害，简直都拆不了信。大个子娜农站在她前面，两手叉着腰，她的快乐好像烟一样，从她棕色脸庞的皱纹中冒了出来。
en: Eugenie turned pale and held the letter for a moment.She trembled so violently that she could not break the seal.La Grande Nanon stood before her, both hands on her hips, her joy puffing as it were like smoke through the cracks of her brown face.

zh: “看信吧，小姐！”
en: “Read it, mademoiselle!”

zh: “啊，娜农，他为什么回了巴黎？他是从索米尔走的。”
en: “Ah, Nanon, why did he return to Paris?He went from Saumur.”

zh: “看了信，你就知道了。”
en: “Read it, and you’ll find out.”

zh: 欧仁妮用颤抖的手指打开了信。一张“索米尔德格拉桑太太和科雷”银行的汇票飘然而落。娜农把它捡了起来。
en: Eugenie opened the letter with trembling fingers.A cheque on the house of “Madame des Grassins and Coret, of Saumur,” fluttered down.Nanon picked it up.

zh: 我亲爱的堂姐——
en: My dear Cousin,—

zh: “不再是‘欧仁妮’了。”她想着，心存恐惧。
en: “No longer ‘Eugenie,’” she thought, and her heart quailed.
You—

zh: “他以前是叫‘你’的呀。”她抱起胳膊，不敢再往下看，眼里噙满了大滴的泪水。
en: “He once said ‘thou.’”She folded her arms and dared not read another word; great tears gathered in her eyes.

zh: “他死了吗？”娜农问道。
en: “Is he dead?” asked Nanon.

zh: “他要是死了，就不会写信了。”欧仁妮说。
en: “If he were, he could not write,” said Eugenie.

zh: 接着，她读起了整封信，全信如下：
en: She then read the whole letter, which was as follows:

zh: 我亲爱的堂姐——我相信，听说我事业有成，您一定会很高兴。您给我带来了运气；我发财回来了，我听从了我伯父的劝告。我刚刚从德格拉桑先生那里得知伯父及伯母去世的消息。父母去世是自然过程，我们必须接替他们。我希望您现在已经节哀顺变了。
en: My dear Cousin,—You will, I am sure, hear with pleasure of the success of my enterprise.You brought me luck; I have come back rich, and I have followed the advice of my uncle, whose death, together with that of my aunt, I have just learned from Monsieur des Grassins.The death of parents is in the course of nature, and we must succeed them.I trust you are by this time consoled.

zh: 什么都无法抗拒时间，对此我深有体会。是的，我亲爱的堂姐，不幸的是，对我来说，幻想的时代已经过去。不然又有什么办法呢？走过很多地方以后，我已经对人生进行了思考。走时，我还是个孩子——现在回来，我已是个大人了。
en: Nothing can resist time, as I am well aware.Yes, my dear cousin, the day of illusions is, unfortunately, gone for me.How could it be otherwise?Travelling through many lands, I have reflected upon life.I was a child when I went away,—I have come back a man.

zh: 今天，我想了很多那时做梦也想不到的事情。您是自由的，我亲爱的堂姐，我也还是自由的。表面上看，没有什么阻挡得了我们去实现当初的希望；但我天性坦诚，不能向您隐瞒我目前的处境。我没有忘记我们的关系；在漫长的旅程中，我一直都记着那个小木凳——
en: Today, I think of many I did not dream of then.You are free, my dear cousin, and I am free still.Nothing apparently hinders the realization of our early hopes; but my nature is too loyal to hide from you the situation in which I find myself.I have not forgotten our relations; I have always remembered, throughout my long wanderings, the little wooden seat—

zh: 欧仁妮仿佛正坐在燃烧的炭火上一样，她站起身来，走过去，坐到了院子里的石头台阶上。
en: Eugenie rose as if she were sitting on live coals, and went away and sat down on the stone steps of the court.

zh: ——我们曾坐在那个小木凳上面，发誓永远相爱，那个过道，那个灰色的大厅，我在阁楼的卧室，还有那个夜晚，由于您体贴入微的关怀，我的前程才更为顺利。是的，这些回忆给了我勇气；我在心里默念，在我们约定的时刻，您一定在想念我。
en: —the little wooden seat where we vowed to love each other forever, the passage, the gray hall, my attic chamber, and the night when, by your delicate kindness, you made my future easier to me.Yes, these recollections sustained my courage; I said in my heart that you were thinking of me at the hour we had agreed upon.

zh: 您总是在九点看云彩吗？是的，我相信是这样的。我不能背叛这么真诚的友谊——不，我不可以欺骗您。我定了一门婚事，它符合我对婚姻关系的所有想法。爱情在婚姻中是个幻象。我现在的经历告诫我，结婚时，我们注定要服从所有的社会法则，符合世俗的风俗要求。
en: Have you always looked at the clouds at nine o’clock?Yes, I am sure of it.I cannot betray so true a friendship,—no, I must not deceive you.An alliance has been proposed to me which satisfies all my ideas of matrimony.Love in marriage is a delusion.My present experience warns me that in marrying we are bound to obey all social laws and meet the conventional demands of the world.

zh: 我亲爱的堂姐，现在，在您和我之间存在着可能会影响到您前程的差别，这差别对您甚至比对我的影响更大。我这里且不说您的生活方式和爱好、您的教育和您的习惯，这些全都跟巴黎的生活不合拍，也不适合我为自己勾画的未来。我打算让我的家豪华排场，高朋满座——简而言之，要有大量的社交活动；我想，我还记得您喜欢的是安静而恬淡的生活。我会坦诚相见，并请您评判一下我的处境，您有权了解并做出评判。
en: Now, between you and me there are differences which might affect your future, my dear cousin, even more than they would mine.I will not here speak of your customs and inclinations, your education, nor yet of your habits, none of which are in keeping with Parisian life, or with the future which I have marked out for myself.My intention is to keep my household on a stately footing, to receive much company,—in short, to live in the world; and I think I remember that you love a quiet and tranquil life.I will be frank, and make you the judge of my situation; you have the right to understand it and to judge it.

zh: 我目前拥有八万法郎的收入。这笔财富使我能够和奥布里翁家联姻，他们的女继承人，一个十九岁的小姑娘，会给我带来一个头衔、一个王室侍从的位置和一个非常显赫的地位。我得向您承认，我亲爱的堂姐，我不爱德奥布里翁小姐；但是和她结婚，我可以保证我的孩子将来有一个前途无量的社会地位：王权思想正一天比一天更吃香。这样，若干年后，等我的儿子成了德奥布里翁侯爵，那时他就会拥有四万法郎年金的限嗣继承的不动产，便可以在朝廷里获得他认为适合担当的职位。我们应该为我们的孩子尽责。
en: I possess at the present moment an income of eighty thousand francs.This fortune enables me to marry into the family of Aubrion, whose heiress, a young girl nineteen years of age, brings me a title, a place of gentleman-of-the-bed-chamber to His Majesty, and a very brilliant position.I will admit to you, my dear cousin, that I do not love Mademoiselle d’Aubrion; but in marrying her I secure to my children a social rank whose advantages will one day be incalculable: monarchical principles are daily coming more and more into favor.Thus in course of time my son, when he becomes Marquis d’Aubrion, having, as he then will have, an entailed estate with a rental of forty thousand francs a year, can obtain any position in the State which he may think proper to select.We owe ourselves to our children.

zh: 您看，我的堂姐，我是多么真诚地向您表白了我心里的想法、我的希望及我的财产。也许在七年的离别之后，您已经忘记了我们年轻幼稚的爱情；可是，我从来没有忘记您的善良，也没忘记我自己的诺言。我记得所有一切，甚至包括那些不经意说出的话语——那些话语如果是由一个不像我这样认真、内心也不那么天真和正直的人说出的，他不会觉着自己有负责任的必要。我之所以告诉您我要缔结的婚约只是便利之需，还有我仍旧记得我们幼稚的爱情，我不就是在把我自己完全交到您的手中，并让您来主宰我的命运吗？难道我不是在告诉您，如果我必须放弃我对社会的野心，我会心甘情愿地满足于那纯洁而简单的幸福吗？那甜美的情景您早已让我领略到了。
en: You see, my cousin, with what good faith I lay the state of my heart, my hopes, and my fortune before you.Possibly, after seven years’ separation, you have yourself forgotten our youthful loves; but I have never forgotten either your kindness or my own words.I remember all, even words that were lightly uttered,—words by which a man less conscientious than I, with a heart less youthful and less upright, would scarcely feel himself bound.In telling you that the marriage I propose to make is solely one of convenience, that I still remember our childish love, am I not putting myself entirely in your hands and making you the mistress of my fate? Am I not telling you that if I must renounce my social ambitions, I shall willingly content myself with the pure and simple happiness of which you have shown me so sweet an image?

zh: “当，得，得——当，得，嘀，”夏尔·葛朗台一边唱着你不要再去做情郎的调子，一边签上了自己的名字——
en: “Tan, ta, ta—tan, ta, ti,” sang Charles Grandet to the air of @Non piu andrai@, as he signed himself,—

zh: 您忠实的堂弟，夏尔。
en: Your devoted cousin, Charles.

zh: “天哪！这就是做事精明！”他一边说着，一边张望着四周找支票；找到汇票后，他又加上了这几句话——
en: “Thunder! That’s doing it handsomely!” he said, as he looked about him for the cheque; having found it, he added the words:—

zh: 又及——随信附上在您名下的德格拉桑银行八千法郎汇票一张，以黄金支付，包括了您曾那么慷慨借予我的本金和利息。我正在等候一只由波尔多运来的箱子，内有一些我想送与您的东西，聊表我无尽的感激之情，您一定要收下。您可以把我的梳妆箱交与驿车，送至德奥布里翁府邸，伊勒兰－贝尔坦街。
en: P.S.—I enclose a cheque on the des Grassins bank for eight thousand francs to your order, payable in gold, which includes the capital and interest of the sum you were kind enough to lend me.I am expecting a case from Bordeaux which contains a few things which you must allow me to offer you as a mark of my unceasing gratitude.You can send my dressing-case by the diligence to the hotel d’Aubrion, rue Hillerin-Bertin.

zh: “交与驿车！”欧仁妮说道，“一件我曾为之拼过命的东西！”
en: “By the diligence!” said Eugenie.“A thing for which I would have laid down my life!”

zh: 可怕的灭顶之灾！在希望的茫茫大海上，船沉了，没有留下一节圆杆，也没有留下一块木板！有些女人在看到自己被抛弃时，会竭力把她们的爱人从情敌怀里夺回来，她们会杀掉情敌，逃到天涯海角——上断头台，进坟墓。毫无疑问，那是很高贵的；其犯罪动机是一种伟大的激情，甚至会令人类的公正敬畏。另一些女人低下了头，默默承受痛苦；她们半死不活，听天由命，痛哭流涕，宽恕，祈祷，回忆，直到咽下最后一口气。这就是爱——真正的爱、天使的爱和在痛苦中生、在痛苦中死的高傲的爱。这就是看完那封可怕的信之后欧仁妮的爱。她抬头望天，想起她母亲临终时留下的最后遗言，母亲凭着临死时所具有的预见本能，把未来看得清楚而透彻：欧仁妮想起了母亲那先知般的死亡，那先知般的一生，转瞬间悟出了自己的命运。什么也没给她留下，她只能展开她的翅膀，振翼飞向天空，在祈祷中活着，直到她解脱的那一天。
en: Terrible and utter disaster!The ship went down, leaving not a spar, not a plank, on a vast ocean of hope!Some women when they see themselves abandoned will try to tear their lover from the arms of a rival, they will kill her, and rush to the ends of the earth,—to the scaffold, to their tomb.That, no doubt, is fine; the motive of the crime is a great passion, which awes even human justice.Other women bow their heads and suffer in silence; they go their way dying, resigned, weeping, forgiving, praying, and recollecting, till they draw their last breath.This is love,—true love, the love of angels, the proud love which lives upon its anguish and dies of it.Such was Eugenie’s love after she had read that dreadful letter.She raised her eyes to heaven, thinking of the last words uttered by her dying mother, who, with the prescience of death, had looked into the future with clear and penetrating eyes: Eugenie, remembering that prophetic death, that prophetic life, measured with one glance her own destiny.Nothing was left for her; she could only unfold her wings, stretch upward to the skies, and live in prayer until the day of her deliverance.

zh: “我母亲说得对，”她哭着说道，　“受苦——然后死去！”
en: “My mother was right,” she said, weeping.“Suffer—and die!”

zh: 第十四章
en: Chapter XIV

zh: 欧仁妮慢慢从花园走回屋子，绕开了她习惯走的过道。　但是，她对堂弟的回忆还停留在那灰色的古老大厅里和那壁炉台上，壁炉台上摆着一只碟子和塞夫尔窑制的旧糖罐，她每天早上吃饭时都要用到。
en: Eugenie came slowly back from the garden to the house, and avoided passing, as was her custom, through the corridor.But the memory of her cousin was in the gray old hall and on the chimney-piece, where stood a certain saucer and the old Sevres sugar-bowl which she used every morning at her breakfast.

zh: 这一整天注定是庄严重大的，发生了诸多事件。娜农通报教区教堂的神父来了。他是克吕绍的亲戚，因而是为德蓬丰先生的利益着想的。过去这段时间，老神父力劝他纯粹从宗教的角度，和葛朗台小姐谈谈在她这种处境下女人结婚的义务。当看见本堂牧师时，欧仁妮以为他是为了她每月给穷人的那一千法郎而来的，便叫娜农去拿钱，可是神父只是微笑着。
en: This day was destined to be solemn throughout and full of events.Nanon announced the cure of the parish church.He was related to the Cruchots, and therefore in the interests of Monsieur de Bonfons.For some time past the old abbe had urged him to speak to Mademoiselle Grandet, from a purely religious point of view, about the duty of marriage for a woman in her position.When she saw her pastor, Eugenie supposed he had come for the thousand francs which she gave monthly to the poor, and she told Nanon to go and fetch them; but the cure only smiled.

zh: “今天，小姐，”他说，“我是来跟你谈谈整个索米尔城都关心的一个可怜的姑娘，她不懂得爱惜自己，忽略了她作为基督教徒的义务。”
en: “Today, mademoiselle,” he said, “I have come to speak to you about a poor girl in whom the whole town of Saumur takes an interest, who, through lack of charity to herself, neglects her Christian duties.”

zh: “神父先生，您眼下这会儿来找我，我还无暇顾及我的邻居，我正为自己的事烦心呢。我很伤心，我唯一的避难所就是教堂；她的胸怀宽大，足以容下所有人类的痛苦，她的爱是如此丰富，我们可以从中汲取，而永不会令它枯竭。”
en: “Monsieur le cure, you have come to me at a moment when I cannot think of my neighbor, I am filled with thoughts of myself.I am very unhappy; my only refuge is in the Church; her bosom is large enough to hold all human woe, her love so full that we may draw from its depths and never drain it dry.”

zh: “小姐，说到这位年轻的姑娘，我们也就说到了你。听着！如果你希望确保得到救赎，你只有两条路可以走——要么离开尘世，要么服从世俗的法则。服从你尘世的命运，或者服从你天国的命运。”
en: “Mademoiselle, in speaking of this young girl we shall speak of you.Listen!If you wish to insure your salvation you have only two paths to take,—either leave the world or obey its laws.Obey either your earthly destiny or your heavenly destiny.”

zh: “啊！在我需要听取指教的时候，您就来指教我了。是的，是上帝派您到我这里的；我要告别尘世，在沉默和与世隔绝中只为主而活着。”
en: “Ah! Your voice speaks to me when I need to hear a voice.Yes, God has sent you to me; I will bid farewell to the world and live for God alone, in silence and seclusion.”

zh: “我的孩子，在采取这样过激的行动之前，你一定要多加思考。婚姻是生，修女生活是死。”
en: “My daughter, you must think long before you take so violent a step.Marriage is life; the veil is death.”

zh: “是的，死——赶快去死！”她说道，语气激动得令人害怕。
en: “Yes, death,—a quick death!” she said, with dreadful eagerness.

zh: “死？但是你对社会有重大的义务要完成，小姐。你难道不是穷人的母亲吗？冬天要给他们衣服和柴火，夏天要给他们工作。你偌大的财产是一笔必须清偿的贷款，你已经庄严地接受了这笔财产。你躲进修道院将是自私的表现，终身做老姑娘就是没有尽到义务。首先，你能够独自管理你偌大的家业吗？你不会把它败掉吧？你会招来官司，会发现自己陷于无法摆脱的困境当中。相信你的本堂牧师吧：一个丈夫是有用的，你一定要保护好上帝赐予你的一切。我是把你当作我最珍贵的宝贝，才跟你讲这番话的。你如此真诚地爱着上帝，就应该在尘世中找到自己的救赎，你是尘世高贵的装点，必须为尘世作出榜样。”
en: “Death? But you have great obligations to fulfil to society, mademoiselle.Are you not the mother of the poor, to whom you give clothes and wood in winter and work in summer?Your great fortune is a loan which you must return, and you have sacredly accepted it as such.To bury yourself in a convent would be selfishness; to remain an old maid is to fail in duty.In the first place, can you manage your vast property alone?May you not lose it?You will have law-suits; you will find yourself surrounded by inextricable difficulties.Believe your pastor: a husband is useful; you are bound to preserve what God has bestowed upon you.I speak to you as a precious lamb of my flock.You love God too truly not to find your salvation in the midst of his world, of which you are noble ornament and to which you owe your example.”

zh: 这时，通报说德格拉桑太太光临。她是出于报复和极度的绝望而来的。
en: At this moment Madame des Grassins was announced.She came incited by vengeance and the sense of a great despair.

zh: “小姐，”她说，“啊！神父先生在这里，那我就不说了。我来是要和你谈事情，可是我看见你们正在商议——”
en: “Mademoiselle,” she said—“Ah! Here is monsieur le cure; I am silent.I came to speak to you on business; but I see that you are conferring with—”

zh: “夫人，”神父说，“我给您腾地方。”
en: “Madame,” said the cure, “I leave the field to you.”

zh: “哦！神父先生，”欧仁妮说，“过会儿回来，眼下我正需要您的支持。”
en: “Oh! Monsieur le cure,” said Eugenie, “come back later; your support is very necessary to me just now.”

zh: “啊，是的，的确，我可怜的孩子！”德格拉桑太太说道。
en: “Ah, yes, indeed, my poor child!” said Madame des Grassins.

zh: “您是什么意思？”欧仁妮和神父一齐问道。
en: “What do you mean?” asked Eugenie and the cure together.

zh: “难道我不知道你堂弟已经回来，而且要跟德奥布里翁小姐结婚的事吗？一个女人可不会把脑子揣到她的口袋里。”
en: “Don’t I know about your cousin’s return, and his marriage with Mademoiselle d’Aubrion?A woman doesn’t carry her wits in her pocket.”

zh: 欧仁妮脸红了，一时没有说话。从这天起，她总是面无表情，她父亲在这点上曾经做得很出色。
en: Eugenie blushed, and remained silent for a moment.From this day forth she assumed the impassible countenance for which her father had been so remarkable.

zh: “好吧，夫人，”过了一会儿，她语气嘲讽地说道，“无疑我是把脑子揣兜里了，因为我弄不明白您的意思。说吧，当着神父先生的面，说说您的意思，您知道他是我的本堂牧师。”
en: “Well, madame,” she presently said, ironically, “no doubt I carry my wits in my pocket, for I do not understand you.Speak, say what you mean, before monsieur le cure; you know he is my director.”

zh: “那好，小姐，这是德格拉桑写给我的信。看看吧。”
en: “Well, then, mademoiselle, here is what des Grassins writes me.Read it.”

zh: 欧仁妮读起了下面这封信——
en: Eugenie read the following letter:—

zh: 我亲爱的妻子——夏尔·葛朗台已经从西印群岛度回来了，到巴黎大约已有一个月了——
en: My dear Wife,—Charles Grandet has returned from the Indies and has been in Paris about a month—

zh: “一个月！”欧仁妮心想，她的手垂到了旁边。停了一下，她接着往下看——
en: “A month!” thought Eugenie, her hand falling to her side.After a pause she resumed the letter,—

zh: 我还得献媚邀宠，才被允许见到未来的德奥布里翁子爵。不过全巴黎都在谈论他的婚事，而且结婚公告也公布了——
en: I had to dance attendance before I was allowed to see the future Vicomte d’Aubrion.Though all Paris is talking of his marriage and the banns are published—

zh: “他是在那以后才给我写的信！”欧仁妮想。她没有往下再想，也没有像巴黎女人那样大叫出“恶棍！”，但是，尽管她没有说出这个字眼，轻蔑却浮现于她的心头。
en: “He wrote to me after that!” thought Eugenie.She did not conclude the thought; she did not cry out, as a Parisian woman would have done, “The villain!” But though she said it not, contempt was none the less present in her mind.

zh: 不过，这门婚事是不会成功的。德奥布里翁侯爵决不会把自己的女儿嫁给一个破产户的儿子。我去告诉葛朗台，说我和他伯父如何为他父亲的事操劳，如何巧妙运作稳住了债权人，让他们直到现在都保持沉默。那个傲慢无礼的家伙竟然有脸跟我说—— 跟我这个五年来日日夜夜为他的利益和名誉尽心尽力的人！——他父亲的事不是他的事！一个诉讼代理人有权要求总计三四万法郎的代理费，即债务总额的百分之一。不过，且慢！依照法律，他父亲还欠着债权人一百二十万法郎，我马上就可以宣告他父亲破产。
